While some of them left, a few others picked up a quarrel.In Tirunelveli, police officials stopped two-wheeler riders and are told them about the seriousness of the curfew and asked them to stay indoors.Similarly, a police official from Uthirakosamangai police station in Ramanathapuram district played recorded messages from a speaker mounted on his two-wheeler about the importance of staying indoors.Tuticorin Collector Sandeep Nanduri said that following complaints received by the public about shortage of masks and sanitizers, shops have been set up at 14 places in the district where masks, sanitizers and liquid soaps manufactured by members of self help groups are being sold. He said that strict action would be taken against those who are found on the streets unnecessarily.Information and publicity minister Kadambur Raju who inspected Tuticorin district said that though the government is taking all precautionary measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19, people should understand the seriousness and should stay indoors.Theni district collector Pallavi Baldev said the district administration had taken steps to provide food during the morning and afternoon for the abandoned people and for government employees who are on duty at the community halls.Ramanathapuram district collector K Veera Raghava Rao who inspected medical shops open in the district advised the public to follow social distancing while going purchasing essential commodities.

Title: Gorakhpur administration stops 2 hrs morning relaxation
Content:
GORAKHPUR: Amid complete lockdown and state government directions of providing essential food items get delivered at your doorsteps, the Gorakhpur administration has stopped the two hours relaxation for residents.

District magistrate Vijyendra Pandian said if any shopkeeper sells things at rate more than the actual rate or MRP or decided rate, the shop will be sealed with immediate effect.

“Anyone can order food items at helpline numbers — at 0551-2201796, 2202205,2204196 at e-district control room and also at mobile number 9450963851,” the DM added.

District magistrate Vijyendra Pandian on Wednesday during meeting, instructed officials to ensure doorstep delivery..

The district magistrate also instructed SDMs, Tehsildar, ADM finance and revenue and Gorakhpur municipal corporation officials to prepare a database of mobile numbers and address of all the grocery and medicine shopkeepers and also of cart owners (thela) for round-the-clock availability of essential food items.

Keeping in view lockdown, Gorakhpur zone Commissioner Jayant Nalirkar appealed all registered construction labourers and construction companies to email the bank account details either at bocwgorakhpur@gmail.com or send them on WhatsApp at 9956522858, 9838447350, 9648769035, 8737823182 in Gorakhpur, in Deoria, 9161410779, 6393765506 in Maharajganj and 7054029235, 9415322990 in Kushinagar so that Rs 1000 per month could be transferred to their accounts.

Title: MP Covid-19 count jumps to 15; 6 in one day
Content: INDORE/BHOPAL/UJJAIN: Madhya Pradesh ’s Covid-19 count shot up by six on Wednesday, with Indore getting its first four cases in a bunch, and Bhopal and Ujjain recording one each. The Ujjain patient — a 65-year-old woman — died within hours of testing positive.There are 15 Coronavirus patients in MP now and five cities under curfew, the latest being Indore and Ujjain.In Bhopal, a 55-year-old journalist who had attended the press meet of former CM Kamal Nath on March 20 — the day he resigned as chief minister — has tested positive, sparking jitters in the fraternity. Most of the city’s senior reporters were at the press conference, and they are now in home isolation.Nath’s media advisor dismissed rumours that he was in self-isolation. “Kamal Nath ji is perfectly alright and is keeping a watch on the Coronavirus situation,” he said.The journalist’s daughter is Bhopal’s first Covid-19 patient and is being treated at AIIMS. In the past five days, the scribe met several people in separate locations in the city. Police are scanning CCTV footage to identify those who came in contact with him and are tracking them via GPS, say sources.The death of the Ujjain victim has caused alarm as she did not have a travel history and is Ujjain’s patient zero. Her son said she had not left her locality for four months. She was admitted to an Ujjain hospital with cough and cold on March 22 and referred to MY Hospital in Indore when her condition deteriorated. Due to her symptoms, doctors had her tested for Covid-19 and it came back positive on Wednesday morning. A couple of hours later, she was dead.“Her oxygen saturation level was low and her condition was complicated by diabetes and respiratory issues. She passed away on Wednesday,” the Indore collector said. “Her body was covered in a body suit and disinfected. The staff involved in preparing the body wore protective gear,” he added. Ujjain collector Shashank Mishra clamped curfew and issued strict instructions to residents to remain indoors. At least 40 people in the woman’s locality have been quarantined. Indore woke up to the shocker that five residents had tested positive. “Detection of four Indore locals as Covid-19 positive is not good news. Now, people need to strictly avoid coming out of their houses unless there is an emergency,” said collector Lokesh Kumar Jatav. All four patients live in a 3km radius. This area has been declared a containment zone while a circle of 5km is marked as the buffer zone, said zilla panchayat CEO Neha Meena. “Everyone in the containment zone will be screened, followed by those in the buffer zone,” said Meena, adding that these areas will be sanitised and fumigated.

Title: Offences registered against three units in Panchmahal
Content:
Representative image

VADODARA: The Panchmahal police registered offences against three companies for not closing operations despite lockdown orders by the state government. All the three units were located in Kalol area.

Sources said that the offences were registered after the police received complaints regarding these companies operating despite notification for lockdown issued on Monday. Police visited the units and after found around 190 to 260 persons working in these units.

However, it later came to light that two of these units of the same group may have been involved in activities that could be classified as essential. Sources said that this came to light only after the offence was registered.

Title: Youth lands in jail for coronavirus ‘prank’
Content:
Representative image

KOTA: Making up false stories of being infected with coronavirus landed 25-year-old Giriraj Sain in jail under judicial custody on Tuesday in Jhalawar. The youth claimed to have travelled to various places and that he had been infected by the virus.

He allegedly made up these stories in his neighbourhood ‘for fun’. When health officials arrived, he said he was doing it for fun and didn’t travel any country. Sain was later arrested by the police.

Title: Police guard households of quarantined persons
Content:
Jaipur: With three more Covid-19 cases, the textile town has recorded the second-highest number of such patients in the country.

Bhilwara with 16 cases is next to Mumbai which has 74 as on Wednesday morning.

The city is under curfew for the past six days. Till date, screening of over 3 lakh people has been done by over 2,100 teams. So far, 5586 suspected has surfaced along with 234 critical patients who have shown all the symptoms.

“The 5,586 suspects have been put under the home quarantined while other critical patients are placed in different hospitals,” said Bhilwara collector Rajendra Bhatt.

Following the common strategy, those home quarantined are stamped on their hands and a poster pasted outside their homes appealing people to stay away. The number of such houses is 6,000 spread over 15-20 places has triggered fear among locals.

The administration has deployed police outside 2,000 home quarantined houses while at other 3,500 places police have engaged community volunteers. “Bhilwara cannot afford any irresponsible behaviour at this juncture else we will collapse. We could identify only 2,000 additional beds for any emergency in the entire district. The future of the city depends upon those in home isolation as they are the potential carriers until their 14 days isolation period is successfully over,” said a senior medical officer.

Title: Madurai: Circles, squares separate shoppers
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: The civic authorities in Madurai have started marking spaces in front of shops to ensure that people maintained a safe distance to ward off the novel coronavirus while waiting to make purchases. Though the government had called for a total lockdown to ensure that the infection does not spread, it was chaotic in public places. Hence the civic authorities resorted to drawing lines, squares and circles with bleaching powder. ``It is to ensure that the people maintain a one metre distance while standing in front of shops,’’ said corporation sources.

The distancing signs were drawn by the corporation personnel in wards 24, 25,26,27 and 49 ward number 88 in SS Colony, 20 and 22 in Pandian Nagar and ward number 19 in Chokkalinga Nagar on Wednesday. Circles were also drawn within the Amma canteen.

Shopkeepers were also seen taking social distancing seriously. A shop in Kamarajar Salai downed its shutters and asked the people to come after 4 pm as the workers drew distancing circles in front of it with paint.

At Balaji Store, a small shop in Gomathypuram, the customers were asked to submit their list of needs and wait at a distance while the shopkeeper gathered the supplies. Grocery stores also refused to supply items if the people did not follow the rules.

In Tirunelveli city , the corporation and district administration drew marking circles with white powder at least one metre apart. The circles were drawn at all the 10 Amma canteens in the corporation limit, from the space where people queue up to the counters for payments and collection of food as well as at the space allotted for having food.

Tirunelveli assistant collector M Sivaguru Prabakaran said a batchmate had shared such an initiative in their social media group. “We did not know the location but the initiative was good and we implemented it,” he said. The temporary circles were also drawn at the Uzhavar Sandhai, fish and meat stalls, shops where people thronged in more numbers and pharmacies as well.

“Considering the need for such measures for a longer period we started permanently painting the spaces with blue the same morning,” the assistant collector said.

Title: Only four relatives attend burial of Tamil Nadu’s first Covid-19 victim
Content: MADURAI: The body of the 54-year-old man from Anna Nagar in Madurai city , who died on Wednesday night while undergoing treatment for Covid-19, was laid to rest at a burial ground in Melamadai early in the morning.His wife, son and two brothers were the only relatives around when the body was taken to the grave.It was around 2 am that health minister C Vijayabaskar declared the man, who was admitted to the Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH), dead. He said the patient had a medical history of prolonged illness with steroid-dependent chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and uncontrolled diabetes with hypertension.The body was shifted directly to the burial ground from GRH around 3.30 am after the authorities completed the hospital procedures. The body was alighted from the hearse van and kept at the ground for an hour until the work of digging the pit was complete.Other than the family members, a police team from Madhichiyam station which accompanied the body, was also present. There was no medical team or sanitation officers during the burial, which was completed by 5 am.Meanwhile, the district administration locked down all the ways leading to the street where he was hailing from using barricades fastened with ropes. All the people from 60 houses on the street have been kept under watch. In addition, one street on either side of the particular street has also been locked down. Barricades have been erected at least at eight places to make sure that no one leaves the place or an outsider goes in, police sources said.Only the residents are allowed to enter, that too after showing proof of residency in the street. One member from the family is allowed to purchase essential articles like milk and groceries from stores available there itself.

Title: Covid fight caught in red tape and kit shortage in Telangana
Content: HYDERABAD: Though Telangana government has been taking stringent measures to contain spread of coronavirus for the past few weeks, shortage of testing kits and red tape seems to be hampering its fight against the infection. Going by statistics provided by the health department officials, just 4% people identified with symptoms were tested for Covid-19. Reason: Acute shortage of testing kits.Since January last week, 77,045 people had arrived at the RGI Airport from various foreign destinations. After thermal screening, 17,283 passengers were identified with some symptoms such as cough, cold and fever. When it came to sample collection, only 764 passengers were tested and of them, 699 were negative for Covid-19. Till March 24 night, 39 people tested positive for coronavirus. In the last two weeks, those who came from abroad were told to be in 14-day mandatory home quarantine and stamped accordingly.“The state government is not procuring kits from manufacturers directly. The kits are being supplied by the Centre through Pune-based National Institute of Virology (NIV). Though the number of positive cases are less, tests have to be conducted on suspect cases,” a senior health department official said.Apart from shortage of kits, cost of the test was also a major concern as each test kit costs anything between Rs 4,000 and Rs 5,000, sources said. According to WHO guidelines, all patients in hospitals with acute respiratory problems, shortness of breath, cold, cough and fever should be tested apart from high-risk patients.As of now, Covid-19 tests were being conducted at Gandhi Hospital, Osmania Medical College (OMC) and Fever Hospital . Even if the government wants to conduct more tests, more laboratories have not become operational. Though the Centre gave the nod for Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology (CCMB), the CSIR laboratory has not started conducting actual tests. “In a day or two, coronavirus testing will begin at NIMS and IPM. CCMB is also in the process of starting tests,” director of medical education (DME) Ramesh Reddy told TOI on Wednesday.Officials said tests were being done on people who had direct contact with positive cases (family members, friends and colleagues) and surrounding areas. In Karimnagar and other places, such a strategy was adopted, another health department official said.Meanwhile, private hospital and laboratories have expressed their readiness to treat patients and conduct Covid-19 tests. The Centre has reportedly permitted three hospitals and diagnostic laboratories to conduct tests. However, there has been no official communication regarding it to the state government so far.

Title: Varanasi: Woman flees after throwing her children into well in Sonbhadra
Content:
Representative image

VARANASI: A woman fled after throwing her three children into a well in Pindari village under the limits of Bijpur police station in Sonbhadra district on Wednesday night.

Two of the children died while one was rescued by the villagers. SP Sonbhadra Ashish Srivastava said that police are searching for the woman after sending the bodies for postmortem. The girl, who survived, was given under the custody of her grandparents.

According to sources, at around 11pm Devanti (30) knocked the doors of her neighbour Rampyare told him that her two children had died after falling into the well while one was alive. Before Rampyare could understand anything Devanti fled the scene. When Rampyare looked inside the well he noticed cries of a child after which he raised an alarm.

A local youth entered the well with a help of a rope and rescued the girl- Anu (6). The bodies of her siblings- Anuj (3) and Dipanshu (1) were also recovered from the well. Later, police reached the incident site. Anu informed police that Devanti threw all the three kids into the well. Initial investigation revealed that Devanti’s husband Vijay Gond was employed in Chennai and had not returned home for past 10 months.

Title: With lockdown, pollution levels dip in Kochi
Content:
From the days the lockdown began, the pollution levels fell by as many as 30 points for nitrogen oxide.

KOCHI: With vehicular traffic almost coming to a standstill, the pollution levels in the city, especially nitrogen oxide levels, recorded a drastic fall on Wednesday, as per Kerala state pollution control board (KSPCB) data.

“We have noticed a drastic fall in the vehicular pollution levels and respirable suspended particulate matter (RSPM) in all our stations, mainly at Vyttila and MG Road which often record the highest levels because of the huge traffic movement,” said KSPCB chief environmental engineer M A Baiju.

According to Vyttila air monitoring station data, the pollution levels crossed 100 microns for nitrogen oxide (NOX) –– a parameter that indicates high emissions from vehicles –– in the first couple of weeks in March. The dust pollution levels indicated by PM 10 (particulate matter) were also very high in this region. The standard for NOX is 80 microns in 24 hours while it is 100 microns for PM 10 in 24 hours.

But from the days the lockdown began, the pollution levels fell by as many as 30 points for nitrogen oxide, indicating that the air was getting cleaner due to vehicular traffic coming down drastically.

“Our air quality index is comparatively good because of our climate. Normally in summer, the RSPM remains high because there is no rain or winds to clear the air. The main pollutants for us are vehicles and the construction sector. Since construction activity has come down due to the Covid situation, we are seeing a drastic fall in particulate matter levels too,” Baiju said.

According to the data recorded by the KSPCB, the PM 10 levels touched 211 microns on March 7, 173 on March 6 and 166 on March 8. The highest recorded in the last 10 days being on March 17, at 161 microns. The fall in levels began from March 20 (96) and it has been falling steadily since then.

Interestingly, at MG Road, the PM 2.5 levels showed a rise from 17 microns on March 22 to 31 microns on March 24, during the lockdown period. There is a growing concern that this could be because of people burning waste at night times. With waste collection affected by the confusion caused due to Corona scare and social distancing, people have been seen burning plastic and other waste at several points in their own neighbourhoods.

Title: 33 Pak Hindus screened
Content:
Jaisalmer: The district administration and health department on Wednesday screened 33 Pakistani Hindus for coronavirus.

During a door-to-door survey in the canal area under Ramgarh police station, the health team found that around 22 Pakistani Hindus were living there on long-term visas and the remaining 11 had come on religious visa recently. Ahead of the sealing of borders of both countries in the wake of the spread of the pandemic in Sindh and Punjab states of Pakistan, these people had walked through the Atari border carrying visa for Haridwar.

tnn

Title: Death toll rises to four in Theni forest fire
Content:
Representative image

THENI: The death toll in the Theni forest fire incident has increased to four as one more woman succumbed to injuries. Three more people - two women and one man - are undergoing treatment at the Theni Medical College Hospital.The fourth victim has been identified as V Manjula, 46.

She died on way to the hospital late on Tuesday night after she was brought down from the hills. K Vijayamani , 45 and her two-year-old granddaughter T Krishiya had died on the spot and S Maheswari, 43, died while being brought down from the hills. According to police, a 10-member group including the child was on their way back to their native village Rasingapuram from Paethotti in Idukki district of Kerala. As three major roads connecting Kerala were closed on the state border, they decided to use the trekking route. When they were trekking down they were engulfed by the forest fire at a place called Araliyuthu. Based on information teams from police, forest and fire and rescue reached the spot and rescued three people without any injuries, and five with injuries. Out of the five injured, two succumbed to injuries.

Title: Allahabad high court, its Lucknow bench closed indefinitely
Content: PRAYAGRAJ: Keeping in view the gravity of the situation arising out of the coronavirus outbreak, the court work in Allahabad High Court and its Lucknow judicature will remain suspended till further orders.Besides, all district courts across the state, all commercial courts, Motor Accident Claims Tribunal and Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Authorities across the state shall also remained closed till further orders, ordered Chief Justice Govind Mathur on Wednesday.However, the remands and bails of arrested person shall be done as per holiday practice, the notification further ordered.However, imminently and urgent cases would be heard by the designated division bench/single judge with the prior approval of Chief Justice.For Lucknow Bench, necessary approval for hearing of urgent cases shall be obtained from senior judge, Lucknow, the notification further ordered.According to high court administration, the decision was taken as part of precautionary and remedial measures keeping in view the gravity of the situation arising due to outbreak of novel coronavirus (COVID-19).Initially, through a notification dated March 18, it was directed that the high court at Allahabad and Lucknow will remained closed from March 19 to March 21.Subsequently, through another notification dated March 21, it was provided that high courts at Allahabad and Lucknow will continue to remain closed from March 23 to March 25 for the purpose of taking preventive and remedial measures to combat the threat of coronavirus.Later, a notification was again issued by the high court on March 23, stating that in continuation of the earlier notification, the high court at Allahabad and its Lucknow Bench will further remain close till March 28.

Title: Bhilwara fights coronavirus the way nation erased polio
Content: JAIPUR: The microplans that helped in eradicating polio from the country, are being followed in Bhilwara — where 16 persons have been found infected with Covid-19 — to contain the spread of the virus.At least 300 teams of healthcare staff have been trained and they are conducting house-to-house survey based on polio microplans. The microplans are prepared in such a way as to ensure that not a single suspected Covid-19 person should remain untraced, just like in the polio eradication campaign, which ensured that every child should administer polio drops.The strategy had worked and the entire country had been declared polio-free by the World Health Organisation. The health authorities have adopted the same way in which they conduct acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) surveillance for eradicating polio from the country.According to WHO, polio eradication microplans had adopted the innovative strategy of house-to-house vaccination over time. The health services in countries in which polio had been endemic, did not reach everyone, and underserved communities had a greater burden of polio. Services were therefore brought to the community.Following the same microplan, the health department has constituted 300 teams of health workers to reach out to each and every person in the area around the private hospital, where 16 persons tested positive for Covid-19 so far. “The moment we realised that a doctor working at a hospital could be the epicentre for Covid-19 spread in Bhilwara, we immediately constituted 300 teams and drew up a three-layered containment plan to cover the entire district. It is just like what health agencies used to do when a case of polio was reported from a particular area. We conducted intense contact tracing. Then, our teams went house-to-house to cover the entire urban population for screening and surveillance. Now, we have fanned out into rural areas to identify suspected cases. The strategy seems to have worked for containment,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary (health).The health department developed 24-hour screening centre of all the symptomatic and contacts of the hospital which is the epicentre of Covid-19-positive cases in Bhilwara.

Title: Rocky road for 30 students in London
Content:
The students were staying in a hotel, paid for by HCI, for the past three days.

HYDERABAD: As many as 30 Indian students , including 27 from the Telugu states, found themselves on the road in London on Wednesday after they were asked to vacate the hotel they were put up in, by The High Commission of India ( HCI ), three days ago. The commission informed them that they would have to vacate the hotel and look for their own accommodation.

“Our problem is that we do not have any money,” Mustafa, a student from Hyderabad told TOI from London. Though the HCI suggested another cheaper accommodation where students could get a twin sharing room for 10 pounds a day, students said even that was unaffordable. “No one has any money. We are literally at the crossroads and don’t know where to go,” Mustafa added.

In fact, one girl from the group said she had only five pounds. While another student had 60 pounds on him, he feared that he wouldn’t have money to buy food if he spent it on accommodation. “We knew we had to vacate the hotel but did not know that we would have to pay when we move into another accommodation,” said a student.

When the students reached the Gatwick airport in London on March 18 to take a flight back home to India, they were informed that flights to India had been cancelled because of restrictions on account of the coronavirus outbreak. Helpless, the students went to the HCI for help as they could not go back to their hostels and universities they had already vacated.

The students slept in the HCI premises for a couple of days, after which they were shifted to the hotel. The HCI paid for the hotel accommodation. During the time that they were in the hotel, food arrangements were done by Telugu associations. One social worker, Gampa Venugopal of Telangana NRI Forum told TOI that other associations were always involved in providing help to students. Meanwhile, the HCI has also announced a shutdown of its premises and therefore, the students cannot go back to the commission.

Title: MSU student outfits demand mass promotion
Content:
Vadodara: Student outfits and representatives from all the sections have demanded mass promotion of all the students currently studying at M S University in view of the 21 days lockdown.

“Nearly 60% students of our university are not residents of Vadodara city. In view of COVID-19 outbreak, most of them have returned to their native without even carrying their study material or luggage,” vice-president of MSU Students Union (MSUSU) Kaksha Patel

“Also, around 45% students reside in rural areas and 70% of them hail from lower income families. They don’t have access to high speed internet or laptops. This nullifies the possibilities of conducting online examination for all the students,” she said.

NSUI’s Gujarat unit too has demanded mass promotion of all the students studying in colleges and universities across the state. “Given the current situation, there is no other option but to grant mass promotion to all the students,” said former head of NSUI’s Vadodara unit Hitesh Desai who along with present head Devang Thakore made the representation.

Title: ‘GRH isolation wards in crowded spots in Madurai, pose threat to public’
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: People of the city have demanded that the isolation wards for Covid-19 patients, which have been established in the vicinity of other wards, frequented by other patients, of the Madurai Government Rajaji Hospital , should be moved to a more secluded place to prevent the spread of disease.

The isolation wards have been established in ward number 120 of the old building of the hospital, the old dengue ward near the outpatient facility and in the super specialty hospital opposite to the Anna bus stand. If the need arises, an isolation ward has also been kept ready in the post graduates’ hostel in the Madurai Medical College .

There are almost 10,000 people at GRH at almost all times. Similarly, the super-specialty hospital has about 1,500 people in this building at any given time including outpatients, in-patients, hospital staff and medical professionals. Hence, there is a need for the isolation wards to be established in more secluded places, people said.

Veronica Mary, a resident of Madurai, said that she was scared after taking her seven-year-old daughter for treatment to the hospital as there were many patients moving around. “I couldn’t get a mask outside the hospital, and no sanitizer was provided to us like it done in private hospitals,’’ she said.

Geriatrician Dr N Raja said that maintaining a distance between the Covid-19 suspects and other patients is important. “It is an infectious disease that fortunately does not spread through air, but a safe distance is a must. But, when taken into account the requirements like ventilators, it was only available in the GRH and the private hospitals. Thoppur would have been a better choice for the isolation ward, but ventilator and other equipment were only available in the city,'' he said. Dr Raja said that all hospitals in Madurai including the GRH and private hospitals have only about 500 ventilators.

Meanwhile, the Madurai MP Su Venkatesan has made an allocation of Rs 56.17 lakh from the MP Local Area Development Fund (MPLAD) for equipping the isolation wards at the GRH. The funds are to be used for procurement of three ventilators for Rs 18 lakh, multi-para monitors for Rs 6.06 lakh, 1,000 N95 masks for Rs 3 lakh, 25 oxygen cylinders with stand for Rs 3 lakh and other equipment.

Title: 2 Mysuru-bound trucks carrying masks, sanitisers caught in lockdown
Content: Mysuru: Two trucks , which took off from Bengaluru and Coimbatore on Tuesday morning carrying the increasingly elusive masks and hand sanitisers , failed to reach Mysuru within the scheduled time. The consignment is expected to considerably ease the shortage of these two items which were declared as essential commodities following the outbreak of Covid-19. The two vehicles are believed to be stuck as the state and district borders are sealed as part of the measures to check the spread of coronavirus After the delay, the district administration tried contacting the local authorities for the earliest entry of these vehicles into Mysuru. Department of legal metrology department assistant controller K M Mahadevaswamy said the deputy commissioner is trying to trace the drivers. “If the trucks reach Mysuru, then there will no shortage of these items and people will have no problem in buying them,” he said.Eye on overpricingIn the wake of the outbreak, the Centre included masks and sanitisers under the Essential Commodities Act which makes certain commodities available at fair prices. However, there have been complaints that they are sold at higher exorbitant prices at some stores. People also resorted to panic buying as pharmacies are running out of stock.On Monday, the legal metrology department raided a medical store in NR Mohalla and fined Rs 5,000 for selling masks and sanitisers at higher prices . The shop was selling masks for Rs 25 instead of Rs 10 and sanitisers for Rs 250 against the MRP of Rs 50.An officer in the legal metrology department said there have been several complaints regarding overcharging. “The drug control department and food and civil supplies department authorities have the right to file criminal case against such medical stores for violating government directions. If one or two such violators are sent to jail, then there will be no such violations. Till then, such violations will continue as they take advantage of the fear in the minds of the people,” the officer said.Mahadevaswamy said the raids will continue.

Title: 167 who were in train with Covid-19 patient identified
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: A list of 167 persons, including 160 co-passengers of a Covid-19 patient and seven railway staff boarded on the train, were received by the health department on Wednesday, which was sent by the divisional railway manager Jodhpur. Despite a week having passed of the Covid-19 person reaching Pali, his 167 co-passengers are yet to be screened for Covid-19.

A senior health department official said that they have received the details of 160 passengers and seven railway staff, who also travelled with a 38-year-old person, who was tested positive for Covid-19 on March 21.

He boarded the train from Mumbai on March 18 in S-3 compartment. “Since there are other passengers in the train, it is must to conduct their screening for Covid-19. There was only one person from Pali travelling by the train. He is the same person, who was diagnosed with the disease. Rest of the 166 persons belong to other districts,” said the official.

Title: Hundreds come out defying curfew in Madurai
Content:
Public goes against the curfew in Chennai

MADURAI: Hundreds of people continued to flout the rules by coming out on the roads and crowding the markets on Wednesday morning, even as Section 144 imposed by the state government at 6pm on Tuesday, and the nationwide lockdown announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi came into effect six hours later. Police had to forcibly shut down about 400 shops in the Central market as the crowds turned unruly.

While the curfew rules strictly specified that gathering of more than five people at a time was an offence, women and men crowding the market to buy vegetables was a common sight in the Central market from as early as 7am on Wednesday. The vendors were unperturbed by the fact that they too were at risk, while customers were happy that the prices of vegetables had come down compared to Tuesday.

Commissioner of police, S Davidson Devasirvatham himself came to the spot on receiving information about the crowds and warned them. A police vehicle was also parked at the entrance to regulate the crowds, but as they turned unruly, authorities ordered the closure of all 400 shops in the market.

Meat stalls and fish stalls also saw more than five people at a time and the authorities ordered them to shut by 11am.

Meanwhile, people on two-wheelers were a common sight in many traffic signals as they continued to violate the rules. In some places like Kamarajar Salai and East Masi Street, police personnel warned the violators while some others were fined Rs 100. Some police officials even resorted to deflating the tyres of some of the riders who were found continuously on the road, as a last resort to prevent them from venturing out again.

Title: Journo who attended Nath presser tests +ve
Content:
Bhopal: A 55-year-old journalist, who attended former chief minister Kamal Nath’s press conference on March 20, was tested positive for Covid-19 on Wednesday. Thus, he is the second Covid-19 positive case in Bhopal, said the health department.

The journalist is the father of Bhopal’s first Covid-19 patient, who is undergoing treatment at AIIMS, Bhopal.

Health officials said that AIIMS Bhopal has confirmed that the journalist had tested positive for Covid-19 on Wednesday — five days after he attended the former CM’s press conference. This is the press conference where Kamal Nath resigned. It was attended by top political leaders, journalists and other staffers. The journalist is a resident of Professors Colony and his family is under quarantine.

Health department is tracing the places that the journalist visited, including press conferences after March 18. The contact tracing took the health officials to Vidhan Sabha too, said sources.

The first Covid-19 case in Bhopal was reported on Sunday. The patient had returned from United Kingdom on March 17 and reached Bhopal via train on March 18. Contact tracing of the patient revealed that she came in contact with 157 people. CCTV footage and other areas visited by the family of the infected are being reviewed. “All those who have come in touch with the journalist will be requested to get a medical check-up and asked to self-quarantine,” said a district health official.

Many, who came in contact with the journalist, had gone into self-quarantine after the daughter was tested positive on Sunday. Test report of the mother, brother and maid of the city’s first patient is awaited.

Meanwhile, the state government has asked journalists, government employees and politicians who came in contact with the girl patient’s father to self-quarantine . In a directive, MP Vidhan Sabha principal secretary AP Singh directed all Vidhan Sabha employees and others who came in touch with the Covid-19 patient in the state assembly to self-quarantine. Another officer, who was OSD for former CM, said on social media that he tested negative for Covid-19. It is not clear, if any politicians are under self-quarantine.

Title: Vehicles parked at homes, air pollution levels go down in Prayagraj
Content:
An empty road in Prayagraj on Wednesday

PRAYAGRAJ: At a time when the country is facing challenging times in view of complete lockdown, it has come as a blessing in disguise for fight against pollution as the city’s air quality index (AQI) has improved drastically.

The comparison of AQI in Sangam city, as recorded on two different dates of the month put up on the display board at Prayagraj Junction, shows how the situation has improved.

Chief public relations officer (CPRO), North Central Railway (NCR), Ajeet Kumar Singh said on March 18, the city’s AQI was 206 (against the standard value of 100). The AQI on PM10 (particles per million) scale was recorded at 162µg/m3 and 91µg/m3 at PM2.5 scale.

“However, on March 23, the AQI was just 24, perhaps the lowest in several decades. The AQI on PM10 scale was recorded at 22µg/m3 and 14µg/m3 at PM2.5 scale,” he said.

To understand the purity of air, as inhaled by residents, one has to look at last year’s AQI. On November 1, 2019, AQI was recorded as 547.

On November 4, AQI was recorded at 622 (six time higher than permissible limits) and 380 µg/m3 on PM10 scale and 64µg/m3 at PM2.5 scale.

“Due to the lockdown, there is almost negligible pollution by vehicles and industries and as such every citizen can heave a sigh of relief as pollution level is very low,” said Ramjas Prasad, an official at UP Pollution Control Unit of Prayagraj.

Physician Dr Kamal Kumar said, “Although these are testing times and many people, especially younger generation could be irritated for being confined to their homes, everyone should start building the capacity of their lungs by following simple inhaling exercise and what better days it could be than the best AQI one could get”.

Title: Uttar Pradesh Lockdown: People unnecessarily venturing out to pay fine in Rampur
Content:
BAREILLY: Rampur district magistrate (DM) Aunjaneya Kumar Singh said gram panchayats, nagar panchayats and nagar palikas have been directed to slap fine on people caught unnecessarily loitering on the streets. The fine amount collected will be used in the treatment of Covid-19 cases. DM Singh said those caught violating lockdown will also be booked under relevant sections of the law.

Singh told TOI, “Since many people continue to violate the orders of lockdown and are often caught venturing out, we have decided to slap fines on such violators. Directions have been issued to local government bodies, including gram panchayats and the nagar panchayat , to levy penalties on offenders. The fine amount will be increased in case of repeat offenders. The amount recovered will be utilized for treatment of coronavirus patients.”

“Imposing penalty doesn’t mean that people will come out and get away by paying a fine, they will also be booked under various sections of the relevant laws and further legal action will be initiated. The move is aimed at sending a message to people that irresponsible behavior will not be tolerated and that guidelines need to be strictly followed by all,” the DM added.

Title: Vegetable vendors told to display price list
Content:
Representative image

UDHAGAMANDALAM: The Nilgiris district administration ordered officials to make vegetable and fruit shopowners to display price list and crack down on shops inflating prices of essential commodities.

Collector J Innocent Divya issued the order on Wednesday after conducting a check at the Ooty municipal market and receiving reports of inflated prices at Coonoor, Kotagiri and Gudalur markets. While at Ooty Uzhalavar sandai vegetables were sold at the prescribed price by the horticulture department, tomato was sold at Rs 40 at the Ooty municipal.In Kotagiri, tomato was sold at Rs 60, said Haldurai , a resident of the town.

The collector instructed shops to follow guidelines issued by the government as markets were overcrowded and shops were without facility for washing hands. The Ooty town DSP was instructed to allow only 25 people to enter the Uzhalavar Sandai at a time and permit the next five after as many come out of it.

Meanwhile, the district police stopped people roaming, including bikers, on streets and let them off after issuing stern warning.

Title: Tamil Nadu government announces police stations for Kochadai, Anupanadi
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: The city will get two more police stations at Kochadai and Anupanadi to be constructed at Rs 6.08 crore each to share the burden of the SS Colony and Avaniyapuram police stations, which have a vast and densely populated areas to cover. An announcement to this effect was made by the state government on Tuesday. Four more traffic police stations too have been announced for Madurai .

Last year, the government announced two police stations at Tirupalai and Mattuthavani to share the burden of vast police stations like Tallakulam and Anna Nagar. The process is under way for the creation of the two stations at present.

Following the expansion of the Madurai Corporation limits from 50sqkm to 147sqkm, the city police expanded its limits coterminous with the corporation limits in 2015.

The city police are having tough time controlling the expanded limits as the strength has not increased much. With the traffic strength too not being revised for long, officials found it difficult to manage the growing traffic. Officials will be relieved, once the four proposed stations come into operation.

City police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvatham told TOI that smaller the size of the area to be covered by a police station, better the services to the public. Since the city is densely populated, more police stations are required to provide better policing.

“When the number of stations increase we can handle emergency phone calls landing in control room, and patrolling effectively,” he said.

Meanwhile, the four traffic police stations would come up in Anna Nagar, Koodalpudur, Tirunagar and Mattuthavani at a cost of Rs 5.52 crore each. Devasirvatham said this will result in increase in traffic police strength, which will help manage traffic more efficiently.

The state government also announcement that sub-inspector led police stations like Perungudi, Austinpatti, Satur, Keelavalavu, Melavalavu, Kadupatti and Appan Thirupathi will be converted into inspector-led police stations.

The number of inspectors will also increase as there was an announcemnt to increase the strength of law and order and crime inspectors in districts like Trichy , Madurai, Coimbatore, Salem and Tirunelveli at a cost of Rs 11.74 crore.

Title: Madurai: Muslim preachers from Thailand too quarantined
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Three people, including two Islamic preachers, who were in contact with the man from Anna Nagar in Madurai who died at the Government Rajaji Hospital after being tested positive for Covid-19, have been admitted to the isolation ward at the hospital.

The 54-year-old had been chaperoning a group of eight Muslim preachers from Thailand to various mosques in Madurai during the past few weeks. Four of them arrived in India before January this year and visited various parts of the country before coming under his care. On tracing the victims’ contacts Madurai district administration has found that the eight men from Thailand and two of their local chaperons were staying in a mosque in Malaipatti near Alanganallur in Madurai.

They were rounded up by the revenue and health officials on Wednesday afternoon.Two of the men from Thailand were admitted to the isolation ward in the GRH, whereas the other eight including two local chaperons have been admitted to the quarantine facility near Thoppur in Madurai, said Madurai district collector Dr T G Vinay . There are three people in the isolation ward at the GRH with Covid-19-like symptoms and their samples have been sent for testing.

No positive cases were reported in Madurai district on Wednesday and 548 are in home quarantine in the district, said health department sources.

Title: Telangana: Contacts of DSP’s family isolated, area cordoned
Content: HYDERABAD: After the DSP of Bhadradri-Kothagudem district, his son and their cook had tested positive for the novel coronavirus , the district authorities have sent all those people who were in contact with the trio to quarantine.The house of the DSP in Kothagudem was fumigated and the area was cordoned off. On Monday, Kothagudem police registered a case against the DSP and his son, who returned from London via Dubai on March 18, for hiding the latter’s travel history and violating the home quarantine rule, after the latter tested positive for coronavirus.Health officials carried out contact tracing and zeroed in on people whom the DSP’s son had come in contact and began the isolation process. On Tuesday morning, the DSP told district SP Sunil Dutt that among those who were quarantined, four persons —his wife, himself and two others — had tested negative. The SP office issued an official release about the same.However, later in the night, an official order released by the director of health and family welfare, Telangana , confirmed that the DSP and the cook who works with the officer’s family had tested positive for the virus.“Thirty persons who have been in direct contact with the DSP and his son have been home quarantined. Those who were in contact with the 30 first contact persons have also been placed under house isolation,” the SP said. He said the entire area around the DSP’s house had been cordoned off. Disinfectant was also sprayed in the area. “The DSP has attended one official meeting recently but did not come in direct contact with anyone,” Sunil Dutt said.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Stay home or 1 lakh could be in hospital
Content: CHENNAI: We will have to pay a heavy price for violating the Covid curfew. A mathematical model has predicted that up to 60,000 people may land up in hospitals across Tamil Nadu when the disease peaks in May and that is the best case scenario, say officials in the state Covid-19 control room. In the worst case, the number may touch one lakh.The numbers are approximate, based on the model prepared by the Centre For Disease Dynamics, Economics and Policy (CDDEP) in association with the Johns Hopkins. “They have estimated the scenarios for Kerala, Karnataka , UP, Telangana and Delhi. We are using a rough calculation and taking a number between Telangana and Maharashtra,” said a senior health official.On Wednesday, Telangana, which has a population of 39.64 million, recorded 39 cases, while Maharashtra, with a population of 126 million, had 107. TN, with 81.5 million people, had 18 covid-19 positive cases. The analysis showed that India might end up with 13 crore to 25 crore Covid-19 infections – symptomatic, asymptomatic and hospitalization -- and between 12 lakh and 25 lakh people may require hospitalisation. “We have asked them for an exclusive report for Tamil Nadu,” said health secretary Beela Rajesh. Other recommendations in the report will stay valid, officials said. The report says most infected cases will be mild. Infections will peak between April and May, when the most number of people will be hospitalised.Government and private hospitals have been asked to increase bed strength, and district collectors and civic bodies to identify buildings that can be used for isolation and quarantine. Hospitals have been asked to drastically cut patient service and elective surgeries.The CDDEP guidance report on COVID-19 in India is based on evidence from the India SIM Model – an agent-based model of the Indian population. Scientists fitted the model to available data from China and Italy under three scenarios –high, moderate and low infection.National containment, it says, may no longer be an option for India, as community transmission of the virus most likely started in early March. “However, state or local (temporary) containment and mitigation is the best option,” it said. Tamil Nadu has found contacts of people who have travelled abroad being infected. Health minister C Vijayabaskar says they are doing their best to stop community transmission of the disease. Experts point out that social distancing can reduce this peak load by as much as 75% although this may be hard to enforce in India, the study points out.Encouraging early testing, it says people should follow social distancing more seriously. Director of public health Dr K Kolandasamy said disinfecting surfaces and hand hygiene should be practised along with social distancing. “This will have more impact than lockdowns,” he said.There is also hope that increase in temperature and humidity should help us in reducing case load, although the report warns there could be multiple peaks on the graph.

Title: Coronavirus scare pushes prices of essentials up
Content: BHOPAL: The corona scare in Madhya Pradesh is driving up the prices of essential commodities — adding to the pressure of household budgets. Prices of fresh vegetables have doubled and that of staples like pulses and flour have gone up by almost 25%, complain residents.On Monday, when Pankaj Sharma had gone to purchase fruits and vegetables from the nearby market, the prices were reasonable. But on Wednesday, the same hawker charged him double. When Sharma asked the hawker to reduce the prices, he told him, “We are not trying to cheat you. We are ourselves getting vegetables at a higher price.”Left with no option Sharma bought potato at Rs40/kg, tomato at Rs50/kg and bottle gourd (lauki) at Rs80/kg.What is strange is that vegetables and fruits are available at half the price at supermarkets — but things go out of stock there within minutes. On Wednesday itself, a supermarket in Trilanga was selling potatoes at Rs22/kg, tomatoes at Rs25/kg and onions at Rs27/kg — but everything was almost sold out by 10:30am.Despite the claims and assurances of government and district administration that there would be a smooth supply of essential commodities, black marketing of items like flour, edible oil, pulses (toor dal), rice, poha and sabudana have begun. These commodities are always “out of stock” and if one persists, you get it in black.“Prices of grocery items are up by at least 25%. Since people have been stocking up over the last few days, many staples are in short supply — because of which they are being sold at inflated prices. Aata which was earlier available for Rs625 per 25kg is now being sold for Rs850 per 25kg ... The prices are expected to rise,” said Vinod Shrivastava, a merchant.Ever since the janata curfew was announced, Bhopalis have been coming out in large numbers to buy grocery items, medicines and other goods. After the PM’s address on Tuesday, residents lined up outside markets to prepare for the 21-day lockdown in India. This buying spree has led to crowding in market areas, raising concerns. As many as 200 persons had reached a supermarket in Kolar on Tuesday, forcing the manager of the store to close the entry, even as the people jostled with the staff members. It was only after police announced that whosoever doesn’t leave will be arrested that the crowd dispersed.Shop owners are taking all precautions to prevent the spread of the virus. Many of stores have made it mandatory for customers to wear masks in their shops. “We have given instructions to all the traders not to allow crowding of people at their shop. They can take phone numbers of the customers and either call them when there are no people in the shop or deliver their order to their homes. Crowding at one place must be avoided, it is the very purpose of a lockdown,” said Bhopal collector, Tarun Pithode.Answering a question on blackmarketing of essential goods, Pithode said, “We have talked to traders and things should normalise in next one or two days."Pithode's assurance notwithstanding, prices of sanitisers and masks — which were the first to start rising following detection of coronavirus cases in India — continue to soar despite the administration enlisting self-help groups, prisoners and distilleries to provide adequate stock of the two commodities in the market.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: 143 booked in Pilibhit for defying lockdown
Content:
Representative Image

PILIBHIT: At least 143 people found loitering on roads have been booked under section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by a public servant) of IPC since Tuesday night. Of them, 72 were named while the rest were unnamed in five different police stations in Pilibhit. The violators were found roaming in groups on roads.

As many as 44 people, including 15 named, were booked in Bisalpur city. And 37 violators of lockdown including 15 named were booked at Puranpur Kotwali police station.

An FIR registered by sub-inspector Achal Singh in Sungarhi police station says, “Seven persons were booked. They were found in group in front of a mosque in Naugma Pakadia.” SHO Atar Singh said, “All the seven persons were sent back home after taking their signatures and thumb impression as the imprisonment under section 188 was less than seven years.”

While in Pilibhit’s Kotwali police station, 11 named and 10 unidentified people were booked.

Title: Horticorp launches home delivery of vegetables in Kochi
Content:
Vegetable shop at Ernakulam market.

KOCHI: To minimise the chances of people stepping out of their houses on the pretext of buying vegetables, the district administration along with Horticorp has joined hands with an online platform to deliver vegetables at their doorsteps.

Thiruvananthapuram-based online platform A M Needs will deliver the vegetables before 7am. As per the plan, the vegetables purchased by the Horticorp from farmers and the agriculture department from wholesale market will be wrapped in a grey paper and transported to the destinations as per the demand of customers.

Vegetables will also be purchased through block-level federated organization under agriculture department and Vegetable Fruits Promotion Council of Kerala (VFPCK).

The order for vegetables can be placed through the mobile application of AM Needs, which currently delivers bread, egg and milk at people’s doorsteps after taking orders online. “We plan to sell around 10 varieties of vegetables, including onion, potato, chilly, beans and bitter gourd online. AM Needs will deliver it before 7am under the brand name of Horticorp itself. The vegetables purchased by the agriculture department and VFPCK will be supplied to the Horticorp, which in turn will wrap in paper as per the demand of each customer. After wrapping the vegetables in paper carrying name of the customer on it, the parcel will be handed over to the delivery boys of the online agency before 5am. The price of vegetables will depend on the procurement rate. The online agency will charge transportation fee from the customer. The payment should be made online,” said a Horticorp official.

The customer should place the order for vegetables a day before delivery as the officials need to purchase the products from market depending on the requirement.

The agency currently plans to distribute the vegetables at Kakkanad, Edapally, Panampilly Nagar, Thevara, Pottakuzhy, Tripunithura, Palluruthy, Palarivattom and Vyttila areas. ‘We have employed 38-40 delivery boys for the job. Online delivery boys are not allowed in many apartment complexes due to the Covid-19 situation. In such cases, we either hand over the parcel to security staff in the building or the customer can directly collect it from the gate. Though we have decided to deliver vegetables at nine places now, we will extend it to other parts gradually,” said Pranav T P, official of AM Needs.

Delivery has already been started on a trial basis at Kakkanad and Edapally on Wednesday.

The customer care department of the agency will be open from 6am to 10pm.

Title: Odias stranded in other states seek government help to return home
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

BHUBANESWAR: Several Odias, including students, stranded in different cities of the country appealed to the state government on Wednesday to bring them back home. A group of 79 students pursuing their BEd in K J Somaiya Sanskrit Vidyapeetham, Mumbai, posted a video on social media urging the state government to rescue them. They are staying in rented accommodation.

Ajay Pati, a first year BEd student at the institute, said they are in a tight spot. “Eight people are staying together in a room near the institute. We do not have rations and cooking gas. We are somehow managing with dried foods and biscuits. We may not survive till April 14 if the government do not rescue us,” Pati said.

He said they stayed back because their examination was scheduled on April 7. “But later it was postponed. We had booked tickets for March 22, but it was cancelled due to last Sunday’s ‘janata curfew’. Later, we booked tickets for Tuesday. Now the trains have been cancelled,” he added.

A group of five people from Bargarh and Sambalpur are stuck in a hotel in Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh. They had gone to attend a wedding in Pratapgarh and are now finding it difficult to return, resulting in an appeal to the Naveen Patnaik government.

“We had come to attend the wedding of our friend’s daughter at Pratapgarh on March 18. The next day, we left for Lucknow. After finishing our work there, we booked tickets for March 21 to return to Odisha. But the train got cancelled. Later, the ‘janata curfew’ and then the lockdown robbed us of a chance to return home,” said Sanjay Kumar Bhoi from Khajurtikra in Bargarh district .

He said they are holed up in a room in the hotel which does not serve food. “With the eateries closed, we are surviving on biscuits and fruits. We are also running out of money. If the government provides us with a car from Sambalpur, we can return home,” Bhoi added.

Meanwhile, a group of 45 students stranded at Markapura in Andhra Pradesh returned home on Wednesday with the help of Andhra Pradesh governor Biswabhusan Harichandan. The students had visited Markapura for their BEd exam. As many as 105 students had returned home on March 19, but these 45 could not due to the lockdown. Following request from their parents, governor Harichandan directed the Andhra Pradesh government to help them out.

Title: Noted freedom fighter admitted to Capital Hospital in Bhubaneswar
Content:
BHUBANESWAR: Noted freedom fighter Bhabani Charan Patnaik, 99, was on Wednesday admitted to the Capital Hospital here after developing a cardiac problem. Expressing his concern over the illness of the freedom fighter, Naveen directed that Patnaik’s medical expenses will be borne by the state government.

Naveen also directed for formation of a medical team headed by director of Capital Hospital Dr Ashok Kumar Pattnaik to monitor the former parliamentarian’s health condition, said an official statement issued by the chief minister’s office.

The Gandhian is a three-time Rajya Sabha member from Odisha . He is among the few persons alive to have witnessed all elections held in India since 1951 to the seventeenth Lok Sabha in 2019.

Title: Non-virus patients in Odisha wait for crisis to end
Content: BHUBANESWAR: For those afflicted with some disease other than coronavirus , getting to a doctor is proving to be difficult during this lockdown.Those patients who were recently discharged following treatment are facing a harrowing time with follow-up health check-ups and diagnosis as some hospitals have stopped OPD services.“I have undergone kidney transplant. I need to visit the doctor and get medicines every month. Now I can’t come to Bhubaneswar after the trains and buses have been cancelled. I have a relative in Bhubaneswar but he can’t send over the medicines with the transport services under lockdown. It is getting very difficult for me,” said Bidyadhar Palai, a resident of Palur in Ganjam district One of the major hospitals of the state, AIIMS Bhubaneswar , has closed OPDs for outpatients in order to reduce gathering in the hospital during the lockdown period to contain the spread of Covid-19.This hospital normally gets between 4,000 and 4,500 outpatients everyday. Other hospitals in the city have also controlled their OPDs to reduce the visitors. Some private clinics have also downed their shutters during this lockdown period.A patient from Bargarh district, who was diagnosed with cancer, reached Bhubaneswar for treatment. He was advised some tests but with most diagnostics centres not open, he is finding it difficult to get those tests done.But amid such takes of desperation, some doctors are providing a ray of hope. They have started providing consultations on WhatsApp, voice calling and video calls.“I request people to use digital platforms like WhatsApp to consult me for any gastro-related problems between 2pm to 10pm everyday. If anybody has an emergency, they can meet me at the hospital between 9 am and 2pm. I will send a scanned copy of the prescription through WhatsApp message so that people can get medicines from the nearby stores,” said gastroenterologist Premananda Pattanaik of SUM Hospital.Ashutosh Mohapatra, a gastroenterologist from AMRI Hospital , also appealed to the public to contact him if they want information on coronavirus and consultation on gastro-related problems.

Title: Police tighten lockdown measures
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: As many as 1,751 cases have been registered in the state by the police for violation of lockdown orders. With this, the police have registered 3,612 total cases in two days since Tuesday.The highest number of cases have been registered in Kozhikode (338) while the least number of cases have been registered on Wednesday in Kasaragod (10). While Kottayam (208), Idukki (214), Alappuzha (178) and Kollam city (170) registered more number of cases, the number was lesser in districts like Malappuram (11), Kozhikode rural (13), Palakkad (19) and Kannur (20).Police have tightened the enforcement measures across the state on the second day of lockdown, in the wake of Covid-19 outbreak. The police have resorted to harder measures like sending those people back whose reasons for moving out of their houses sounded unconvincing.While the overall number of people who left their houses on the second day was lesser compared to that on Tuesday, in some places where the public still used their vehicles to move out, the police confiscated the vehicles and slapped charges for violation of CrPC section 144, that clearly imposed several restrictions including on grouping of people. “The situation has improved when compared to yesterday and the public largely are responding well to the restrictions. But for those who are yet to understand their responsibility, we will be stricter tomorrow,” Thiruvananthapuram city police commissioner Balram Kumar Upadhyaya said.When compared to other places, the enforcement in the capital became harder for the police as the government employees were given exemption along with other essential services and a large section of the capital city’s population are government employees.At the same time, the enforcement in other parts of the state were much smoother. The police also resorted to some innovative ways of monitoring the public movements. In Thrissur, the police are using drones by which they can monitor by-lanes and pocket roads where the public movement is likely to be more. “We are using four drones covering the city during the peak hours of morning and evening. This is proving to be much effective for us,” Thrissur city police commissioner R Adithya said.In northern parts of the state, people are generally confined to their houses. The police contacted all the people who came to the state through Kannur and Kozhikode airports from March 1. “People have begun cooperating with the government orders. Also, we are contacting them every week, tracking their movements, and also ensuring that they are strictly quarantined in their houses,” DIG (Kannur range) K Sethuraman said.

Title: Three more family members of coronavirus patient test negative
Content: KANPUR: The son, daughter-in-law and grand daughter of Vijay Narain, resident of NRI city, tested negative for COVID-19, stated the district administration on Wednesday. Narain was tested positive for coronavirus and is undergoing treatment at Lala Lajpat Rai hospital where his condition is said to be stable.The administration had already received the report of his wife as negative. The reports of his son, daughter-in-law and grand daughter also came out negative. The health authorities had quarantined Narain’s family members at UHM hospital for 14 days.Meanwhile, the district authorities had sanitized the NRI city.The report also brought a sense of relief to the residents of NRI city. They have been taking necessary precautions and have closed the gates of the area so that no outsider could enter in the quarantine period.Educational institutes too have joined the fight against the deadly virus and have offered to provide their hostels for quarantine, if required. Naraina Medical College Hospital has already reserved 100 beds for isolation and has also offered to provide its 120-room hostel for suspected or confirmed COVID-19 patients.Similarly, Rama Medical College has reserved 30 beds for coronavirus patients.Both colleges have also proposed to provide the services of doctors and paramedical staff. The district authorities have taken the proposed areas under their control. Besides, Axis College, Kanpur Institute of Technology , Dr Virendra Swarup Group of Institutions and Allenhouse Institute of Technology have also offered their resources and infrastructure for the same.

Title: Odisha: Villagers set up barricades against outsiders’ entry
Content: BERHAMPUR: To take social distancing to the highest level, people of Kalabada panchayat in Ganjam’s Chikiti block on Wednesday decided to practice social isolation to prevent the spread of the dreaded coronavirus “We will not go out of the villages. At the same time, we will not allow outsiders to enter our panchayat till the situation improves,” said sarpanch of Kalabanda Sanju Pradhan.Kalabada panchayat has 12 villages with a population of around 10,000 people. In each village, the youngsters will keep an eye on the entry of outsiders. The decision was taken in village committee meetings,” said Narasingh Pradhan, a member of a village committee.“The dreaded virus can spread only if someone comes from outside. Hence, we decided to distance ourselves from outsiders,” added Sushant Panigrahy, another member of the committee. The decision was first taken by Bada Baranga village and then other villagers followed suit. The villagers have also been educated not to venture outside if there is no urgent work.“The lockdown is total in the panchayat with the residents, many of them daily labourers, voluntarily confining themselves to their homes,” the sarpanch claimed.Like Kalabada, villagers of Deulapada under Chandapur panchayat has also decided not to allow any outsider into the village to check the spread of covid-19. The villagers have also decided not to go outside during the lockdown period till April 14, a villager said.At Khajuria, on the outskirts of Berhampur , villagers have made a barricade at the entrance of the village to keep outsiders away. The villagers, who go outside on any urgent work, should enter the village after washing their hands, the villagers urged. “We have taken this decision to restrict the spread of deadly virus to the village,” said Santosh Sahu , one of the villagers.

Title: 16,000 get home delivery of gas cylinders in Bijnor
Content:
Representative image

BIJNOR: Supply department in Bijnor has provided gas cylinders to 16,000 people at home here on the first day of the nationwide lockdown on Wednesday due to the Covid-19 outbreak.

District supply officer Manish Kumar told TOI, “There are over six lakh consumers in Bijnor district who used to get cooking gas from 90 agencies. Since the complete lockdown, we have shut all gas agencies and started providing 100% home delivery. On Wednesday, we have provided over 16,000 cylinders to consumers who had booked their gas through proper procedure. All cylinders are sanitised before they are being sent to the consumers’ houses.”

“Besides, we will have a mobile number on which consumers can send their demands for essentials. We are planning to prepare a ‘grain kit’ for people. They will be sent home of the ‘callers’ at market price. This will help to curb black marketing,” Kumar added.

Title: 8 more leaders pledge for aid from development fund
Content: KANPUR: Eight more public representatives in Kanpur have come forward with monetary contribution to fight against Covid-19.BJP MP Devendra Singh Bhole has announced to donate Rs 1 crore from his MP fund. Similarly, technical education minister Kamal Rani Varun has announced Rs 50 lakh from her MLA fund besides one month’s salary. Deputy CM Keshav Prasad Maurya has donated Rs 25 lakh to LLR hospital.Industries minister Satish Mahana minister of state Neelima Katiyar have announced Rs 25 lakh each for medicines, masks and other equipment. BJP MLA Surendra Maithani has announced Rs 25 lakh his counterparts Mahesh Trivedi and Bhagwati Prasad Sagar have announced Rs 10 lakh each as their contribution. tnn

Title: Oppn seeks more welfare measures
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala has asked the state government to roll out more welfare measures for helping financially backward people ‘who are worst hit by lockdown ’.

“The government should immediately disburse a financial assistance of not less than Rs 1000 to people under BPL category, daily or weekly wage workers, farm labourers, construction workers, coir, cashew and handloom workers, fishermen, auto/taxi workers, NREGA workers, senior citizens and differently abled people,” he told reporters here on Wednesday. The expenditure could be met from various welfare funds, Chennithala added.

The Opposition leader also urged the government to distribute food kits through ration shops to all people irrespective of their BPL or APL status. “The government should implement the announced financial package of Rs 20000 crore immediately, besides offering support to migrant labourers,” he said.

Among other recommendations and demands raised by the opposition leader were establishing a ‘community kitchen’ centred around Anganwadis for home delivery, one-year moratorium on bank loans irrespective of defaults, ensuring availability of masks and sanitizers besides life-saving medicines, measures to procure paddy at Kuttanadu, Palakkadu and Thrissur and deferring implementation of tax proposals in Budget 2020-21.

TNN

Title: Muzaffarnagar police start issuing passes to people providing essential items
Content:
Muzaffarnagar: Providers of essential services in Muzaffarnagar, like groceries and medicines, can now get passes by sending the photos of their vehicle’s registration plate and other required documents on a WhatsApp number to ensure their smooth run on the roads during the lockdown, local police said on Wednesday.

“With the help of the passes, policemen on duty would be able to identify and segregate them, and provide uninterrupted passage,” a police officer said.

The documents can be sent on helpline number 8057680112, he said, adding that once the documents are received passes will be issued to them.

The move comes against the backdrop of complaints that policemen were “harassing” drivers of vehicles on road to ferry items of daily needs. On Wednesday, despite the lockdown, people were seen roaming on roads.

Police arrested 16 such people who were caught roaming on roads and couldn’t give a valid reason for their outing. As many as 200 challan were also slapped and 27 vehicles were impounded.

Senior superintendent of police (SSP) of Muzaffarnagar, Abhishek Yadav, said, “We are trying to ensure that no one has to go out. Every essential item will be available. Medical stores and grocery shops will be open.”

“If anyone has to come out in an emergency then avoid taking other person with him. Otherwise action will be taken against him,” the SSP cautioned.

Title: Odisha government plans corona test lab in Vimsar
Content: SAMBALPUR: With the fear of the coronavirus outbreak getting worse, the state government is now planning to set up a Biosafety Levels 2 (BSL 2) laboratory here at the Veer Surendra Sai Institute of Medical Sciences and Research (Vimsar), where the screening test for the Covid-19 suspects can be conducted. The state government had sought a feasibility report for this purpose from the Vimsar authorities.Vimsar superintendent Jayashree Dora confirmed that the government had sought the feasibility report. She said, “We sent the report on Wednesday. The laboratory has been proposed to be set up in the microbiology department of the hospital.”She added that with the setting up of the laboratory here at Vimsar, the Recombinant Technology Polymerase Chain Reaction (rt PCR) test will be possible here. “We will be able to get the test reports of the Covid-19 suspects here once the laboratory becomes operational.”Currently, the premier healthcare institution is sending the throat swab samples of the patients suspected to have contracted the Covid-19 to the Regional Medical Research Center (RMRC) in Bhubaneswar. As a result, it is taking time to get the test report.The hospital here caters to patients from across the western part of the state. The people of the region will be benefited with the setting up of the BSL2 Laboratory here, Dora said.The Junior Doctors’ Association (JDA) of Vimsar had put forth the demand to set up of a Covid-19 laboratory at Vimsar, Burla and at MKCG, Berhampur, before the government.Sanjeeb Mishra, president of the JDA at Vimsar, said, “More tests for Covid-19 is necessary to identify the patients and to isolate them to contain the virus. Till date, India has conducted only about 18,000 tests, which is roughly the same as South Korea’s daily tests. The laboratory here will enable early detection and proper isolation of patients, which will go a long way in checking the epidemic.”In view of the outbreak of coronavirus, the Vimsar authorities have already opened a Covid-19 counter outpatient department (OPD) here at Vimsar. Around 80 to 100 patients visit the the counter daily.

Title: CM announces relief for poor, free treatment to Covid affected
Content: BHOPAL: In a relief to the people of the state, Madhya Pradesh chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan on Wednesday announced a relief package for those affected by Coronavirus assuring treatment at government expenses, besides announcing financial assistance to poor and students.Chouhan also warned of strict action against black-marketing and hoarding of essential commodities during the crisis period.“The government will provide two months advance to all beneficiaries availing social security pension and announced Rs 1,000 as assistance to the labourers. We have also instructed the officials to deposit Rs 156 crore to the accounts of 65.91 lakh students under the mid-day meal benefit scheme,” said Chouhan in special address to the public, on Wednesday.The chief minister also stressed to observe complete lockdown in the state in view of Prime Minister Narendra Modi 's advice. He said 46 lakh pensioners will get Rs 600 per month under social security pension which amounts to Rs 275 crore per month. The government will also provide Rs 1,000 each to labourers and Rs 2.20 lakh to Saharia, Baiga and Bharia tribals as advance to help them meet their expenses, he said.“We will also treat corona positive cases in the government hospitals and medical colleges. The government will also ensure payment to private hospitals under Ayushman scheme," he said. Voluntary organisations will be involved to distribute food packets to the affected destitute people, he said.Chouhan directed for a complete ban on organising meeting, gatherings and festivals. Guidelines of social distancing will be followed strictly and said social vigil to trace suspected corona affected cases be maintained in each locality so that the district collectors and authorities are informed about suspected patients.The chief minister further said the government will ensure proper supply of essential commodities and medicines through municipal corporation and panchayats.Earlier the chief minister held video conference with district authorities instructing proper security to medical staff, supply and logistics and unabated supply of essential goods. He said responsibility of senior officials be fixed to ensure flawless working and management.Chouhan also announced sops for the farmers and assured that arrangements will be made for the proper procurement of Rabi crops, supply of fertilizer, seeds, urea and other necessary things will be maintained.

Title: Health workers at checkposts risk exposure to coronavirus in Panaji
Content: PANAJI: Frontline health workers posted at the Patradevi, Naibag and Kiranpani checkposts for screening coronavirus suspects have been left to fend for themselves after it was found that basic facilities such as hand sanitisers, masks, thermal scanners and drinking water have not been provided to them.The monitoring and advisory committee for Pernem taluka, that has been formed to oversee the implementation of the restrictions in view of the nationwide curfew , conducted an inspection of these areas on Tuesday.The committee informed the government there is an urgent need to provide health workers with thermal scanners at three checkposts, as they found to be using digital thermometers to record body temperatures.It has also been suggested that the staff be provided with basic requirements for their safety, including hand sanitisers. “There is a need to provide drinking water and washing facility - a wash basin, a small-sized water tank along with hand wash and soap, as police and health workers handle various documents and vehicle papers,” stated the committee in its report.
