NEW DELHI: In an unexpected move , the only slaughterhouse of the capital city at Ghazipur has been closed down by East Delhi Municipal Corporation (EDMC).

While the shops selling meat and poultry products have been exempted from the 21-day lockdown announced by the central government to contain novel coronavirus, the municipal corporation has reasoned that the closure is in public interest. Meat merchant associations have, meanwhile, claimed that the authorities did not consult them. The decision to shut down the abattoir is unfair, they say.

As per the order issued by the deputy director of veterinary services (in-charge) at EDMC, the closure will remain in effect till further orders. The order issued on Wednesday states that “in-view of the ongoing steps to control, contain and eliminate the Covid-19 pandemic in compliance with the guidelines issued to restrict proximity of human involvement, it has been decided to close the Ghazipur slaughterhouse till further order in public interest.”

The order, however, clarifies that the animal rendering plant of Ghazipur—which processes animal carcasses found in the city—will remain operational because it has to scientifically dispose off the fallen animals. Ghazipur — the only functional slaughterhouse complex in the capital — processes over 5,000 cattle in a single shift under normal circumstances. A senior EDMC official said, “Since there is no movement of people and animals to the premises, the facility at the plant cannot be operated. There is no supply of animals, so there is no point in keeping it open.”

However, Md Arshad Quraishi, Delhi meat merchant association head, said that the claim that no animals were being supplied was not accurate. “There are still some animals left in the animal market near the slaughterhouse.”

Title: 550 homeless people get food, thanks to Good Samaritans
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: Good Samaritans in the city came to the aid of homeless people by distributing food to the needy on Wednesday. With hotels and temples providing annadhanam (free food) closed as part of the nation-wide lockdown, volunteers from the Trichy chapter of the NGO No Food Waste provided food to the homeless after obtaining the consent from the district administration.

The volunteers from the NGO said that over 550 food packets were distributed to people on the streets. Tomato rice cooked at three different kitchens, were distributed by 20 youths, who split into 10 teams, and reached out to destitutes at various spots. A bottle of drinking water was also provided along with the food packets. Majority of the homeless people were found near spots like Amma Mandapam , Thiruvanaikoil, Chathiram bus stand and Woraiyur.

“Social distancing was maintained while preparing and delivering the food. The volunteers also had gloves and masks on while distributing the food. We procure the food through our sponsors and manage to offer it to the homeless once a day,” G V Karthik , the organiser said.

Police personnel who are in charge of surveillance in Cantonment area too did their bit to help people on the streets by distributing food packets available with them. Meanwhile, the shelter homes at three locations, run by Trichy Corporation , have reached maximum capacity.

Title: Cops face wrath for curbing movement
Content:
AHMEDABAD: A 23-year-old man and his 21-year-old wife attacked cops of SG-1 traffic police at Kargil crossroads in Sola for restricting their movement due to the lockdown.

According to the FIR lodged with Sola police station, the accused, identified as Sagar Vaghela, a resident of Chandkheda, was riding his scooter when he was stopped by a traffic cop.

Vaghela apparently got incensed and entered into an altercation with the traffic cops. Vaghela’s wife Kajal Naneja weighed in and the argument escalated. A woman police constable intervened and tried to explain to Naneja that her husband had committed a mistake. Naneja began abusing the woman cop and attacked her.

“When Naneja was thrashing the woman cop, her husband attacked a male cop with his helmet. Vaghela hit the helmet on the cop’s head and injured him,” said a cop.

Soon, around six cops overpowered the couple and arrested them under the charges of assault, causing obstruction in police's duty, abetment and hurling abuses at the cops.

In another case, a Prahladnagar resident, Sulabh Sarogi (30), allegedly abused cops when they asked him why he was roaming around. An FIR registered with Anandnagar police station alleges that Sarogi had initially given his name as Rahul Jindal, but when the cops sought his ID proof, he revealed his real name.

Title: Maharashtra health minister appeals for sympathy for those returning to villages
Content: KOLHAPUR: Taking note of the reverse migration from cities to villages, Maharashtra health minister Rajesh Tope appealed for sympathetic treatment of these people.Tope took to Twitter to talk about the large number of people — who had gone to Pune and Mumbai in search of work — returning to their native villages.In his message, the health minister said that such people were not being allowed to enter their villages and are seen with suspicion. “Do not stop them. Respect human values while behaving with these people and their families,” the minister appealed.The minister’s tweet evoked sharp responses from the people. Swapnil Bansode, a citizen, complained that people coming from cities were forced to stay in temples, chawdi or samaj mandir in several villages.there have been reports that several villages have banned the entry of guests to their villages. The trend is seen even in a city like Kolhapur . In the Bawda area, such boards have been put up at the entrance of a lane. The board reads: “Anybody who does not stay in the lane is not allowed”. The lane has been barricaded by the residents there.In Satara. Sangli, Kolhapur and Solapur districts, police patils, talathis and gramsewaks have been asked to alert the police and health officials immediately if any guest comes to the village. The guest is taken to the primary health centre and then to the nearest hospital in case of Covid-like symptoms. The district administration has advised home-quarantine for such people.In Karnal village of Sangli district, police have registered an offences against a father-son duo, who were told to quarantine themselves at home, but are now missing.

Title: Infectious compassion: From cops to citizens, Amdavadis inspire hope
Content:
People board a bus arranged by cops

AHMEDABAD: The overcast sky was the only respite for Bharat Parmar, 21, a native of Dungarpur in Rajasthan, and six of his friends, when they started off from Changodar early on Wednesday morning. “We work at a fabrication unit and if we don’t find work there, we search at a few packaging units nearby. Ever since the lockdown has been imposed, it’s has been difficult for us to survive. First public transport was closed and now the country has been locked down for 21 days,” said Bharat. “There’s no option but to return home on foot and hope we get some means of transportation.” K T Kamaria, DSP, Sanand, said hundreds like Bharat are passing through transit points for past two days. “We have made four makeshift counters on the route to provide them snacks, food packets and water. When there is no one except police on the road, we thought we could reach out to them,” he said. Likewise, Ahmeadabad traffic police arranged for three private buses and five mini buses so at least the women with children, teens and the elderly could get to the Ratanpur border. S G Damor, a sub-inspector with city traffic police, said that public transport is banned but the sight of women carrying children, determined to walk 100km, motivated them to make arrangements for 200-odd persons on Wednesday. Several city-based groups and individuals also distributed hundreds of food packets to the people living in slums and daily wagers, for whom the lockdown has become a major challenge to staying afloat.

Title: Nagpur: Food for homeless with social distancing
Content:
The meals are being provided twice a day free of cost under the Deen Dayal Antyodaya Yojana due to the ongoing... Read More

NAGPUR: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) on Wednesday fed over 300 homeless and those living on footpath after bringing them to its five shelter homes across the city. The meals are being provided twice a day free of cost under the Deen Dayal Antyodaya Yojana due to the ongoing lockdown.

Under the central government scheme, a nominal fee is charged for a thali but because of the prevailing situation the NMC is serving the khichadi, sabzi, dal, rice and chapati for free.

Preventing any possible spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19), the inmates are asked to sit at a distance of 3 feet during the meal. Before entering the shelter homes, the inmates were shown how to wash their hands properly, a practice which is now followed regularly during the day.

They have also been asked to stay indoors at the shelter homes for the next one month as part of the preventive measures undertaken by the city administration.

The shelter homes are at Hansapuri Primary School in Timki-Bhankheda, Buty Girls’ School in Sitabuldi, Guru Gansidas Samaj Bhavan at Dipty Signal, NMC library and samaj bhavan at Nara Road, and near Tekdi Mandir under railway station flyover. All of them were sanitized.

Deputy municipal commissioner Ranjana Lade told TOI that the NMC has tied up with NGOs who are helping creating awareness among the inmates about social distancing which is needed at the moment. “The drive of shifting homeless is underway 24X7. They are arriving in batches. We are ready to feed all homeless at our shelters. We are targeting any number but all will be fed till the lockdown is in force,” she said.

Title: India and China discuss joint fight against Covid-19
Content:
Times News Network

New Delhi: Amid growing threat from the novel coronavirus, India and China on Tuesday discussed cooperation to jointly fight the pandemic which has killed more than 17,000 worldwide.

Foreign minister S Jaishankar said in a tweet that he and his counterpart Wang Yi discussed working together and agreed to build further on bilateral efforts. The two also spoke about the upcoming G20 summit.

India had earlier sent a planeload of relief supplies to coronavirus-hit Hubei province as a mark of solidarity with China. Providing more details of the conversation, Chinese ambassador to India Sun Weidong said on Twitter that the two ministers expressed sympathy and solidarity with India in its fight against Covid-19 and that China was ready to share its experience, provide assistance within its capacity and "open its channel for procurement to India".

Significantly, as the US and China spar over the origin of Covid-19, Sun tweeted that Wang said in his conversation with Jaishankar that "it’s not acceptable and detrimental to international cooperation to label the virus and stigmatise China, hope India opposes such narrow mindset".

"Jaishankar agreed not to label the virus and the international community should send strong signal of solidarity," Sun said.

There was no official response from India to Sun’s comments.

"Wang Yi said we are confident that India can handle and win the battle against Covid-19. China and India should support each other, and jointly safeguard global public health. Jaishankar thanked China for its sympathy message and assistance of medical materials to India," Sun said.

Wuhan, the central Chinese city where the virus cases were first detected in December last year, on Monday reported one new confirmed case of Covid-19 after reporting zero cases for five consecutive days. On Tuesday, China announced that it will lift the three-month lockdown on more than 50 million people in the Hubei province, the epicentre of the deadly coronavirus outbreak, on Wednesday as Covid-19 had begun to abate.

Title: Kerala high court suspends functioning till April 14
Content: KOCHI: The high court on Wednesday decided not to conduct regular sittings until April 14 in the wake of Covid-19 outbreak. In addition to suspending the functioning of the court, the HC has also decided to extend all interim orders passed by it until April 14.A full bench comprising Chief Justice S Manikumar and Justice CK Abdul Rehim and Justice CT Ravikumar issued the directive after considering a high court’s case registered suo motu.Meanwhile, bail applications will be entertained by a committee constituted as per the directive of the Supreme Court.During Wednesday’s hearing, state government, represented by additional advocate general Ranjith Thampan , and the central government, represented by assistant solicitor general P Vijayakumar, undertook that no coercive steps will be taken by government authorities during the period of lockdown. After recording the undertakings, the high court directed the state government to make arrests only if inevitable.

Title: Ahmedabad: Kindness served to hungry and needy
Content:
It now identifies the needy and supplies food packets to them and serves tea to police personnel.

AHMEDABAD: Aejaz Chanawala and his friends have for years been serving tea and food free to the kin of patients at VS Hospital. Ever since the lockdown was announced, Chanawala’s group has extended its services outside, mainly to cops, for there is nobody to offer them tea and food during their long duty hours on deserted streets.

Chanawala is associated with a group named ‘Genuine Help’. It now identifies the needy and supplies food packets to them and serves tea to police personnel. “There are more than eight persons involved in this activity, but they are busy in their respective areas,” Chanawala said. “We have been preparing food and supplying packets to the needy.”

He further said, “This time around, policemen do not get anything to eat. No restaurant or roadside tea stall is open. So we cater to them too by offering them tea and food twice a day.”

Title: Al-Burooj residents make own sanitizer, stay safe
Content:
AHMEDABAD: Al-Burooj, a multi-storey building complex with more than 12 towers of 11 storeys each and having about 450 flats is setting an example of fighting the pandemic. Youths of the society located on Makarba Road are pitching in to help every member of the society stay sanitized, including the domestic help.

The secretary of the building society, Naved Mirza, told TOI that there are four chemical engineers in the complex and several doctors. “They have made the sanitizer themselves. The doctors living in the building have ensured that the sanitizer works efficiently,” he added.

Rafiq Mansuri, a resident, said they provide the sanitizer to every visitor to the society, and also spray his or her vehicle with the sanitizer. “The society youths stand at the gates with sprays and sanitize every visitor. Security guards are sprayed 8-10 times a day for safety,” Mansuri said. “Youths of the building who are staying at home due to lockdown take turns to stand at the gate on sanitization duty.”

“It is not just about sanitizing, but we are managing our own grocery and other essentials through collective action so that fewer people have to enter and exit the society ,” Mansuri added.

Title: Trichy: Gated communities impose curbs on entry of outsiders
Content: TRICHY: Gated communities in the city accommodating at least eight to 100 dwelling units each have framed rules and restrictions to prevent the spread of Covid-19. The advisories include restricting the entry of outsiders except those supplying essential commodities including milk, water, cooking gas and newspapers. Residents have been insisted not to let their children play in the common area.With more than 450 apartments in the city, the risk of community transmission of Covid-19 is high in gated communities since they share common lifts and staircases.Ever since Section 144 of the CrPc was enforced to curtail the movement of people in public places, gated communities simultaneously prepared a list of dos and dont’s and notified them to the residents. “We have provided hand sanitizers to the security guards. Handrails, lifts and common access area are being disinfected,” V Nadaraja , president of a gated community in Cantonment said.At least 25 to 500 people on an average reside in the gated communities at Srirangam and K Abishekapuram zones. Caretakers of the apartments, who come from faraway places have been asked to avail leave during the shutdown. To ensure social distancing, residents in a section of gated communities were instructed to skip morning walks in groups.“All visitors including those supplying essentials should sanitise their hands before entering the campus,” L M Raj, in-charge of a gated community in Sangliyandapuram said.Most apartments had closed the common entrance. Residents welfare associations said that the temporary restrictions were well adhered to by the residents. Many residents were seen using the staircase instead of the lifts.Meanwhile, many residents have asked their maids not to report for work. The absence of public transportation during the lockdown and to ensure social distancing were cited as the reasons. “The maid was paid full month’s salary and asked to stay at home as there is a lockdown,” Malar Viswanathan , a resident of Lawsons Road said.

Title: Coronavirus & lockdown cause a drop in district’s crime rate
Content: Kolhapur: The coronavirus outbreak and the subsequent lockdown has led to a reduction in the crime rate in Kolhapur district.According to the police department, every day, about 12 to 15 cases are registered with the various police stations in the district. However, on Sunday — the day janata curfew was in effect — only three cases were registered. According to police officers, as everyone was staying at home and there was a heavy police presence on the roads, there has been a fall in the district’s crime rate.Prashant Amrutkar, the deputy superintendent of police, Karveer division, said: “On an average, 12 to 15 criminal incidents are registered with the police in the district. These include thefts, robberies, chain snatchings, murders, attempts to murder and other disputes between families or individuals. Since the coronavirus outbreak, we have noticed that there has been a reduction in the number of cases registered with the police stations.”“As the coronavirus threat has increased in the state, we are experiencing a reduction in criminal activities in the district. In the past 10 days, the officers from different police stations in our jurisdiction have been saying that fewer criminal activities have been reported in their respective police stations. Incidents like robberies, murders, thefts, attempts to murder and chain snatchings have reduced. Even criminal activities like gambling and matkas have shut. Road accidents have also reduced as there are fewer people on the roads,” he said.“We suspect the reason is that the people are staying at home and there are low chances of thieves targetting houses. The continuous patrolling of the police has also helped,” he said.

Title: Coronavirus lockdown: Garbage generation reduces 25%
Content: NAGPUR: The lockdown necessitated due to coronavirus scare has reduced the city’s garbage generation drastically. Against approximately 1,185.23 metric tonne garbage generation per day, the city is generating almost 300MT less garbage post lockdown.Data compiled by Nagpur Municipal Corporation ’s solid waste management department shows the city is generating around 894MT garbage every day after March 15 as against 1,185MT a day before that, confirmed a senior official from the Bhandewadi dumping yard.AG Enviro is lifting door-to-door garbage from zone numbers 1 to 5 which include Laxmi Nagar, Dharampeth, Hanuman Nagar , Dhantoli and Nehru Nagar, while BVG India is collecting waste from Gandhibagh , Satranjipura, Lakadganj, Ashi Nagar and Mangalwari zones.All the garbage generated from the city is being transported to Bhandewadi dumping yard where NMC owns around 77 acre land, of which 52 acre is being used for dumping garbage while 25 acre is for sewage treatment plant. The dumping areas are already full to its capacity.“Post coronavirus scare, all the 10 zones have witnessed drastic drop in garbage being generated by households. Nehru Nagar zone has witnessed sharp decline in garbage collection . Against 134.89MT of garbage per day, the residents of this south Nagpur locality are generating around 43.37MT waste a day now,” the data revealed. It was followed by Mangalwari zone. It too has witnessed decline in door-to-door garbage collection. Against daily collection of around 107.20MT, the private agency is lifting only 67.20MT waste per day, the officer explained.Even the zones with commercial areas have also witnessed drop in garbage collection. Gandhibagh zone, which has most commercial establishments, too generates lesser waste of almost 35.98MT a day now, down from 131.22MT per day earlier.The official attributed the lesser garbage generation to the lockdown. “With all business hubs closed, garbage generation from commercial markets like Itwari, Sadar, Gaddigodam, Jaripatka etc has been zero. We are now getting garbage from household residents only,” the official said.Environment expert and founder or Green Vigil Foundation Kaustav Chatterjee said: “Humans are the only waste generators. We are in ‘quarantine’, shops are closed, construction activities have stopped. Thus the garbage being generated is domestic waste only.”

Title: Telangana police to use AI to spot breach in commute cap
Content:
By assessing the movement of motorists through CCTV footage from various junctions in Hyderabad, Cyberabad and... Read More

HYDERABAD: With many motorists violating the 3-km commute cap set by authorities, the Telangana police on Wednesday decided to use Artificial Intelligence ( AI ) to crack down on those in the wrong from Thursday.

By assessing the movement of motorists through CCTV footage from various junctions in Hyderabad, Cyberabad and Rachakonda, police will calculate the distance travelled by each motorist using AI. “As of now, there are 250 junctions, where automatic number plate readers (ANPR) are set up. Using ANPR and AI, violators will be identified. The system will automatically record the distance travelled by motorists. ANPR will capture all vehicle details at every given junction,” sources in the office of the director general of police told TOI.

The state government for the benefit of the citizens during the lockdown period, permitted people to travel a maximum of three km to buy provisions during the day up to 7 pm. As of now, police are physically seizing vehicles whenever they come across motorists who are coming onto the roads without any valid purpose.

By assessing the movement of motorists through CCTV footage from various junctions, police will calculate the distance travelled by each motorist using AI

Title: Alappuzha: Farmers deliver produce to your doorsteps
Content:
Farmer Bhagyaraj distributes organic vegetables in Alappuzha on Wednesday.

ALAPPUZHA: To ensure supply of vegetables to families in Alappuzha and Kochi , the young organic vegetable farmers of Kanjikuzhy and Mararikulam are supplying vegetables at the doorsteps of families. People can order the organic vegetables through WhatsApp, mobile apps and websites.

Bhagyaraj B, a young organic vegetable farmer here, was shocked after the customers for his vegetables reduced drastically after the outbreak of Covid-19.

“Me and my friend Sujith have conducted organic vegetable cultivation on 30 acres and it is harvesting time. We have a shop on the side of National Highway 66 in Cherthala for selling organic vegetables. But after the outbreak of Covid-19, customers footfall has reduced and our vegetables have started to decay. Some days, we were in big trouble. So, we have started to think for a solution to this issue and thus, we came up with the idea of collecting orders through WhatsApp. We received good response after informing our customers about the idea and we delivered produce to 60 families in Cherthala on Wednesday,” he said. They have also a WhatsApp group named Veg2home Alappy for receiving the orders from customers.

Sujith Swaminikarthil, the young farmer, who received the state government’s award for best young farmer in Kerala, said that after the lockdown was declared by the state and union governments, the order for their vegetables by families has skyrocketed. “We are trying to deliver maximum vegetables to the doorsteps of the people. We also have a chicken, duck and quail farm and we also deliver the meat to our customers in tune with their demand,” he said.

The price for cucumber is Rs 35 per kg, ladies finger is Rs 60 per kg, bitter gourd Rs 70 per kg, snake gourd is Rs 50 per kg, banana Rs 40 per kg, pumpkin Rs 45 per kg, green chilly Rs 100 per kg. WhatsApp number of Sujith is 9495929729 and Bhagyaraj is 9995564936.

Nishad V R, an organic farmer in Mararikulam, is mainly distributing vegetables to the families in Kochi apart from Alappuzha. People can order the vegetables through the mobile app Mararifresh or the website www.mararifresh.com.

“On Wednesday, we received 300 orders from Kochi. Once the people order their products, they have to transfer the amount online. We will hand over the products to the securities of the flats or place the packets in front of the houses. We will not have directly meet or contact our customers in the present situation,” said Nishad V R.

Title: Sonam Kapoor gets trolled for remark on KCR
Content: HYDERABAD: Bollywood actress Sonam Kapoor was trolled on social media on Wednesday for questioning chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao ’s comment on the extreme measures the state may have to take if citizens violate the lockdown rules.“I’m confused. Is this normal?” she asked on Twitter, pointing to a report which quoted CM KCR as saying that he may impose a 24-hour curfew, and may call in the army and give shoot-at-sight orders if people do not restrict themselves to their homes.The chief minister made the statement at a press conference on preventing the spread of coronavirus in Telangana, on Tuesday.

Title: Trader booked for sanitizer negligence in Ahmedabad
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The city police on Tuesday booked a 23-year-old grocer under charges of spreading infectious disease, invoking the Indian Penal Code (IPC). The grocer had not made hand sanitizer available for his customers and thus increased the chances of coronavirus infection.

A team of Vejalpur police was patrolling the Juhapura area to ensure complete lockdown. The cops found a few grocery shops open in the area. Though grocery shops can remain open to supply essential commodities, shopkeepers must make their customers to maintain social distancing, said a cop who was part of the Vejalpur police team.

“When the cops reached Amiraj Traders near Famous Bakery at Juhapura crossroads, they found that owner had not made hand sanitizer available for his customers,” said inspector L D Odedara of Vejalpur police. He said that the trader, Renish Kothia, a resident of Juhapura, did not give a satisfactory explanation.

The city police and civic body authorities have regularly instructed traders and shopkeepers to take utmost care. “We have booked Kothia under section 269 of the IPC which deals with those who commit a negligent act that is likely to spread an infectious disease dangerous to life,” said Odedara. According to the section, a person charged can be jailed for six months.

Title: Hyderabad Cricket Association offers stadium for isolation
Content: HYDERABAD: With the Telangana government stepping up efforts to contain the spread of Covid-19, the Hyderabad Cricket Association (HCA) on Wednesday offered the Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium in Uppal to the government to set up an isolation centre. The stadium has 40 rooms and parking space which HCA believes is an ideal venue for an isolation centre.In a letter to chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao , HCA secretary R Vijayanand said: “In tune with your commitment and passion in implementing the measures, I, on behalf of HCA president Mohammed Azharuddin , and members of the apex council, would like to offer the facility of the Rajiv Gandhi stadium to set up the isolation centre.”“This, we feel, is a moral obligation on our part. There are 40 big rooms which can take care of some of the virus-affected patient,” he said.

Title: Thrissur: Rs 100 crore for waste management
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

THRISSUR: The Thrissur Corporation has allotted Rs 100 crore for waste management in the budget for 2020-21.

Apart from giving importance to waste management, the budget presented by deputy mayor Raphi Jose on Monday gave emphasis on drinking water facilities.

“When the new council came into the power in the corporation, there was no policy or project to the manage waste. The waste was dumped in Laloor for the last several years and there was no project on waste management. Various waste management projects will be implemented in this year,” the deputy mayor said.

Water connection for all homes, new bus stands, underpasses in Kuriachira and Naikkanal, Macadam-type roads in each division, shopping complex in Chempukkavu, second gas chamber in Kuriachira crematorium, formation of 100 elder clubs, new dialysis unit in Thrissur General Hospital , solar plants in 80,000 homes, financial assistance to SSLC and Plus Two students for buying laptops, Karate, Yoga, dance and classical music training for women, meat-processing units in Kuriachira and Mattampuram, 10 new hunger-free hotels, 25 new toilets and 300 youth clubs are some of the projects in the budget in this year, mayor Ajitha Jayarajan said.

The budget also allotted Rs 5 crore for the renovation of Shaktan bus stand and Rs 3 crore for the construction of a new bus stand. A total of Rs 3 crore was allotted to a new skywalk in the city and Rs 50 lakh to a foot and overbridge at the Vadakke bus stand. Besides, Rs 100 crore was allotted to the road and junction development in corporation limits. To reduce the crowd, a subway will be constructed in Naikkanal junction and the budget allotted Rs 5 crore for it. The budget also allotted Rs 10 crore for the developmental activities on M G Road.

Title: Kolhapur Administration orders doctors to open their clinics
Content: KOLHAPUR: The district administration has ordered private doctors to keep their clinics open, which were shut over coronavirus fear.The doctors claimed that they had shut the clinics to ensure the infection does not spread among other patients.However, after getting complaints from citizens, the district authorities spoke to the general practitioners’ body and asked them to refer the persons with coronavirus infection symptoms to the screening centres identified by the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC).“The fear of transmission has led to closure of many private clinics. They need to remain open to take care of other patients. Some measures can be adopted to ensure social distancing so that the suspect may not spread of infection. The doctors can take care of themselves by using protective gear,” said a senior official of the district administration.The officials said that people with small health issues were approaching the KMC-run hospitals and public hospitals, where the staff is engaged in screening and quarantine.The general practitioners body agreed to re-open their clinics after the health authorities ensured them that the KMC has carried out door-to-door survey to find the suspects. The KMC authorities have appealed to the citizens to approach KMC hospitals in case of coronavirus symptoms and do not approach private hospitals.Meanwhile, after the district administration's request, the Kolhapur branch of Indian Medical Association (IMA) has assigned several doctors to the handle the OPD's of the KMC run hospitals and Chhatrapati Pramila Raje Hospital along with the 11 screening centres set up for screening coronavirus suspect.Asha Jadhav, secretary of Kolhapur branch of IMA, said, “We are also ready to provide private health infrastructure to the government to tackle the spread of COVID-19 . We are providing the list of the additional beds and ventilator facilities in the private hospitals, which can be exclusively reserved for institutional quarantining of the suspects.”The district administration has set the target of making around 1,000 beds with ventilators ready to tackle the emergency situation.

Title: Kolhapur Administartion assures home delivery of essentials, citizens stay home
Content: KOLHAPUR: After the panic-buy on the eve of the first day of the nationwide lockdown, the citizens responded positively to the administration’s appeal to staying home.Apart from the ones who went out to buy the essentials, most of the citizens stayed at home.The administration is working out means to provide essentials to the citizens. The officials said that there is adequate stock of the food grains in government storehouses. However, the supply of other essentials was reported lacking in some parts.On the occasion of Gudi Padwa , many retailers had shut their shops which led to inconvenience for the citizens. Some of the agencies supplying cooking gas cylinders were also shut. The home delivery of the cylinders was stopped.Responding to a complaint, district guardian minister Satej Patil said that he will order the agencies to deliver cylinder at doorsteps. The citizens had complained that they were obstructed by the police while on their way to get the cylinder.“Some glitches are bound to happen in supplying the essentials to the citizens. We are assuring people that most of the supplies will be provided to their doorsteps," said the minister.The civic administration has assured supply of essentials especially the vegetable carts in the housing societies. The police are prohibiting the carts on roadside as it may lead to gathering by people.To ensure social distancing, the civic administration has started demarcating spaces at major places such as vegetable markets, medical and retail shops. The public announcement is made to ensure people follow the rules.The civic administration has launched two WhatsApp numbers for the citizens to report their inconvenience or demand for civic service. Patil said that the complaints made to these numbers will directly reach the civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti who will then ask respective officers to resolve them at earliest.The numbers are 9766532010 and 9766532016.

Title: Amul, Mother Dairy promise uninterrupted supply
Content:
NEW DELHI: Supply of milk and value-added dairy products, including paneer and lassi will not be hit as a result of the lockdown across India, assured dairy giants Amul and Mother Dairy .

Both organisations have reported an increase in milk procurement at their centres across the country.

“Our collection of milk has increased by 10-15% over the last few days,” said RS Sodhi, managing director at GCMMF (Amul), India’s largest dairy and food company. “We witnessed a surge in demand due to panic buying, but we expect it to settle down in the coming days. The situation is under control.”

Dairy companies are in talks with government bodies, Sodhi said, to allow packaging plants of essential food commodities such as milk resume operations.

Mother Dairy, too, said it has made adequate arrangements to ensure supplies. “Mother Dairy is selling an average volume of over 35 lakh litre of milk per day and we are already procuring in excess of the current demand,” said a Mother Dairy spokesperson.

Title: To be back with kin, tweeple seek KTR help
Content: HYDERABAD: The nation-wide lockdown to prevent the spread of coronavirus has thrown life out of gear by separating several families, with some stuck in different cities or towns and unable to travel. A large number of such instances are being shared on social media with the hope that the authorities will be able to understand their problems and solve them.Some have been able to reach out to IT minister KT Rama Rao, who responded favourably on multiple instances. Fifteen-year-old Tanvi Jasmine and her grandparents had gone to visit relatives in Bengaluru on March 19 but are stuck there. “Please find a way so that we can get back home to Hyderabad,” she said. KTR responded, “These are difficult times Tanvi. We will try and get you home ASAP but please bear with us. Glad you have your grandparents with you.” The minister directed his office to get in touch with her. Balaji Nani said his physically challenged sister was stuck at a hostel at Ramanthapur, which was going to be closed down. “There is no food and bed and now they are asking her to leave the hostel. Please help,” he said. The minister assured help. There was a request from Aditya Aadi who said 20 students were stuck in a hostel, which was about to close, at Madhura Nagar in the city. “They are asking us to leave. There is no transport and permission available to go back,” he said. The minister requested deputy mayor Baba Faisuddin to look into the issue.A man, Gopi, said his uncle passed away on Tuesday and the body was kept at the mortuary at Gandhi hospital, but his family lived in Thodupuzha near Kochi in Kerala . “Would you please assist in allowing the ambulance carrying the body to travel to Kerala?” he asked. KTR directed his office to assist Gopi. A woman, Nidhi Mishra, resident of Arvindnagar colony in the city said she was nine months pregnant and the expected delivery was on April 28. She added doctors had suggested weekly check-ups. “Now cab facilities are not available and we do not have a four-wheeler to visit a hospital. Please help,” she said. Raju Reddy of Makthal, Mahbubnagar sought help to travel to Hyderabad as he had fractured his leg and had a doctor’s appointment on March 28.

Title: Five new suspects kept in isolation
Content:
Vadodara: Five new suspected cases of COVID-19 were admitted in government hospitals in Vadodara on Wednesday.

A 55-year-old male with travel history to the UK was under isolation at the GMERS Gotri Medical Hospital so was another resident of Mota Fofaliya village.

After sample of a 32-year-old male from Nizampura area was declared positive late on Tuesday night, the number of COVID-19 positive cases had touched seven.

Out of seven, six belong to the same group of family and friends who have either travel history of Sri Lanka or had come in their close contact. Report of another patient who has travel history of Sri Lanka is being awaited as also reports of samples of three others.

A total of 11 patients are currently under isolation at SSG Hospital of which seven are COVID-19 positive.

Sources said that while one of the seven is on ventilator, two other positive cases are on bilevel positive airway pressure, one on nasal oxygen while others are on oxygen.

Vadodara’s chief district health officer Dr Uday Tilawat told TOI that of the 51 samples tested so far, 39 are negative, eight are positive while report of one is awaited.

Title: Mumbai police chalk out novel ideas for safe distance between shoppers
Content: MUMBAI: City police came up with innovative ideas on Wednesday to prevent overcrowding of public spaces by Mumbaikars rushing out to stock up on essential items such as groceries, vegetables and medicines. Two of the ideas were successfully implemented. One, marking of square or round outlines with chalk outside shops and in vegetable markets for shoppers to stand in at a distance from each other and avoid getting infected while moving in queues. Two, in the western suburbs, police have pasted notices outside grocery stores asking customers to jot down lists of essential items with their names, addresses and phone numbers and hand them over to the shopkeepers without crowding shops.Additional commissioner of police (west region) Manoj Sharma said the ideas were the brainchild of Zone-X deputy commissioner of police Ankit Goyal to enforce social distancing after Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced a 21-day lockdown on Tuesday.“The ideas have helped us gain the confidence of people who have now overcome their fear of a shortage of essential commodities. They have also understood the importance of social distancing and maintaining peace. They can buy what they need without risking their lives,” said Goyal.Some of the shops in Jogeshwari (East), MIDC, Andheri and Powai had notices pasted outside that read: “Please leave your list of items in the basket with name, address and contact no. You may collect your items from the store after 2 hours. No crowding the store please. Help us to serve you better.”Premjibhai, owner of Spain Enterprises (Daily Needs) on Military Road in Andheri (East), told TOI: “Customers left their lists in a basket. After packing the orders, we called them and asked them to collect the items. This helped in not just social distancing but also in running our business without any hurdles, all thanks to the police.”Marol’s Pramod Chavan told TOI: “Customers are made to stand inside circle or square markings in queues. Wherever there is a space constraint, people have been asked to place their orders and are called once the order is ready.”Juhu’s Rahul Singh said several grocery stores have begun to give out token numbers and asking people to turn up at a specific time to collect their orders. “Hats off to the police who in coordination with shop owners have worked out plans to curb crowding,” he said.People waited patiently inside shapes drawn outside shops in Vile Parle, Kherwadi, Bandra-Kurla Complex and elsewhere too. Antop Hill police senior inspector Prashant Raje and staff said this idea should be replicated everywhere.

Title: Sunni organisations suspend Friday prayers in mosques
Content: MALAPPURAM: Considering the Covid-19 lockdown Sunni organizations in the state have decided to suspend Friday prayers in mosques across the state.The announcement was made in a statement issued on Wednesday by EK and AP factions of Samastha Kerala Jamiyyathul Ulama. The different factions of Mujahid organizations had earlier announced suspension of prayers in mosques.In the joint statement issued by Sayed Muhammed Jifri Muthukkoya Thangal and Panakakd Sayed Hyderali Shihab Thangal, president and vice-president of Samastha Kerala Jam-Iyyathul Ulama respectively, they said that it was the responsibility of the Muslim community to cooperate with the efforts of government to prevent the spread of infection. The leaders have appealed the believers to perform Zuhur (mid-day prayers) at their homes.A statement issued by Kanthapuram A P Aboobakcer Musaliyar and E Sulaiman Musaliyar, general secretary and president of AP faction of Samastha Kerala Jamiyyathul Ulama, says that the organisation have decided to suspend Jummah prayers on Friday until further notice, to avoid congregation of believers in mosques.The statement also says that the Friday prayers in mosques with limited number of people also should be avoided, considering the situation. The statement urges people to follow the directions from the government to stay home and involve in prayers to save humanity from the coronavirus.

Title: Hyderabad: Patients complain of poor hygiene at fever hospital, say takes two days to meet doctor
Content: HYDERABAD: Patients quarantined in the isolation ward at state-run Sir Ronald Ross Institute of Tropical and Communicable Diseases ( Fever Hospital ) in Nallakunta , on Wednesday, complained about poor hygiene standards at the facility. One of them also rued how no doctor had visited patients even after close to 48 hours of being quarantined.“They did not even provide drinking water after my wife and I were admitted in the isolation ward of the hospital. They locked us from outside and no one responded even though I was shouting my lungs out. I had to ultimately break open the lock in the evening to ask the ward boys to give us some water. The bathrooms in the hospital are also in a pathetic condition,” said one of them, adding, “There was absolutely no communication from the doctors for two days after they took our swab and blood samples for test. Before the doctors, we got to know from the media and friends that my wife tested positive.”The 38-year-old man and his 39-year-old wife were admitted in Fever Hospital on March 23.The wife, who tested positive for Covid-19 has a travel history to Germany. A twitter post by the patient went viral on Wednesday. When TOI contacted her, the patient said she developed high fever on March 22 and called the government helpline number.The hospital later let go of her husband without any means to return home in a lockdown period, before a friend picked him up. “I drove from Begumpet and negotiated dozens of blockades and got him in my car and got him home,” said Indranil Chowdhuri, a friend. “I had earlier gone to Ronald Ross and handed the patient a medicine,” he said.When contacted, superintendent of Fever Hospital Dr K Shankar said, “We are providing mineral water and all other necessities to all those who are admitted in Fever Hospital.” He said all positive cases are being transferred to Gandhi hospital, King Koti Hospital or Chest Hospital.

Title: Man booked for escaping quarantine
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: A 35-year-old man, who had returned from Dubai three days ago, was booked for allegedly escaping quarrantine on Tuesday. Meanwhile, four cases were registered across the city for allegedly violating curfew orders.

MP Nagar police said that a scooter-borne 35-year-old man, a resident of Kotwali area, was stopped at checking point at Board Office Square on Tuesday morning. During questioning, he told cops that he returned from Dubai three days ago. The screening team at airport told him to remain in quarantine for 14 days and posters of Covid-19 suspect were pasted outside his house. He said that he was feeling suffocated and so moved out. Police rushed him to a hospital and registered a case for violating quarrantine order.

Nishantpura police registered cases were against five for opening shops and roaming out on Tuesday. Parwalia police also registered a case against a crusher unit owner for operating the plant.

Title: No flights at Kolhapur airport from March 25
Content: KOLHAPUR: All flights flying from Kolhapur airport has been suspended from Wednesday, March 25, said Kolhapur airport director Kamalkumar Kataria.As per the instructions from the Ministry of Civil Aviation , the domestic flights stand cancelled until March 31.“The Central Government considers the movement of persons within the country by flights carrying a large number of persons together will aid and assist the spread of the above virus within India and for prevention of the further spread of the epidemic disease, such movement of people shall be restricted,” said the circular from the ministry,The circular further said that all the airports continue to function for handling permitted flight operations. “The operation of all scheduled flights by any aircraft operator holding an air operator certificate issued by Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) India shall cease from 2359 hrs on March 24.”Kataria said that on March 24, out of 10 scheduled flights, six were operated and four were either diverted or cancelled.The airport director said that till March 24, around 9,473 travellers used the domestic flight facility from the Kolhapur Airport. “We have taken all the safety measures at the airport in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak,” he added.

Title: Despite KCR rap and lockdown appeal, most public representatives MIA
Content:
Minister KT Rama Rao interacts with people of the city on Wednesday.

HYDERABAD: Despite chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao’s call to elected representatives to spread awareness among people and assess the situation, only few have ventured out in their respective areas. Ministers KT Rama Rao , V Srinivas Goud , T Harish Rao, Vemula Prashanth Reddy, deputy speaker T Padma Rao and MLA Maganti Gopanath were among the few to have reviewed the situation in their constituencies.

KTR toured the city and held a review meeting with disaster management officials over response teams and GHMC’s control room. He later inspected night shelters and interacted with inmates about facilities being provided at shelters. While on his way to GHMC office, KTR came across a few labourers walking on the road and asked officials to arrange transport for them to reach their homes.

Meanwhile, tourism and excise minister V Srinivas Goud donned the role of traffic police and regulated the movement of vehicles in Mahabubnagar town for almost three hours. He urged locals not to venture out and abide by the lockdown orders. The minister also asked vendors to ensure that customers maintain social distance. The minister claimed that as many as 300 people from outside were in the area for various reasons. He held a review meet with local officials and instructed them to open three new markets to avoid crowding.

Finance minister T Harish Rao reviewed preventive measures taken by Sangareddy collectorate and health officials. With Sangareddy sharing borders with both Maharashtra and Karnataka, Harish asked officials to maintain strict vigil on borders. He also visited district government hospital and inspected their isolation facilities.

Roads and buildings minister Vemula Prashanth Reddy held review meeting with officials in Kamareddy and Nizamabad. He interacted with some people under home quarantine and asked them to remain at home during the lockdown. As many as 1,075 people have come to Kamareddy district from other places in the past one month.

Jubilee Hills MLA Maganti Gopinath visited Erragadda Rythu Bazar and enquired about rates of vegetable. He urged locals to maintain social distance and warned that action would be taken against vendors if they sell vegetables and fruits at higher prices.

Labour minister Ch Malla Reddy also interacted with local leaders at Ghatkesar and asked the leaders to bring awareness among the people. Minister Mahmood Ali visited some police stations in the city. In Karimnagar , minister Gangula Kamalakar toured in the city for strict enforcement of lockdown and also reviewed with officials.

Similarly Serlingampally MLA Arikepudi Gandhi visited areas in Chandanagar, Kondapur and supervised spraying of sodium hypochlorite. Deputy speaker and Secunderabad MLA T Padma Rao along with mayor Bonthu Rammohan visited various sites including night shelters in Sitaphalmandi. Among GHMC representatives, deputy mayor Baba Fasiuddin interacted with locals in Borabanda and also visited Masjid-e-Mohammedia near Swarajnagar. He urged people to perform Namaz and Haza at home.

Title: Delhi high court judges hear cases from home via video
Content:
NEW DELHI: It was an extraordinary situation in Delhi high court on Wednesday, when judges had to conduct hearing via video conferencing from home , as some of the essential court staff couldn’t reach court due to the lockdown.

A bench of justices Siddharth Mridul and Talwant Singh innovated, since an urgent plea highlighted the plight of around 300 Indian students stranded at Almaty Airport in Kazakhstan for the past two-three days without food or medical aid due to the novel coronavirus pandemic.

In absence of availability of the three court rooms prepared by HC administration for virtual hearings on Monday, the judges and lawyers made use of video-multi conferencing option of WhatsApp to conduct hearings from respective homes/offices to ensure necessary orders are issued and passed on to the government to act.

The bench during the hearing asked the ministry of external affairs (MEA) and concerned authorities to immediately arrange for basic amenities and assistance for the stranded students .

Advocate Fozia Rahman, who appeared for the petitioner Sehla Saira, informed the court that 300 Indian students, who are enrolled for higher studies at Semey Medical University in Kazakhstan are stranded without food, water, transportation and medical aid. Saira is mother of one of the students. The court issued notice to the Centre through MEA and granted time to file response by March 28.

Title: Which movie to watch? Ask police
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: While their compatriots deployed on the streets are busy chasing motorists and dispersing crowds to enforce the lockdown, the cops handling the social media page of the state police spend the day preparing a playlist of must-watch movies for the people staying indoors. The playlist was for the followers of their Facebook page Kerala Police , to keep them entertained at home.

According to officials of the social media cell of the state police that handle the page, it was one of the many tasks they discharged on Wednesday to encourage their followers stay at home.

On Tuesday, the Kerala Police page, threw open their inbox encouraging the followers to have personal chats so that they don’t feel bored at home. The move received an enormously positive response.

“There were youngsters seeking ways to kill boredom and we sent them website links where e-books could be downloaded for free. There were many who wanted us to suggest good movies to watch at this time, which we did”, said one of the three officers who were handling the messenger inbox on Tuesday. He said that the social media cell’s intention behind the move was to achieve through a friendly approach the same goal that their colleagues on the field were trying to achieve through stern measures. Having a huge following of 1.4 million, if they succeeded in keeping at least half of them at homes, it would make a huge difference on the streets.

It was at 8.28 am the announcement in this regard was uploaded on the page. In the first minute itself, they received 40 messages. In the next minute, it rose to 60 and kept going up till the evening, the officials said. Soon, the traffic became more than what the officials on duty could handle.

“However, we tried to reply to maximum queries possible, regardless how silly many of them were”, the officer said. Serious queries were received too. Most of them were from Keralites trapped in other states and were unable to return home owing to restrictions as part of the nationwide lockdown. There were several messages that touched the cops. They were from expatriates who did not have any means to reach their families.

With the huge response by followers, the officials have sought more manpower to handle the personal messages.

Title: No earning for 3 weeks, porters have heavy burden
Content: BHOPAL: Dressed in red, porters are a familiar sight at railway stations. Their helping hand makes travel hassle-free. But, with trains halted amid the corona lockdown , their source of income has vanished and the porters are struggling for their survival.On a normal day, porters earn Rs 500-600 a day. They survive on daily incomes and have no savings to fall back on. With the trains cancelled till April 14, the porters at Habibganj and Bhopal railway station are worried, how they will go so long without any income. Many had to borrow money from their friends and relatives to purchase little ration for the lockdown. As per railways, 122 porters are working at Bhopal railway station and 36 at Habibganj station. The number of porters at all stations of Bhopal railway division is around 820.Porter Shriram Sisodia, who works at Habibganj station, said: “For many years, we have been helping railway passengers carry their luggage from one platform to another. After spending 12 hours on the platform, we were able to earn Rs 500-600 a day to support our family. But the lockdown due to coronavirus has put our life in trouble. We welcome this decision taken by the railways in the interest of the passengers, but the railways should think about how we will feed our families in such times.”Mukdadham Rakesh Shakya, another porter of Habibganj station, said that just as the government is coming forward to offer financial help to labourers, it should also consider the plight of porters and help them out with financial aid and free ration.

Title: Hyderabad: Milk tankers, LPG supply vehicles don’t need passes
Content: HYDERABAD: City police commissioner Anjani Kumar and Telangana IT and Industries secretary Jayesh Ranjan on Wednesday held a meeting with representatives of various companies and formed a COVID-19 cell at the commissionerate to ensure smooth supply of essential commodities .More than 200 representatives of essential commodities/service providers attended the meeting at the commissioner’s office in Basheerbagh .People from dairy, medical, food, cable TV, internet service, LPG supply, CPDCL sectors and suppliers of essential commodities through e-commerce sites such as Amazon, Big Basket and also media organisations attended the meeting. “We have established a special COVID-19 cell which will work round the clock to facilitate supply of essential commodities to public,” Hyderabad commissioner Anjani Kumar said. Certain services such as milk tankers , CPDCL vehicles and LPG supply vehicles do not require passes as police can recognise them from a distance and ensure trouble free passage, the commissioner said.Traffic police are working with vegetable market association, cooking oil suppliers, grocery store merchants of Begum Bazar , Siddiamber Bazar, fish merchants association representatives for movement of vehicles early in the morning by issuing passes. traffic police are working in coordination with market associations.Employees of hospital if they show ID card issued by the hospital they will be permitted to commute. Cable TV and Internet service company technicians will get individual passes for specific locality. “Media employees can also show ID cards to be allowed to pass, if they paste ‘Press’ sticker on their vehicle’s windscreen with the name of the organisation they work for, they can get past checkposts. No pass is required. Newspaper delivery boys will not be stopped,” the CP said.Vehicles supplying fodder will be allowed passes. Vehicles carrying medicines are permitted to move by sticking ‘Medicine Inside’ tag on the windscreen. “E-commerce firms such as Amazon and Big Basket will get vehicle passes as per their requirement only for supply of essential commodities,” the CP said. Cyberabad CP VC Sajjanar also held a similar meeting on Wednesday with representatives of essential service providers.

Title: Temple festival held in Trichy defying lockdown norms
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: Defying the nation-wide lockdown imposed to control the spread Covid-19, a temple festival was permitted to be conducted in Trichy city on Wednesday. At least 350 people participated in the festival held at Periya Kammala Street near Gandhi Market here.

While the city police were enforcing section 144 of CrPc restricting the movement of even the individuals venturing out to purchase essential commodities, locals of Periya Kammala Street gathered to host the temple festival of Kaliga Parameshwari temple. The temple car was positioned on the street, which was thronged by scores of people including those wearing masks. Meanwhile, the other parts of the city appeared deserted as a part of the lockdown.

The lockdown guidelines were flouted as people were seen standing next to each other at a very close distance, locals said and added that police did not restrict the huge footfall of devotees. “Hundreds of people, despite the nation-wide lockdown, are not understanding the seriousness of Covid-19 and were standing through the streets,” a resident of Gandhi Market told TOI under the condition of anonymity. However, the city police were in a denial mode. “No such incident happened in our jurisdiction,” a police officer in Fort Range said.

Title: Corporation of the City of Panaji leads way, drops food items to nearly 500 homes
Content: PANAJI: The Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP) the first local body to respond, even before the state government distributed essential food items to hundreds of houses on Wednesday.Mayor Uday Madkaikar told reporters that the corporation’s grocery service delivered food grains to as many as 480 houses within the jurisdiction of Panaji.The corporation put out a new list of grocery items, including bread, noodles and biscuits that will be supplied once the helpline is opened again on Thursday between 9 am and 6 pm. This is apart from salt, rice, oil, sugar, tea, dals, atta, onions, coconut, tomatoes and chillies already on the list.The service was strictly announced for those in dire need with preference to senior citizens and the home bound. However, many complained that they couldn’t get through the helpline and were put perpetually on hold, while others who got through were told that they had limited stock that could be provided only to senior citizens.Others appreciated the corporation’s efforts, but said they shouldn’t force people to tender exact change in these times and should accept plastic money as well, while others said they were being charged few rupees more than the rate put out.

Title: Waive penalty, charges on air tickets: IAAI
Content: KOCHI: With more air passengers cancelling tickets and losing money as penalty or due to non-refundable tickets in the wake of Covid-19 outbreak, IATA Agents association of India IAAI ), on behalf of the travel agents and the traveling public, approached the Director General of Civil Aviation DGCA ) requesting waiver of penalties and charges on air tickets.IAAI as requested DGCA to intervene and issue necessary directives to all airlines operating in India (to/from/within) to treat the current situation as a “natural calamity” under “force majeure” and waive all the corresponding penalties/ fees or other charges levied for ticket cancellations, refund, and reissue or rescheduling process, even for those tickers issued under ‘non-refundable’ clause.

Title: ‘Goa Suraksha Manch workers are ready to volunteer’
Content: PANAJI: Goa Suraksha Manch (GSM) president Subhash Velingkar on Wednesday put the onus on the state government to ensure that essential commodities reach every citizen in need during the lockdown. He also extended the services of his party workers for any voluntary service required. “The state should conduct a survey to make sure that essential commodities reach all citizens across Goa,” Velingkar said.He further said, “Some antisocial elements are trying to obstruct implementation of the lockdown. The government should take strict measures against them.” In view of social distancing advised to control the spread of Covid-19 , GSM’s core committee held its meeting on Tuesday via video conferencing. tnn

Title: Mumbai teachers want last remaining SSC exam cancelled
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

MUMBAI: As the lockdown over Covid-19 has been extended by a few weeks, city teachers want the state government to cancel the last remaining SSC paper instead of postponing it.

The state education department had announced the last SSC paper of Geography, scheduled for March 23, will be postponed and a fresh date announced after March 31. As the lockdown has been extended by 21 days, the exam is unlikely before April 15.

Teachers said the government must set up a committee to look for an alternative. “If the exam is held in April-end, results will be delayed and the very important first-year junior college admissions will be delayed.”

“For one year, the board could score students only on five subjects. Since they have appeared for History exam, the board can allow them to pass the group based on an average score,” said Sudam Kumbhar, principal, Shailendra Education Society, Dahisar. B

Board officials said they have not received an official request from teachers yet.

Title: Five arrested for attacking social activist in Karur
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: Karur police have arrested five people including a retired sub-inspector of police for attacking social activist Thirukumaran , 40 with weapons on Wednesday.

The arrested have been identified as Vidyaraniyan (retired sub-inspector of police), Raj Kumar , Radhakrishnan, Balasubramani and Karthikeyan. They have been booked under sections 294(b) verbal abuse, 323 for voluntarily causing hurt and 324 causing hurt by dangerous weapons.

Thirukumaran had lodged a complaint with the Vangal police station against the accused for attempting to illegally mine sand from Cauvery river near Manmangalam.

The arrested persons came to know about Thirukumaran’s complaint and attacked him with a machete on Tuesday morning. He sustained injuries on the neck and head and was admitted to the Karur government hospital for treatment.

Based on his complaint, police arrested all the four accused and lodged them in Trichy central prison.

Title: Govt sets up six teams for Covid-19 contingencies
Content:
Bhopal: Six teams comprising 19 IAS officers and 20 officers of other services have been tasked with ensuring supply of essential goods and meeting with any contingencies during the 21-day nationwide lockdown across the country.

The teams will coordinate with hospitals and create awareness on several platforms. To ensure proper coordination among all groups, principal secretary of health department Pallavi Jain Govil has been appointed as the chief coordinator. The groups will look after medicine supplies; equipment and logistics; medical treatment and hospital management; mobility services; ambulance services and 104 call centre; essential services and state-level coordination; information, contact and communication group, and human resource management.

Principal secretary Faiz Ahmed Kidwai; S Dhanaraju, director health; Vijay Kumar J and joint controller, D K Nagendra have been tasked with medicine and logistics.

Principal secretary Sanjay Shukla; commissioner health, Prateek Hajela; commissioner medical education, Nishant Warwade; additional mission director, Sonali Sadana; IAS Chhavi Bhardwaj, BDA CEO, Anju Pawan Bhadoria; director medical education Alka Shrivastava; additional director health, Veena Sinha and technical advisor Dr Lokendra Dave will monoitor medical treatment and hospital management.

Mobility services, ambulance and 104 call centre will be managed by secretary State government B Chandrashekhar; MD MPSIDC, Nandkumaram; managing director Swati Meena Naik and director, CM Helpline, Bhupendra Singh Paraste.

Essential services and state-level coordination will be managed by additional chief secretary, ICP Keshari; principal secretary industries, Rajesh Rajora; principal secretary, MSME, Manu Shrivastava; principal secretary, urban administration and housing, Sanjay Dubey; principal secretary, Shiv Shekhar Shukla; principal secretary, Pallavi Jain Govil; deputy secretary, Sudhir Kumar Kochar and tehsildar Akash Shrivastava.

Commissioner public relations, P Narhari; and Sapna M Lovanshi, additional director health will look after information, contact and communication.

Ruhi Khan, OSD, RCVP Noronha Academy of Administration; additional director, Lata Sharnagat, Dr Archana Mishra and B D Khare will oversee human resource management.

Title: Daily wage workers worst affected due to lockdown
Content: DEHRADUN/NAINITAL/PITHORAGARH/ROORKEE: The nationwide shut down for three weeks is already hurting daily wage workers who are now out of work and have no means to earn two square meals.In Dehradun , the local administration has started the process of providing daily wage workers, who have Jan Dhan accounts, with an aid of Rs 1,000. For the purpose, a list of daily wagers has also been sought from the department of labour.“So far, we have transferred Rs 1,000 in accounts of 13,600 daily wage workers. To ensure aid to more such people, we have directed the banks to work for two additional hours,” Dehradun DM Ashish Kumar Srivastava told TOI.The move comes a day after Prime Minister Narendra Modi, in his address to nation, announced that daily wagers who are Jan Dhan account holders can be assisted with Rs 1,000 so that they don’t suffer much during lockdown DM Srivastava added that those workers who are not registered with the department of labour are being provided with food packets.In Nainital district, hundreds of daily wage workers coming from neighbouring Uttar Pradesh as well as states like Bihar and Jharkhand have become stranded due to the lockdown. “I want to go to my village in Darbhanga (Bihar) but all trains have been cancelled. I don’t have the means to survive for the next three weeks,” said Ram Charan Singh, a daily wage labourer.The district administration has said that though no arrangement has yet been made to send these labourers back home, efforts are being made to provide them with essentials. "Due to the countrywide lockdown, it is not possible to ensure return of these labourers. However, efforts are being made to provide all the essentials to the people who need it. The poor and needy will be our focus and the administration is working towards helping them," said Nainital’s district magistrate (DM) Savin Bansal.Similarly in Champawat , SP Lokeswar Singh has directed in charges of all police stations in the district to help people in need. Police have also released helpline numbers (059652- 30444, 30607 and 18001804178) for people to ask for help.And in Pithoragarh, social organisations and police are coming forward to help those in need during lockdown. Sushil Khatri, chairman of a social organisation “Seemant Youth Morcha”, told TOI, “We find out about the people in need through a WhatsApp (8979221108) group. Before delivering us ration, we make sure that the person (or family) is actually needy. Subsequently, we provide the needy with essentials like flour, rice, edible oil, potato, onion, among others.” He added that his organisation provided three Nepalese families with supplies on Wednesday.Meanwhile in Roorkee, the situation is grim for many labourers and rickshaw pullers who are left with no means to earn money due to the lockdown and have not been offered help as yet. “More than 300 rickshaw pullers in Roorkee are forced to go hungry due to the lockdown. We can provide their names to the administration. They all must be given help,” said Mumtaz Naqvi, president of Roorkee Rickshaw Pullers Union.

Title: Health team initiates steps to guard vulnerable sections
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: With five positive Covid-19 cases and over 5,900 persons under isolation in the district, the district administration and health team have now embarked on a mission to guard the old people and persons with underlying medical conditions against possible exposure to coronavirus Data on these two groups, which are considered most vulnerable to be infected with Covid-19, are being collected through various sources as a precautionary step and to remain prepared if community spread happens in the worst-case scenario.The health officials said that in case of an infection, persons with co-morbid conditions would be included under high-risk category. Comorbidity is the presence of one or more additional conditions co-occurring with a primary condition. Information is mainly collected regarding aged people, palliative patients and those with various other diseases.Database of health department, local bodies and social welfare pension are being mapped for this purpose. In addition to this, ground-level surveillance teams, which are deployed to monitor persons under home quarantine, are collecting data from households regarding elderly persons in the family or those with various ailments.“We are taking steps to prevent a possible infection to those with co-morbid conditions from persons with travel history to Covid-19-affected countries. Primary and secondary contacts are being included under this data collection process to find out if anyone in their family comes under the vulnerable group,” said an official.Early collection of data will enable both the district administration and health wing to be prepared to deal with further spread of the disease. If necessary, reverse quarantine is being considered for such persons, especially aged persons and those who are under palliative care. Home quarantine will be extended to these sections as well, if found necessary. As of now, health officials estimate that precautionary action may be taken for 92 persons in the district.Every local body in the district maintains database of beneficiaries receiving old-age pension. Data regarding persons with underlying medical conditions are obtained through health department.The risk communication guidance prepared by the World Health Organization (WHO) in a situation report cites that two groups of people are at a higher risk of getting severe Covid-19 disease. These are older people (that is people over 60 years old); and those with underlying medical conditions (such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, chronic respiratory disease, and cancer). The risk of severe disease gradually increases with age starting from around 40 years.WHO has issued advice for these two groups and for community support to ensure that they are protected from Covid-19 without being isolated, stigmatized, left in a position of increased vulnerability or unable to access basic provisions and social care. This advice covers factors including receiving visitors, planning for supplies of medication and food, going out safely in public and staying connected with others through phone calls or other means. It is essential that these groups are supported by their communities during Covid-19 outbreak, WHO notes in the situation report.

Title: Police turn saviours for homeless amid lockdown
Content:
Distribute food and water to the footpath and slum-dwellers

Vadodara: The cops have begun cracking down on citizens venturing out of their homes during the lockdown and earning wrath of some people. But amid the crisis, police is also extending help to the homeless who have nowhere to go. They have begun distributing food and water to the footpath and slum-dwellers across the city.

After the state government announced lockdown two days ago, the police department began reaching out to the poor. “Those having homes and jobs can survive under the lockdown but these homeless people have nowhere to go. Many of them don’t even earn and with shops closed down and people off the roads, they won’t get any food,” said a police official.

Footpath dwellers in Sayajigunj, Soma Talav area, Karelibaug, Makarpura and other areas were given food and water by the police as well as traffic cops. While the daily wage workers and handicapped persons were given food packets.

The cops, though, didn’t just stop helping fellow humans. Several teams of policemen fed stray dogs with biscuits and offered grass to cows in different areas. Even pigeons were fed with grains near Bird Circle by some cops.

“We are ensuring that even homeless people stay safe and don’t suffer due to the lockdown. Some organizations have come forward to help us in this drive,” the police said. On Wednesday, some good Samaritans were seen offering food and other help to the needy amid the lockdown. The cops are allowing them to move around on humanitarian grounds.

Casual labourers, who were stuck in the city for the want of transport, were helped by the cops to reach their villages in Panchmahals and Dahod.

Title: Uttarakhand CM announces insurance cover for ‘Covid-19 Warriors’
Content: DEHRADUN: Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat on Wednesday declared that an insurance cover would be provided to all the ‘Covid-19 warriors’, including health officers, mediapersons, police personnel, doctors and medical staff, who were carrying out their duty during the ongoing crisis even at the risk of their own health. The modalities of the insurance cover that would be extended was still being worked out, a source in the CM’s office said.The CM made the announcement during the assembly session convened on Wednesday in which the state’s Rs 53,526-crore budget for financial year 2020-21 was passed. The budget had been tabled in the assembly session held at Gairsain earlier this month. In wake of the coronavirus scare, the day’s proceedings were restricted to less than an hour, following which Speaker Prem Chand Agarwal adjourned the House sine die.Addressing the House, CM Rawat said, “Around 2,082 people from China and other Covid-19-affected countries have come to Uttarakhand. Of this, 628 people have completed a quarantine period of 28 days and 1,323 are undergoing quarantine. Remaining 131 people have left the state.”He assured the House that adequate arrangements have been made for quarantine and isolation of patients and suspects, and the task force that has been constituted for the purpose, is monitoring the situation closely.Leader of opposition Indira Hridayesh said that the Congress party supports the state government in its effort against Covid-19 “but the only concern is that district and health officers do not receive calls.” “If they cannot receive calls, they should depute someone for the purpose so that if there is any case or an emergency, prompt action can be taken.”

Title: Amid row, govt steps back on age relaxation for EWS quota
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: In a sharp about-face, the government has officially withdrawn its proposal to relax the limit on eligibility age and attempts in public employment for upper caste candidates under the 10% reservation for Economically Weaker Sections. The proposal was moved in the form of a cabinet note by the social justice ministry and was expected to be cleared swiftly but political rethink seems to have scuppered it for now.

R Subrahmanyam, ecretary for social justice and empowerment, told TOI, “The cabinet note has been withdrawn for now. It requires more detailed examination.”

The proposal stated that the age limit for eligibility in public employment and education should be relaxed by three years for EWS individuals, at par with the benefit available to the OBCs under the 27% Mandal quotas. The proposal was circulated to all the ministries for their comments amid indications from the social justice ministry that it would be cleared at the earliest.

This is the first public announcement on change of stance on the controversial proposal which was first rebuffed by the department of personnel and training last August, only to be moved again with gusto by the social justice ministry this February, amid intense lobbying by the interested upper caste groups.

While there is no indication on the reason behind the withdrawal of note, the rethink appears to be rooted in the controversy generated by the wide belief that EWS category was being given the relaxation just to put them at par with OBCs without the sufficient grounds which originally resulted in this benefit to the backward castes as well as to SCs and STs.

A government insider said the proposal has not been junked for good while pointing to “political reasons” which have put it on hold for now.

As reported by TOI on August 5, 2019, DoPT minister Jitendra Singh had reacted negatively to the proposal by arguing that “in the past, the question of age relaxation has been decided only after observing the impact of reservation policy, ie, whether the required number of persons from that particular category are getting inducted in the services reserved for them”.
