It implied that age concession is given only if the beneficiary group of a particular quota regime is unable to compete and succeed within the laid down eligibility norms of age.

Given the argument, relaxation under the EWS was seen as unlikely because economically weaker upper castes are assumed to be competitive. This is unlike Dalits and backwards who, because of historical social handicap, are unable to compete under a lower age bar. The shortfall noticed during earlier years of SC/ST/OBC quotas led to their being given the age rebate.

In his response, Singh had pointed out that age relaxation for OBCs came three years after the Mandal quotas were implemented while it was longer in case of SCs and STs.

Title: Fire tenders spray disinfectants in Jaipur
Content: Jaipur: Fire tenders are now being used to spray disinfectants on city roads by the Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC).Around 120 teams are involved in spraying sodium hydrochloride to disinfect all the public places. For speeding up the process, 17 fire tenders and vehicle-mounted machines have been deployed for the purpose.One fire tender and two vehicle-mounted machines have been deployed in each zone.JMC commissioner V.P.Singh issued the order on Wednesday and work begun since morning.Sodium hydrochloride solution is being sprayed all over the city especially in temples – Govind Devji, Khole Ke Hanuman ji and Moti Doongri as they see thousands of visitors every day. The main market area and inner lanes of colonies are also being disinfected.However, there have been complaints received that VIP areas like Tilak Nagar and C-Scheme have been given priority.“Calls have been received to spray in VIP areas on priority,” said a JMC source.JMC doctor Soniya Aggarwal said, “Work has been going on everywhere. No risks are being taken. The building of JMC is also being disinfected every day especially the staircases, toilets and corners. This will be a continuous process.”

Title: 137 held for breaching lockdown restrictions in city
Content:
T’puram: Intensifying their vigil against those who breach lockdown protocols, the city police have started taking steps to suspend the registration of vehicles that are taken out for unnecessary trips. City Police Commissioner Balramkumar Upadhyay informed that vehicles taken out for unnecessary trips will be confiscated, invoking Section 53 of Motor Vehicles Act that deals with suspension of vehicle registration.

On Wednesday, the second day of state lockdown, the city police registered as many as 134 cases and recorded the arrest of 137 persons for breaching lockdown restrictions. They also confiscated 117 vehicles from motorists in connection with these cases. Among these, 85 are two-wheelers, 19 autorickshaws and 13 cars.

The vehicles were given back to owners after case was registered. If the same vehicle is caught again for the same offence, its registration will be suspended, the Commissioner said. The police have also taken measures to check the unwanted outings of individuals that go undetected by the cops on roads. The security personnel of all apartment complexes in the city have been directed to keep a register in which the entry and exit of all residents must be recorded. The local police personnel will check this register every day and find out who all are going out unnecessarily. The residents’ association office bearers and caretakers of apartment complexes that do not comply this direction will have to face legal action.

The Commissioner has also requested people to arrange accommodation facilities at homes for home nurses and palliative care volunteers instead making them travel every day for the remaining days of the lockdown. As movement of people is restricted, the police are also taking steps to bring various services of the police to the doorsteps. Henceforth, people can register their complaints or file applications for police clearance certificates via e-mail, phone or Whatsapp. Janamaithri Community Relations Officers at each police station have been entrusted with the task of the providing the email ids, phone numbers and Whatsapp numbers of the police among the public through residents’ associations

The rural district police on Wednesday registered 460 cases, 365 people were arrested and 120 vehicles were seized. Also in the rural police district, the Deputy Inspector General awarded good service entry to four officers attached to Parassala police station, including SI Sreelal for arresting a group of DYFI activists for violating lockdown restrictions. The police had taken action against them on Tuesday evening, which had made way for a minor clash. The DIG awarded good service entry to the officers at a time when DYFI local leadership at Parassala has launched a campaign to transfer the cops involved as a retaliatory measure.

The Kollam city police on Wednesday registered 210 cases and arrested 180 people. As many as 195 vehicles including cars, autorickshaws, and motorcycles were seized .

Title: Gandhi market to function only during night hours from today
Content: TRICHY: The Gandhi market in Trichy will function only during night hours from Thursday onwards. The decision was taken after district collector S Sivarasu held a meeting with traders organisations on Wednesday evening. In a statement, the collector said that the market will remain out of bounds for public for any kind of purchase. However, whole sellers have been instructed to sell the vegetables only to retailers coming to the market from 9pm till 7am the next day.This has been done to ensure supply of vegetables and fruits in the district during the lockdown period and to prevent the spread of Covid-19. Apart from remaining closed during the day, it will also be kept closed during Saturdays and Sundays.

Title: With temples shut, virus affects Navratra celebration
Content: Jaipur: The 21-day lockdown imposed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi to check the spread of Covid-19 has hit Navratra celebrations which started from Wednesday. For the first time, all temples remained shut in the state during the festival forcing people to perform pujas within the confine of their homes. Shila Mata temple in Amber , Karni Mata temple Bikaner, Jwala Mata temple in Jobner and other famous temples of goddess Durga have been closed down for the safety of people.Priest of Shila Mata temple Banwari Sharma said the puja will be organised in the temple but people are not allowed inside. “It is in the interest of the people to avoid spreading the disease. Priests of the temple will follow all the rituals while maintaining distance in the temple itself but the public will not be allowed. In my knowledge, I have never seen the spread of such a deadly disease,” said Banwari.People are trying to keep the festival low-key this time. Nirmala Sharma, a resident of Raja Park said, this is the first time she is staying indoors during Navratra. “Temples are shut so it will be better for everyone to celebrate at home. We have decorated a small temple at home for the goddess. This is safe and secure,” said Nirmala.Unlike last year, when shops were all decked up with pooja items, people are preferring hand-stitched clothes for the goddess this year. “I had purchased the pooja items in advance. But many are now stitching dresses and chunari (stoll) for the goddess at home. In my colony, people are borrowing some items from the neighbours for pooja. This is a difficult time when we must co-operate,” said Varsha Mangani, a resident of Adarsh Nagar.There is a custom of serving food to nine girls on the day of Ashtami and the local festival of Gangaur is also to be celebrated on Friday. Due to social distancing, people have cancelled inviting girls for the feast.Mukesh Kothari of Chandpole said that till last year, young girls used to roam around the city and people would call them and serve them food. “Due to epidemic, a majority of the people have cancelled inviting them or they have decided to distribute food packets to the children, going door to door. On Gangaur, we are planning to distribute packets to 14 children and have started the preparations. Need to find a way out to celebrate without putting any life in danger,” said Mukesh.

Title: MGMGH ready with over 600 beds to handle Covid-19 cases
Content: TRICHY: As the number of Covid-19 suspects has been rising, Mahatma Gandhi memorial government hospital ( MGMGH ) in Trichy has kept the entire six-storey super specialty block ready to accommodate over 600 patients.MGMGH had a total of 13 patients including 10 men and three women with the symptoms of Covid-19 admitted at the isolation ward as of Wednesday evening. The hospital administration has taken the swab of all 13 patients to put them through Covid-19 tests at the newly-opened testing facility at MGMGH attached to KAP Viswanatham government medical college (KAPVGMC) in Trichy.Medical superintendent of MGMGH, Dr R Yeganathan said that the results of all the patients will be out on Thursday. Till now, the tests were done at viral research and diagnostic laboratory (VRDL) in Tiruvarur.Keeping in line with the number of cases, MGMGH has kept 640 beds in the general ward and 60 beds in intensive care unit (ICU) in the six floors of the super specialty building. The patients in the wards have been either discharged or shifted to the old block depending upon the necessity for emergency treatment. However, the hospital administration has left eight patients in the burns ward on the fourth floor of the super specialty block undisturbed.The hospital administration said that a total of 85 ventilators have been kept ready, of them, 40 were being used while the 45 others were available.MGMGH already has 32 beds including 12 beds in the isolation ward and 20 beds in the de-addiction ward converted into isolation ward.On Wednesday evening, Trichy collector S Sivarasu said that the screening has been done of the 483 quarantined people, who came to Trichy through the Trichy international airport and 141 quarantined people, who reached Trichy by other modes of transports after landing at airports in other cities. Trichy district administration has received Rs 10 lakh each from four MLAs in Trichy district towards Covid-19 prevention measure, said the collector.

Title: Farmers may soon take vegetables to societies
Content:
Pune: The weekly farmers’ group and the state agriculture department are working with municipal corporations in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad and the district administration to set up a system to supply vegetables and fruits at housing societies during the ongoing lockdown.

Coordinators from the weekly farmers’ markets said over 400 farmers’ groups had expressed their willingness to suply produces to the cities every since the weekly markets they used to hold had been stopped because of the restrictions. The markets were held at over 50 places in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad to supply vegetables and fruits.

A coordinator said, “A new concept is being explored to deliver packets of vegetables to housing societies. This could be bulk supply for the entire society. Preliminary discussions were held in the last two days. Soon a plan is expected to be out. To streamline the functioning, the farmers’ groups will be attached to municipal wards so they will have specific areas to cover. There may not be an open market. The groups will only deliver packets.”

Another coordinator said options were being explored where the housing societies could register their demands over call or through an online system. This would also help the administration and farmers’ groups to maintain accounts. While the administrative part will be dealt by authorities the farmers’ group will look into the supply of vegetables. A PMC official said the administration will provide assistance in terms of infrastructure and space for packaging of vegetables.

Possibilities were also being explored to decentralize distribution of vegetables and fruits in the city, where the wholesalers will supply farm produces to local retailers in every ward, another coordinator said.

Title: Coronanxiety: Focus on mental healthcare
Content:
Who are most vulnerable?

But impact radius is huge

Cut out info overload

NEW DELHI: Unlike anything in living memory, Covid-19 has upended people’s lives and stolen away old certainties. When a pandemic happens, the impact goes far beyond physical health .Divya Dureja, counselling psychologist, LGBT activist and TEDx speaker, sums up the story of a troubling 2020 so far: “On any given day, all of us wish to stay at home but now, since we have been asked to not go to work, we feel shackled.”A pandemic’s effect on mental health, even among those unaffected by it, could be bigger, doctors suggest. Anxiety , depression and fear are some of the most common symptoms that require attention, says Dr Nimesh Desai, director of the Institute of Human Behaviour and Allied Sciences. “For the generation in existence, this is the first such experience of a global pandemic. But it’s important to take it well. Those who are able-bodied or able-minded have a responsibility to support the vulnerable ones, for example elderly, children, pregnant women and people with disability among others,” he says.“The virus is omnipresent in our minds,” adds psychiatrist Praveen Tripathy. “Through overexposure to information, we are getting to see a lot of mental-illness scenarios aggravated.”Unlike in the past, when a pandemic like this would cause complete social isolation, people now have the option to stay connected, explains Dr Desai. “We need to focus on the positive things, channelise our energy towards new interests and keep in contact with people through various means,” he says.Those who contract the infection. The department of mental health of the World Health Organisation (WHO) recently issued an advisory to support psychological wellbeing of patients during lockdowns because of the novel coronavirus outbreak. “Those with the disease have not done anything wrong,” the advisory says.Jacqueline Levin of the department of psychiatry at North Shore University Hospital (Manhasset, US), in his book titled Psychiatry of Pandemics, writes that in such a scenario, the loss of functioning because of illness may leave survivors feeling demoralised. “If the patient experiences marked distress or significant impairment in social or occupational functioning, they may meet criteria for adjustment disorder,” he writes, adding, both individual and group therapy can helpDoctors also warn that those quarantined are vulnerable to psychological disorders. “People already have a fear, and by staying at home they are getting more access to news and, also fake forwarded messages on WhatsApp and social media, which is adding to panic,” says Dr Shweta Sharma, consultant, psychology and counselling, Columbia Asia Hospital, Gurgaon.According to Dr Samir Parikh – director, department of mental health and behavioural sciences, Fortis Healthcare – there are multiple factors at play when it comes to understanding mental health in such circumstances. “One is general anxiety because of the virus, which can affect people and their families. Second, there is concern about financial implications. Third is home quarantine, where people are forced to bring in a change in their lifestyle. Hence, they need time to adjust,” explains Dr Parikh.Healthcare personnel are also susceptible to mental health problems because of prolonged shifts, seeing traumatic images of their patients, and working during surge conditions in overburdened settings with chronically scarce supplies and medication and their own fatigue and burnout.Doctors say among people who are not affected by the virus but by the impacts of the pandemic, uncertainty and lockdown, some mental illnesses like obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD), depression and anxiety are resurfacing. “Some patients who had come out of depression and anxiety are showing signs of relapse. The reason is a restriction on physical mobility combined with information about the virus,” says Dr Tripathy.Also, with frequent washing of hands and checking of screens becoming normalised due to the virus threat, the signs of OCD, believe doctors, are being strengthened. “OCD is a situation in which a person repeats a behaviour or thought pattern and can’t stop themselves – like repeatedly washing hands. Now that such patients are getting to see everyone doing it, their symptoms are getting reinforced,” explains Priyanka Goyal, a psychiatrist.The closure of clinics due to the lockdown also has therapists worried. “Mental health services fall among non-essential medical services and thus psychologists’ clinics and special education centres are all closed at this time. This could lead to regression among patients. Children with special needs could also fall back on the curve,” says Manish Samnani, occupational therapist.Among the counsel offered by mental-health professionals is not let yourself be swamped with information. “Stick to just one source of information; if you read a particular paper, read that each day to stay informed. If you watch a channel, log on to that,” advises Dr Tripathy. “People are sharing messages about taking scheduled drugs as self-medication – they are highly damaging not just for mental wellbeing but for physical wellbeing too,” he adds. “Now is a great time to do some deep cleaning of your house, read books, get some exercise, organise your belongings at home. Do things that you never have time for in the,” advises Goyal.

Title: Maharashtra: Bhujbal for doorstep delivery of essential items during 21-day cap
Content: PUNE: State food and civil supplies minister Chhagan Bhujbal on Wednesday said his department was mobilising teams for doorstep delivery of essential items, such as food and vegetables, like it was done in Wuhan, the epicentre of Covid-19 in China.“We have instructed all districts to take measures towards this. Revenue and police teams have to ensure that essential items are supplied to housing societies or at some select points for the individuals to collect them without crowding. The 21-day lockdown is a long period and we have to ensure that there is a smooth flow of the supplies,” he told TOI.On Wednesday, the Uttar Pradesh government announced using over 10,000 vehicles for delivery of essential products such as vegetables, milk and medicines for he people to prevent them during the 21-day lockdown period.“We have reached out to every district in the state and are working on a plan. We have mobilised the Agricultural Produce Market Committee (APMC) markets, farmers, local hawkers and grocery shop owners to streamline the supply system. In Mumbai, a list has been drawn out of grocery stores and chains supplying services at people’s doorstep. The model can be replicated in all areas,” Bhujbal said.The food and civil supplies minister said he has urged his home department counterpart, Anil Deshmukh, to go easy on people stepping out of home to buy essential items with the state being in the lockdown mode in the time of Covid-19.“I have told the home minister that action is essential to prevent people from movement. If two persons are stepping out to buy grocery or other essential items, police can send back one home. If this is not followed, a penalty of Rs20,000 can be slapped on the offender. But one person going to get the essential supply should not be manhandled or beaten up,” Bhujbal said.The revised order issued by the chief secretary stated that plying of private vehicles should be restricted only to the extent of procuring essential commodities, health services and activities permitted under the directive. The order added only two persons, besides the driver, in a car should be allowed in cases of essential services.All ration card holders would get items from the fair price shops and supply of grain would be uninterrupted for two months. “We are urging people and traders to not hoard grains or pulses. If they do so, they will face action under the Essential Commodity Act,” the minister said.He added that ever since the nationwide lockdown was announced on Tuesday, he has been speaking to his officials and departments to streamline supply of essential items. “Everything will be in place within two-three days,” Bhujbal said.

Title: Coronavirus in Delhi: Five new cases, three more linked to case No. 10
Content: NEW DELHI: The web of positive cases connected to Delhi’s case number 10, a 38-year-old woman from Dilshad Garden with travel history to Saudi Arabia, reached nine with three more persons connected to her testing positive for the novel coronavirus infection on Wednesday. The total number of Covid-19 cases in Delhi now stands at 35.The five new cases on Wednesday include two residents of Sainik Farms — not connected to the woman — with travel history to Brazil and London, respectively.According to a Delhi government official, eight cases in the city are so far linked to the Saudi Arabia-returned woman, excluding her. The latest additions are the wife and the daughter of the mohalla clinic doctor who examined her on March 12 and a relative of the woman’s brother who picked her up from the IGI airport on her return to India.The woman, Delhi’s case number 10, was diagnosed positive on March 17. Three days later, her brother and mother tested positive, and on March 21, her two daughters. The mohalla clinic doctor tested positive the next day.All of them are in stable condition in hospitals, a source said. On Tuesday, the doctor was shifted to the Safdarjung Hospital ICU from Guru Tegh Bahadur (GTB) Hospital after developing respiratory distress but has since been kept in an isolation ward.Since March 12, the doctor had seen several patients at the mohalla clinic. On Wednesday, the subdivisional magistrate of Shahdara directed that all those who had visited the clinic in Maujpur’s Mohanpuri between March 12 and 18 should home-quarantine themselves for 15 days.A district health official also said 74 people living in the neighbourhood of the Saudi Arabia-returned woman are under surveillance. “After the woman tested positive, we immediately asked her family for the names and addresses of the people who had visited them since March 10, the date of her return,” a health official said. “They weren’t cooperative, so we had to seek local police’s help to get information. We also used footage from the CCTV cameras installed near their home to identify some people who needed to be put under surveillance,” he added.The woman’s brother and mother live in Jahangirpuri. The people who came in contact with them are also being screened, a source said.

Title: 3 DCPs to aid movement of crucial services
Content:
Pune: Pimpri Chinchwad police on Wednesday appointed three deputy commissioners of police as incident commanders to facilitate movement of essential and emergency services, during the 21-day lockdown period.

Those requiring passes for the essential and emergency services can contact Smita Patil on 9834957526 or send an email at dcpzone1.pcpc-mh@gov.in for areas under Pimpri, Chinchwad, Bhosari, Bhosari MIDC, Nigdi, Chakan, Alandi and Dighi police stations. People can also reach out to Vinayak Dhakane on 9529861471 or send an email at dcpzone2.pcpc-mh@gov.in for areas falling under Wakad, Hinjewadi, Sangvi, Dehu Road, Talegaon Dabhade and Talegaon MIDC police stations.

The police also released a WhatsApp number (9529691966) to ease the transport of employees engaged in essential services. Issuing a statement in this regard on Wednesday, Pimpri Chinchwad police commissioner Sandeep Bishnoi said hospitals, firms involved in production and distribution of health products, medical shops, laboratories, clinics, private nursing homes, ambulance services, doctors, nurses and hospital staff in the Pimpri Chinchwad area have been exempted from the lockdown order. These people can contact on WhatsApp number 9529691966 for any complaint or information, the statement read.

Helping the

senior citizens

On Monday night, a senior citizen from Hinjewadi contacted the Pimpri Chinchwad police’s helpline number ‘1090’ and said the police were not allowing his cook to come to his house. He also informed the police that he did not have anything to eat. A team of the Hinjewadi police then went to his house with food and also assured him that his cook would reach on time every day from Wednesday.

Title: Nagpur: Some goods run short as buyers store up and supply falters
Content:
The streets were deserted, but people could still be seen at grocery shops or vegetable stalls that were open ... Read More

NAGPUR: The streets were deserted, but people could still be seen at grocery shops or vegetable stalls that were open for limited period. As the district administration is trying to ensure adequate supplies amid increased buying due to the lockdown, traders had a mixed reaction.

Bulk dealers in grain said there was no shortage as they had received orders to keep their establishments open.

However, dealers in grocery that include a whole gamut of food products other than grains said there was shortage of packaged items and other fast moving consumer goods (FMCG). Transportation has been hit due to the lockdown. Even supply of wheat has been hit because curfew has brought trucks to a standstill, said a trader.

Dairy plants that have managed to meet the demand of milk so far are also facing hassles, said sources in the industry. Vegetable wholesalers at the agriculture produce market committee’s (APMC) at Kalamna will remain shut till Monday. Other shops at Kalamna are also closed till Friday. Traders who have shut down said they had already pumped in enough supply to retail markets to last till they reopen.

Bulk dealers in fruits decided to close the business during the entire lockdown period because supplies from other states have been held up. Closure of resautrants which are major buyers of fruits has also led to a significant drop in the demand, prompting the traders to close.

Officials of the oil companies said they were already geared up to meet any hike in demand for cooking gas and the bottling plants can work overtime too.

Secretary of Itwari Grain and Seeds Merchants Association said after a meeting with the district administration officials it was decided that the grain traders’ shops in Itwari and Kalamna will be open. Even the labour engaged for loading and unloading have been issued passes to move out during the curfew, he said.

Prabhakar Deshmukh, president of Nagpur Chillar Kirana Vyapari Sangh, said even as there was enough supply of rice and pulses the traders had not been able to replenish their stock of wheat which comes from Madhya Pradesh. This has led to a slight shortage of wheat flour also. A whole gamut of branded packaged food and cosmetics are also not available from bulk dealers due to restrictions on transport, he said.

Nandkishore Gaur, who heads the vegetable traders’ association at Kalamna, said the traders want to close down as they were more susepctible to infection because of a large number of persons coming to Kalamna. “Those at market places have to interact with hundreds of persons which increases the risk of infection. I had plans to shut down for more than six days but due to officials’ insistence, the shops will open on Tuesday,” said Gaur.

Shyam Laddhad, who heads Amul’s plant at Nagpur, said procurement of milk had gone up during this period. This may be because other buyers are not there due to the shut down. “The distributors are facing troubles in moving around. They should be given permission by the police,” he said.

Ajay Kumar Upadhyaya of Dinshaw’s Dairy said the company had witnessed a major reduction in demand due to shops closing down. “Workers are finding it difficult to reach the plant. Not only this, some workers are not able to return home after finishing their shift,” he said.

Officials of the three oil companies- Indian Oil Corporation (IOC), Bharat Petroleum Corporation and Hindustan Petroleum Corporation (HPCL), said the demand for cooking gas has been more or less stable. “All the gas agencies have been issued instructions to carry out home deliveries of cylinders which is being followed too,” said a source in BPCL, which is also the state level coordinator among the three oil marketing companies.

“Mass SMSes have been sent to the consumers intimating that they can book a second cylinder too during this period. This means one can have two filled cylinders at a time these days,” said an official in HPCL. There has been a hike of around 2% in the demand due to the situation which will be easily met. The official in IOC said even as there is no increase in demand, any spike will be met easily. The three companies supply 25-30,000 cylinders each throughout Vidarbha region daily.

Rajesh Chabrani, a former director of APMC and fruit dealer, said there was no sense for bulk traders to stock fruits because the trade channels down the line are closed.

‘Drivers should have IDs and essential commodities label’

Director general of police (DGP) has appealed to all the associations engaged in transportation of essential commodities and providing essential services to ask truck drivers to carry their identity cards and display a placard of essential commodity/service on their vehicles.

Police have given instructions time and again to all the personnel on the field to facilitate movement of these vehicles and persons. Despite this if there is any inconvenience then it may be reported to 100 number which is working directly under the commissioner of police or superintendent of police.

In case the issue is not resolved, the person may contact the state police control room any time on +912222026636 or +912222822631. Manoj Patil, SP of state control room, will be available on 9075080344.

Title: Delhi Coronavirus News: Crowding at shelters for food a cause for concern
Content:
Free lunch and dinner will continue till the capital is under lockdown

NEW DELHI: City’s night shelters have turned into the biggest centres of community food with a large number of homeless and the poor converging to have food during the lockdown. Officials said at least 16,000 people were offered both lunch and dinner at the city’s 220 night shelters on Wednesday.

Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal had last week announced free lunch and dinner for anyone who was willing to eat at the night shelters. The services started on Sunday and will continue till the time the city is under lockdown.

Delhi Urban Shelter Improvement Board (DUSIB) has roped in shelter management agencies to augment its capacity and provide food to everyone coming to the shelters. “Every day, we cook food for 40 per cent more people than the total count of those who consumed the previous day. Our priority is to ensure that no one is left hungry,” DUSIB member-expert Bipin Rai said.

The number of those coming to the shelters during the daytime has increased to at least three times since the government has started the free food facility. The beneficiaries mostly include migrant labourers, construction workers, helpers and cleaners at shops and small factories. With most of the gurdwaras and temples either closed to public or not offering food, these poor people are left with no place except the night shelters to get food.

“Thousands have collected at shelter homes where Delhi govt has directed cooked food be provided. Overcrowded, overwhelmed- shelters don’t have adequate ration & infrastructure. Govt needs to ensure cooked food distribution at all anganwadis & govt schools also,” Anjali Bharadwaj of Delhi Rozi Roti Adhikar Manch tweeted.

However, crowding at night shelters threatens to demolish the idea behind the lockdown. TOI learnt that crowds reached shelters near Nigambodh Ghat cremation grounds on Tuesday resulting in a somewhat unwieldy situation and reports of large number of people reaching other shelters in areas like Jama Masjid, Sarai kale Khan to seek food also came in on Wednesday. Things are expected to get worse, say social activists.

By Wednesday evening, it was evident that thousands of people are struggling with hunger amid lockdown.

The plan involving community organisations, including gurdwaras and temples, can probably provide a sustainable solution to prevent large crowds from gathering at one place, said an activist.

Rai said the government’s top priority was to provide food to the hungry. “But we are exploring options on how to maintain social distancing. We are working out a plan and hope to roll it out on Thursday,” the DUSIB member-expert said.

Delhi Rozi Roti Adhikar Manch on Wednesday wrote to CM Arvind Kejriwal demanding emergency measures to ensure access to food to all and prevent starvation deaths during the Covid-19 crisis.

Title: 6 rabbits, 8 birds locked up in Hyderabad pet shop rescued
Content:
Owner of the shop in police custody

HYDERABAD: As many as six rabbits and eight birds were rescued from a closed pet shop in Narayanaguda on Wednesday. The incident came to light after a twitter user tagged municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao asking him to help the animals locked up in pet shops without food and water after the government announced ‘janata curfew’ in the state on Sunday.

Posting a video of one such pet shop, Mayura @redearthz tweeted, “@KTRTRS sir, could you kindly look into petshops in Hyderabad that are locked with pets inside with no ventilation and water. This is one such pet shop in Narayanguda . Request you to help. (sic)”

Responding to the twitter post, the enforcement vigilance and disaster management (EVDM) wing of GHMC raided the pet shop on Wednesday and rescued the pets.

Sharing pictures of the pet shop owner with the rescued pets on his twitter account, the director, enforcement vigilance and disaster management (EVDM) @Director_EVDM said, “Six rabbits and eight birds have been rescued from the closed pet shop. The owner has agreed to take care of them by shifting them to his residence.”

Meanwhile, senior BJP leader Maneka Gandhi asked people to keep an eye on pet shops as the owners are leaving the animals and birds inside during the lockdown without food or water. She also appealed to the people to call police or write to her office to inform about the same.

“Pet shops are locking up with their animals and birds inside. These will die in two days. If you see a pet shop and hear animals inside call the police or let me know at gandhim@nic.in,” tweeted Maneka Gandhi @Manekagandhibjp.

The former union minister’s remarks came after the government announced complete lockdown in the country amid the Covid-19 crisis.

Title: Food deliveries hit as apps grapple with restrictions in Pune
Content:
Representative Image

PUNE: Home deliveries of essential items have started to falter despite a government notification that permits delivery of food and other items.

The lockdown has left restaurants, groceries and other stores short on manpower. Many shops have limited working hours to slots from 7am to 11am and 4pm to 9pm. About 85% of restaurants across the city have stopped home deliveries altogether.

Citizens TOI spoke to said orders placed via food apps were being cancelled. Food delivery firms such as BigBasket also paused deliveries after citing issues with local authorities. Other websites and apps were displaying a limited number of items — with delivery dates as late as April.

“Reach the stores as early as possible if you want something,” said a shopkeeper in Model Colony’s Deep Bungalow Chowk. “We have not been able to secure supplies because transporters have been impacted by traffic curbs.”

The problem has left citizens worried. “I had to rely on volunteer groups to get my elderly parents food. All the delivery apps cancelled my order,” said a US-based woman.

Delivery portal BigBasket told TOI on March 25 it is currently not operational in cities such as Chandigarh, Chennai, Delhi, Ludhiana, Pune and Vizag. “In each of these cities, our operations have been shut down due to severe restrictions on staff and vehicular movement. We have been trying to work with local authorities, but have not gotten necessary help so far,” a statement said.

Sources from the Pune Restaurants and Hoteliers Association (PRAHA) said many restaurants — almost 85% — are not finding home deliveries viable. “We hope online delivery of food resumes properly by next week,” the source said.

A Swiggy spokersperson said it is “working with local restaurants to remain operational”. “As per the Prime Minister’s directive, food delivery has been designated under essential services. There has been a short-term impact on volumes, which can be attributed to supply shortage due to temporary closure of many high-volume restaurants in malls and disruptions on ground across certain states.”

A Zomato spokesperson said, “Coordinating with multiple local authorities is has been challenging. Our delivery partners are facing several hurdles across cities. We are communicating with the relevant authorities and hoping these issues are sorted soon.”

Title: Helplines to provide citizens key information
Content:
Pune: The civic body and the Smart City Development Corporation have commissioned helplines to assist citizens in seeking medical help and provide information about availability of essential commodities during the 21-day lockdown starting Tuesday.

A Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) official said staffers have been deployed at the helpline centre. “The helplines will prove useful, especially for senior citizens and those well versed with the city, to get necessary information,” the official said.

The helplines were operational as a part of the PMC’s disaster management plan. The official said the citizens’ queries would be routed to the departments concerned for prompt replies. “We will give basic information about the functioning of grocery shops and the locations of nearby medical shops and hospitals,” he said.

Some corporators have on their part set up help desks through dedicated WhatsApp numbers and helplines to assist citizens about availability of essential goods and vegetables in their areas.

Amol Balwadkar, chairman of the PMC’s city improvement committee and corporator from the Baner-Balewadi area, has set up a system to reach out to people. He said, “The primary aim is to arrest spreading of wrong information among people”.

Another corporator said he was preparing a list of grocery shops in the area. “We area getting several calls from residents. We now plan to provide the list to them so they can approach nearest shop, vegetable vendor or medical store,” the corporator said. Hadapsar MLA Chetan Tupe said he has told party (NCP) corporators to be present in their respective wards and minimize the citizens’ fears about the 21-day lockdown.

Title: 370 stranded passengers in Trichy airlifted to Malaysia
Content: TRICHY: Around 370 passengers, who had been stranded in Trichy following the cancellation of international flights from India in the wake of Covid-19 outbreak, were airlifted by two special rescue flights to Kuala Lumpur early on Wednesday. Earlier, as many as 186 stranded Malaysian passengers were flown to Kuala Lumpur on a special flight on Saturday.A group of Malaysian tourists arrived at Tamil Nadu two weeks ago and had planned to return to Kuala Lumpur on March 18 via Trichy international airport. On arrival, they were told that all flights to Kuala Lumpur have been cancelled.On information, an official from the Malaysian consulate in Chennai arrived at Trichy airport on March 18 and assured them to do the needful to send them back safely after arranging a special flightAir Asia operated two rescue flights from Trichy to Kuala Lumpur to ferry the stranded Malaysian nationals on Tuesday night.

Title: Delhi Lockdown: In Delhi, RWAs & residents locked in a feud
Content: NEW DELHI: While the authorities have permitted transportation of essential items during the three-week nationwide lockdown as well as delivery of newspaper, milk, grocery, medicines and food to homes to dissuade people from coming out, a few gated communities and residents’ welfare associations in Delhi are barring entry of outsiders, among them delivery executives and hawkers.The residents themselves have expressed mixed opinion about the measure. While some thing the RWAs are making unnecessary rules, others argue that strict steps are a must now.Vasant Kunj’s Sushma is one of those who feel that by restricting entry to service providers, people are being exposed to risks by having to leave home and stand in queues at shops. “This will beat the entire purpose of the curfew and heightens the chances of spreading infection,” she said. “No vegetable vendor has been allowed in for four days. Ideally, they should be issued cards and given fixed timings.”At Dwarka, a resident said, “In my society, we’ve not got a newspaper for two days. Initially I was told to collect it from the entry gates in morning, but the deliveries stopped. For other stuff too, one has to go to the entry gate because delivery people are not allowed inside.”M K Gupta, RWA member of S Block, GK-I, disclosed a few residents had wanted newspapers restricted for fear of infections, but the RWA decided absence of information would only create more panic. “Moreover, on an idle day, reading newspaper is the perfect way to get details about things happening in society. So we placed soaps at the entry gate and requested vendors and delivery people to sanitise their hands and wear masks before coming in,” he said.Gated societies argue they are only restricting entry of delivery executives into their complexes while allowing collection at the gates. “The chances of infection are high if common areas are frequently visited by outsiders,” reasoned K Ramamoorthy, president, Aravali Apartments. “We allow newspapers, but restrict other services. For senior citizens, we plan to engage our own in-complex delivery boys to take goods from the gates to their houses.”Another RWA member, Sulbha Gupta of Alaknanda in south Delhi, said it took a lot of effort to sanitise the society area. “People only need to walk to the gate, it’s not an inconvenience,” she said. “We have called vegetable and fruit vendors to the gate at fixed times.”Dwarka resident Kamaljeet Sherawat accepted that societies were being extra cautious but hoped that things would be streamlined soon.

Title: 2 sheds atop bldg guttedin Yousufguda
Content:
Hyderabad: A fire broke out atop a two-storeyed building at Jawaharnagar in Yousufguda on Wednesday. Luckily, there were no casualties. The property loss at the site was put at Rs 3 lakh.

According to a fire services official, the fire broke out on the terrace of the building where two temporary sheds were there. The sheds, which were erected for a marriage function, were completely destroyed.

“There was an electric short-circuit, which triggered the fire. The fire occurred at around 10 pm,” said Sultan Pradeep Kumar, station fire officer.

“Two fire tenders were rushed to the place to put out the fire. The property loss is estimated to be around Rs 3 lakh,” added the station fire officer.

Title: Cops provide 148 passes to auto drivers
Content:
Pune: The traffic branch of the Pune police has given 148 special passes to the company coordinating the ‘dial an auto’ service to be handed over to the autorickshaw drivers.

“The traffic police gave us 148 passes. We hope the drivers will not be stopped by the police now,” Rahul Shitole, chief executive officer of CityGlide Auto, that runs the service in coordination with the police, said.

On Wednesday, the service, which can be booked by calling 9859198591, received 647 calls. “ There were people who wanted autorickshaws for their regular check-ups and physiotherapy sessions. We were able to provide autorickshaws to 104 callers. But the service could not be extended to 310 callers due to non-availability of vehicles. We have 58 three-wheelers on the roads at present,” he said.

From Thursday, there will be 150 autorickshaws for people with emergencies.

They must inform the reason for the transport while booking the autorickshaws, Shitole said.

Title: Showers add to anguish of working from home
Content:
Pune: The concept of work from home went for a toss for many on Wednesday afternoon when summer showers lashed several parts of the city, interrupting electricity supply.

In theory, techies say, internet speed of 5MB per second is sufficient to seamlessly go about their work in most cases. However, fluctuations in speed combined with electricity outages posed a challenge for hundreds of techies working from home.

“My office has supported me in every way with connection issues and setting up my machine for remote work. The problem is with internet speed that keeps wavering as well as electricity. Since yesterday, it has started raining heavily in Pune, which leads to power cuts. Somehow, the infrastructure does not support even a little bit of downpour. Until now, I have faced three under-one-hour long power cuts,” said Shripad Tak, a techie.

According to IT firms, productivity levels are still at about 50% of the usual seen on a daily basis. However, since this is new on such a large scale, firms are willing to be patient for now. “We know that our staffers are getting used to this and the challenging environment around. Our managers are in touch with their teams. We are sure the productivity will improve in the weeks ahead,” said a senior executive of a Hinjewadi-based IT company.

Employees are also facing the challenge of reducing the number of devices connected to the internet. However, with the entire family, and their varying interests, being together at home makes it more complicated. Besides, people have had trouble reaching out to service providers with their complaints in the wake of the nationwide lockdown.

As per Sandeep Sawarkar, principal general manager for BSNL Pune circle, while internet services are functioning, complaints are coming in daily. “We are getting complaints from citizens and we are registering them through our call centre. Internal systems are also working to resolve issues. There are certain delays in rectification of issues as most of our staff is outsourced.”

Title: One lakh people in Bareilly to get free ration, distribution to start on April 1
Content:
Representative Image

BAREILLY: In view of the total lockdown due to Covid-19 scare, the district supply officer said all ration card holders would be distributed ration, starting April 1, five days ahead of the scheduled date of April 5. In normal times, ration distribution commences from the fifth day of every month.

District supply officer Seema Tripathi said all labourers listed with the labour department, and Antyodya card holders, would be provided ration free of cost. “Labourers who aren’t listed with the labour department are being issued ration cards, so that they can also avail the ration on time,” she added.

She further said as many as 99,687 Antyodya card holders were registered with the supply office , that they will be provided 20 kg wheat and 15 kg rice every month. “The food grain to Antyodya card holders will be provided free of cost, along with 693 families of labourers registered with the labour office,” the DSO said.

Notably, every labourer family will be distributed 5 kg wheat and 2 kg rice per person. All job card holders under Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MNREGA) will also get the same quantity of grains free of cost.

Officials said a team has been tasked to survey labourers who are neither registered with the labour office nor have ration cards. “We are going to issue ration cards to them so that they can avail free ration in time,” she said.

The supply office has also issued a helpline number 0581-2510892 for any query related to ration availability.

Title: No case reported in Warangal: Min
Content:
Hyderabad: To take stock of the situation in districts, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao called on panchayat raj minister Errabelli Dayakar Rao and enquired about coronavirus preventive measures and water supply for irrigation in kharif season. The CM was informed that there were no positive cases in erstwhile Warangal district. Dayakar said that he held a review meet with officials on coronavirusand thanked the CM for sanctioning a corona testing centre at MGM Hospital in Warangal.

KCR asked Dayakar Rao whether the district was getting enough water from Kaleshwaram project or do they need more supplies. The minister informed that Kaleshwaram water was required for another 15 days for ayacut in the Palakurthy assembly constituency.

Meanwhile, Rythu Bandhu Samithi chairperson Palla Rajeshwara Reddy said following CM’s directions procurement of agriculture produce will begin in villages through IKP and primary agriculture cooperative centres with the coordination of the agriculture and marketing departments. He said there was no need for panic and urged farmers not to come in groups for taking up their works.

Title: Quarantine facility for 1,000 soon
Content:
High speed Railway Training Institute hostel that is being converted into a quarantine facility

Vadodara: A major exercise has been taken up by the state government and district administration to augment facilities for quarantining and treating any possible cases of COVID-19.

Facilities for quarantining 1,000 persons and treating around 500 persons will be available in the city soon including those already in use. Several institutions and hospitals across the city are been roped in for creating quarantine and treatment facilities. A drive has also been started to recruit medical and paramedical staff needed for these facilities. Education secretary Vinod Rao, who has been appointed as the secretary in-charge of Vadodara city and seven districts in central Gujarat for COVID-19, said that the hostel for the training institute for the high-speed railway project will now be used for creating a quarantine facility. “The hostel has an excellent facility of 165 twin-bed rooms with attached toilets. We will be able to keep around 330 people in quarantine there,” Rao said.

The other facilities that have been identified include that for 360 persons at 180 rooms of hostels of the GMERS Medical College and Hospital, Gotri. There is availability of a capacity of 140 persons at the State Institute of Health and Family Welfare that is in use. Also, petroleum and petrochemicals giants in the city have agreed to accommodate around 200 persons in quarantine at their townships. Rao said that hotels in the city had also been identified for the purpose, but would be put under use only if needed.

For treatment of patients testing positive for COVID-19 and suspected cases with severe respiratory infections, a 50-bed capacity already exists at GMERS, Gotri. Another 100 beds are being added to this facility. The ESIS Hospital in Gotri will also be upgraded to accommodate 200 patients for treatment. The railway hospital at Pratapnagar is being equipped to handle 100 such patients.

Rao said that a capacity of over 100 beds will also be available for treating patients at private hospitals in the city. Some of these hospitals have already been notified along with the capacity there. He added that a drive to make recruitment of both medical and paramedical staff needed for COVID-19 facilities has been started.

Title: Hyderabad Coronavirus News: IIT-Hyderabad professor develops simulator to predict virus transmission
Content: HYDERABAD: A researcher at the Institute of Information Technology, Hyderabad (IIIT-H) has developed a ‘viral spread simulator ’ to show various possible scenarios of infection transmission across the world and to highlight the need for social distancing to minimise the spread.The study by Vikram Pudi, professor of Data Sciences and Analytics Center at IIIT-Hyderabad, highlights the fact that when people move about more, the spread of infection becomes faster.While virus transmission is swift and across continents, the study reports that the number of people who travel abroad is much less than those who don’t travel. With community transmission being the current concern in India, the professor emphasises that high hover distance (localised movement within a neighbourhood) is the most important parameter of the study.“When the population is high, the infection can spread more easily. While there is nothing much we can do about the population of our neighbourhood, we can easily change how much we move around. Seeing how much this impacts the spread of infection, hopefully, will inspire us to restrict our movement,” said Pudi.In the study, the professor tested variables such as population size, hover-distance, travel probability (to different parts of the world), death probability, transmission probability, transmit distance (distance within which the infection can transmit), and duration of the infection (pegged at 15 days in the experiment). Pudi said that the purpose of the simulation is to see the impact of strategies that governments can implement on containing the virus and added that the highly optimised code that can run on any android device.“There is no server in the back-end. It runs directly on the browser. Because of that it is highly scalable and will not slow down even if several people are viewing it at the same time. It has multi-lingual support and currently displays in Hindi, Telugu or English, based on the settings in one’s browser / mobile,” he added.Calling the simulator a basic version with scope to build on and improve further, the professor said that actual data from various websites such as the WHO Covid-19 dashboard, the Johns Hopkins Covid-19 dashboard, and others could be included in the next version.

Title: Delhi Lockdown: No-entry for ragpickers defeats lockdown in Delhi
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: As the nationwide 21-day lockdown to fight the novel coronavirus kicked in on Wednesday, the residents’ welfare associations ( RWAs ) and some inhabitants at several high-end colonies in the capital barred waste-pickers from entering the colony.

Chitra Mukherjee, the head of advocacy and policy at Chintan, which works with the community, said waste-pickers were doing a tough job at this critical time without any support and people should come forward with water and soap near dhalaos, and masks and hand sanitisers for them. “Instead, we are getting these complaints from many areas. This is the time to help, not boycott, them.”

Md. Tariqul, who has been lifting garbage from Defence Colony for the past 10 years, said a RWA member had called and asked him not to come due to the virus scare. “My friends and other workers have also received similar calls.”

Some residents said they had reported the matter to the municipal commissioner and police. “Defence Colony RWA members are asking waste collectors not to come. This will mean over 6,000 people will step out each day in one colony to dump their mixed waste in dhalaos,” pointed out Bhavreen Kandhari, who has approached the authorities. RWA president Ranjeet Singh, however, claimed, “We only stop those categories of people who, as per police, should not come to the colony, such as casual workers and maids.”

At B1A block in southwest Delhi’s Janakpuri, RWA president Navneet Singh Bhambri said two waste-pickers serving over 100 houses had been asked not to come to safeguard the residents.

With several dhalaos closed in many areas, locals are leaving their waste. by drains, which may eventually lead to clogging, said Amit Sharma, a resident of northeast Delhi’s Nand Nagri.

Title: Two killed, 10 injured in road accident in Thanjavur
Content:
Representative image

THANJAVUR: Two people were killed in a road accident involving a tourist van and a two-wheeler near Athirampattinam in Thanjavur district .

The deceased have been identified as S Muthu, 18, a native of Gandhi Nagar near Athirampattinam in the district and Shanmugasundaram, 39, of Pinnathur village in Tiruvarur district .

According to police, Muthu, a labourer, was returning from Athirampattinam town to his home riding his two-wheeler.

A group of people hailing from Pinnathur village were heading towards T Pallapatti in Dindigul district to attend a meeting.

The two-wheeler collided head on with the van near Pattukottai. In the impact, Muthu died on the spot. Shanmugasundaram who was sitting on the footboard of the van, was thrown on to the road and died on the spot. As many as 10 people who were travelling on the van also suffered injuries, police said.

Muthu was under the influence of alcohol and had been rash riding the bike, police sources said. On information, police rushed to the spot and sent the injured to Pattukottai Government Hospital .

Police also sent the bodies to the hospital for postmortem. Athirampattinam police registered a case and an investigation is on.

Title: Covid-19 scare? Ugadi spirit remains high in Hyderabad
Content:
Savouring the pachadi, which is a mix of six ingredients signifying life’s six emotions and phases, is a tradi... Read More

HYDERABAD: People did not let the lockdown dampen their festive spirit on Wednesday. Though celebrated low-key, most families in Hyderabad ushered in the Telugu New Year with Ugadi pachadi.

Savouring the pachadi, which is a mix of six ingredients signifying life’s six emotions and phases, is a tradition on Ugadi day among Telugu families. “There can be no better reminder of the bitter-sweet journey of life than the Ugadi pachadi,” said Lalitha Kumari, a resident of Miyapur.

Teaching her children how to make the recipe with raw mango, jaggery, tamarind, neem flowers, chilli and salt, she said the novel coronavirus pandemic has brought families together. “Since my children were not out playing, they helped me.” Residents, who were confined to their homes, watched the live telecast of Panchanga Sravanam and other rituals performed in Tirumala.

Endowments minister A Indrakaran Reddy along with his family attended the state government’s Ugadi festivities held at the department’s offuce. Srinivas Bellam, a resident of Bhagyanagar Colony in Kukatpally, decorated his house with mango leaves, neem flowers and rangoli. “Ugadi signifies the beginning of Telugu New Year. This is a very auspicious day for Telugu people. I hope the gloom and fear of the virus is replaced with positivity and hope,” Srinivas, who is into facilities management, said.

Ramana Eshwaragiri of Tellapur said though this has been a quiet Ugadi, it has taught people to be kind and considerate. “In the wake of the coronavirus situation, the New Year should bring a better understanding among people to follow rules and refrain from going outside in the fight against coronavirus,” he said.

Title: Pune: Mandai finds unique way to maintain social distancing among veggie buyers
Content:
Citizens maintain distance while they wait for their turn to buy vegetables from a vendor in Mandai on Wednesd... Read More

PUNE: Mahatma Phule Mandai, one of the biggest vegetable markets in the city, has redesigned each stall in a way that customers and vendors deal with each other from a safe distance.

Each stall has been given a designated area, with markings to indicate where the customer must stand, to ease vendors’ operations.

Of the nearly 1,000 vegetable and fruit stalls at the market, only about 100 were functional on Wednesday. “The market will remain open between 7am and noon every day for the next three weeks,” Rajabhau Kasurde, president of Shet Maal Trader Association told TOI.

Kasurde said the city police had redesigned stalls in such a way that there would be at least 3 to 4 feet distance between two persons and the vendor. “We have also decided to appoint our personnel at five gates of the market. They would only allow 10 people to enter the market from one gate. It means, only 50 people can visit the market at a time,” he added.

On Wednesday, the police allowed people to visit the market. However, no vehicles are allowed in the market as of now. “We will to keep a tab on vendor activity as there is a chance that they would sell vegetables and fruits at high rate,” he said.

The system being followed at Mandai was first introduced by the Talegaon Dabhade Municipal Council (TBMC) two days ago. “We had to close the market for four days to avoid mass gathering here but that was not a prudent solution as people were facing trouble. Then we not only redesigned the stalls but also shifted or relocated vendors to 13 different location across the towns so that people would not come to one place for their purchases,” said TBMC chief officer Dipak Zinjad.

Title: Elected representatives in Telangana to keep eye on foreign returnees
Content: HYDERABAD: The Telangana government has issued orders directing the sarpanches in villages, councillors in towns and corporators in cities to keep an eye on those who have arrived from foreign countries on or after March 1.Chief secretary Somesh Kumar issued the orders directing the elected representatives to keep an eye on foreign returnees and keep the government informed about their health status in coordination with local police and medical and health officials. The orders were issued with instructions for strict compliance to control the spread of Covid-19.“All sarpanches, councillors and corporators should be directed to inform the arrival of a foreign returnee immediately. They should be sensitised about the fact that non-reporting of persons who have come from abroad in March will lead to endangering the lives of their own family members and also others,” stated the GOs.The orders further stated that people must dial 100 in an emergency. Prices of all essential commodities will also be monitored daily and violators shall be booked under PD Act.

Title: Hyderabad: Shelters at maximum capacity, homeless still at high risk
Content:
In Andhra too, homeless are left in the lurch due to a lack of shleters

HYDERABAD: The homeless across the city are at a higher risk of contracting coronavirus with only 12 functioning shelter homes here. According to GHMC, there is a dire need for an action plan to be charted out for the homeless amid the lockdown.

“Local corporators and MLAs have to step up and coordinate with GHMC, health, police and revenue departments to identify the homeless first. Currently, there is no action plan for the homeless, but they are the most vulnerable and exposed to the virus,” said an official.

While there are 12 working shelter homes with nearly 600 beds, they have reached their capacity. “Although each shelter home has been given 100 sanitizers, 1,000 masks and ration for over a month, there are still thousands of people, including migrant labourers, who are trying to travel to their homes. Some are even living with acquaintances in slums,” added the official.

The official said that community centres and educational institutions which are currently closed can be utilised to accommodate the homeless after sanitizing the space. “They will also have to be provided with ration but until now, no plan has been made,” said the official.

The private shelters also seem to be helpless as the homeless will need to be screened before being taken in. “The authorities can collaborate with NGOs. People can be sent to the care of shelter homes, but only after being screened. We cannot put the existing inmates at risk,” said George Rakesh Babu, from Good Samaritan’s India and the international human rights organisation director for elderly welfare and homeless.

The 21-day nationwide lockdown is especially scary for those on the streets. “We live on the streets, what precautions can we take? Neither we can go back home, nor sleep outside. I am scared but there is nothing much we can do,” said Mohammed, who came to the city from Odisha.

According to GHMC commissioner, Lokesh Kumar, the department plans to collaborate with 93 NGOs to give shelter to the homeless during the lockdown. “There are around 2,600 homeless who were previously identified, but the number is expected to have increased given the current situation. The 93 NGOs working with GHMC will be asked to accommodate the homeless,” said Lokesh Kumar.

Title: Hyderabad: Annapurna canteens turn life-savers for daily wagers
Content: HYDERABAD: Annapurna canteens which offer meals at Rs 5 proved to be life-savers for several daily wage workers on Wednesday. A video of a worker who walked from Moosapet to Jubilee Hills for his meal has become viral all over social media. “I came from Moosapet to Jubliee Hills on foot. There was an Annapurna canteen in Moosapet but the food was over. As there is no public transport I had to walk,” said Sreekanth, the daily wage worker.Presently, there are 151 canteens under GHMC limits of which 20 re-opened on Tuesday. “We are asking people to eat it somewhere far away from the stall and throw the plate in a dustbin,” a GHMC official said. In areas where canteens were closed, IT employees along with NGOs and activists helped to provide meals to workers.Some GHMC corporators were also seen distributing food on Wednesday. “In three days, we distributed food 600 food packets in parts of Madhapur, Kukatpally and Gachibowli. NGOs and GHMC officials of Kukatpally zone helped us too,” said Sai Teja, an activist from the city.The GHMC has now decided to open all canteens. “We are planning to make all the canteens across the city operational by Thursday. We are approaching companies too,” said a GHMC official.

Title: Hyderabad: After glitches, e-commerce firms to restore supply
Content: HYDERABAD: Following an assurance from the authorities that delivery agents and trucks delivering goods would not be stopped by cops, all the major e-commerce companies have decided to resume operations from Thursday. On Wednesday evening, some e-commerce websites issued a statement that they are operational following the assurance from the authorities concerned.Companies which deliver essential goods to homes had stopped functioning on Wednesday citing police action. Following this, a high-level meeting was held by IT and industries secretary Jayesh Ranjan with police commissioner and representatives of these companies. “Online stores will be operational from Thursday. Police will coordinate and ensure that essential goods and services’ supply is not affected,” the IT secretary said.Flipkart had said their trucks and delivery boys were stopped by police. “There were multiple reasons for services being closed on Tuesday and Wednesday. Since it was a lockdown, we were not sure whether we would be allowed on the road,” said S Sheeta, a spokesperson for Flipkart. The Flipkart spokesperson said they were resuming services immediately following assurances from the government. Meanwhile, a BigBasket respresentative said they were experiencing unprecedented demand and would resume operations.“Our top priority at this time is to get the products customers need most... to arrive safely and timely at our customers’ homes. We appreciate the government has recognised ecommerce as essential to help citizens remain at home and maintain social distancing. We are working with the central government and local authorities, asking them to help us urgently with detailed on-ground operating procedures...,” said an Amazon spokesperson.Earlier in the day, people who depend on home deliveries reached out to municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao on Twitter and voiced their concerns. KTR directed Jayesh Ranjan to look into the matter and resolve the issue. Ranjan said all issues had been sorted out and hoped that regular supplies would resume on Thursday. He asked the companies to obtain passes for their delivery staff and vehicles.

Title: Only professionals can give HCQ tablets: Doctors in Telangana
Content: HYDERABAD: Prompted by social media messages, many residents are now landing up at their local medical stores to buy HCQ ( hydroxychloroquine ) tablets — a medicine that doctors say should only be used by healthcare professionals treating coronavirus patients. The rush has led to the shortage of the drug.HCQ is an anti-malarial drug and is supposed to be sold only on prescription. Yet many managed to get it over-the-counter. “This panic buying has resulted in a shortage of the drug for medical professionals and now the health authorities have issued clear orders for supply of the drug only to health facilities,” said Dr Ravi Shankar, a senior cardiologist.“This drug should not be taken without a doctor’s advice. It can be especially fatal if taken by people with heart diseases. Side effects include QT prolongation in EGC, leading to a sudden death. We have come to know that people are randomly purchasing it and having it thinking that it will work like a vaccine against Covid-19. I strongly advise people not to use it.”Other cities apart from Hyderabad are also witnessing a similar situation, health officials claimed. In fact, the Government of National Capital Territory of Delhi (Drugs Control Department), issued a letter to the All Chemists Association of Delhi, on Wednesday, asking them not to sell the drug to anyone without the prescription of a registered medical practitioner. “Any deviation in this regard by any of the chemists/druggists will be viewed seriously and stringent action as per Drugs & Cosmetics Rules will be initiated against them,” the advisory stated.But while supply of HCQ has been hit, drug supplies say that there is no shortage of regular drugs at the moment. “Right now there is stock, but the problem is distribution, especially to far-off locations...We have requested the police commissioner to allow the staff, distributors and dealers’ movement by showing their ID cards and letters on our letter head,” said Ramesh Chandragupta, president Chemist and Druggist Association, Telangana.

Title: Pune Civic body to geo-tag open gyms to keep a tab on funds utilization
Content: PUNE: The civic body, in a bid to track the utilization of funds, has decided to geo-tag the open gyms across the city.Pune Municipal Corporation has spent Rs 9 crore on these gyms in the past two years and approved another Rs4.5 crore recently. The fresh allocation has come under the scanner, as reports about the current status of the gyms set up earlier are missing.“Many citizens have demanded such facilities. People out on morning walks or jogging use them. The decision to approve the proposal was taken by the standing committee,” said Hemant Rasane, head of PMC’s standing committee.According to PMC’s documents, the civic officials had made remarks about checking the earlier approved facilities before giving approval for new open gyms. Additional PMC commissioner Shantanu Goel told reporters that no such cross-verification was done. “We have decided to geo-tag the open gyms so that citizens will be able to locate these facilities,” he said.Civic officials said the equipment for open gyms are purchased as per the demand. Elected members put up proposals and the procurement was done after due approvals. These open gyms are set up on footpaths, gardens, sports grounds and community halls.Some of these equipment include single chest press, elliptical cross trainers, inversion machine, push bars, single-seated puller, sitting and standing twister, sit-up board double, Surf boards, Air walker, Thi-Chi Spinner, bench with fixed dumbbell and pommel horse.

Title: Coronavirus Update in Hyderabad: New methods devised to ensure social distancing in Hyderabad
Content: HYDERABAD: To curb the threat of coronavirus , residents across the city have taken it upon themselves to devise ways of practising and encouraging social distancing within their communities. From adopting a token (or slot) system to inviting a limited number of local vendors inside their apartment complexes, residents have stepped in to avoid overcrowding at in-house supermarkets and grocery stores.These systems have restricted the number of people making purchases at a given time. “All residents have to register on the gated community mobile application for tokens. Only 20 token holders are being allowed to make purchases at a time in an hour,” said Shikha Gupta, a resident of community in Nallagandla . In some areas, residents also helped their neighbours with grocery shopping, to reduce the number of people stepping out.Similarly, all residents stepping out to purchase essentials at a gated community in Manikonda divided slots on first-come-first-serve basis. “There are two shops within the society – a vegetable shop and a grocery store. For both the shops, separate slots are being issued to the residents. Fifteen minutes before our slot, they remind us and ask us to come for shopping,” said Robin Chatterjee, resident of the community. Some communities also collaborated with local vendors to deliver on particular days.The GHMC , on its part, too rolled out unique measures to propagate social distancing. The assistant medical officers of health outlined circles in front of several stores in Serilingampally and Kukatpally circles to earmark spaces for people to stand, at a distance from each other, while waiting for their turn.Apart from helping each other with preventive measures, residents of many colonies in the city also made a concentrated effort to curb rumour-mongering. “There are a lot of conjectures doing the rounds on our apartment WhatsApp group. We are trying to tell people to refrain from such activity and instead concentrate on keeping themselves and their families healthy,” said Goutham R from Somajiguda.

Title: Don’t panic if you test positive, says patient in awareness video
Content: NAGPUR: One of the three Covid-19 positive patients admitted in the GMCH isolation ward has come out with a 4-minute awareness video clip on Wednesday. This clip, made with the help of the company in which he works, is being largely circulated on social media to make people aware of the reality that Covid-19 can be defeated.In this video, the patient interacts with viewers to share his own experience of being tested positive for Covid-19. “It was a shock for me and was very difficult to digest, but I must say I was mentally prepared a bit as one of my colleagues had already tested positive,” the patient wearing a mask on his face, says. The video has been made on a smart phone by him only.Speaking about his treatment, he says he was asymptomatic carrier of the coronavirus and doctors advised him full isolation for 14 days. “I was not facing any health problem but decided to keep myself in isolation to stop the spread of virus. I used to wake up early, sleep on time, and follow my daily routine during these 14 days,” he says. He also thanks his company that arranged cab service for his family members due to which he received fresh food, snacks and tea daily on time.On a final note, the patient gives four recommendations to others in case they test positive. “Don’t panic. Get ready for 14 days of isolation. Focus on maintaining good physical and mental health. It is important to have a good immune system and your immune system only fights against the virus. Finally, have a good plan to effectively use your time during isolation,” he concludes.

Title: Six samples tested negative for Covid-19 in Bareilly
Content: BAREILLY: Samples of six persons which were collected in the last two days, tested negative for novel coronavirus (Covid-19). Bareilly has not reported any positive case of Covid-19 so far, and health officials said they should not heed rumours on social media. Though no confirmed case has been reported, some fake messages are being circulated on social media that a Bareilly resident has tested positive.Elsewhere, a 19-year-old boy was admitted in the isolation ward of district hospital on Wednesday, after he showed symptoms of Covid-19.Additional chief medical officer Dr Ranjan Gautam said, “In the last two months, we had collected samples of 21 people who showed symptoms of Covid-19 in Bareilly. Of these, 18 people have tested negative, while the reports of three cases are awaited.”In Bareilly, samples of suspected cases are currently being collected only at district hospital. Health officials said they are currently checking facilities of sample collection at other private medical colleges, and if they are equipped with necessary kits, they will be given permission to collect samples. However, the health department will send samples to a government laboratory in Lucknow for testing.

Title: Seafood exporters from Telugu states seek central aid
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: Seafood exporters from Telugu states have sought financial assistance from the Centre, as demand from Europe, USA and China has taken a serious hit.

“Several small exporters and a few large players have been affected as sales have dropped from more than 100 shipments to 20 shipments now,” a senior official from Seafood Exporters Association of India told TOI.

Exporters from the two Telugu states are afraid they might be penalized if they don’t ship the goods in the given time period. “The government should relax the deadline for shipping. Companies with good presence in Chinese and European markets were impacted as demand has fallen significantly since February,” he added.

The worsening situation due to Covid-19 could hamper the movement of marine consignments to foreign destinations. “The lockdowns have also led to wholesalers and processors declining our products,” said Vishwanath, a seafood exporter from Zaheerabad. The European market has totally cut itself off and there is negligible procurement from the Chinese market. However, representatives of seafood associations said restaurants in China had reopened and that should result in increase in exporters business

Title: Summer rain with thunder and hail in some pockets
Content:
Pune: In a 14-hour time block, starting from early Wednesday till 5.30pm, Pune received its first spell of summer rain with thundershowers and hail.

Light rains and thunderstorm began in Pune around 3.30am on Wednesday, followed by sunny skies during the day. The city witnessed its next spell of thundershowers around 2pm on Wednesday, which gave Shivajinagar 1.8mm rain in a few hours. As is with localised thundershower activity, Lohegaon recorded no rainfall on Wednesday.

Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD, Pune, said the thundershowers on Wednesday were localised as some areas received rain while others did not. “A few areas like Kondhwa, NIBM Road witnessed hail activity too. We expect thunder showers to continue on Thursday as well in Pune city with more or less the same intensity as Wednesday,” he said.

“We are working from home and the heavy rain caused a power outage for around an hour and a half. My laptop was charging while I was working and after the power went off, the battery died soon while I was in the middle of something important,” Suresh Kumar, who works in an IT firm and lives in a housing society in the area, told TOI.

It also rained in Bhusari Colony and Bavdhan areas for about 30 minutes in the afternoon. “As soon as it started raining, the power supply went off for some time. Bhosari area also received heavy rain between 3am and 4am on Wednesday, a resident said.

Tuesday’s systems have become less marked but there is a trough at the lower atmospheric level persisting from East Central Arabian Sea to South Madhya Pradesh via South Konkan and South Central Madhya Maharashtra. These systems are dragging moisture from the Arabian Sea.
