The trough in the easterlies from north interior Karnataka to East Rajasthan via Madhya Maharashtra is also influencing the weather over Maharashtra, Kashyapi added.

“We expect generally cloudy skies and very light to light rain in Pune on Thursday as well while the rainfall activity is likely to reduce from March 28. But once again, from March 29 for a couple of days there would be generally cloudy skies with a possibility of light rain. These rain spells are expected to recur during the next few days because there is enough moisture over the state,” he said.

Since the temperatures have been increasing, the moisture availability and high temperature are triggering local convective activity in the afternoon.

IMD rainfall data on Wednesday showed that locations like Jalgaon, Solapur and Nashik received trace rainfall while Mahabaleshwar received moderate rainfall at 33mm.

Among IMD’s regular stations in Vidarbha, only Buldhana recorded rain on Wednesday at 9mm.

Title: Low-key Gudi Padwa celebrations minus big buys as shops stay shut in Pune
Content:
Residents of Narayan Peth wear masks while celebrating Gudi Padwa on Wednesday

PUNE: Markets across the city remained closed on the auspicious occasion of Gudi Pawda for the first time in decades.

The festival, which fell on the first day of the national lockdown, was celebrated by families in Pune by hoisting the Gudi and with traditional food.

Kothrud resident Siddharth Date said, “Though Gudi Padwa celebrations were low-key, many families in my area celebrated it with zeal. My mother is not in the city and so my wife and I did all the preparations. When I stepped out to buy fruits and other essentials, I saw the roads were deserted but Gudis had been installed outside several households.”

He added that at their home, they installed a Gudi, and made a sumptuous meal. “I helped my wife with the cooking. She rolled the palak puris and I fried them. As part of Gudi Padwa celebrations, social visits to seek blessings of elders is common, but we refrained from doing so. I believe nobody stepped out for social visits this Gudi Padwa,” Date said.

An obstetrician and gynaecologist from the city, Manasi Naralkar, said, “We had a lovely family meal at home on the occasion of Gudi Padwa, cooked by my mother-in-law, Vidya. My husband helped clean the house for the festivities while I helped in the meal preps and washed the utensils. We also wished our family and friends virtually this year.”

Roads across the city were empty and the shutters of shops were down. An auspicious occasion to purchase gold, valuables, vehicles and white goods, this Gudi Padwa recorded no sales as traders refused to open stores even for the festival. A Dhayari resident Sachin Jadhav said, “It was a strange feeling this year. Empty roads and everything shut. Our prayers this year are for the entire world. We performed a small puja with immediate family on Gudi Padwa and prayed for this outbreak to stop. It was a very different Gudi padwa this year.”

Prominent jeweller Fatehchand Ranka said, “I got several calls and enquiries from Punekars wanting to buy gold today. Many even told me to open the back door of the store so that they could make purchases. However, lives are more precious and I had to turn them down. I requested everyone to make a double purchase during the next festival if it was so important but told them that the shop will not open on Wednesday.”

Title: Delhi lockdown: Food delivery chains have too much on plate
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: Despite food delivery being one of the services exempted from the lockdown, reports are coming in from across India of kitchens being forced shut, delivery executives being roughed up and colonies denying them entry into residential complexes. Finally on Wednesday, state governments and local police took note. Food delivery outlets and online players spent the day applying for movement passes for their staff and delivery personnel.

Many people in Delhi heaved a sigh of relief because they rely on food delivery for their meals. Arushi Menon, 24, a communications professional living in south Delhi’s Alaknanda, had no stash of groceries at home and was worried when her food provider messaged her that police were not allowing deliveries. “Delivery services are hampered by staff problems or claim they are being stopped by police. Directions on how people like us can cope with the lockdown will be helpful,” Menon said.

Ankit Thukral, an IT professional who moved recently to the city, with his long work hours, does not have the luxury of organising a kitchen at home or hiring a cook. Not fully clear about how long he would be in the capital, he only kept the minimum of provisions at home, managing mostly on food ordered in. “Many of us do not even have gas connections or water filters. We depend on online food and water services,” he said.

Karan Nambiar of Big City Pizzas and Captain Grub said the ban on interstate travelling was deterring his cooks from reporting to work, while Vishal Jindal of Biryani by Kilo said many of his kitchens were not being allowed to run.

A Swiggy spokesperson acknowledged the supply problems caused by the temporary closure of restaurants located in the closed malls. However, the company assured it was working with the authorities to remain operational. Similarly, the spokesperson for Zomato said, “Our delivery partners are facing hurdles in many cities while trying to deliver food, which has been classified as an essential service. We are communicating with the relevant authorities and hoping these issues are sorted soon.”

Samir Modi, founder 24Seven convenience stores, explained his commissaries were closed due to employees fearing for their personal security if they reported for work. “We are working only from 9am to 7pm because of reduced staff and supplies,” Modi said, adding that the chain has applied for permissions to get all the outlets fully operational.

Clarifications from both central and state governments eased many concerns by Wednesday evening. “There are three authorities in Delhi-NCR. One is the central government, the other, Delhi government and third, the RWAs,” sigh a food delivery operator. “While the guidelines of the two governments are now clear, the RWAs have their own laws and this is cause for confusion and panic at times like this.”

Title: Hyderabad: KVs to promote all students of class 1-8
Content:
Representational image

HYDERABAD: Kendriya Vidyalaya Sangathan (KVS) has decided to promote all students of classes 1 to 8 irrespective of whether or not they appeared for exams. The principals at KVs in the city said they received a communication from the Sangathan directing them not to conduct any improvement exams , even for students who failed or remained absent in the annual examinations.

“We received a communication from the board asking us not to conduct improvement exams for students up to class 8. Generally, improvement exams are conducted after annual examinations for students who have backlogs,” said Ch Sreenivasulu , principal at KV, Bolarum. He said that students (class 1 to class 8) had already appeared for annual examinations and irrespective of the outcome, they will be promoted to the next class.

Meanwhile, parents and child-right activists demanded that the state cancels annual examinations in schools affiliated to state board.

“My son is currently in class 8 and his school is yet to conduct the annual examinations. The school principal is asking us to ensure that he prepares for the exams daily so that he can appear for them when the school reopens. In the current situation, it would be better if annual examinations are cancelled and students are directly promoted to next class,” said V Satyanarayana, a parent.

Title: Maharashtra: Trucks allowed passage after Shashi Tharoor tweet
Content:
Shashi Tharoor, MP (File Photo)

PUNE: Truckers from across the country stranded in the state breathed a sigh of relief with the Maharashtra government permitting plying of empty trucks on highways.

The state government has also made arrangements for food and essentials for truckers along the highways. MP Shashi Tharoor recently tweeted to the Maharashtra chief minister’s office about truck drivers from Kerala being held up at Bhiwandi without food, water or toilet facilities.

His tweet mentioned that the drivers were returning home in empty vehicles after delivering fruit and vegetables in Gujarat. He sought instructions from the government to the police to allow the drivers to go to Kerala. “The conditions are poor and police are behaving inhumanly. Please help. The four hours from PM’s speech to #lockdownindia were not enough for truck drivers to drive back from Gujarat to Kerala! Please help,” his tweet read.

Speaking to TOI over the phone from New Delhi, Tharoor said, “I received several forwards containing recorded Whatsapp messages by drivers who were stuck. First, they got held up at the Maharashtra-Gujarat border while returning to Kerala. Later, they were not permitted to move beyond Bhiwandi. They had to park in abandoned quarries without food or water. Since I did not have a direct contact with Maharashtra government, I tweeted about it.”

He said that the Maharashtra government responded immediately. “The CMO called me, but could not reach me. On Wednesday, Aditya (Thackeray) called me to inform that the truckers have moved on,” Tharoor said.

State transport commissioner Shekhar Channe confirmed that the problem had persisted till Tuesday, but it was taken care of by Wednesday. “We have instructed the authorities on the highways to allow movement of trucks. If a trucker has dropped some goods in the state and is going back to his base, he will be allowed. The same holds for trucks which are on move with goods. In many cases, trucks carry essential commodities and cannot be stopped,” he stated.

Title: RTO likely to register major drop in vehicle registration in Pune
Content:
Representative Image

PUNE: The Pune regional transport office (RTO) is likely to record a major drop in registration of new vehicles during the Gudi Padwa period, officials told TOI.

The automobile dealers are also concerned over their stock of BS-IV vehicles which have remained largely unsold due to the Covid-19 scare and lockdown , said officials.

“While we cannot provide the figures as the staff strength at the RTO is minimal and the 21-day lockdown means that exact figures can only be arrived at later. However, the registration of new vehicles has been minimal. The registrations take place through the dealers who have demanded an extension for registration of BS-IV vehicles as their stocks have remained unsold,” an RTO official said.

Virmeet Singh Maini, president, Pune Auto Dealers’ Association, said that the automobile industry, which is already facing a slowdown, is among the worst hit.

“The number of new registration of vehicles has been negligible. The showrooms have been shut down for days altogether. And now with the 21-day lockdown, it will remain the same. Though the BS-VI version of different brands is already out, there have been fewer registrations. The BS-IV stock is still with us. The RTO had said that they will not register the BS-IV vehicles after March 31. But the stocks have not been cleared due to the virus scare and lockdown. The Union government should help us by extending the deadline to at least June or July,” he said.

In 2018, a total of 7,279 vehicles were registered with the Pune RTO during the week leading to Gudi Padwa. In 2019, the figures had dropped to 7,198. In 2017, as many as 5,500 vehicles were registered. In 2019, the RTO had collected a revenue of around Rs33 crore from registrations. The revenue earned in 2018 was Rs31 crore.

The RTO officials said that with fewer registrations taking place during Gudi Padwa, there would be a major drop in revenue.

Abhay Jagtap, a Kondhwa resident, had planned to buy a four- wheeler this year during the festival. “We had decided to go to the showroom last week to book a vehicle and take delivery on Wednesday. However, our plans have now gone for a toss due to the lockdown. So, we have dropped the idea,” he said.

Title: Cops lose cool, Nagpur citizens feel the heat
Content: NAGPUR: Many citizens were at the receiving end of the flying temper of cops enforcing the lockdown on Wednesday, after Prime Minister Narendra Modi extended the restrictions till April 15 to break the coronavirus chain. Some questioned the harsh attitude at places, which has marred the general appreciation for the police force and their humanitarian effort displayed elsewhere.Guardian minister Nitin Raut, along with divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar, city police chief BK Upadhyay and other officials toured various markets in the city on Wednesday, including Kalamna, Jaripatka, Khamla, Gokulpeth and others, following complaints of short supply of essential commodities and disruption of emergency services.“We checked the availability of essential commodities and also emergency services, and are satisfied to find them in place. I have instructed police, civic and district administration to keep tabs on essential commodities and report any short supply immediately,” Raut said. He promised to ensure that no one is deprived of basic needs during the lockdown. “Public is in self-defence mode and situation is under control,” he said.“I have told police to keep a vigil on the colonies and report short supplies immediately. Similarly, the civic administration has been asked to collect information on availability of essential commodities and emergency services through their zonal office. District collector too has been asked to rope in NGOs to supply essential commodities,” he said. Raut said there should be no power cuts or inadequate water supply.The rising heat, with outside temperature touching 35 degree Celsius at noon, apart from Maharashtrian festival of Gudi Padwa , onset of Chaitra Navaratri and Sindhi community’s Cheti Chand has already done half the work of the cops by keeping people in their homes. However, their rising temper at a few places left citizens with a bitter taste. Around 324 violators were detained while six offences were registered related to breach of norms in the backdrop of Covid-19 virus scare.Though cops had begun on a strict note earlier this week, the enforcement had a more moderate approach, allowing unhindered movement of citizens with passes from the police stations a day ago. City police had started issuing passes to citizens for movement in vehicles for genuine reasons, like procuring essential commodities and availing emergency services. On Tuesday, 4,156 passes were distributed from different police stations.Some stray cases of police manhandling citizens were reported on social media too. A man was struck with canes by the cops at Mate Chowk when he was heading to a grocery shop with his father. In another incident, also at Mate Chowk, a man was beaten by cops when he was going to purchase medicines with his father-in-law. In Pachpaoli, citizens also claimed that a police volunteer was found beating citizens with a cane.Another citizen shared an ugly experience of having to cough up Rs300 at Durga Mata Mandir Chowk near Chhaoni to cops to ensure his two-wheeler was not seized. “I was wrong in venturing out without a police pass but that does not mean the police should extort Rs300 from me,” he said.City police chief BJ Upadhyay has asked officers to ensure personnel working on the roads refrain from using more than moderate force on citizens. “I have sought a report from senior PIs against the constables who manhandled citizens on the road. There is an instruction to avoid tough means without reason,” he said.On the other hand, traffic API at Sitabuldi Chowk helped a woman reach Kamptee when she was stranded without vehicles. He ensured that the woman was helped by two other commuters who were heading towards Kamptee. “They ended up travelling triple seat, but I ensured they were not penalized anywhere as it was important for the woman to reach Kamptee without public transport,” he said.

Title: Vegetable prices soar giving a hard time to consumers
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Prices of some of the vegetables in the city nearly doubled in the past two days giving a hard time to consumers.

The price of tomato, which was Rs 30 per kg rose to Rs 60 per kg on Wednesday. Shallots were sold at Rs 80 per kg.

The price of beans also doubled within a week as it hiked from Rs 60 to Rs 120 per kg.

The merchants said that there has been a delay in procurement of vegetables which has resulted in the price rise.

“Usually trucks deliver the items from neighbouring states on a daily basis. The delivery has been halted for two days which now reflects in vegetable prices. Without goods arriving on a regular basis there are chances of further increase in price,” said Chandran, a vegetable vendor at Palayam.

Babu a wholesale dealer said that panic buying by some of the residents also resulted in shortage, which forced merchants to increase the price.

“We tell our customers to purchase only what is required,” said Rajan, another vegetable vendor at Palayam market.

The merchants in Chalai said that prices of only some of the vegetables have risen and once goods movement from the border gets smoothened, the prices would come down.

Owing to lockdown, the shops in Chalai and Palayam market wore a deserted look. However, some of the customers turned up to purchase essential commodities, regardless of the price. “We have to purchase things because there is no other way. I came today to purchase commodities for one week,” said Smitha, a resident of Kumarapuram.

Meanwhile, in a meeting of Thiruvananthapuram and Kanyakumari collectors held at Kovalam here on Wednesday, it was decided that goods transport would not be blocked on Thiruvananthapuram-Kanyakumari border.

Only two persons including driver shall be allowed to travel in goods vehicles.

Title: Criminal held, 14 burglary and theft cases detected in Pune
Content:
Representative Image

PUNE: The crime branch of the Pimpri Chinchwad police on Monday claimed to have detected 14 burglary and theft cases with the arrest of a criminal on police records.

The police have recovered gold and silver ornaments and two scooters, collectively worth Rs 15.13 lakh, from Rafiq Shaikh (26) of Hadapsar, who was arrested by a crime branch team led by inspector Mohan Shinde.

Assistant commissioner of police Shridhar Jadhav told TOI Shaikh was taken into custody from Sangvi following a tip-off. “Shaikh has 24 cases against him with the Pune police,” he said. He said the police detected 14 cases, including 12 burglaries and two vehicles thefts, which occurred in the last eight months. “Of these, three cases are from Pimpri Chinchwad, while 11 from different police stations in Pune,” Jadhav said.

Explaining the modus of the suspect, assistant inspector Ambarish Deshmukh said during the day, Shaikh used to carry out recce of locked houses on ground floors. “During the night, he used to break locks of the pre-decided houses by using a bicycle stand before fleeing with the valuables,” Deshmukh said.He said the police were probing if Shaikh was involved in more cases.

Title: 45 pilgrims return to Karur, sent to home quarantine
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: All the 45 residents of Karur district who have returned from Maharashtra and Andhra Pradesh after a pilgrimage on Wednesday underwent medical examination.

As they didn’t show any symptoms of Covid-19, doctors have instructed them to be in home quarantine for 28 days and approach doctors in case of any symptoms such as fever, sore throat and breathing difficulties.

The pilgrims from Vedichipalayam village started their journey from Karur on March 6 on a hired bus to the neighbouring states. As soon as they returned on Wednesday morning, they were taken to a government primary health centre at Vangal where a medical team examined them. The bus they had travelled was sanitised with disinfectants and the pilgrims were offered hand sanitisers and mask.

They have been advised to take food that boosts immunity and maintain social distance with family members at home. Officials from the revenue department said that the 45 people would be monitored for the next one month. They are the second batch of pilgrims who have returned from pilgrimage to other states. TNN

Title: Trichy: Panic buying continues even after government promises to protect food supply
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: To stock groceries and essential commodities, people continued to crowd retail outlets and grocery shops in and around the city on Wednesday morning as well. The shops witnessed panic buying on Tuesday as well following Prime Minister Narendra Modi ’s call for the 21-day lockdown . In some places police had to ask shop owners to down shutters for a while to disperse the crowd. Panic shopping could not be avoided despite the promises made by the PM and chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami that the supply of essential commodities will not be affected.

A grocery shop owner in Kallukuzhi of Trichy said that people were shopping more than the usual. Since the lockdown is in effect for the next 21 days, they fear shortage of supply and want to stock more food stuff.

“Some of the retailers had to return without buying vegetables from the Gandhi market as the stock was finished in the morning. If the situation continues in the coming days, the prices of vegetables may go up in the coming days,” said the shop owner.

Crowd started thinning by the afternoon following measures taken by the administration by restricting people outdoors. There was a large gathering at Gandhi market on Wednesday. Apart from the whole sale sellers, public too gathered in the market to purchase vegetables.

Asking people to avoid gathering at one place during the lockdown period, Trichy district collector S Sivarasu said that only whole sale sellers with identity cards will be allowed in the Gandhi market. Saying that stringent action will be initiated against people who try to visit Gandhi market for vegetables, he asked people to visit nearby vegetable outlets.

Title: Lockdown hits salt production in Vedaranyam
Content:
Representative image

NAGAPATTINAM: The curfew in place from Tuesday evening has halted the movement of tonnes of salt from the salterns in Vedaranyam to various states in the country, as truckers are asked not to operate their vehicles. Saltpan owners say that this would lead to revenue loss worth lakhs of rupees.

To curtail the spread of Covid-19, the state government has imposed a curfew from 6 pm on Tuesday. Meanwhile, on the same say Prime Minister Narendra Modi has announced a lockdown until April 14. This has brought the production as well as the movement of tonnes of salt worth several lakhs of rupees to a grinding halt in Vedaranyam in the district. Around 75,000 tonnes of salt, meant to transport across the state and the neighbouring states such as Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh , are lying in the salterns owing to the curfew, saltpan owners said.

Salt is being produced in about 9,000 acres in Vedaranyam, Agasthiyampalli and Kodiyakkarai coast of which nearly 6,000 acres were run by two corporates companies. The remaining 3,000 acres are owned by about 900 individual licensees affiliated to Vedaranyam Small and Medium Scale Salt Producers’ Federation.

Around 2,250 tonnes salt is being produced in 9,000 acres on a daily basis, where around 10,000 people are working. Nearly 5,000 people are benefitted indirectly from the salterns, V Senthil, secretary of the federation, said. “Every day we produce salt worth Rs 17 lakh. However, the entire work has been stalled. Though this is not a peak season for production, but we will face revenue loss to the tune of Rs 17 lakh per day. Moreover, around 75,000 tonnes of salt are kept on the salterns itself, as we are not able to transport it,” Senthil added.

Title: Trichy: Many throw curfew rules to wind on day 1, face music
Content: TRICHY: Policemen and the district administrations had a tough time enforcing the precautions being taken over Covid-19 on the first day of curfew on Wednesday as violators continued to swarm the roads on bikes in Trichy and seven districts. In all, 216 violators were booked while the district administration closed down all tea shops.The morning turned out to be a new experience for most of the people who were witnessing a curfew for the first time. Indeed, most of them stayed indoors, but Trichy region saw many moving around on bikes and cars.A visit to some parts of Trichy city showed that most people who were stopped by the police cited medical emergency for moving out. While some managed to convince the police, many were turned back. The police allowed some migrant workers to leave for Karur with their family members and their belongings on mopeds.“As per the reports, several people continue to move on the road for no reason. It should be curtailed so that the purpose of the curfew will be served. As of now, we are doing it as advisory. I have ordered our policemen to book the violators after this evening,” city police commissioner V Varadharaju told TOI.In Trichy city, the police booked two people for organizing swimming coaching to 15 students in Sethuraman Pillai colony, one person for allowing crowd in a roadside eatery and another person for engaging labourers in construction work.In the central zone, a total of 166 cases including 52 in Trichy rural, 40 in Pudukottai ,, nine in Karur, 12 each in Perambalur and Ariyalur, 57 in Thanjavur, 20 in Tiruvarur and 11 in Nagappattinam were registered for violating the curfew.The commissioner also said that the violators will be booked and arrested for disobeying the lawful order, negligent act likely to spread infectious disease, disobedience to quarantine etc under sections of IPC, Epidemic Diseases Act and Tamil Nadu Public Health Act.While most of the tea shops remained closed, some served their customers from the early hours. What was worrying was that all the shops were crowded with the customers sipping the tea

Title: Citizens take to video calls to stay connected during festive time in Pune
Content: PUNE: An increasing number of citizens are taking to video calls like never before to stay connected with their near and dear ones and wish them on Gudi Padwa amid the prevailing lockdown in the wake of the coronavirus spread.Kothrud resident Surabhi Pawar made an early morning video call to her parents staying in Bibvewadi on Wednesday to wish them on Gudi Padwa. “Every year, my parents used to invite me, my husband and kids for special lunch on Gudi Padwa. This year, however, we are celebrating the festival at home, while staying connected with others over video call,” she said.Like Pawar, a huge section of the society is using video call facility in their cellphones to wish friends and family on Gudi Padwa, besides sharing recipes and staying in touch with colleagues. Even close neighbours are making use of the facility to avoid visiting each other’s houses.Roshan Nilgiriwala, a Vimannagar resident, said, “I had hardly used this facility earlier. But now, I am using it daily for work or just to be in touch with my family.”Rashmi Supekar, a resident of Sinhagad Road, said, “My husband is stranded in Chennai, where he had gone for some office work. Now, we make use of video chat facility every day to keep a tab on each other.”Nikita Sharma, a resident of BT Kawade Road, has been using the facility to share and learn new recipes. Even the elderly have taken to the video calling facility on their cellphones. Senior citizen Vasant Gholkar of Kharadi said, “My wife had recently undergone a knee surgery and has to do her physiotherapy regularly. The physiotherapist conducts the sessions through the video call, something that we were not so used to earlier.”

Title: Savitribai Phule Pune University trains 16 librarians to upload study material online
Content:
The librarians started uploading the content remotely from Monday

PUNE: After designing an e-content portal to help students to learn from home, the Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) has now trained 16 college librarians to manage the study material.

All the librarians have started uploading the content remotely from Monday onto this portal. SPPU has also appealed to faculty from affiliated colleges to share their material, a statement said.

In the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak, all SPPU departments and colleges had shut last week. Teachers have been asked to work from home. In this backdrop, SPPU has created e-content portal (accessible on ‘http://econtent.unipune.ac.in’). Videos, lectures, notes, assignments, and PowerPoint presentations have already been uploaded on the website.

The librarians were trained via a webinar on March 22. In addition, 19 coordinators have been appointed to upload content from different subjects. Their names, email addresses, contact numbers and subjects have been circulated among institutes.

Title: Rajasthan: RAC constable on duty stabbed
Content: UDAIPUR: A constable from RAC , who was on duty with a medical team on the Rajasthan-Madhya Pradesh border in Pratapgarh was stabbed by unknown assailants. The injured constable Om Prakash Jat was attacked when he deterred three men passing through the route on a motorcycle on Tuesday late night.He stopped them from crossing the border due to the lockdown and asked them to return, however, the men didn't listen and one of them took out a knife and stabbed the constable on his neck. The attack was so sudden that the jawan couldn't save himself and the assailants fled from the spot.Om Prakash was taken to the nearest Chhoti Sadri Hospital, who was later referred to Udaipur. A case has been registered against unknown persons and police has launched a search for them.

Title: Delhi HC extends till May 15 all interim orders set to expire
Content: NEW DELHI: Taking suo motu note of the 21-day lockdown announced by the central government and the “extraordinary circumstances,” Delhi high court on Wednesday extended till May 15 all interim orders passed by it or by district courts that were about to expire on or after March 16.In a separate move, a panel of top eight judges of the high court also extended till April 15 the suspension of work in the high court and all subordinate courts. A bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and justices Siddharth Mridul and Talwant Singh took into account problems faced by litigants and lawyers due to the recent developments.The bench ordered “that in all matters pending before this court and courts subordinate to this court, wherein such interim orders issued were subsisting as on March 16, 2020 and expired or will expire thereafter, the same shall stand automatically extended till May 15, 2020 or until further orders, except where any orders to the contrary have been passed by the Supreme Court of India in any particular matter, during the intervening period.”In its order, the high court explained that in view of “lockdown in the state of Delhi and the extremely limited functioning of courts, routine matters have been adjourned en bloc to particular dates in the month of April...Thus advocates and litigants have not been in a position to appear in the said matters on or before March 16.”The bench also said if the extension of interim measures till May 15 causes hardship to a party to such proceeding, “they would be at liberty to seek appropriate relief, as may be advised”.HC suspended the work of all district courts till April 15.

Title: Deprived of essentials, Goans slam government’s management
Content:
‘Govt should have roped in NGOs to reach out to people’

MARGAO: Day one of the sudden 21-day lockdown of the state on Wednesday led to many people being deprived of their daily essentials leading to government facing flak from the citizens for what they called its “poor management skills” in dealing with stemming the spread of the novel coronavirus.Several people that TOI spoke to complained of not getting milk at their regular milk booths, while non-availability of newspapers left many of those relying on the print media for information, clueless about the government’s moves to tackle the crisis.The sudden lockdown has affected not only the marginalised but the affluent as well.“This is absurd. I don’t even have stocks that can last for two days. Though I have been following the updates on television and newspapers, I didn’t imagine this could lead to a lockdown,” Rajesh Sawant (name changed), a property dealer said, indicating that the severe shutdown measures have hit all sections of the society.President of International Human Rights Association (IHRA) – Goa, Navnath Khandeparker, said that the ill-thought-out measures of the state government added to the panic and chaos among the citizens.“The government has no doubt taken several steps to tackle the crisis of this magnitude, but given that government’s resources are limited, the government should have roped in voluntary and non-government organisations to reach out to the needy and vulnerable. How will people be able to survive without essentials? Even the elected representatives don’t seem to have been engaged in the task. The panicky situation that followed the Prime Minister’s address saw people rushing to grocery shops, defeating the very purpose of the intended measures. The government is talking of tomorrow, but people are suffering today, what about them?” Khandeparkar said.Echoing his views, wellknow physician Dr Oscar Rebello warned that the situation could lead to riots if people are unable to procure essential commodities.“Enforcing a lockdown without a system in place to allow people to procure essentials is beyond my imagination. There is no clarity on how people should buy their basic stuff. Making arrangement to facilitate people to purchase essentials should have been priority when such extreme measures are enforced. Grocery stores should have been kept open allowing in five persons at a time, and police should monitor and if people crowd, they have to act,” Rebello said.Principal of CES College, Cuncolim, Sanjay Dessai, said that multiple points of communication added to the confusion. “The task of conveying government’s directions should have been left to the district collectors and the entire district administration — BDOs, mamlatdars, talathis — should have been on the ground along with police, reaching out to people guiding them and reassuring them of all required support,” Dessai said.

Title: No word yet from Saudi on Haj: Telangana panel
Content: HYDERABAD: The Telangana State Haj Committee on Wednesday allayed fears of those bound for Haj pilgrimage in the wake of coronavirus threat.The committee said it has not received any official communication from Saudi Arabia on a possible cancellation of the annual pilgrimage scheduled in July-August this year.Despite the assurance, uncertainty continues over the pilgrimage, if the official communication from the Haj Committee of India is any indication.Social media has been agog with speculation that Haj-2020 will be cancelled to prevent the spread of the virus. About three million people from across the globe gather at Mecca. Saudi Arabia has already stopped issuing visas for Umrah or minor pilgrimage that is performed round the year.The rumours in the social media have been triggered following an announcement by a Saudi official to tour operators to not book hotels in Mecca and Medina for accommodation of Haj pilgrims this year.Telangana Haj Committee chairman Mohammad Masiullah Khan said as things stand now, Haj-2020 would be held.“There are all rumours in social media. There is no official communication to the Central Haj Committee from the government of Saudi Arabia. The Central Haj Committee in its latest communication on March 24 extended the last date for payment of second instalment for Haj- 2020. The last date is March 31. The second instalment can be paid along with the third instalment,” Khan added.Maqsood Ahmad Khan, chief executive officer, Haj Committee of India, in a communication to all state Haj committees, said: “Considering the uncertainty and the situation all over the world the declaration of the third instalment will be done after getting confirmation of the Haj and participation of Indians in Haj by Saudi Arabia.”He said Saudi Arabia has not yet decided on Haj-2020. “The latest communication from Saudi authorities has asked Haj operators to not make any new commitments for Haj this year,” he said.The Haj Committee of India has also clarified that the money paid so far by prospective pilgrims is safe and it would refund the amount in case of “any unexpected decision in the future”.About two lakh pilgrims from India, including 5,000 from Telangana, are scheduled to perform Haj this year. The Saudi government had increased India’s quota from 1.75 lakh to two lakh pilgrims last year.

Title: Tanot Mata temple remains closed on Navratra
Content: Jaisalmer: For the first time in its 1,200-year history, Tanot Mateshwari temple along the Indo-Pak border remained closed on Chaitra Navratra on Wednesday.Following instructions of the district administration, no functions were organised at the temple. A priest offered prayers, the video of which was posted on social media. The priest requested people to offer prayers on Navratra from home.Other temples in the district also remained closed on Navratra. Leading Shaktipeeth in the district are Tanot Mateshwari, Ghantiyali temple, Degrai Mata temple, Kale Dungar Rai Mata temple, Tembade Rai temple, Nabh Ka Dungar Mata temple, Gajroopsagar Swangia temple and Barmer’s Jasol Mata temple.

Title: Two Covid-19 patients at GMCH to complete 14 days, first test today
Content: NAGPUR: Two of the three Covid-19 positive patients admitted to Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) are completing their 14-day isolation period on Thursday. Their samples will be tested on Thursday and Friday (March 26 and March 27). If tested negative both the times, they will be declared free from the coronavirus infection.Meanwhile, on Wednesday, first positive Covid-19 patient, who is on road to recovery at the IGGMCH, was tested one more time as per protocol. His reports were pending. If tested negative, doctors will conduct physical check-up and chest x-ray of this patient on Thursday. “If the patient is found free from any lung infection, he will be given discharge,” said IGGMCH dean Dr Ajay Keoliya.Earlier in the day, food delivery cos stopped their services temporarily. Nagpur Municipal Corporation NMC ) has taken proactive steps and started health check-up of 1,200 delivery agents of various food delivery firms. First batch of 300 delivery agents reported at the MLA Hostel where they were screened for any symptoms like cough, throat infection and fever. They were also counselled about the food safety practices and hand hygiene. After all the delivery personnel are examined, food delivery app services will be restored in the city.In door-to-door containment drive conducted in 3km radius of houses of four positive patients, NMC found that five persons have been admitted to private hospitals. NMC team collected swab samples of these persons and sent to Mayo Hospital . The NMC had made it mandatory for private hospitals to inform it in case any patient with severe acute respiratory illness was admitted with them. Accordingly, the civic body received information about 12 such patients. The civic officials have also sent swab samples of these patients for testing to Mayo Hospital.NMC’s assistant medical officer (health) Dr Praveen Gantawar told TOI, “As of now, 13 samples have tested negative and reports of the remaining four is awaited.”It’s was another good day for Vidarbha as no new positive patient was recorded for ninth consecutive day on March 24. Four patients in Nagpur and three in the isolation ward of GMCH Yavatmal are also showing considerable improvement in their health. Two more isolated patients were discharged on Wednesday in Yavatmal.“Now, only four patients are there in the isolation ward. Three of them are positive and one a presumptive case. The swab sample of this suspect has been sent for testing and the lab report is awaited,” stated district collector MD Singh.In Chandrapur, six new persons with foreign travel history were quarantined on Wednesday. This has taken the number of total people under home and institutional observation to 44 in the district. So far, 48 persons have completed their 14 days of quarantine. No positive patient has been found in the district so far.Amravati collector Shailesh Naval informed that out of the 73 throat swabs tested for coronavirus to date, 68 have been found negative while reports of the rest five are awaited.

Title: Cops want all police stations sanitized
Content:
Cap

Vadodara: Hundreds of policemen are out on the streets to ensure that people d not expose themselves to the hazards of Coronavirus. However, when it comes to their personal sanitization, very little efforts have been done to keep the police personnel safe. Looking at this, police officials are demanding that police stations too need to be strictly sanitized by the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC).

Police are given facemasks and hand sanitizers to protect themselves from contracting the virus. Hand sanitizers have also been provided at every police station, but officials believe that these measures aren’t enough to protect them as they have to spend around 12 hours in the field, meeting different people.

Of the 2,700-strong police force, 90% staff is involved in field duties currently and the remaining 10% staff is handling work at 24 police stations and different branch offices.

“Right now the staff is involved in ensuring that lockdown is made totally effective and nobody comes out of their homes. Some of our colleagues are also involved in social work like feeding the poor people and stray animals — such acts that are doing under extraordinary circumstances,” said a police official.

“At the end of the day, the field staff is expected to come to the police station once before going home. So, the risk of them bringing in infection from outside to the police station, where even citizens come with their complaints, are much more. But the condition of the police stations remain the same,” the aggrieved official added.

Several inspectors, who head their respective police stations, too have voiced their concerns and want the civic body to properly sanitize their police stations too. The police officials have made an informal request regarding this to their higher-ups, but are yet to get a response. “We have already sanitized police lines and will also be taking up sanitization of police stations because that is a very important place. We have already provided hand sanitizers and sprays to all the police stations which the officials are using,” said police commissioner Anupam Singh Gahlaut.

Title: Class X public exam postponed in Goa
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Goa Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education on Wednesday said its Class X public exam, which was scheduled to begin on April 2, was postponed.

New dates will be announced at least 10 days prior to commencement of the exam.

The government had already cancelled the Class XII board exams in view of the Covid-19 situation. Only three subject papers were left to be answered. Dates for these papers will also be declared 10 days before they are held, Goa Board said. It has also announced that its answer sheet assessment camps to be held in Margao and Panaji stand cancelled until further orders.

Teachers have conveyed to their organisations that Class X exam work, including assessment, should ideally be completed latest by April 20, so that admission and other processes can run smoothly.

Title: Mandis open in Delhi, getting there a big struggle
Content: NEW DELHI: To ensure that vegetables and fruits continue to reach people without any hindrance, Agricultural Produce Marketing Committee (APMC) has started giving out passes to those involved in the supply chain for their easy movement in the city.While there is no scarcity of vegetables and fruits arriving in the capital, wholesale traders said that sending it to retail markets was a challenge. Because of the lockdown, the retailers are finding it difficult to reach the wholesale market.APMC chairman Adil Ahmad Khan said about 2,500 passes were issued on Wednesday to wholesalers, trucks, tempos and local transport vehicles. About 400 identity cards were issued to sanitation and security staff working at Asia’s largest wholesale vegetable and fruit market at Azadpur.“We got complaints of truckers finding it difficult to bring the supplies to Azadpur and to the retail markets. We held a meeting today and decided to issue passes to them. A copy of these passes has been sent to the local and traffic police so that they are not stopped anywhere,” Khan told TOI.Vegetable traders’ association general secretary Anil Malhotra alleged that wholesalers and staff were not able to reach Azadpur mandi leading to rotting of the stock of perishable items.“Government agencies, including the corporations, police and officials of the SDM office, should go to large retail vegetable markets and issue passes to the vendors. It is okay if they let the mandis function for just 2-3 days in a week, but they should devise a mechanism so that vegetables and fruits reach the local markets,” Malhotra said.Meanwhile, prices of all commodities started soaring forcing buyers to stock up large quantities. Abhimanyu Singh, an IT professional living in Malviya Nagar, said he bought huge quantities of potato, onion, tomato and other vegetables at almost three times the usual rates.However, Ghazipur APMC chairman Satyadev Gupta said that retailers in east Delhi, Ghaziabad and Noida increased the prices to maximise profits even though there was no scarcity.

Title: Soaps, sanitisers to fight virus at fair price shops in Telangana
Content: HYDERABAD: The Telangana government on Wednesday decided to utilise biometric equipment installed at fair price shops for distribution of 12 kg rice per person free of cost to white card holders.Sources said that care will be taken to sanitise the biometric equipment as well as the card holder for every transaction as a preventive measure against spread of coronavirus . Sanitisers and soaps would be in place at fair price shops.While the distribution of rice commenced in Karimnagar district on Wednesday, it will start in parts of Hyderabad, Rangareddy and Medchal on Thursday. The rice distribution in remaining parts of the state will start from Friday.The biometric system is being used to ensure that the rice meant for supply to the poor and needy is not diverted and the government has an exact data of which of the white ration card holders had come out to avail the rice and cash offer. “Plans are afoot to issue tokens with time slots to card holders so that they don’t gather at the fair price shops, and come as per their allotted time and maintain three to five feet distance from each other,” civil supplies minister Gangula Kamalakar told TOI.As all the white ration cards have been linked with Aadhaar cards, Rs 1,500 cash, as announced by chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao to be given to the white ration card holders for purchase of essentials, would be deposited into the bank account of the beneficiaries. “Bank account details will be verified once again with the white card holders when they come to take the rice,” Kamalakar said.It is also proposed to give two-month rice i.e. 24 kg rice to the card holders as a precautionary measure. “There is no need to panic. The 1 kg rice per person is sufficient for a month for an individual,” said civil supplies commissioner Satyanarayana Reddy.While school buildings would be utilised to keep the rice stocks in the rural areas, the government will use community halls in towns and cities to stock the rice bags. A vehicle with audio and speaker facility would be used to make announcements in villages and residential areas in the city about the fair price shop timings, token system, time slots and other necessary norms to be followed before coming to take the rice.

Title: Meat supply stops as NMC closes Nagpur's only abattoir
Content:
A pair of Guineafowl roaming on Kamptee road took residents by surprise on Wednesday

NAGPUR: Though meat, chicken and other non-vegetarian items are considered food and hence permitted to be sold during lockdown, butchers here are unable to cater to the demand as slaughter itself is banned. Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has shut down city’s only abattoir in Mominpura.

Traders say even if slaughter is allowed, there is a little chance they may still be able to supply meat. This is because transport of animals for slaughter too has been hampered. As business has come to a standstill, it has led to another problem at Kasabpura pocket in Mominpura where butchers live. The storages are full with dead animals’ hides that were kept for being sold to leather traders who take it to tanneries in Chennai and Kolkata.

Now as everything has come to a standstill, the hides are not being lifted leading to complaint of stench. The butchers, on the other hand, are making desperate calls to the NMC for lifting the hides but in vain, they said. As labourers are not available, the butchers are not in a position to dispose of the hides on their own, said traders here.

Ashok Patil, the in-charge of NMC’s Gandhibagh zone that covers Mominpura, confirmed he had closed the abattoir because meat vending itself has been banned. Resident deputy collector Ravindra Khajanchi said he will look into the matter.

Ateeq Qureshi, a political worker and a resident of Mominpura, said the NMC had stopped the slaughter house itself despite the district administration including meat in exempted list. Butchers are not being allowed to carry out slaughter on their own too. “Now even fodder is in storage for the animals kept for slaughter,” he said. Qureshi pointed out abattoirs are working in neighbouring Chhattisgarh.

Taufiq Qureshi said the entire movement of goats is stopped. Bakra Mandi at Nagpur gets supplies from villages in Chhattisgarh and Madhya Pradesh . Chhindwara is one of the major sources, he said. Even local supply has been stopped due to curfew.

Syed Qureshi, a hide trader, said, “the lockdown has left the daily wagers employed at the market facing tough times. As funds have been blocked, even we are not in a position help them.”

Meanwhile, a member poultry farmers’ association here said there are chances sale of chicken may begin as the matter has been taken up with the district administration.

Title: Interest booms in doomsday material
Content:
You can read the entire story on TOI+

A bat drops a fruit, a pig eats the fruit, a human eats the pig and you have a global viral outbreak. It’s the plot of the 2011 Steven Soderbergh film, ‘Contagion’.Search interest, an index of how many times a term has been searched on Google as a ratio of all searches, from India for the film spiked from 11 in the second week of March to 54 last week. Everyone seems to be watching it.

Title: Many cook up stories to try and beat restrictions in Delhi
Content: NEW DELHI: When Shubham Kumar, who was travelling in his car with his family, was caught violating the lockdown on Wednesday, he started pleading with the policemen to let him go claiming he hadn’t eaten in the past three days. However, it turned out that he had gone to visit a relative and had cooked up the story to mislead police.Shubham was one of the many violators who came up with a range of excuses while trying to breach the lockdown. A man in Ghaziabad donned the attire of a milkman and carried empty cans to go on a joyride. When he was caught, he claimed that he was supplying milk to needy children.Police said in most cases the violators initially got aggressive when asked for proof to back their claims. “We had people trying to pose as government officials or even repairmen on their way to fix broken power cables. During random checks, none of them were found carrying any identity proof,” said an officer.A majority of the violators were small businessmen who were on the way to their shops. “When questioned or booked, the violators revealed that they owned small businesses and were on their way to their office or shop to carry out commerce. We are not against their motive, but the rule of law is paramount,” said another police officer.Last week, police visited an airline official’s house in west Delhi when his neighbours complained that he had violated home quarantine norms by visiting a relative in another apartment nearby. He and his family members were booked for the violation. They claimed that they were visiting the relative due to a medical emergency, which was found to be false upon verification.Most violators were caught in east and northeast Delhi. “There was a man from Ghaziabad who had managed to enter the city with someone’s help. When he was caught returning, he first tried to intimidate us claiming to be a police officer. However, when we asked for his ID proof, he started pleading with us to let him go,” said a police officer.

Title: Nagpur citizens celebrate Gudi Padwa with cops, sanitation workers
Content:
Representative image

NAGPUR: Gudi Padwa , the Maharashtrian New Year, is believed to bring peace and positivity, and one couldn’t agree more as citizens, currently grounded at home because of the lockdown, celebrated the occasion with utmost zeal and enthusiasm. The festival was celebrated not only with families, but, at some places, also with cops deployed on duty, and sanitation workers working day and night to keep us in safe and clean environment.

Shailesh Jadhav, a cop deployed at Subhash Nagar , missed his Gudi Padwa celebration for the first time as he was on duty. His son performed the puja this year, and Jadhva served the city. “For the first time, I missed being at home for the celebration. But my duty is my priority,” he said.

Residents of Subhash Nagar brought them fasting snacks such as sabudana khichdi since many cops on duty were fasting on the occasion, “We are overwhelmed to see such a nice response from the public. It shows that they trust the cops and have faith in us,” he added.

Sheela Kulkurni also felt extremely cheerful as she made a sweet dish, sheera, for the lady who comes everyday to sweep the road in their residential area. “I celebrated the occasion with my family. Corona has made everything depressing, but we woke up in the morning, wore new clothes and offered prayers to the gudi. I served sweets to the sanitation worker as they are working selflessly for us,” she said.

Ruchika Asatkar, who stays in Mahal area, is also making sure that the cops don’t do duty on an empty stomach, especially on the occasion of new year. She and her mother served them home cooked meal and refreshments as a gesture of gratitude and appreciation. “My mom makes snacks everyday for them around 4pm and we serve them yogurt and butter milk or lemon water. They are taking care of us; hence we are taking care of them,” she said.

Sharing her celebrations at home, Shefali Dudhbade said, “We are following self quarantine and are supporting policemen by showing our full support by staying at home. Instead of moving out to bring the stuff required to perform puja, we gathered everything at home. We celebrated by drawing rangolis, putting up torans, and hoisted Gudi,” she said.

Dr Shwadha Kotpalliwar said, “My family and I pushed away all the negativity of the coronavirus and prayed to the god to bring peace and positivity to the world. We had a small puja in our house and we stand by all the policemen and workers who are day and night tirelessly doing duty for us,” she said.

Title: Married man caught for lover’s murder drinks phenyl at police station
Content:
Representative image

NAGPUR: A murder accused who drank phenyl at Umred police station is currently admitted at Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH). He was caught on Monday for the murder of his lover, who had gone missing in August 2018.

The accused identified as Jitesh Kumbhre, 24, is yet to be officially arrested as he drank phenyl in the bathroom of police station after going there on the pretext of using the washroom before his arrest was recorded.

According to police, Aishwarya Chavhan , 19, had an affair with Jitesh, who is married and has a daughter. Aishwarya was pressing him to marry her but he was not willing to leave his wife, who was also upset about her husband’s extramarital affair. On August 6, 2018, Chavhan went missing. Her parents approached Umred police station and filed a complaint.

Cops initially failed to trace Chavhan, so the case turned cold. However, recently API Shital Khobragade took over the case and began scrutinizing call records of Chavhan only to find her in frequent contact with Jitesh.

She probed further and came across a teenager who told them that Kumbhre was with Chavhan on the day she went missing.

Cops later brought Jitesh and his wife for questioning. After questioning the couple separately for hours, the accused spilled the beans. He allegedly confessed before the cops that he strangled Chavhan at his farm and buried her as she was pressing him to marry her.

Cops suspects Jitesh’s wife is also involved in the murder along with some others.

Cops were recording statement of the accused when he asked to go to the toilet. Jitesh went alone inside but did not come out for long, leading policemen to break the door. They found him lying on the floor with the phenyl bottle nearby. He was rushed to GMCH where he is currently under treatment and said to be out of danger.

Cops are trying to trace the location where the accused had buried Chavhan’s body.

Title: Nagpur: Lockdown may hit feeding of animals in zoo & Gorewada
Content: NAGPUR: The Central Zoo Authority (CZA), a statutory body under MoEFCC monitoring zoos in the country, has asked states to include upkeep and health care of captive animals housed in zoos under the essential services.In a late evening development, the central government issued orders to include maintenance and upkeep of the animals in zoos, forest offices staff, field staff required to monitor nurseries, water plantations, wildlife areas, patrolling, firefighting and their necessary transport under essential services.“The state government is yet to follow suit and there is confusion among the staff whether they should go ahead with their duties amid the lockdown for which they might face action. Now, state needs to issue similar notification to clear the confusion,” said senior forest officials.Amid the 21-day lockdown, CZA has learnt that many zoos are facing tough time in getting supply of food owing to restrictions under Section 144 and the curfew imposed to contain coronavirus . As slaughter is also banned, getting meat for carnivores in zoos may be hampered.CZA member-secretary SP Yadav said, “In the wake of the crisis, we have asked state governments to include upkeep of animals in zoos and rescue centres under ‘essential services’. We have also asked the chief wildlife wardens to ensure animal health care is not sidetracked.”Even the latest Maharashtra government notification issued on March 25, though has included veterinary hospitals and animal care centres and pet shops under emergency services, it makes no mention of forest and wildlife and zoos.Following the CZA advisory, TOI took stock of the situation at Gorewada Rescue Centre and Maharajbagh Zoo and found that both the captive animal centres are coping with the situation by stocking material.Dr Sunil Bawaskar, Maharajbagh Zoo officer-in-charge, said, “Till March 31, we were prepared. With the extended lockdown till April 14, to fulfil the needs of animals, we are even contemplating to rear over 100 hens in a cage in case the situation worsens following transportation restrictions. Yesterday, one vehicle carrying fodder was detained for an hour. Now, we have issued an emergency certificate to the transporter, which he has pasted on the windscreen so the vehicle is not stopped by the cops.”“We don’t know whether we will get buffalo meat or not. We need 35kg of it to feed tiger and leopards daily. Besides, 350kg green grass & vegetables and 30kg fruits to feed herbivores. The zoo houses over 150 animals. In worse scenario, we may have to cut tree branches and feed the herbivores,” said Dr Bawaskar.The zoo in-charge said at present herbivore feed that will last for four days has been stocked and daily supply is also being receiving. Policemen are cooperating to allow food vehicles and staff too. Zookeepers have been asked to stay put and we have made arrangements so that they do not mix up with people outside,” said Bawaskar.Similarly, Gorewada Rescue Centre, which houses eight tigers, 24 leopards, 10 sloth bears and 40 chitals and nilgais, has also geared up to handle the situation. FDCM divisional manager Nandkishore Kale said, “We have reduced the strength of labourers and those present have been accommodated in the quarters.”“As we have not been included in the essential services, we are stocking non-perishable vegetables like cabbage, lauki (bottle gourd) and fruits like payaya and water melon in an air-conditioned room. We have stock for four days. The contractors, though, have assured supply of buffalo meat, we have flexibility to supply goat meat and chicken,” said Kale.“Stocking of vegetables and fruits is being done as Kalamna Market, major supplier of fruits and vegetables, has also ordered closure for three days. We are also in touch with local farmers for supply of grass and oranges in case of emergency,” Kale said.

Title: Lockdown crackdown: Over 700 vehicles seized in Jhalawar, Bundi
Content: Kota: Police in Bundi and Jhalawar districts seized as many as 724 vehicles and slapped challans on 100 others for violating the lockdown and Section 144 by venturing out in the market on Tuesday. Meanwhile, compliance of the lockdown and Section 144 was effective on Wednesday, and essential commodities were made available uninterrupted in the markets.As many as 315 vehicles were seized at different checkposts and various places across Jhalawar district on Tuesday, and effective measures were put in place to ensure compliance of the lockdown, additional superintendent of police (ASP), Jhalawar, Rajesh Yadav said. The number of vehicles seized and challans slapped on Wednesday is yet to reported by late evening, he added.Similarly, as many as 409 vehicles were seized and 88 challans were slapped for violation of lockdown on Tuesday against the people who unnecessarily ventured out in the markets in Bundi, a Bundi police officer said.Meanwhile, Kota police also took up stricter measures to ensure compliance of the lockdown in Kota city. Taking action against the violators, who ventured out in the markets unnecessarily, police asked them to hold placards in their hands saying, ‘I am anti-social, I cannot stay at home’ and asked some of them to do sit-ups on the road.Besides, Kota police marked circles at distance of one metre in front of medical stores and grocery shops to ensure distance among the customers reaching at these shops to purchase the items. However, in some markets of Kota city, gatherings of people for purchasing necessary items was visible but as soon as police vehicles’ siren echoed in the area, the people dispersed.

Title: Sanitization work begins in all wards of the Surat
Content:
VADODARA: The fire department undertook sanitization across the city on Tuesday night and Wednesday. At least 70,000 litres of water and chemicals were sprinkled in all 12 administrative wards of the city.

“We had handed over our manpower and resources to ward-level officers and the sanitization was done as per their instructions,” said in-charge chief fire officer Parth Brahmbhatt. “Details of those who are home quarantined and tested for coronavirus were with ward-level officers so our staff worked as per their directions,” he added.

Fire department sources said that besides homes of quarantined persons, major establishments like banks and stores which will remain open were also sanitized from outside. “So far we have only covered major roads and areas and not the internal roads except for homes of quarantined persons. We will be covering internal roads too in coming days as the exercise will continue for days as of now,” said a fire official.

On Monday, fire department had sanitized homes of those who were tested positive for coronavirus and also other places in their neighbourhood which they might have visited. tnn

Title: Sans any protective gear, sanitary staff keeping Nagpur clean
Content:
Scary situation

NAGPUR: Kanchan Sahu is among over 7,000 sanitary workers of Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) out to keep the city’s 200sqkm roads clean amid the outbreak of coronavirus Kanchan and her colleagues start work every day at 7am and continue till 2pm. This is their routine throughout the year.But due to the lockdown now, the streets are by and large clean. Even the otherwise garbage-littered streets in commercial areas like Itwari, Sitabuldi etc are relatively clean. “But we have been asked not to avail any leave,” she told TOI. In other words, it means that they are contributing in their own way in fight against coronavirus by giving priority to city’s cleanliness, especially at a time when the entire population is under lockdown and asked to stay indoors.However, the lockdown has increased problems for them. Sanitary workers, especially women, face transportation troubles. Sapna Rai, a sanitary worker, said she cannot drive and with the lockdown in force, reaching her designated place of work has become difficult. “Even my son cannot drop me as police are not allowing any citizen to drive on Nagpur roads. At least during this crisis period, the NMC should provide pick-and-drop facility,” she said.Now, these sanitation workers in Nagpur are living under fear of contracting coronavirus infection in the absence of any protective gear. TOI spotted many workers sweeping the roads without proper masks and hand gloves. Sahu too was cleaning the streets in Jaripatka without any hand gloves or mask.Though sanitary workers are not openly seeking any healthy safety equipment, their leader Kishore Samudre of Maharashtra Pradesh Safai Karmachari Mahasangh demanded face mask, sanitizers and hand gloves for sanitary workers.“There are over 7,000 sanitation workers in Nagpur and they are at the highest risk of infection. They pick up garbage from door to door but the municipal corporation has not provided any safety gear,” Samudre said.Most of the workers, requesting anonymity, said they have neither been given face masks, nor hand gloves and the staff has to lift garbage with bare hands. “If any sanitary worker contracts coronavirus, then the mayor and civic chief will be directly responsible for it,” a miffed Samudre said.Echoing Samudre, independent corporator Abha Pandey expressed anguish over sanitary workers cleaning city’s streets without any safety gear. Pandey said sanitary workers are not aware of the health hazards while handling garbage and clearing the waste.Pandey said she will provide 500 masks to workers cleaning streets in her prabhag in east Nagpur.Leena Budhe, director of Centre for Sustainable Development , said, “I have been telling them (sanitary workers) to adopt simple preventive measures such as use of masks and hand and foot gloves. Usage of these will go a long way in checking various diseases.”The working situation of 1,000-odd employees of both door-to-door garbage lifting firms AG Enviro and BVG India is more grim. Without any hand gloves and masks, they visit almost 6 lakh households across the city and collect garbage. “They too pose a threat to lakhs of residents,” said Budhe. Health committee chairman Virendra Kukreja has assured to look into both the issues at the earliest.

Title: First advise violators, then act against them: IGP to Goa cops
Content: PANAJI: With the 21-day lockdown coming into force on Wednesday, inspector general of police (IGP) Jaspal Singh directed police personnel to take legal action against citizens not abiding by the curfew even after repeated advises.People have been told to stay within their residences.The IGP, in a message to all police personnel, said that officers need to move beyond just notings and follow through with action.“We are the most important agency of the state. The writ of the state is run through us. So, rise to the occasion and advise people to stay indoors. Advise, advise and advise. If they listen and abide, well and good. But if they defy our lawful action, use legal instrument and take action,” he said.He added that these are difficult times for the nation and police forces have always risen to the occasion whenever the country has faced a challenge, be it a natural disaster or violent agitations.Police have intensified patrolling to avoid any untoward incident in the state. Additional police force has been deployed at borders to stop the entry of vehicles, except those registered in Goa.Earlier, Goa police had appealed to priests of all religious institutions to advise their followers to pray from home as a precautionary measure.

Title: One detained for spreading coronavirus rumours in Nagpur
Content: NAGPUR: The police on Wednesday registered a case over misleading audio and video clips about increase in coronavirus cases in the city that were circulating on the social media.One person, suspected of sharing these clips on WhatsApp , was detained and is being questioned, said police spokesperson Manoj Sutar.A case was registered at Sadar police station under IPC section 188 (disobeying lawful order of a public servant) as well as relevant provisions of the Disaster Management Act, he said.The police has appealed that people should not forward such audio or video clips or spread rumours in other forms.

Title: Groom shamed publicly for taking out wedding procession in Rajasthan
Content: JAIPUR: A groom was publicly shamed for taking out his wedding procession in Sriganganagar district. He was made to hold a placard saying he is an enemy of the society and his picture was clicked and circulated on social media. Although no legal action was taken against the wedding party, the police claimed that awareness was still lacking among the locals, due to which they had to take such measures.Kashyap Singh Raghave, SHO, Lalgarh said, “We stopped the wedding party, which had five people in a car and questioned them as to why they were organising this event amidst a lockdown. The biggest problem that we are facing is that people themselves are reluctant to follow orders and expect police to take the necessary actions.”The groom was in a car along with five other people and the cops did not arrest him since it was his wedding day, though made to pose him with a photograph which said — ‘I am an enemy of the society and will not sit at home despite being told. I will infect everyone and die myself as well.’While the groom was allowed to attend his wedding, the official added, “The problem is controlling the people who are stepping outside despite the lockdown. We are trying our best by taking measures but the public is not concerned. Though we did not arrest the groom, it was a public message sent out to everyone to follow the law,” added the official. With the three-week lockdown, cops claim that they have a big task on their hands to calm down the wedding parties but are still not taking any action against them.As Covid-19 takes a firm grip over India, the Central and state authorities are working in overdrive to try and curb the spread. As per latest government data, Covid-19 has affected over 562 people in the country.The Indian Centre for Medical Research (ICMR) has maintained that the virus is still in phase 2 of transmission, which means there is no evidence of local transmission yet. As the cases climb, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has announced a complete lockdown in the country for 21 days and the health ministry has said states would need to earmark hospitals to exclusively treat coronavirus patients.

Title: Ahmedabad civic body facilitates collective buying of vegetables for societies
Content: AHMEDABAD: In a major initiative, the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has decided to coordinate buying of all daily vegetable provisions for residential societies in the city. Choose a representative from your society who then places bulk orders — of 100kg or more including all vegetables — for the society with the AMC’s WhatsApp helpline number 94087-53064.The civic body’s zonal representative will commission a vehicle for the society’s bulk purchase at the nearest vegetable market. A society representative will have to accompany the vehicle to the market. Once the purchase is made, the AMC’s team will help load the vegetables at the market and unload them at the society’s entrance respectively. Deputy municipal commissioner Mukesh Gadhvi said, “AMC will provide the vehicles for free.”“It will be the responsibility of the society members to ensure distribution of vegetables in an orderly manner without violating the existing Epidemic Act provisions,” said municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra. On whether the AMC will face shortage of loading vehicles, Nehra said, “We will hire more vehicles, it is not a problem for the AMC.” This is not all, Nehra had also convened a meeting with major super and hyper mart chains in the city who have now agreed to deliver daily provisions to doorsteps wherever the chains are currently functional.“We don’t want people congregating on the streets,” Nehra said, adding that another special network of 2,183 shops for supply of grocery, vegetable, milk products and more than 1,000 pushcarts has been formed so that the daily provisions are supplied from a fixed point for societies and slum clusters.

Title: Begusarai youth hangs self in police custody
Content: BEGUSARAI/ PATNA: A 21-year-old youth, who was arrested for eloping with a minor, committed suicide in police custody in Begusarai after he was informed that his girlfriend had given a statement accusing him of abducting her, police said on Wednesday.Vikram Kumar, a Class XII student of a local undergraduate college, hanged himself from the ceiling fan in a room near the lockup inside Birpur police station on Tuesday evening soon after he came to know that his 17-year-old girlfriend, who studies in the same college, had “betrayed” him in court.Kumar, a native of Parra village under Birpur police station in Begusarai district , and his girlfriend were traced to New Delhi on Monday and were brought to Birpur where he was interrogated in a kidnapping case filed by the girl’s father. The girl was sent to the sadar hospital for medical examination and later produced in a court where she recorded her statement on Tuesday.The girl, who is from the same village as Kumar, told the court that she was kidnapped for marriage and subsequently taken to New Delhi by the accused.“Kumar was allowed to go out as he wanted to use the toilet. But due to laxity on the part of the constable on duty, he sneaked inside a room near the lock up and hanged himself with the ceiling fan. Realising that the boy is taking too long, the constable started looking for him and found him hanging in the room,” SHO Amar Kumar said.As the news about the custodial death spread in the town, Kumar’s family members and relatives gathered outside the police station demanding a probe. SDPO Rajan Sinha reached the police station to pacify the crowd and the body was sent to the sadar hospital for autopsy. The victim’s father, Dukho Poddar, demanded a fair investigation and action against the police personnel.Sinha said the SHO of Birpur police station was out when the incident took place on Tuesday evening. “The SHO was on patrolling duty to enforce the lockdown in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak,” SDPO Sinha told this newspaper over phone.He, however, hastened to add that he had recommended disciplinary action against the SHO for his negligence. Later, the SHO was shifted to the police lines. Begusarai SP Awakash Kumar said a medical team was set up to conduct the autopsy and the process was video recorded as per guidelines of the National Human Rights Commission.Earlier, DM Arvind Kumar Verma ordered a magisterial inquiry into the incident.

Title: Radhika Apte urges people to understand the seriousness of coronavirus
Content: Actor Radhika Apte believes at a time when the country is battling the coronavirus pandemic, it is important for people to stay at home and maintain social distancing.The actor said something like this has never happened so people may find it "bizarre" but the 21-day lockdown should be taken seriously. "It is important for celebrities or anybody who has slightest influence to pass on information that is valuable because people are not taking it seriously. Something like this has never happened before and people are finding it bizarre."And the immediate need of feeding their families and getting work done seems important. People think nothing is going to happen to me and that it is just flu and I am going to do it. But it is spreading so rapidly and people do not understand the seriousness of it," Radhika told .The actor said with the industry in the shutdown mode, celebrities are doing their bit by reminding people to not venture out of their homes.The actor said people should also spare a thought and extend help to those who are most affected by the crisis, the daily wage earners."I will advise people to stay at home and try to feel grateful for what they have as there are lots of people, who are in a bad place at the moment, like the daily wage workers and so many."Try to make people aware of the situation and if you have domestic help or workers, if you can keep (them) on payroll, it will be extremely wise to do that," she added.Radhika, who is currently in London, said the period of social distancing has given her time to focus on her creative side as an artiste."I am trying to write, watch, read but more important than that there are so many things that you forget when are busy, like caring for yourself. The first thing I did was to clean and organise my house, it took me a while."But it was so satisfying, de-cluttering everything, throwing things I do not need. I made a whole bag for charity and did shopping for charity, which was important to do," she said.As an actor, she said everyone has suffered a setback, including her, as there are no film shoots happening."The situation at the moment is so difficult, you are living in such strange times that the work for everybody has suffered so I don't know how much of the work will happen or what will happen in the future. As of now, I have finished a mini-series, a futuristic mocumentary sci-fi comedy, which is actually a murder mystery."I have film called 'Raat Akeli Hai' to be released and I was supposed to do 'Shantaram' which has got pushed."The actor celebrates Gudi Padwa (a Maharashtrain festival) every year with her family but this time she is away from home due to coronavirus pandemic."I don't plan to celebrate Gudi Padwa this year as I am in London and there is nobody to celebrate it with."
