Title: Passes will be issued for vehicles ferrying essentials in Ahmedabad
Content:
Top police officials said passes will be issued to such vehicles so the supply of essential items continues on... Read More

AHMEDABAD: The city administration and has decided to issue passes to trucks and other vehicles used to supply essential items like vegetables, milk, fruits and other food items, to keep supply chains intact. Top police officials said passes will be issued to such vehicles so the supply of essential items continues on.

City police chief Ashish Bhatia said passes will also be issued to trucks and other vehicles bringing vegetables and other food items to the city. “These passes will be issued by the collector’s office,” Bhatia added.

Top police officials said association members of major fruit and vegetable markets met city police officials and asked for permission to open their markets. “Major markets such as the APMC, Madhavpura Market and Naroda Fruit Market will open from Thursday,” said Bhatia.

More importantly, Bhatia said that major online retailers will also be given permission to home deliver essential items. “We are announcing this through public address systems so the rush seen at provision stores on Tuesday can be curtailed to prevent transmission of the coronavirus,” he added.

To maintain law and order during the lockdown period, one company of SRP and one of RAF have been deployed in the city. “We are ensuring nobody moves on the roads without valid reason. We are not closing shops selling essential items. We have instructed police stations across the city to book those who violate lockdown rules,” said a senior police official.

After Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced the lockdown across the country on Tuesday, labourers from Rajasthan who were working in the city tried to go back. As no public transport was available, they started walking back to Rajasthan. City police stopped them, gave them food and water and arranged for private vehicles. “We even informed out counterparts in Rajasthan of their arrival,” said Bhatia.

Title: Kolkata: Consumers’ ordeal worsens as e-grocers blame local crackdown
Content:
KOLKATA: Five days after placing an order for atta, edible oil and sugar on an e-grocery app, Sweta Palit, a senior citizen from Maniktala, received a message on Wednesday that her order had been cancelled due to “unforeseen circumstances”. With deliveries getting delayed or cancelled, many online grocery buyers like Palit are facing a tough time. Overburdened e-grocers have blamed it on restrictions imposed by local authorities on the movement of delivery staff and goods and sudden rush in demand.

Although e-grocery biggies — BigBasket, Grofers and Amazon Pantry — contended that they would be offering priority items among the existing orders owing to unprecedented surge in demand, many customers in the state are still counting days to get the deliveries. Like every month, Meera Banerjee, a homemaker in Naktala, was trying to place an order for some essential items like rice and pulses on BigBasket. But, she was told there were no slots available for delivery. “Now, as they have stopped taking orders, I am worried about replenishing my stock,” Banerjee said.

Most e-grocers are in talks with the authorities concerned to find ways for keeping the supply chain going. BigBasket told TOI that better coordination with the state and local police would help smoothen services. “It has to be ensured that our delivery vans and bikes don’t get stopped by police. Some of our delivery partners are getting beaten up by the cops,” said a spokesperson.

Kolkata Police commissioner Anuj Sharma on Wednesday said: “We had a meeting with the e-grocers. We have asked them to continue with their operations. The state government has already issued specific guidelines. There should be no problem in delivery.” Later in the evening, state chief secretary Rajiva Sinha issued a guideline that said e-commerce personnel and delivery boys can move in the state with a letter of authorisation from their employers. It should be endorsed by the local police or SDOs.

Grofers co-founder & CEO Albinder Dhindsa assured that despite a few hiccups, the company was taking every measure to ensure delivery of essential supplies. With a 100% growth in daily gross merchandise value over the last few days, Grofers’ order backlog has touched four lakh.

Paucity of manpower is another aspect troubling the online grocery suppliers. “We need to add bikes, vans, and delivery men to our fleet, and that is a difficult thing to do in a short period of time,” BigBasket clarified.

Amazon Pantry, the e-commerce giant’s grocery section, too, said local restrictions are making it tough for them to keep operations intact. It is currently serving only household staples, healthcare and hygiene products. Spencer’s on Wednesday told its customers that its stores were open for groceries and essential needs, but services may get temporarily disrupted.

Title: Kolkata: Fluctuating price graph reflects buying frenzy
Content:
(With inputs from Jhimli Mukherjee Pandey and Monotosh Chakraborty)

KOLKATA: Prices of vegetables, fish and poultry have mirrored the surge in panic among customers, similar to how the Sensex has reacted to PM Narendra Modi’s ‘Janata Curfew’ and then three-week-long lockdown.The city witnessed the first bout of frenzied buying on Friday and Saturday following Modi’s address to the nation on Thursday, in which he urged citizens to observe a curfew on Sunday. Prices of vegetables, fish and egg spiked as demand soared. Some who were aware of the Covid-19 threat looming over India and long-term restrictions in China, South Korea and elsewhere sensed Sunday’s “janata curfew” was just a rehearsal of the inevitable lockdown ahead and stocked up. The rise in demand pushed up prices considerably.The prices had begun to ease on Saturday evening when two announcements on Sunday, one by the Centre on restrictions in 82 districts in the country, including Kolkata, till March 31, and CM Mamata Banerjee’s announcement that the state would enforce the curbs till March 27 and review it before a subsequent decision, saw anxiety among large sections of people, leading to a spectacular rise in prices on Monday morning. Vegetable prices soared by 100%-150%. Fish and egg prices increased by 50% while the hike in chicken price was slightly lower.The following morning though, the markets opened as usual and though grocery stocks had depleted, vegetable, fish and chicken vendors were present with the usual stock and there was no indication that a crisis lay ahead. With prices declining by 35%-40%, some even regretted making bulk purchase at high prices the previous day.But the uneasy calm lasted only a few hours. When Modi announced a more strict lockdown for three weeks, all hell broke lose as people rushed to the nearest market to stock up. In the few hours left to the lockdown, grocery shops were nearly emptied out. But since the announcement came past the hour when perishables like veggies and fish are sold, it was on Wednesday morning that the markets went on fire.Some vegetables like lemon and bottle gourd could not even reach most markets due to restrictions. Whatever else was on offer, was sold at a premium. “There was a mad rush as early as 5am and people started buying everything in huge quantities. No one purchased less than 5kg of potato. Some even wanted to buy a sack (50kg). But we decided to ration it and fixed the upper limit at 5kg,” said Sujit Ghosh, a potato retailer at Behala market.Similar rationing was done by retailers of onion and eggs at Gariahat, Kasba, Lake, Bhowanipore and Maniktala. In several places, the rationing happened after a bit of police advice. In Howrah, the city police notified markets would operate from 5am to 9am to maintain maximum possible social distancing.Despite the steep rates, stocks of most vendors were exhausted by 9am. Many shops marked out how customers should stand with gaps between them to adhere to social distancing norms. Big retail chains regulated the entry of buyers.West Bengal Vendors’ Association president Kamal Dey said retailers had sensed the panic among buyers before they had even started business with many receiving frantic calls from regular customers inquiring when they would reach the market. “The 21-day nationwide lockdown announcement had clearly spooked them though the PM had clearly mentioned that essential commodities were exempt,” said Dey.“The mad rush defies logic. I heard people jostled to buy things. I am once again assuring everyone that there is no reason to panic. There is enough stock of foodgrain and pulses to feed the entire population of the state for the next few months,” said food and civil supplies minister Jyotipriya Mallick. He expects the market to cool down after the CM addressed the issue and assured people of smooth supply. “Those who bought vegetables more than their requirement at a premium will regret when the price starts going down from Thursday,” said Jyoti Guha, secretary, south suburban vendors association.And though price of fish did not jump as much as vegetables, they got emptied out real fast. Ironically, chicken and egg whose prices had crashed following fake messages that claimed one could acquire the dreaded virus by consuming poultry products witnessed the sharpest rise when the lockdown was announced to break the coronavirus chain.

Title: Goa Coronavirus News: Essentials out of reach, people face many tests
Content:
Pharmacies, medical facilities and most petrol pumps were open despite assurances that other essentials would ... Read More

PANAJI: Several people began their day without milk and bread on Wednesday, sending them into panic.

Only pharmacies, medical facilities and petrol pumps were open despite assurances that other daily essentials would be supplied. Some citizens were too afraid to venture out after videos of police lathi charging people went viral.

A mother with a year-old infant living in Aquem ran helter-skelter for cow milk after the tetra pack she used gave her child diarrhoea.

“She couldn’t find milk anywhere. I shared a packet with her. She became emotional with gratitude and cried,” her neighbour told TOI.

“The lockdown is a good initiative, but little more structured planning was needed,” said a woman in Taleigao who tried with little success to help her elderly neighbour access the basics.

At Gandhi market in Margao, people gathered early morning to panic-buy.

“We are hurt because we heeded the government to not go out and buy, and it abruptly notified a lockdown,” a Porvorim resident said.

Many began rushing out of their homes after the PM’s speech on Tuesday night itself. “I rushed to Ponda sabji mandi for vegetables where only one shop was open. From nowhere, two masked men with sticks started hitting around. The scared shop owner begged to leave immediately. I couldn’t pay him. I just rushed back. Does the government want us to starve?” asked NIT Goa professor Sarani Ghoshal, who lives on campus at Farmagudi.

Similarly in Merces, a senior citizen stepped out in search of milk, eggs, rice and vegetables but returned home after he was witness to the police lathi-charging a young man outside his residence.

“People will lose patience in a day or two and rebel on the streets. They said don’t hoard but now those who did not hoard are the ones who are suffering. The CM should intervene immediately. Government representatives aren’t even responding to messages,” a St Andre resident told TOI.

“The government should have given people the opportunity to buy and store. It’s the responsibility of the government to provide required food grains,” he added.

Meanwhile after a meeting of committee members of a society in Ribandar, the residents were instructed not to visit general stores and place orders for essential items through WhatsApp to the store owner beginning Thursday.

The residents have been told to keep the money outside their door and open it only after the delivery person leaves. It was also decided that a book and pen would be kept in every building where all have been requested to write down their building number and requirements with quantity of essentials required.

Title: Fuel stations to stay open 8am-4pm in Gujarat
Content:
According to a decision taken by Federation of Gujarat Petroleum Dealers’ Association, fuel stations across th... Read More

AHMEDABAD: In the wake of the countrywide lockdown imposed by the government of India to curb the spread of Covid-19, fuel stations across the state will observe timing restrictions from Thursday.

According to a decision taken by Federation of Gujarat Petroleum Dealers’ Association, fuel stations across the state will remain open from 8am to 4pm only.

“As a countrywide lockdown has been imposed to prevent further spread of Covid-19, the association president and secretary have collectively taken the decision to restrict timings of the fuel station from 8am to 4pm. The timing restrictions will remain until lockdown is lifted,” said Arvind Thakkar, president, Federation of Gujarat State Petroleum Dealers’ Association (FGSPDA).

Some 4,000 petroleum dealers across the state will observe the timing restrictions.

Title: Bihar to give Rs1,000 to all ration card holders
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

PATNA: The Bihar Government on Wednesday decided to provide financial assistance of Rs1,000 to all ration card holder families across the state in the wake of countrywide lockdown due to Covid-19 scare. This amount would be transferred directly in the bank accounts of the beneficiaries through direct benefit transfer (DBT).

Earlier on March 23, the government had announced Rs1,000 to only those ration card holder families who were living in urban and semi-urban areas, including in the block headquarters towns where lockdown was imposed by the state government.

“Now, since 21-day lockdown has been imposed in the country, the state government has decided to provide the financial assistance to all ration card holders across the state, even in rural areas,” a state government official told TOI on Wednesday.

Title: ID cards for sweepers who clean public roads in Pune
Content:
Representative Image

PUNE: Sweepers, appointed by private contractors to clean public roads, will be able to do their duty without hassles. The Pune Municipal Corporation ( PMC ) will give them identity cards so that they can work even during the lockdown.

Over 4,000 such workers were finding it tough to venture out as they have no documents to prove their role in emergency services. Their workers’ union had demanded ID cards after a sweeper was beaten up by the police when he failed to prove his identity. The civic administration in association with the contractors will provide these ID cards which will have details like the name of the person, photo, name and logo of the PMC and other details.

“We have made a temporary arrangement for giving the ID cards. They will be usable only during lockdown period. These cards will stand suspected after the lockdown ends,” said Dnyaneshwar Molak, head of PMC’s solid waste management department, told TOI on Wednesday.

He said the ID cards were prepared up to March 31 but as the lockdown period has been extended till April 15 they will be valid for the extended period.

According to PMC’s data, nearly 3,600 people are working on contract as conservancy workers, while around 6,600 are part of the PMC staff for solid waste management. “Such identity cards are a must for the workers. These people are working for an emergency service,” Mukta Manohar, trade union leader representing the workers, said.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Guntur cops book 227 cases, seize 642 cars
Content:
Representative image.

VIJAYAWADA: In the last two days, 227 people were booked for violating lockdown orders across both Guntur rural and urban police limits. According to Guntur rural SP CH Vijaya Rao, 104 cases were booked against people under section 188 of IPC (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant). In Guntur urban police limits 123 people were booked under the same section.

Besides, cops impounded 642 vehicles. The most number of cases were registered in Guntur city and in rural areas, Sattenapalli was found to be a major violators of the lockdown.

Issuing a statement, Guntur urban SP PHD Ramakrishna said that section 144 of CrPC is in force across the district. More than five persons are not allowed to assemble in an area. Moreover, if individuals are found roaming, they would be booked under Section 188 of IPC which can land them in prison up to one year. “If people want to purchase essential commodities, they can do so between 6 am to 7 pm and that too only one person in the family should consider going out,” Ramakrishna said.

In Guntur rural police unit, around 71 check posts have been set up across the district limits. Cops are restricting people from travelling within three kilometer radius from their residential area.

Title: Vegetable shortage may hit Vizag soon
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Sources in the horticulture department and the rythu bazaars are warning of an impending crisis of vegetable shortage in Visakhapatnam. With both the wholesale market and rythu bazaars running short of vendors and suppliers, sources believe that the crisis could happen in the next 48 hours.

The main reason for the non-availability of vegetables is the shut down of inter-state borders restricting farmers from selling their produce in the wholesale bazaars in Visakhapatnam and Vizianagaram. Another issue is the taboo that many of these vendors and suppliers face from their villages, where they are not being allowed into their homes.

Elaborating on the situation in rural areas, K Nookaraju, a farmer and vegetable supplier to the Visakhapatnam wholesale bazaar said: “The last trip I made to Vizag was two days ago. Nw my own people, natives of Uratla, are refusing to let me back into my village if I venture out again. I do not know what to do with my stock of vegetables.”

T Jagadish Kumar, estate officer of the Pedda Waltair rythu bazaar said: “Ninety percent of the farmers are not selling their produce in the rythu bazaars. The stock availability is woefully short of the demand. If this continues, we will surely face a shortage of vegetables.”

Sources in the rythu bazaars have even urged people to stock up on dry foods such as lentils, soya peas and channa, just to ensure that they do not depend on vegetable supply.

Consumers too are worried, with many defying curfew norms to rush to the nearest kirana stores to stock up on vegetables and other essentials. The district administration, however, has made it clear that they will ensure that the supply lines are kept open.

L Shiva Shankar, joint collector, Visakhapatnam said: “We have issued orders and permits to wholesalers, vegetable suppliers and vendors to keep the supply going. Moreover, we are coordinating with all the law enforcement authorities to help in the process.”

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Man held for accusing one of being Covid-19 positive
Content: VIJYAWADA: Guntur rural police on Tuesday arrested a man for allegedly spreading false information and stigmatising a 28-year-old woman at Narasaraopet town.According to Narasaraopet Two Town police, the incident happened on Monday but came to light on Tuesday after the control room received a call claiming that a woman had been infected with Covid-19.Soon, cops along with a doctor reached the spot and found a woman hiding behind some bushes. The woman was rushed to a local hospital where upon screening, doctors declared that she did not have the disease nor its symptoms. Police said that the woman appeared to be mentally-disabled and upon further investigation, identified her father and handed her over to him. Police identified the person who made the anonymous call upon information from locals in the neighbourhood. The man was arrested and booked under relevant sections of the IT Act for spreading false information. tnn

Title: Bareilly group feeds poor, stray animals
Content: BAREILLY/AGRA: District administration in Agra will provide cooked food to street-dwellers and poor families soon. The work to identify all such people began on Wednesday as the country started its 21-day lockdown to prevent the spread of novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak. Several social organisations have also come forward to help the district administration for the cause.District magistrate (DM) has assigned responsibilities for doorstep delivery of essential items such as fruits, vegetables, grocery, dairy products and medicine, while for any medical emergency, people have been advised to call helpline number ‘108’ and ‘102’.Talking to TOI, DM Prabhu N Singh said, “We are working on a plan to distribute cooked food with help of certain industrialists and social organisations. We have identified 15 places where street dwellers and poor families will be given food packets. The process to identify the needy has been initiated. The distribution of food packets will be done by the police.”Taking cognizance of profiteering by some, the district administration on Wednesday ensured fixed rates of 21 fruits, vegetables and other food items. The DM stated that FIR will be registered against profiteers under Essential Commodities Act, 1955.After PM Narendra Modi’s announcement of the complete lockdown on Tuesday evening, locals rushed to the vegetable markets, grocery and flour shops the next morning. At a few places, Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) officials along with local councillors ensured supply of essential items at doorstep. Police maintained strict vigil after 9am. They patrolled the interior parts of the city appealing to residents not to step out of their houses.In another act of kindness, a Bareilly-based group has arranged food for poor who dwell in the city’s slum areas, at bus stands and railway platforms. They are also feeding stray cattle and dogs. The group’s president Nadeem Shamsi said a campaign has been initiated to feed the needy and stray animals at the time of this crisis.Shamsi, who runs an NGO called ‘Samaaj Sewa Manch’, further said, “On Wednesday, we visited a few areas in the city to look for stray cattle, dogs and even birds, and fed them with bread and biscuits. They were mainly spotted in Civil Lines, Quila, Choupla, Qutubkhana and near dumping sites. We have decided to carry on with this drive to ensure these animals don’t starve or not die. The local administration has allowed us. We will continue with the drive. We are also following the necessary precautions like wearing masks and sanitisers.”“We had bought food - milk packets, wheat and pulses - in large quantities to distribute among the poor. We have chalked out a plan to identify and give food to slum-dwellers near Bakerganj and Chawni, along with beggars at public places like railway stations,” Shamsi added.Meanwhile, Agra DM also chaired a meeting with representatives of medicine retailers and wholesalers. Decision was taken that retail medical shops will operate from 10am to 5pm on even days and wholesalers will operate on odd days from 12pm to 3pm. The DM asked the chemists to publish their contact numbers. Chemists will be taking orders over phone. Their representatives will be issued passes to deliver medicine on two-wheelers. For ordering fruits and vegetables, residents can call in the following numbers: “9058512391”, “9997995812” and “9068311511”.

Title: Pune: Wakad housing societies take steps to check contagion
Content:
Masked security personnel guard Shonest Towers society’s closed gate in Wakad

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: Several housing societies in Wakad are taking a slew of measures — from closing amenities such as swimming pools and gymnasiums to restricting people’s movements through the main gates — for effective social distancing in the time of Covid-19.

Bhavana Bhakre, chairperson of Westone housing society with 96 flats off Wakad-Hinjawadi road, said, “We have closed the swimming pool, garden, club house, gymnasium and playground in the society. Though there were some resistance to a few measures, we sorted it out with the help from police.”

The Elementra housing society, with 900 flats off Pune-Bengaluru highway, and Nandan Inspira, with 390 flats along Dutt mandir road, have closed their swimming pools, gymnasiums, club houses, gardens and children’s play zones a week ago.

Pravin Farad, secretary of Elementra society, said, “We are allowing delivery of essentials such as milk, medicines and LPG cylinders to the flats. We have told the housekeeping agency to reduce its staff strength from 100 to 50 by adopting the system of alternate-day duty.”

Silver Orchard housing society, with 48 row houses and bungalows, has restricted the entry or exit, with the exception of emergency purposes, between 5pm and 5am.

Society chairperson Avinash Takate Patil said, “ The aim is to reduce crowding in markets and other public places. We closed the swimming pool and club house a week ago. We have also removed the benches provided by the civic body.”

Title: Vijayawada: Takeaway services minimal, bachelors struggle to get food
Content:
Several bachelors were caught by cops as they were looking for hotels and food stalls around the highway.

VIJAYAWADA: Bachelors, daily wagers, the destitute and others who either can’t cook or don’t have a kitchen are struggling to find food .

While the state government has permitted restaurants and hotels to run take away services, a majority of them are still unwilling to open for business. For one, they fear that they may not even break even with the amount invested in food ingredients for the menu.

Secondly, there is a lack of awareness as to whether the take away service would be considered on par with essential commodities.

K Ramana, a private insurance agent from Nidamanur village near Vijayawada , said the situation was bad in the city outskirts. “The cops have barricaded the highway and there aren’t any hotels within the 3-km radius and I don’t have a kitchen. Thanks to my neighbours, I have managed to survive,” he said.

Several bachelors were caught by cops as they were looking for hotels and food stalls around the highway.

Daily wagers, the destitute and beggars who rely on small streetside eateries are struggling to make their ends meet. Beggars residing on pavements of Durga Ghat, BRTS Road and Bandar Road footpaths are now refusing currency and seeking food from people.

Some eateries in a remote location were opening and closing their shutters while letting the customers in and out.

Meanwhile, police and civic officials have been providing food packets to the poor in the city. The same cannot be said for those who stay in remote locations in Krishna district.

“We have kept our menu simple to avoid wastage. We stopped making biryani and are providing idlis and Chinese food,” Karisetty Ramudu, a food stall owner in Gudavalli said.

Title: 21-day govt leave: Essential staff on duty in Gujarat
Content:
Representative image

GANDHINAGAR: Following the announcement of a nationwide lockdown for three weeks, the state government on Wednesday issued a government resolution, announcing a 21-day holiday period for all state government offices and public sector undertakings. Except emergency services and departments engaged in maintaining essential services, all other government offices will remain shut for 21 days.

In a resolution issued on Wednesday, Kamal Dayani, principal secretary, general administration department (GAD) in his order said, “As per directions of the government of India to control novel coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak, it is notified that all state government offices, board, corporations will have 21 days holidays starting from March 25. During these days, except notified essential services, all the government offices will remain closed.”

Listing out the services which will remain functional through the lockdown, Dayani said in the resolution, “Officials working in the health & family welfare department, civil supply & consumer affairs department and other government offices like collector’s office, disaster management services, panchayat, municipal corporation and municipalities, gas, electricity, and water supply will function.”

Title: Police forced to wield baton to enforce lockdown
Content:
Vijayawada: With the police using batons against people gathering in large numbers and to discourage motorists from taking to the roads, most of the residents of Vijayawada city remained confined to their homes on Wednesday.

The police, with the support of few other departments, strictly enforced the lockdown to curb the spread of coronavirus. The police used batons on some motorists at few places in the city to discourage them from taking to the roads uneccesarily. “We will not allow motorists on the roads for unnecessary travel and will act tough against the violators of the lockdown under various sections of IPC,” the police chief added.

Tirumala Rao said that Rythu Bazaars have been relocated from congested locations to the ground in the city for strict implementation of social distancing to prevent the spread of the virus. “Despite our instructions, some people are coming on the roads unnecessarily and arguing with the police, who have been performing their duties for the safety of the people. We are appealing the people to stay in homes and follow the precautions to fight against the virus,” Tirumala Rao said.

“We have observed that some youngsters are defying the lockdown and riding the bikes at high speeds. We are also examining CCTV footage to register cases against all the violators,” a traffic police officer said.

“Thanks to some videos going viral, where the police were seen beating up motorists for violating the rules of the lockdown, youngsters remained at home on Wednesday,” said K Narayana, a resident.

Title: Narendra Modi: Despite disruptions, lockdown is best option
Content: NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Wednesday said the 21-day national lockdown to contain the spread of coronavirus was bound to cause disruptions but the choice was stark as social distancing and isolation were the only and best means to ensure the disease did not extract an incalculable cost.In a video interaction with residents of Varanasi, the PM, in his first comments after he announced a lockdown, said even in a normal situation, there was the possibility of inconveniences like water/electricity shortages and missing service providers, and to assume that a crisis of the magnitude that coronavirus presented would not create problems was akin to defrauding ourselves."To think there will be no difficulties will be to delude oneself. The Centre and state governments are trying hard to help. Still, I do agree that it is important to question the arrangements. But we should also pause for a moment to ask ourselves whether despite the problems, faced with a danger like coronavirus, do we have to win or not. The difficulties are going to be there for only 21 days but the damage that coronavirus will cause if it does not go away cannot be calculated " the PM said.Modi seemed to be trying to prepare people to put up with various inconveniences like irregular supplies of everyday items while arguing that the threat of wider or uncontrolled transmission of coronavirus was a danger that needed to be averted at all costs.Seeking to drive home the point, Modi said the battle of Mahabharata was won in 18 days, and the one against coronavirus was going to take 21 days. "Our endeavour is to win it in 21 days. Whereas Lord Krishna was the general and the guide in Mahabharata, the battle against coronavirus will be led by 130 crore Indians,” he said, adding that the common man believed in taking the right step at the right time.“On March 22, it was clearly seen how all citizens supported janata curfew and then at 5 pm, expressed gratitude to professionals fulfilling their duties in essential services,” he said.However, the PM also cautioned that focusing exclusively on shortcomings and instances of dereliction on the part of a few would not be beneficial. "There can be thousands of reasons for spreading despair and some of those could be valid ones too. But we should remember that this nation is sustained by hope and trust," he said as he lavished praise on doctors, nurses, paramedical personnel, police, government employees and the Air India crew.Modi made a pointed reference to incidents of harassment faced by medical professionals and others such as airline crews, who were being asked to vacate residences or ostracised, and said such reports were deeply painful. He said states and police chiefs had been asked to take tough action to curb such instances of discrimination against people providing essential services.“I appeal to all citizens, if you notice any incident where professionals, such as doctors and nurses are ill-treated, then you should take an initiative to make such people understand that they are wrong,” Modi said in response to a doctor, who cited incidents where medical staff was asked to vacate premises by their landlords.The PM said he had told the home ministry and state DGPs to take strict action against those who were not supporting or not cooperating with doctors, nurses and other professionals.“These days, people in hospitals are working for around 18 hours per day. Professionals in the healthcare sector are not getting more than 2-3 hours to sleep. Civil society people are working day in, day out to help poor. We should salute such people who are serving society in this critical hour,” Modi said, adding that those not cooperating with such professionals would have to face the consequences.He said healthcare professionals "working in white uniforms in hospitals were like god for us today as they were saving people" from the disease. “They are saving us by risking their own lives,” he added.Responding to the question of a textile merchant, Akhilesh Khemka, about the sufferings of the poor and the roofless, the PM urged better off sections to offer food to at least nine families for the next 21 days, which, he said, would be the best way to offer prayers to Ma Durga during the auspicious period of Navratra. Modi stressed that social distancing, which has resulted in hardships, was unavoidable as part of the "military strategy" deployed to fight the pandemic.“However, we consider humans to be embodiments of divinity and compassion should be part of the larger strategy to defeat corona. Whoever has the capability, take the pledge to take care of nine families for 21 days, it will be a true 'Navratri'. Due to the lockdown, animals are also facing trouble. I appeal to people to take care of animals around them too,” Modi said.The PM started the interaction expressing grief over terror attack in a Gurdwara in Kabul where several people are said to be killed.He said that as MP of Varanasi, he should have been among the people of the city in times like these but was not able to do so due to engagements in Delhi. “Despite being busy here, I've been taking regular updates about Varanasi from my colleagues,” Modi said, adding that Kashi could be the torchbearer in the fight against Covid-19.The PM once again highlighted how some people were still not sensitive towards the coronavirus scare. “At times, people don't pay attention to things which are important. The same is happening in India. I request people to understand facts and not believe in rumours. Covid-19 doesn't discriminate between rich and poor. It will not spare anyone just because they perform yoga or exercise daily,” he added.Modi said one should not attempt to treat coronavirus infection on their own.He also announced that the government had formed a help desk, in collaboration with WhatsApp , to seek correct information about coronavirus.“If you have access to WhatsApp, you can use the number 9013151515 for the purpose,” Modi said, adding, “If you write 'Namaste' on this WhatsApp number, either in English or in Hindi, then you will get an immediate response.”

Title: VSP lowers staff strength, production
Content:
Visakhapatnam: With the district administration turning its focus on reducing workforce strength in industries, Vizag Steel Plant (VSP) has reduced its manpower from around 35,000 to 9,000 personnel, working in three shifts.

A high level review meeting held by deputy CM and health minister Alla Kali Krishna Srinivas with ministers, people’s representatives and district officials stressed the need to maintain social distance in industries, apart from marketplaces and shopping malls.

On the technical issues involved in shutting down the plant, chief manager of corporate communications, VSP Sarma told TOI, “We can’t shut down blast furnace and coke oven battery. Once they cool down, it would take months together to bring them to operational condition and sometimes it would take a year also.”

Operations at the plant will continue though production will fall “since supply chain management is under strain, we controlled the production,” said Sarma.

The district administration is also finalising the minimum manpower required by the pharma industry. “We are discussing with various pharma industries and will take all precautions in controlling the coronavirus,” said collector V Vinay Chand.

Title: 64 people travelling in two buses from Delhi quarantined after two of them show mild fever
Content:
Nainital: The Champawat district administration has quarantined 64 people traveling in two buses after two of them were found to have fever. The district administration had arranged these roadways buses to evacuate people stranded in Delhi. However, as they were checked on the district borders by a team of doctors, two of them were found to have mild fever. The district administration took their samples and sent them for testing in Haldwani. “One person in each bus was found to have mild fever and therefore all the passengers in both the buses have been quarantined,” said SDM Dayanand Saraswati, adding that the quarantined include the driver and the bus staff as well.

He added that the samples of the passengers who are sick will be tested and if they are found to be negative, all of them will be allowed to go home, but till the sample results come, they will remain quarantined.

Title: Free supplies for ration card holders in Gujarat
Content:
Vijay Rupani

GANDHINAGAR: The state government on Wednesday announced that ration card holders will receive free supplies of essential commodities like wheat, rice, dal, sugar and salt from April 1 onwards. Over 60 lakh ration card holders, covering 3.25 crore persons, will benefit from the decision, the state government said.

After a meeting with officials of the task force formed to oversee supply of essential items, chief minister Vijay Rupani announced the decision to start free supply of basic requirements through public distribution system (PDS) shops.

Rupani said, “In a bid to ease problems faced by labourers and other citizens during the lockdown period, the state government has decided to start distribution of 3.5kg wheat, 1.5kg rice, 1kg dal, 1kg sugar and 1kg salt free of cost from ration card shops.”

The CM added that the government is taking all necessary steps to ensure that supply of grocery, vegetables, fruits and medicines across the state remains interrupted. He urged people not to hoard items.

Title: Pune: Tech hub villages disinfected
Content:
PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The villages of Hinjewadi, Maan and Marunji, where the Rajiv Gandhi Infotech Park is located, have started decontaminating vehicles and areas in their limits in the wake of the Covid-19 spread.

Vishwanath Raikar, village development officer, Hinjewadi gram panchayat , said, “We decontaminated playgrounds, public places, benches, lifts and staircases in the housing societies five days ago. Two days ago, we conducted a second decontamination drive. We are spraying vehicles that enter the village with sodium hypochlorite. We have also sprayed BHC and TCL powder in areas where garbage is dumped.”

Title: Power demand goes up during lockdown in Andhra Pradesh
Content: AMARAVATI: The state-wide lockdown has seen domestic power demand going up in the last few days. Power utilities are struggling to keep the supply uninterrupted despite sudden spike in consumption According to sources, domestic consumption has almost doubled in the last few days. Authorities are worried that the supply system might trip if consumption levels go up any further.Although all commercial establishments had remained closed since Sunday, there was no proportionate fall in overall power consumption. The officials suspect that steep rise in domestic consumption has evaporated savings of commercial establishments.Although there are no issues on the generation side, managing sudden overload on supply lines would pose a big threat to the entire system, a senior official of CPDCL said.

Title: Covid-19: Japanese firm MD in home quarantine
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The Covid-19 vigilance team of the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has asked the managing director of a Japanese company that manufactures specialised lubricants and adhesives based out of Sanand to go into home quarantine.

The Japanese national had landed in the city on March 19. Since the company official did not understand English, the AMC team contacted the HR division manager of the company and advised the official to immediately go into home quarantine.

The vigilance team will keep a close eye on the official and will be paying regular visits at his residence, a senior AMC official told TOI.

Title: For majority, Ugadi was watching live telecast of ‘Panchanga Sravanam’
Content: VIJAYAWADA: Ugadi celebrations on Wednesday were restrained amidst the lockdown imposed by the government to contain the spread of Covid-19. In Vijayawada , residents confined festivities to home and watched the live telecast of the ‘Panchanga Sravanam’ and other rituals performed at the Tirumala Tirupati Devastanams and the Kanaka Durga temple Police permitted vendors to arrange special stalls selling mango leaves, neem, raw mango and other festival merchandise. Social distancing was maintained at markets under the supervision of the police.“We never celebrated Ugadi in a simple way. Coronavirus made us stay home on the festival day. There is no chance for purchasing new clothes nor offering prayers at the temple. But all our family members spent some quality time together and shared household work,” said Naveen Kumar, a techie in the city.Endowments minister Vellampalli Srinivas and his family attended the state government’s Ugadi celebration at Kanaka Durga temple. Temple authorities provided hand sanitizers to guests who attended the celebrations.Astrologer Kappaganthula Somayaji Siddhanti participated in the ‘Panchanga Sravanam’ and recited the almanac for the upcoming year. Temple officials offered Ugadi ‘pachhadi’ to devotees.Temple priests and Vedic scholars offered special ‘pushparchana’ with nine kinds of flowers as part of Vasantha Navarathri Utsavams.

Title: Love story goes wrong in Jodhpur
Content: JAISALMER: A youth from Madhya Pradesh came to meet his lover in Jodhpur district but landed in jail . To meet his lover in a village in Jodhpur district, he first came to Ramdeora in Jaisalmer. Here he did not get any vehicle to go to Jodhpur district. So, he stole a motorcycle, said police.When the youth reached his girl’s place, her family members caught him and handed him over to the police. The boy was arrested and the motorcycle recovered from him, said police.SP Kiran Kang said that the youth reached Ramdeora and stole the motorcycle and went to the village under Bhap police station area in Jodhpur district where her family members caught him and handed over to police.The accused was identified as Mahesh, resident of junapani in Guna district of MP. He allegedly stole the motorcycle of a teacher of govt school. Kang said that bhap police seized the motorcycle under section 207 of MV Act. The culprit was produced in the court where he will be inquired for other theft cases.

Title: Give workers cash, aid: Gujarat Congress
Content:
Gujarat congress leaders met chief minister Vijay Rupani and requested him for giving free ration and cash dol... Read More

GANDHINAGAR: A delegation of Gujarat congress leaders met chief minister Vijay Rupani and requested him for giving free ration and cash doles to those who have suffered loss of employment because of the state-wide lockdown.

Congress leaders handed over a memorandum to the CM, stating that ration kits should be distributed free to both BPL as well as non-BPL families under provisions of the National Food Safety Act. The party has also demanded that those who have suffered loss of employment because of the lockdown must be doles.

Among other demands, the Congress asked the government to pay two months’ advance pension to all pensioners and deferred loan repayment for farmers.

Title: Coronavirus crisis: 335 arrested for violating lockdown in Uttarakhand
Content: DEHRADUN: As many as 335 people were arrested by state police on Wednesday for violating lockdown orders issued to contain the spread of Covid -19. Police officials said that 51 cases were registered by them on Wednesday. On Tuesday, police had registered 59 cases and arrested 175 people, while on Monday, the first day of the lockdown called by the state government, 160 people had been arrested.A maulvi (Islamic scholar) of a mosque in Vasant Vihar area along with 20-25 people was also booked by police for participating in evening prayer at the mosque despite ban on any religious gathering during the lockdown.Officials said that a case has been registered against all the people who attended the evening prayers, under section 188 of Indian Penal Code (IPC). In Almora, 21 people were booked including a restuarant owner for violating the lockdown. Meanwhile, Rajkumar Thukral , BJP legislator from Rudrapur , was also found defying state government’s lockdown call multiple times for distributing masks to people. On Wednesday, Thukral distributed masks to people who had gathered at his house. Later, the MLA and his supporters went to Adarsh Colony, Ghaas Mandi, and Adarsh Indira Bengali Colony to distribute masks.

Title: Lockdown hits real estate market, cycle of buying and selling stalls
Content:
bird’s eye view: An aerial view of residential houses beyond the Yerawada bridge

Pune: Property consultant Ibrahim Shaikh has seen a staggering fall in client interest over the last week. “Even a week ago the client footfall was more or less normal, but now the count has gone down to zero giving way to inquiries being made over calls,” he pointed out, adding hopefully, “The market should pick up once things go back to normal. Till then, safety is of the utmost importance.”

One man’s spending is another man’s earning, but the entire cycle falters in the midst of a highly necessary lockdown and successive curfews in view of the Covid-19 pandemic.

Builders, sellers, suppliers, furniture shops and other personnel attached to the industry have also been hit. “If there are no people seeking our services, supply of material ceases to matter. It is a global pandemic. I cannot say what the repercussions may be in the long run, but, for the time being, it is a positive move on the people’s part to follow the quarantine effectively,” said interior designer Bharat Solanki.

Khushnam Chauhan, a real estate consultant, spoke of the short and long term effect on the finances of everyone involved in the business. “Right now, we are in the process of closing almost done deals. The pandemic has had a cascading effect. People seeking houses have declined drastically. The number of people selling houses have also reduced. A seller refused to meet because she had a child at home and she did not want to take the risk of physical interaction and that’s how it should be. There is no new business coming our way, inquiries too are dwindling,” Chauhan added.

Suparna Pillai, a banker, said, “Wherever a property investment is involved, short term and long term gains come into play. Property holders need to file for capital gains in the form of reinvestment, pay a 24% tax or sign up for government bonds for five years at least by July end usually. But they need to complete necessary transactions, such as buying of property or investing in it by July end. As per finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman’s announcement of March 24, the fiscal has been extended to June 30 offering some relief to property holders with capital gain accounts.”

“With this 21-day lockdown business will come to a grinding halt triggering an economic slump which will require months to recover. Some people with no option to work from home will face a money crunch,” she added

Vasant Pillai, a Retail specialist and Suparna’s husband, had been seeking to rent out a property in Mumbai to a new tenant in April. “Our present tenant was supposed to leave the house by March-end. Now, I cannot go to Mumbai to close the deal, neither can he find some other accommodation in such trying times. We have decided to allow him an extended stay,” he said.

“This time around the demand for accommodation increases. I have properties in Pune and Powai as well. The situation has definitely hit choppy waters,” he added.

Financial advisors and bankers say it’s too early to opine on the impact on the economy but did express that the situation was dire with the Sensex declining at a rapid pace.

Realtor S Pirani said, “Societies are not allowing entry to outsiders. They are exercising caution and following the mandate of social-distancing and rightly so. It is just a business, our lives and safety of loved ones comes first.”

Most employers in the real estate business have granted their employees paid holiday so that they can stay safe and in quarantine along with their families.

“Clients have postponed meets and business is being conducted virtually. I closed shop on March 17. Financially, we have definitely been impacted,” said realtor Charu Bhatnagar.

Real estate advisor Khalid Memon said nothing concrete could be said about the impact felt by the realty sector until the first week of April, after the retraction of the lockdown. However, most businesses are positive that things would look up post the lockdown.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Man kills wife, buries, lodges complaint
Content:
Representative image

TIRUPATI: A 30-year-old man was arrested by local police on charges of murdering his wife and tampering with the dead body at Peddapalle, Chittoor district.

According to police, the accused, identified as Malreddy, works as a driver of a private travels bus. He married G Gayatri in 2019, without the consent of their parents. But a few months after the wedding, Malreddy and his family members began harassing Gayatri for additional dowry.

Since January 2 Gayatri has been untraceable, Malreddy lodged a missing complaint. Later, on her parents’ plaint police took Malreddy and his family members into custody. Upon interrogation, the husband confessed that he killed Gayatri and buried her.

Title: Surat: Five cases of public notification violation filed
Content:
Representative image

SURAT: Police registered fresh five cases of the violation of public notification in two police stations of the city on Wednesday.

These were the cases on the first day after the 21-day countrywide lockdown was announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The police detained 66 vehicles on Wednesday from the commuters who were caught moving in the city without any important reasons.

However, there was a considerable drop in the number of cases pertaining to the notification violation compared to the past few days. On Monday, a total of 21 cases were registered, while on Tuesday, 19 cases were filed.

Since the last five days, the police have registered 60 cases of the violation of public notification and detained 587 vehicles. The cops are likely to step up their vigil in the city for the strict implementation of the lockdown with each passing day.

Those booked for the violation of public notification were those who were found running their businesses despite the orders of the lockdown.

Title: No coriander: Father-son duo beat up woman vendor in Ahmedabad
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A woman vegetable vendor, Sonal Patni, 30, of Daskroi has complained at Nikol police station that a father-son duo, Rohit and Vishal Patni, had beaten her on the service road of Kathwada GIDC because she refused to sell them coriander leaves (cylantra) and some other spices. Top police officials said they registered a case under sections 323, 294(b) and 114 against the accused and are hunting for them.

“On Tuesday evening, while the complainant was on the service road near the Hudko Gate in Kathwada GIDC area, the accused asked for coriander leaves and spices. The vendor said that the police had stopped all sales as it was getting late,” said a police official.

The duo began beating the complainant and threatened next time they will deal with her more seriously.

Title: Kotdwar man, 26, who travelled to Spain is U’khand’s 5th Covid-19 positive case
Content: Dehradun: A 26-year-old man from Kotdwar in Pauri Garhwal who came back from Spain recently has been tested positive for Covid-19. He was admitted to Base Hospital, Kotdwar, on March 16 and his report came on Wednesday.Talking to TOI, health department officials said that the man was in Spain between February 20 to March 13 and returned to his hometown on March 15. He was brought to Kotdwar Base Hospital after he complained of cough, cold and uneasiness in breathing.“The man was initially treated in the isolation ward and his sample was sent for testing on March 21. The report came on Wednesday and he was found to have tested positive,” a health official said.Elaborating on the route taken by the man while going to his hometown, the official said that he took a flight from Spain to Delhi on March 13 and then stayed in a hotel in Delhi on March 14.He took a train to Dehradun on March 15 and reached his home on same day.Meanwhile, the doctors at Government Doon Medical College (GDMC) on Wednesday informed that the condition of a trainee officer of Indian Forest Services, who was admitted here on March 19, has improved and he was tested Covid-19 negative within 7 weeks of treatment.“He will be discharged after 72 hours if another round of tests also confirm his negative status. However, he will be kept in home quarantine for another 14 days,” said Dr Amita Upreti, DG (health).

Title: Businessman jumps off 6th floor of hotel in Coimbatore
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: A 34-year-old businessman committed suicide by jumping from the sixth floor of a private hotel on Avinashi Road in the city on Tuesday after he incurred losses in his business.

Police identified the deceased as N Sooryaprakash, a resident of Velampalayam in Tirupur district .

“Sooryaprakash checked in at the hotel on Tuesday morning. He leaped off the building around 7pm and died on the spot,” a police officer said.

After being informed by the hotel management, the Race Course police reached the spot and recovered the body.

“He was involved in solar panel business and incurred losses in it. He was depressed and undergoing treatment for the past 20 days at a private hospital in the city. It also seems he had some family issues,” the officer said.

On Tuesday morning, he told his family members that he was going to Bengaluru to meet his business friends, but came to Coimbatore, the officer said.

Based on a complaint from his relative, police filed a case under Section 174 (unnatural death) of the Indian Penal Code . Further investigation is on.

Title: Ahmedabad: Grocer attacked for demanding milk dues
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A dairy owner in Bodakdev area of the city was manhandled allegedly by a customer after he refused to give him milk on Tuesday.

Police said Ashish Chawda (25), who runs a dairy and grocery shop in Bodakdev, alleged in his complaint that one Lagdhir Rabari and his three aides attacked him.

“At around 4 pm on Tuesday, Rabari came to Chawda's shop and asked for a milk pouch worth Rs 10. Chawda told him that he would not give him milk as he had not paid Rs 250 in milk dues.

This angered Rabari so much that he and his men beat Chawda up and ransacked his shop,” said an official from Vastrapur police station.

Title: Coimbatore man who gave false information on Naxals booked
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: The city police booked a 45-year-old man on Tuesday after it was found that the information he gave on Naxals was false.

Police said V Rajendran, a daily wager from Pannimadai, called forest guards and told them that Naxalites had approached him while he was at a farm in Varapalayam and demanded sacks of rice. The accused was staying with his father, who works at the farm, for the past two weeks after a family dispute.

Immediately, forest personnel, Special Task Force (STF) and Naxal Special Division (NSD) personnel reached the spot to conduct inquiry. “While questioning, they found that Rajendran lied about Naxalites and learnt that he was consuming liquor with his friends when he made the call,” a police officer said.tnn

Title: Minister Nitin Raut hits the street after complaints of short supply
Content:
The minister said he would look into the matter as to why the mills had not been operational

NAGPUR: District guardian minister Nitin Raut on Wednesday surveyed city markets after receiving complaints about scarcity of essential commodities and disruption of emergency services in the backdrop of national lockdown due to coronavirus outbreak. He also interacted with a few citizens and traders .

The minister was accompanied by divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar, city police chief BK Upadhyay, superintendent of police Rakesh Ola and others. Raut also had a meeting with high level officials at the divisional commissionerate to review the situation.

Raut, who visited Kalamna, Itwari, Jaripatka, Khamla, Gokulpeth and some other markets, said he was satisfied to see adequate availability of grocery items, fruits, vegetables with the vendors and also to see medicine shops open.

“I have issued instructions to the police department, civic and district administrations to ensure citizens are not adversely affected due to short supply of any essential goods/services. None should go hungry and be deprived of any essential commodity,” said Raut.

After coming across a few closed flour mills during the visit, the minister said he would look into the matter as to why the mills had not been operational.

“I will urge chief minister Uddhav Thackeray to make some emergency provisions for the daily wagers who have lost their livelihood because of the lockdown,” he said.

Title: Maharashtra: High-power panel for release of prisoners
Content:
PUNE: Additional director-general of police ( prisons ) Sunil Ramanand on Wednesday cited the Supreme Court’s latest directives and said a high-power committee was being set up for considering the release of undertrial prisoners and convicts on parole in view of the Covid-19 health scare.

“The panel would comprise chairman, state legal aid services, a high court judge, additional chief secretary (home) and the ADG prisons,” Ramanand said, adding that the objective was to decongest the overcrowded jails.

The Supreme Court has suggested parole for convicts jailed for up to seven years term and similar benefits to the undertrial prisoners awaiting trial for offences entailing maximum punishment up to seven years. The committee would meet once every week, as per the apex court directives.

A data of convicts and undertrial prisoners meeting the criteria suggested by the SC would be forwarded to the committee members in a day or two, Ramanand said. “The committee members will check the data submitted and recommend the release of the inmates from the prisons after applying some filters and criterion,” he said.

“It is important to decongest the prisons as early as possible,” said Ramanand.

Title: Good samaritans come to the aid of those stranded
Content:
Dehradun: Ankit Negi, a labourer from Himachal Pradesh, had got stranded in Haridwar due to the lockdown. After staying in the factory, where he works for two days, Negi decided to walk all the way to his home in Chamba from Haridwar. After walking for 90 kilometres and all but exhausted, he could hardly walk anymore.

Fortunately, a local journalist Kiran Kant noticed Negi in tears and offered to drop him home. Negi, who was overwhelmed with the kind gesture, has now made a video which has gone viral on social media.

In the video, he says, “Kiran Kant helped me when I was in need. I request all to help others during this coronavirus crisis. I promise that I will also help people to repay Kant Ji’s gesture.” Kant also dropped a woman, who works in a hotel in Devprayag, to her home in Rishikesh.

In yet another such instance, a brother-sister duo, who had got stranded near Dehradun’s Clock Tower, were also similaarly helped. They were sent to disaster control room from where the authorities arranged transport to take them to their home in Uttarkashi. Police personnel in several areas were also seen helping people reach their homes. Meanwhile, CM Trivendra Singh Rawat on Wednesday announced a helpline number — 6398500571 — for all those who are facing issues in reaching their homes.

Title: No more ambulatory bags: PGI to start testing ‘ventilator’
Content:
The team of experts had started making this ventilator when they felt that manually pumping ambulatory bags wa... Read More

CHANDIGARH: The Union ministry of health and family welfare, which is facing an acute shortage of ventilators vital for critical care of Covid-19 patients, is interested in a low-cost portable ventilator, weighing just 1.5 kg, designed by a team of experts from Chandigarh’s PGIMER and Indian Institute of Science (IISc), Bengaluru.

India has only 30,000 ventilators in all the hospitals for its population of over 1.3 billion and it is estimated that at least 5% of Covid-19 patients would need them because of respiratory distress.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday had announced a Rs 15,000-crore package to improve and augment health infrastructure, including ventilators, to manage Covid-19 cases.

“We have recently been approached by the Mahindra Group, which is looking for mass manufacturing of ventilators. We have been working on this for a year and now we feel this will be beneficial for the society during this pandemic,” Dr Rajeev Chauhan, neuro-anaesthesiologist, PGIMER. A patent has already been published for the device, named “Respiration Control (RC),” and it abides by the international guidelines.

The team of experts had started making this ventilator when they felt that manually pumping ambulatory bags was not only tiresome, but also required a patient’s attendant to be immobile for a long period. “Our price will be between Rs 10,000 and Rs 12,000 only. The cost of highend ventilators is around Rs 10 lakhs,” said Eshaan Dhar, an IISC Bengaluru passout and former scientific officer, department of atomic energy.

The device works on battery for 7-8 hours and can then be connected with direct current. The complete unit is noiseless and requires no manual assistance. The apparatus is made of high quality plastic with no sharp edges. The safety of this device is ensured by incorporating volume and pressure microsensors at patient end. Moreover device is incorporated with disconnection alarm. “It is a shortterm alternative to critical care ventilators, which are expensive complex microprocessor driven devices,” said Dr Chauhan, who has spent his own funds to design this device. He said, “We have ethical approval for testing on patients and the same will start soon.”

The designers claim that the device has advantages like sparing human being of tiresome effort, low cost, delivering required volume per breath, easily transportable and easy to assemble. “Although this model is not intended to replace the expensive/ efficient mechanical ventilators, it may be considered for short-term ventilation as required in Covid-19 for which we have a dearth of ventilators,” said Eshaan.

Experts feel that mass production of the device will not take more than 15 days. “We have done field tests and now it has to be seen how it works on patients at the PGI,” said Eshaan.

Title: Pune: Sassoon hospital to treat Covid-19 patients under 1 roof from March 31
Content: PUNE: The newly constructed 11-storey building of the state-run Sassoon General Hospital will function as a dedicated facility to treat patients diagnosed with the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) infection from March 31.The 11 designated private hospitals, four identified isolation facilities, including Naidu hospital and YCM hospital, and two other health hubs in Pune district will initially admit suspected patients and get their tests done at National Institute Virology (NIV).The patients will then be moved to the dedicated 1,100-bed facility at Sassoon hospital , if they test positive for Covid-19, for further treatment.“We are working round the clock to make the facility functional. We gave out the work order for fitting a gas pipeline on Monday. Once that is done, we can make the hospital operational,” said Ajay Chandanwale, spine surgeon and dean of B J Medical College-attached Sassoon General hospital.“Once it is ready, every patient diagnosed with Covid-19, either at designated private hospitals or any other government isolation hospital in Pune, Pimpri Chinchwad and the rural areas of the district, will be shifted to the new facility for further treatment,” he told TOI.“It is observed that many patients seeking medical care for a host of other ailments do not visit a private hospital any Covid-19 positive person is admitted there for treatment. Their fear is that they may contract the infection. Keeping all this in mind, the district administration has decided to treat all positive patients under one roof,” Chandanwale said.The state government had in 2008-2009 decided to build a super-specialty hospital at the existing building of the Sassoon hospital. Initially, the decision was to build a six-storey hospital to provide super-specialty treatment in areas such as minimally invasive cardiac surgeries and neurosurgeries.“The government subsequently decided to build an 11-storey building for super-specialty treatment to needy patients. The same building will now be used as a dedicated Covid-19 hospital in Pune district,” Chandanwale said.A district administration official said, “To make this hospital functional, we require trained manpower, mainly intensivists, pulmonologists, doctors and nurses, for critical and non-critical care areas, Class IV staffers and equipment. We will need cooperation from private hospitals and, if required, their staffers need to volunteer for services."

Title: Pune: 4 other Naidu hospital inmates on road to recovery, may be discharged soon
Content: PUNE: Four Covid-19 patients__ the cab driver admitted to Naidu hospital, the daughter of the couple discharged on Wednesday, a co-passenger from Yavatmal who had travelled to Dubai, a student studying in the US who returned home during vacation— are on the road to recovery.Their swabs were taken for testing on Wednesday morning and the test reports are awaited. If they are favourable, all four will go home on Thursday or Friday.The 21-year-old student, who self-reported to Naidu hospital after he developed symptoms of irritation in his throat, told TOI on Wednesday, that his first test was done on Wednesday morning and the results were awaited.“Once the first test result is negative, the doctors will test me again on Thursday and if that result is favourable I will be eligible for a discharge. I am fine heathwise and doing good. I have no complaints now and have recovered well,” he told TOI.The cab driver, who was the third patient in Pune to test positive, is also on his way to recovery. The 21-year-old student said, “Almost all of us are recovering and following the protocol. The cab driver also tested negative in the first test and the results of his second test is awaited. Once that is confirmed, he may also be discharged.”The patient hailing from Yavatmal was also awaiting his second test results.The daughter of the couple discharged on Wednesday was hopeful of a discharge soon. She said, “My swabs have been taken and I am waiting for my results. But, like my parents, I shall also be home soon.”

Title: Surat Municipal Corporation asks city doctors to report severe ARI cases
Content:
Representative image

SURAT: Now, members of Indian Medical Association (IMA), private hospitals, physicians and paediatrician will have to mandatorily report acute respiratory Infection (ARi) cases to Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC).

In a notification issued by SMC’s health department on Wednesday, doctors, IMA members, physicians and paediatricians have been asked to upload reports of their ARI cases on a regular basis on vbdc.jaiminisoftware.com along with follow-up details. Negligence on the part of doctors and hospitals will be dealt with under Gujarat Epidemic Regulation-2020.

According to the notification, surveillance, monitoring and random sampling of severe ARI cases will help in preventing COVID-19 transmission in the community.

Dr Ashish Naik, deputy municipal commissioner (health and hospital), told TOI, “We have noticed that patients with no travel history have tested positive for COVID-19. This means that COVID-19 transmission has started in the community. Regular monitoring and surveillance of severe ARI cases reported in hospitals will help prevent COVID-19 transmission among members of the community.”

Dr Naik added, “All the doctors, IMA members, physicians and paediatrician will have to regularly upload their ARI cases with SMC online, failing which strict legal action will be taken against them under Gujarat Epidemic Regulation-2020.”

Title: Labourers’ appeal in Gujarat: Don’t lay us off
Content: AHMEDABAD: Representatives for workers’ groups have written to the state government, demanding a slew of measures for labourers in the unorganized sector during the Covid-19 lockdown.On Tuesday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced a 21-day lockdown stating that it was the only way to break the chain of infection.The Gujarat Construction Workers’ Association on Wednesday, pressed certain demands of theirs, including 50% of minimum wages for labourers during the 21-day lockdown period and Rs 3,000 for every farm labourer, among others.General secretary of the association, Vipul Pandya, in a letter to the state chief secretary, said that the International Labour Organization has warned about large scale employment in the coming days due to coronavirus pandemic.He said that while the Gujarat government announced that organizations should not lay-off workers or introduce pay cuts during the lockdown, it was not mandatory.“Many industries are shut due to the lockdown. The state government, instead of passing the buck to industries, should itself ensure that workers and labourers do not suffer financially in this 21-day period,” Pandya said.There are 15 lakh construction labourers in the state of whom about 6.50 lakh are registered with the Gujarat Building and Other Construction Workers Welfare Board. The board has Rs 2,900 crore in funds to be used for the welfare of workers and we request the government to directly transfer 50% of their minimum wages to eligible workers, the letter said.Another group, a network of civil society groups, researchers and urban practitioners, among others, wrote to chief minister Vijay Rupani, seeking “emergency support for urban informal sector workers in cities of Gujarat to combat the Covid-19 pandemic”.Informal workers in Gujarat constitute 80% of the workforce of urban areas.

Title: Schools can’t ask for fees till they are reopened: Uttarakhand govt
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand government on Wednesday issued a notice stating that schools can’t ask for fees from students until the lockdown is lifted and they are reopened. The order applies to all CBSE, ICSE, UBSE and other schools of the state, officials said, adding that the decision has been taken after it was found that some private schools were pressurising wards of students to submit fees online.

The parents of school children welcomed the move. saying that it would be a big relief for them.

Meanwhile, city-based Graphic Era University on Wednesday offered use of 60 rooms with attached toilets outside the university campus to be used for quarantine purpose.

A communique from the university said that a letter in this connection has been sent to the union ministry of human resource development.

Title: Ajmer parents queue up for permits to bring kids back
Content: Ajmer: There was a long queue outside the district magistrate’s office on Wednesday as most of the parents wanted permit to go to Jaipur and Kota to bring back their children studying there.The state government has imposed ban on travelling by private vehicles and the toll booths are closed.Parents are worried about their children as they are residing alone in hostels and want to bring them back. A single woman parent said she is trying to get permission to travel to Jaipur from the last two days as SMS Medical College is closed and her daughter is alone in the hostel. Another parent said his son was taking coaching from Kota and now there is no way to bring him back.On the direction of the state government, district collector issued a notification to get travel permit on a genuine reason and asked to apply online through email to RTO of Ajmer But the situation was different in Ajmer as there were long queues of not only parents, but also pilgrims from different states, who were stuck in the dargah region and wanted to go back to their places.In Ajmer, most of the students take coaching in Kota and Jaipur. They also choose colleges mostly in Jaipur or Udaipur. When the state government had announced lockdown till March 31, parents were assured that classes will resume after that and asked their wards to remain in hostels. But after the 21-day lockdown announcement made by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, parents fear that it is going to be difficult for their children residing alone.

Title: PMC to rope in pvt hostels to boost capacity for quarantine
Content:
Pune: The civic body has planned to take over 10 private hostels and convert them into isolation wards in a bid to increase the quarantine capacity by 2,000 beds in the first phase.

“A number of cases have come to light where patients have flouted the rules set for home quarantine and have ventured out. In such cases the only option is to put them into institutional quarantine,” said Sanjeev Wavre, a senior health official of the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC).

PMC officials said the step had been taken in consultation with the district administration. Hostels run by government departments as well as those owned by private institutes would be acquired.

According to the civic administration nearly 5,000 beds can be acquired for isolation by converting the hostels. Nearly 2,000 would be available in the first phase while the remaining would be added in the days to come. The authorities want to be prepared with 15,000 to 20,000 beds for isolating suspected and positive cases across the city. Around 45 hostels would be acquired for the makeshift arrangement.

“These hostels are to be acquired on a temporary basis. Converting them into quarantine facilities will be easier and we hope to start the first phase of acquisition in a week,” said Rajendra Muthe, head of PMC’s land and estate department.

He said, “Basic facilities like beds, separate rooms and sanitation facilities are already present in these hostels. The PMC would have to provide protective equipment like masks, hand gloves and sanitizers in these hostels to convert them into isolation wards. The civic body would also take care of maintaining cleanliness and hygiene. Talks are underway with both government authorities and private institutions. Five institutions have already consented.”

PMC officials said most of the hostels have mess facility, but most of them were empty right now because the workers and staff members had left the city due to the coronavirus scare. Thus, catering services needed to be outsourced they said.

The civic administration has already converted two PMC properties at Sinhagad Road and Sanas ground into additional isolation wards. These facilities have a capacity of 350 beds. Even the Naidu hospital has space and to isolate nearly 100 patients.

Title: Pune: Separate rooms for foreign students
Content: PUNE: The Savitribai Phule Pune University has provided separate rooms to each of the 124 foreign students at its international students’ hostel in view of the Covid-19 outbreak.Most of these students are from the southeast and west Asian countries.“The capacity of both the boys and girls’ hostels is adequate and hence we could allocate them separate rooms for maintaining social distance,” said Vijay Khare, the head of SPPU’s International Students Centre.Besides, the university has decided to arrange a separate vehicle for students, if they want to buy necesssary food items from the market.“The university couldn’t make common food arrangements as they are from different countries and their food habits are varied. As a result, we have made available necessary equipment at a common kitchen where these students can prepare their food. Water, electricity connectivity etc are in place to facilitate their daily use,” Khare added.

Title: Uttarakhand: Seven suspected Covid-19 patients quarantined in US Nagar
Content: RUDRAPUR: As many as seven suspected coronavirus patients were quarantined in Udham Singh Nagar district on Wednesday. All the seven patients are from the same family, district health officials said, adding that the residential premises where the family stays, were also disinfected by the department.District’s chief medical officer Dr Shailja Bhatt told TOI that the suspects are related with a woman from Pilibhit (Uttar Pradesh) who has tested positive for Covid-19."As reported to us, the family came in contact with a coronavirus positive woman a few days back. So as a precautionary measure, we have quarantined them,” she added.However, sources told TOI that the family members were denying that they came in contact with the infected woman.Meanwhile, health department officials found out about a woman from Bageshwar who had returned from France recently and was staying at a hotel in Rudrapur.The woman has now been quarantined in that hotel itself.

Title: NGOs pitch in to serve food to the needy in Coimbatore
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: In the wake of 21-day national lockdown, NGOs in the city have floated a forum ‘Coimbatore Food Emergency Team’ to provide food to people in shelters, sanitary workers, homeless people and unorganized sector workers such as security personnel.
