With some civic bodies, as in Chennai, laying curbs on volunteers of service organizations providing food, representatives of the forum said they have strict rules in place for volunteers, who come forward to serve people, and would maintain hygiene of kitchen workers.

It is to be noted that some of these NGOs have been working with the city corporation to provide food for people in shelters.

While some NGOs have kitchens at Town Hall and Balasundaram Road, others have come forward to provide food to the needy in their own areas.

On Wednesday, NGOs such as No Food Waste and Nizhal Maiyam provided food to sanitary workers, homeless people and others in need.

Padmanabhan Gopalan, of No Food Waste, said not more than two volunteers would be involved in distribution work and that they would always maintain distance. “Kitchen workers won’t be changed, and their health would be screened regularly. All personnel would wear gloves and mask,” he said referring to the regulations that they had formulated.

Usually, he said, No Food Waste would get calls only from those who have excess food to be donated. “But now we are getting calls from people saying they can’t get food and asking for help. Security personnel, cleaners and other unorganized workers need help at this time.”

Vaishnavi Balaji, of Food bank Coimbatore, said they were allowing only those volunteers with proper credentials to offer services. “We would provide food for pavement dwellers, daily wagers and anyone those who can’t access food because of the lockdown,” she said.

B Murugan, of Nizhal Maiyam, said they had provided food to around 1,150 people, including sanitary workers, homeless people and others who couldn’t get anything to eat as shops were closed, on Wednesday.

Title: Jaipur: Nurses, doctors face threats from landlords for treating coronavirus patients
Content:
A deserted road during the lockdown in Jhotwara on Wednesday

JAIPUR: Four days ago, people clapped and clanged their utensils from their balconies to appreciate the role of doctors and nurses for their untiring efforts to treat Covid-19 patients and suspects.

But these bravehearts are now receiving threats from their landlords for the same reason for which they were appreciated. The state government was however quick to react to the problem and sternly warned houseowners from victimising such people.

The health department has been flooded with such complaints from doctors and nurses who informed higher authorities about the threats they have been receiving from their landlords.

“I have been deployed for the treatment of suspected Covid-19 patients at SMS Hospital. My landlord is aware about it. Since it is a highly contagious disease, my landlord is apprehensive that they might get infected with it because of me, which is not true at all. They have asked me to vacate the house,” said a nursing staff on condition of anonymity.

Not only her, but there are others such healthcare staff facing the same problem. Such cases have been reported in Bhilwara, Jhunjhunu and Jaipur where large number of health department's teams have been deployed in survey, treatment and care of the Covid-19 suspected patients and positive cases.

In Bhilwara and Jhunjhunu, they are working hard in areas where curfew has already been imposed as these areas reported Covid-19 cases in clusters.

Taking it as a serious issue, health department has decided to take action against such landlords. “Some complaints have been received about landlords threatening nurses and doctors, who are tirelessly working for Covid-19 related cases. The state government has taken serious note of it and issued a notification in this connection,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary, health department.

The notification says, “Landlords and house owners are forcing them to vacate their rented residences. The behaviuor amounts to obstructing public servants in discharging their duties. The state government has issued Rajasthan Epidemic Diseases Covid-19 Regulations 202 under Epidemic Diseases Act 1897 and Rajasthan Epidemic Diseases Act 1957 for prevention and containment of Covid-19.”

It further directed district collectors, SPs and zonal deputy commissioners of municipal corporations to take strict penal action against such landlords and house owners under relevant provisions of law and submit action taken report on a daily basis to the health department.

Title: Ajmer needs strong food supply system
Content:
Ajmer: The first day after the announcement of 21-day lockdown witnessed chaos and confusion in the city. There were complaints of hoarding and black-marketing from some places in the city. The public distribution system, too, was not able to work to its optimum. However, were some groups and organizations came forward and distributed food in kacchi bastis.

Ajmer Municipal Corporation on Wednesday started a massive cleaning campaign in the city and started fogging at different places. Ajmer has a considerable number of daily wage workers as there is no industry and people mostly work in unorganized sector. “There are people working in Transport Nagar on daily wages and there are those working in masonry,” said AMC councillor Chandresh Sankhla, who has initiated a group of AMC councillors to feed them daily.

Similarly Kirti Pathak, a social worker, started a hunger helpline for those who wanted cooked food and her team on Monday distributed food to over thousand people living in kacchi basti. “We wanted to show that we are united in times of crises. Councillor Lalit Verma also initiated a drive and asked people in his ward to call his number to distribute wheat flour and milk any time in the Dalit-dominated region of Dholabhata. He asked people not to come out and arranged a van for door-to-door supply. On the other hand, district administration was confused on providing the supply as there was no arrangement of any vehicle. tnn

Title: Pune: Citizens try their hand at baking, brewing & broiling to pass time
Content:
An enticing dish made by Aniruddha Patil

PUNE: From simple to exotic meals , from sweets to savouries — hundreds of Puneites have taken to cooking to pass time during the coronavirus lockdown. With plenty of time on their hands, citizens are cooking up a storm with either stocked or fresh ingredients.

Men, women, even children are cooking unique meals together and posting about their experiments on social media. City-based entrepreneur Shruti Digholkar has been experimenting with baking bread for the last three to four days. “So far, I have tried to make Brioche and pav. I am a foodie and I need good food. I wanted to eat something different without going out on Tuesday and ended up making vada pav at home, including the pav. The pav didn’t turn out to be exactly like what you get in bakeries but with the vada and chutney, it tasted good. For the last few days, I have been experimenting with different recipes and chutneys. The plan is to experiment a lot more over the coming 21 days,” she explained.

Kothrud resident Siddharth Date has taken up the challenge to learn cooking during the lockdown period. “I fried puris on Wednesday,” he declared, with a hint of pride.

Aniruddha Patil, founder of the popular food platform Pune Eat Outs, too has busied himself rediscovering his passion for cooking. “Since work-from-home was announced, I have been cooking every single day. I used to enjoy cooking but gave it up due to various reasons. Now, I am rediscovering the joy. I have made chicken biryani , AP Chicken Curry, and much more,” he explained.

Patil said to keep people hooked, the platform has also asked its members to cook and share their experiences via social media. “We are getting nearly 180 posts about people’s experiments each day. We have a lot of people from outside India participating as well,” he said.

As per grocery store owners in the city, baking ingredients like flour, yeast, cream, brown sugar and others have been registering a high demand as many have taken to their kitchens to experiment.

Title: Nagpur: Coal capacity pipeline declines in India, new coal projects continue to be added
Content:
Representative image

NAGPUR: On the brighter side, a staggering 47.4 gigawatt (GW) coal-fired power projects at different stages were cancelled in the country last year. On the darker side, 8.8GW of new coal-fired capacity has entered the under-construction phase, all of which is reliant on significant public funding.

This was revealed in the latest report ‘Boom and Bust 2020: Tracking The Global Coal Plant Pipeline’ which is the fifth annual survey of the coal plant pipeline. Jointly released by the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air (CREA), Greenpeace International , the Sierra Club and Global Energy Monitor , the report highlights that the capacity of coal power plants in the pre-construction phase fell by half from 2018 to 2019 in the country.

From 60.2GW in 2018, it saw a sharp fall to 29.3GW last year. “In India, capacity under construction and in pre-construction phase declined 80% from 311.1GW in 2015 to 66GW in 2019, with only 2.8GW newly proposed in 2019,” the report adds.

The findings state that the biggest growth in construction took place in South Asia in 2019, with India starting construction of 8.8GW of new coal power capacity. Along with this, 8.1GW coal- based capacity was commissioned in the country last year. “This, despite the country already having 19.3GW of coal plants frozen in construction mainly due to financing problems,” the analysis states.

The new construction includes four coal plants —- Adani Godda, Patratu and Udangudi having 1.6GW each and Yadadri with 4GW.

All the 8.8GW of new construction received substantial financing from the Power Finance Corporation or the Rural Electrification Corporation , both of which fall under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Power and are set to merge this year.

The report further indicated that with the private sector exiting coal plant development in the country, the public sector is stepping in and footing the bill. “In a submission made by the ministry of power in Parliament on March 17, it removed more than 23GW capacity of coal fired power stations belonging to the private sector from under-construction category. Most of these plants started development before 2011,” states a press release issued by the organizations.

The report also highlights that even as the coal power development shrank in India, the amount of new coal-fired capacity added to the grid last year outpaced the retirement existing old power plants, resulting in net growth in the coal-fired capacity in the country. This further negatively impacted power load factor of coal plants, thus indicating worsening overcapacity.

“The shrinking coal pipeline in India, forced by huge over-capacity,subdued demand for electricity, falling utilization factor, falling prices of renewable energy, drying investments, and increasing public resistance due to pollution gives hope for a future with reduced fossil footprint for the country. But, at the same time new capacity is being added to the grid, new projects are given clearances and infusion of public money into new projects by the government raises concerns,” said Sunil Dahiya, analyst at Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air.

Stressing on the environmental and economic crisis faced by the country, Dahiya added that a strict policy against building or clearing new coal-based plants with rapid retirement of older units is urgently required.

Despite the decline in development, the coal fleet grew by 34.1 gigawatts (GW) globally last year. Nearly 64% of the newly commissioned capacity was in China and 12% in India. “Global power generation from coal fell by a record amount in 2019, as renewable energy grew and power demand slowed down,” said Christine Shearer, lead author and Director of Global Energy Monitor’s Coal Program.

Adding that the number of new plants added to the grid accelerated, Shearer said, “The world’s coal plants operated a lot less. For banks and investors that continue to underwrite new coal plants, this means weakened profitability and increased risk.”

Title: Maharashtra: Farmers offer home delivery of vegetables
Content: NASHIK: A group of farmers from Dindori taluka has taken the initiative to provide vegetables to citizens at their doorsteps amid the 21-day nation-wide lockdown to contain the spread of coronavirus The farmers are delivering fresh veggies in their own vehicles to socieity residents on the conditiong that minimum 20 families place bulk order.“People are finding it very difficult to get fresh vegetables. Hence, we have taken the initiative of home deliver,” said Vaibhav Jagtap, a farmer who has formed the group.“Bulk order, from 20-25 families from one housing society, will make it easy for us to transport vegetables to the city residents. We are reaching out to people through social media platforms,” said Jagtap, who hails from Chinchkhede village of Dindori taluka .The farmer said that they have been supplying vegetables for the last two days. “We have already provided vegetables to four-five housing societies. Over 20 families are staying in each of those societies.”Soon after the PM declared a complete lockdown late on Tuesday evening, the orders have increased considerably. “I have got collective orders for vegetables from 25 housing societies in the city,” added Jagtap.The group plans to add more farmers to their group and increase vehicles to meet the increasing demand.

Title: Rain, dust storm in east Raj, mercury takes a dip
Content:
Edited

Jaipur: With active western disturbances and upper air cyclonic circulation, many places in the eastern Rajasthan witnessed dust storms and rainfall. Many places in Jaipur and other parts of the state witnessed abrupt power cuts.

Dust storm , rainfall and lightning were witnessed at many places in the state including Jaipur, Dausa, Sikar, Alwar, Bharatpur and Sawai Madhopur on Wednesday evening. The sudden rainfall also guided mercury to take a dip while many places in the state witnessed waterlogging.

People in Jaipur woke up to a comparatively warmer morning as a minimum temperature of 19.6°C was recorded. In the afternoon, many places in the city witnessed heavy showers, dust storm and lightning. With sudden rainfall, the localities, including Jhotwara, Khatipura, Vaishali Nagar, Sodala, Shyam Nagar and others witnessed power cuts.

“As a precautionary measure, power was switched off but was restored in an hour,” said an officer with the Jaipur Vidyut Vitaran Nigam Limited.

This was the fourth time in this month so far when heavy rainfall and dust storm was witnessed which has disturbed the farmers in the state.

` Jaipur Met office said that similar spells of the rainfall and dust storm will take place for the next 48 hours in the eastern and western parts of the state.

However, earlier in the day mercury took an upward swing across the state as Sringanganagar remained coldest in the state where a minimum temperature of 16.3 °C was recorded.

On the other hand the day temperatures across the state were between 35°C to 39°C.

Sriganganagar was followed by Churu where a minimum temperature of 17.7°C was recorded, Jodhpur 19.5°C, Ajmer 20.8°C, Bikaner 21.4°C, Jaisalmer 21.7°C, Barmer 21.8°C and a minimum temperature of 23.3°C was recorded in Kota.

In its forecast Jaipur Met office said that mild showers accompanied with dust storms will occur at many places in the eastern and western parts of the state in the next 24 hours.

Title: IB board class X, XII students promoted
Content:
International Baccalaureate (IB) board has decided to promote students of classes X and XII. This is the first time that such a step has been taken by any board but as the crisis is affecting everyone and with exams being cancelled, the board was compelled to take the call. Earlier, private schools decided to promote students till class VIII.

In Jaipur, only a few schools are affiliated with IB board. Jayshree Periwal International School, Jaipur is one of them. Principal of the school, Jayshree Periwal said, “Since the crisis is global, IB board , which is an international board, has decided to promote the children to further classes. Students are being evaluated on internal assessment marks. This was necessary or else students would have been in trouble.”

Other boards are yet to make any decision on it. There has been no notification by the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) as of now.

Board of Secondary Education, Rajasthan (RBSE) chairman Dharampal Jaroli said that they are planning to give exams once the lockdown is removed. “Only two subjects for class X and a few subjects in class XII remain. We need just one week’s time and within a month, we will announce the results as well. After the lockdown, we will conduct the remaining exams,” clarified Jaroli.

Title: Nashik Municipal Corporation to start quarantine facilities in private hotels, colleges
Content: NASHIK: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) is planning to take over hotels and colleges in the city to increase quarantine facilities in view of the Covid-19 outbreak.The civic body has already made an arrangement for 220 people in municipal and other private hospitals.People, who have recently returned from Covid-19 affected countries/areas are quarantined, while the suspected or positive patients are to be treated in isolation wards.NMC health officials didn’t disclose many details but conveyed that they are adding facilities as a backup option for newer patients. “We have made arrangements for 220 people right now. But we are also increasing the capacity as part of the preparedness in view of the emergency as we don’t want to take any risk,” said a health official.Therefore, the civic officials are planning to take over some city hotels and colleges to provide quarantine facilities, the source said.Currently, the quarantine wards are functioning at its own building in Tapovan, Panchavati and Bytco Hospital in the Nashik Road area of the city. Apart from this, some beds have been reserved in some private hospitals for quarantine.The district and civic administration has also planned to treat Covid-19 patients in NMC’s Zakir Hussain Hospital. Earlier, the hospital was serving pediatric patients and maternity homes. But the hospital has now been reserved to treat Covid-19 positive patients only.The civic body is taking strict sanitary measures across six divisions of the municipal corporation. Even there is a lockdown in the city, the health machinery of the municipal corporation is keeping the city clean.All the garbage vans are operational across six divisions of the city to collect the daily waste. Approximately 1,110 tonnes of garbage was collected on Monday and Tuesday.During the janata curfew days, the NMC cleared all the black spots collecting a total of 575 tonnes of garbage.

Title: Nashik: Chaos at grocery stores, people engage in panic buying
Content: NASHIK: Several grocery shops across the city witnessed huge rush of consumers on Tuesday night after Prime Minister Narendra Modi addressed the nation and announced complete lockdown for 21 days.People had to wait for nearly an hour before they could get a chance to buy grocery items. Some shop owners even threatened to close down their outlets to rein in the unruly buyers.“There was huge rush in the evening as people rushed to buy grocery items. Hence, we had not option to allow people in groups of few people a time in the outlet, said Ashish Kankariya, a grocery outlet owner .“The rush began on Tuesday evening after people panicked following the 21-day complete lockdown announcement by the PM, he said.“We are unable to control the crowd as they are indulging in panic buying for one-two months. They are buying in such a way as if they will not get grocery. This may create shortage and other may face inconvenience,” said another trader Rajesh Daga.He said that people should not indulge in panic buying. They should think about everyday customers, including daily wage earners and slum dwellers. “People should also think about such common people who can’t purchase grocery at once,” said Daga.“I had made markings in front of my grocery outlet and had requested people to maintain social distancing. We had also provided them with hand wash and sanitizers to consumers as part of preventive measures for Covid-19 ,” said Dinesh Patel, a grocery outlet owner.

Title: Pune: Official duty coupled with domestic chores takes a toll on women cops
Content: PUNE: It is a tough time for women police. They are required to be out on the city streets to deal with people, who are not taking the lockdown seriously and at the same time thinking about the safety of their near and dear ones.Some women police officers have sent their children to their native places while others reach home so late in the night that it has been days since they saw their children before they were tucked into bed.Considering the speed at which the coronavirus can transmit among people, the police force is at a high risk. Taking a serious note of the situation, sub-inspector Kavita Rupnar of the Hinjewadi police has already sent her two daughters to her native place in Sangola, Solapur district , about 250km from here. “Now, I can perform my duties without tension,” Rupnar told TOI.Her elder daughter is four years old while the younger one is only 18 months old. “My younger daughter can’t even talk. It was very difficult for me to send them so far but I do not have any choice,” Rupnar said.She said her husband too had gone with them and her in-laws are taking good care of her daughters. “Every day I contact them through a video call. That is the only relief after a busy day,” she added.Deputy commissioner of police (Pimpri Chinchwad) Smita Patil too has a similar story to share. Patil’s three-year-old son has hardly been able to see his mother in the last two days. “In a way, it is good because during the day many people come in contact with us. We take maximum care but why should we put our children at risk,” Patil said.Patil, who only caught a four-hour nap in the last 36 hours, said that she’s careful not to interact with her family members unless she has taken a shower after returning from work. “I’m able to manage things only thanks to my mother-in-law, who takes care of the kitchen, as well as my son,” Patil said.Her cabin has also undergone a quick makeover since the coronavirus scare began. Now, only four chairs remain in her cabin for visitors. “We have sensitised all police officers about personal health,” she said.The senior police officer, who has been appointed as an incident commander, said that she has been receiving 100 applications to facilitate movement of essential and emergency services every day. “We are doing our best in this critical time,” she said.

Title: Virus delays Koregaon Park police station opening in Pune
Content: PUNE: The much-awaited inauguration of the Koregaon Park police station has got delayed because of the coronavirus outbreak The state government had allotted 20 gunthas at survey No.112/5 between lane numbers four and five at KP in August 2008.The project gathered momentum and the construction work commenced after the German Bakery bomb blast killed 17 people and injured 64 on February 13, 2010.The KP police station was carved out from Bundgarden police station for meeting challenges related to rapid urbanisation and a spurt in crimes. The police station is currently functioning from below the Koregaon Park bridge.Deputy commissioner of police (zone II) Shirish Sardeshpande told TOI, “The finishing work of the police station is over after a new contractor was appointed for expediting the project. The work of installing paver block is in the final stages. The work related to electrification, interiors and furniture has been completed.”He said, “We planned to inaugurate the police station in 10-15 days but have put our plans on hold because of the coronavirus outbreak as no labourer wants to come and complete the pending work.”Pramod Patki, senior inspector, Koregaon Park police station, said, “The work of constructing a garden is also in progress. We hope to complete the pending civic works at the earliest.”The KP and the Hinjewadi police stations, now under the Pimpri Chinchwad police commissionerate, are the only two planned facilities built in recent times.

Title: Coronavirus Update in Chandigarh: Punjab STF for 28-day take home drug dose for patients
Content: CHANDIGARH: In a step to save drug addict patients from relapsing as well as coronavirus infection during the ongoing curfew, Punjab antidrug special task force (STF) head ADGP Harpreet Singh Sidhu has suggested to the state health department and the home department to allow such patients to take home medicines for 28 days at one go.Drug addict patients are being allowed two- week take-home dosage at one go as of now. Over 3.66 lakh patients have so far been registered for treatment in 193 Outpatient Opioid-Assisted Treatment (OOAT) clinics, 35 government de-addiction centres and 106 private de-addiction centres and nine central jails.The STF head warned that the lack of medicine would not only lead to relapse of drug abuse victims but such patients could possibly indulge in experimenting with concoctions which may even lead to death. Sidhu also recommended that the health department should ensure presence of adequate staff at government de-addiction health facilities with sufficient stock of medicines.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Pune: 4 admitted to isolation wards, 15 swabs sent for testing
Content: AURANGABAD: Four more people with a travel history and Covid-19 symptoms were admitted in two separate isolation wards on Wednesday.Three were admitted in District Civil hospital while one in Government Medical Hospital respectively.As many as 15 swab samples of suspected persons were sent to National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune on Wednesday for tests. So far, 79 swabs have been sent to the NIV for Covid-19 testing. Reports of 28 samples are still awaited. The district civil hospital is keeping a close watch on 720 persons.With no domestic flights taking off from Wednesday, there were no screenings conducted at the Aurangabad Airport.Meanwhile, the screening centres at Aurangabad Railway Station, Central Bus Stand, Cidco Bus Stand, Harsul T Point, Cambridge Chowk, and Nagar Naka witnessed 4,818 people screened on Wednesday. Altogether, 97,049 people have been screened at these six centres until 2 pm on Wednesday. In total, 11 people were found with fever, cough and cold symptoms and were referred to the District Civil Hospital.Among the screened people, 17 had travelled from outside the country out of which eight were stamped mandatory 14-day quarantine as per the doctor instructions.Three people were sent to Kalagram Exhibition Centre in Chikalthana MIDC which took the total number of quarantined patients to 11. The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation is providing beds, sanitation and food to these persons with the help of the Aurangabad branch of Confederation of Real Estate and Developers’ Association of India. Remaining ones had displayed the availability of secluded accommodation within their homes.State health department issues guidelinesIn a letter written to the district civil hospital, Maharashtra deputy director of health services Archana Patil has outlined a pharmacological protocol for the treatment of Covid-19 cases. The letter advises the doctors on using hydroxychloroquine, oseltamivir, azithromycin, lopinavir, and ritonavir. Meanwhile, on Wednesday joint secretary, health ministry Lav Agarwal stated that the hydroxychloroquine can only be given to two particular cases for use as prophylaxis. First to the health staff, dealing with suspected or confirmed cases and immediate contacts of the confirmed cases. The rest should be avoided, he said.

Title: Civic aid: Essentials delivered at doorstep in Kolkata
Content: KOLKATA: Various corporators in Kolkata and Salt Lake have stepped in to help senior citizens living alone as they are finding it tough to meet their daily dietary and medicine requirements owing to the lockdown.Realizing that in her ward there were several aged residents, whose children lived abroad, Juhi Biswas — KMC councillor from ward 81 in New Alipore — reached out and assured them that they had no reason to worry about procuring essentials. “Please call or send a text and we shall deliver milk, bread, rice, wheat, pulses, potato, onion, cooking oil and medicines. Rest assured, my colleagues will wear masks and gloves and sanitize their hands before delivering the same doorstep,” she said.In Salt Lake, Bidhannagar Municipal Corporation ward 41 councillor Anindya Chatterjee took up a similar initiative. It was the plight of a 71-year-old resident of BB block with restricted mobility, who didn’t have anyone to help him shop for essentials, that drew Chatterjee’s attention. “In the absence of domestic help, a relative was sending me cooked food. But then came the lockdown and no one could deliver the food to me,” Ray said.Now, Chatterjee and his team has stepped in. “We are going to be his meals-on-wheels for the next 20 days so that he doesn’t go hungry,” he said. He has made a list of 100-odd residents above the age of 70, many with children abroad. His ward covers AA, AB, AC, AD, BB, BC and BD blocks.Bidhannagar mayor Krishna Chakraborty said all councillors were in touch with residents and providing assistance. On Wednesday, an elderly resident called up Chakraborty and sought help to go to the bank. A car was arranged so that he could make the trip to the bank and return. In ward 40, councillor Tulsi Sinha Roy said that an elderly person had called her up from CD block, saying that he needed milk packets, but was not being able to step out. “We delivered the milk to his house. We are trying to help the residents as much as possible,” Roy said.“Our men from ward offices are visiting elderly residents to check if they need help,” said a civic official.

Title: RU postpones exams till April 14
Content: Rajasthan University has postponed all its exams till April 14 until further notice. The decision was taken due to the ongoing lockdown and suspension of classes by the authorities. University teachers have been demanding the postponement of examinations as gathering of thousands of students can lead to spread of virus in the area.

Title: Kolkata Lockdown: Stopped for lockdown flout, woman attacks cops
Content: KOLKATA: A woman, her friend and the driver of the app cab they were in were arrested on Wednesday when they broke the lockdown protocol and ventured out on the road, allegedly lying to cops that they were going to buy medicines. When stopped at a police naka near the Punjab National Bank crossing at Salt Lake, the woman got into a confrontation with the policemen, pushed one of the officers and allegedly smeared his uniform with blood from an old cut on her forehead.The cops on the spot as well as onlookers recorded the entire incident on multiple video cameras. Subsequently, officers from the Bidhannagar North police station arrested Sarmistha Debnath, her friend Nirmal Balmiki and the driver, Md Javed, all residents of Picnic Garden.These three arrested were among the 871 people who were rounded up on Wednesday for violating the nationwide lockdown, imposed to minimize chances of novel coronavirus infection. Since Monday evening, the count added up to 1,874. Police also spent a considerable time, marking out zones for buyers to stand in queues outside grocery shops, medicine shops, ATMs and even inside malls and departmental stores in Ultadanga, Phoolbagan, Narkeldanga, Patuli, Jadavpur and Rashbehari. “No need to crowd around the shops in the market. Maintain social distancing! @KolkataPolice has started marking the area in front of the shops so that safe distance is maintained by customers,” commissioner of police Anuj Sharma tweeted. At neighbourhoods in and around Beliaghata and Phoolbagan, the local cops also introduced a token system to reduce crowding near shops.The Salt Lake’s violation took place around 12.30pm, when sub-inspector Suman Bhattacharya and his team were at a check-naka near PNB. They stopped the app cab that came from the CA-Island direction. The officer asked to see the passengers’ identity cards and the purpose of them travelling during the nationwide lockdown, imposed to minimise novel coronavirus infection.“The passengers initially refused to respond and then said they were going to buy medicines. When our officers asked them to show the prescription, they couldn’t. Then they claimed they were returning after buying provision. When we asked them what they had bought, they showed us a few packets of noodles. The claims seemed unjustified and we told them they would be prosecuted for violating the lockdown protocol. At that point, the woman alighted out of the car, got into a confrontation and bit an officer. She had an old cut on her forehead, which she scratched and wiped the blood on the officer’s shirt, saying she would frame him that ‘he injured her’. But all of her histrionics were captured on camera,” said a senior officer of Bidhannagar City Police.Based on the complaint lodged by the policemen, the three were booked them under IPC sections 186 (obstructing public servant in discharge of public functions), 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), 269 (negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life), 270 (malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life), 506 (criminal intimidation) and 34 (common intention). The three would be produced in a Salt Lake court on Thursday, police said.Another act of defying police was reported from Konnagar in Hooghly on Tuesday, when cops went to shut a sweet shop that was kept open near the station. Local councillor Tanmay Deb allegedly stepped in and started an altercation with the cops that a sweet shop was an essential goods facility and that it should be kept open. In the melee, he also allegedly pushed the cops. Deb was arrested under IPC Section 188 and released on bail.

Title: Day 1: Coimbatore locks itself down
Content:
Curfew in Coimbatore

COIMBATORE: There was total adherence in the city as well as in rural areas of Coimbatore on Day 1 of the lockdown on Wednesday. Buses remained in their depots, cars and bikes in the parking spaces and people stay put in their houses. But for those who stepped out for buying groceries or medicines, the entire population of Coimbatore remained indoors.

The arterial Avinashi Road, the commercial hub of Town Hall, walkers’ paradise Race Course and every other place in the city was deserted. The only men out there in all these places were police personnel keeping a tight vigil to enforce the curfew.

“I have been living in Coimbatore for the past 35 years. Never have I seen the city so deserted. The sight of empty roads everywhere itself is disturbing,” said S Mahadevan, a senior executive in a construction company.

Police stopped each and every one who ventured on to the roads and let them off only after convinced they were out for essential purpose. While some were warned and sent back, a few youths who were found roaming out just to have a view of the city during curfew had to face punishment.

In some places like Thondamuthur they were made to remain in squatting position for a few minutes, while in other places they were made to do sit ups.

At Singanallur, a motorcycle-bound duo had to face the wrath of a policeman who beat them with a lathi after finding that they were roaming out for no reason at all. As the video of the incident started going viral, senior police officers instructed police personnel not to beat motorists but warn them. “Compared to other places in the state, the number of people who ventured out randomly without any purpose is less in Coimbatore. But we gave punishments like sit ups so that even those less number of people don’t come out,’’ said a police officer.

By evening, the number of such wanderers also came down. By the time, police had booked about 38 cases on people for violating Section 144 of CrPc. All these cases were in rural areas, particularly, Sulur, Thudiyalur , Kinathukadavu , Madukkarai and Chettipalayam.

“Only if there is an emergency or something very essential you can come out of house,'' said animal husbandry minister Udumalai Radhakrishnan after holding a review meeting at the Tirupur collectorate to take stock of the situation. He said 172 people are being monitored in the district and all are stable. Five teams have been formed to keep tab on them.

“A number of people could be seen coming out in motorcycles, please don’t do it,’’ he appealed.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Essentials stores to stay open till 1 pm in Krishna district
Content: VIJAYAWADA: Krishna district collector A Mohammed Imtiaz passed an order on Wednesday, permitting stores selling essential commodities, like rythu bazaars, milk booths and grocery stores, to operate from 6 am to 1 pm.He also warned traders and vendors in the city against creating artificial shortage and hiking up prices. Rythu bazaars would be set up at multiple locations in the city to prevent rush of buyers, he said.

Title: Good response to lockdown, essentials to be available: Nashik Administration
Content: NASHIK: Strict implementation of the lockdown was seen in most parts of Nashik on Wednesday and the city wore a deserted look despite the festive occasion of Gudi Padwa.Most of the roads were clear and only the vehicles transporting essentials were seen moving around on Wednesday. It was in stark contrast of the scenes from Tuesday.“As against huge rush to the market places on Sunday night and Monday morning, Wednesday was quite peaceful and the streets were deserted. The only ones to move around were those ferrying essential services with valid proofs,” a senior police officer said.Since Tuesday morning the streets and chowks in the city have been barricaded, disallowing movement of vehicles. Moreover police officials manning a few chowks are discouraging movement of people.“The borders of the district have been sealed. All junctions have been barricaded. The message to the citizens is very clear. The media reports about people being punished for loitering have also worked to reduce the people on the road. The intention is to keep everyone safe,” the officer said.Nashikites told TOI that they were relieved after the government assured supply of essentials would not be hampered.“There was some confusion as to whether we would get our essentials. Now that government has made it clear that there is enough stock and that shops will remain open, we will step out as per requirement,” Keshav Shinde, a Nashik Road resident, said.District guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal also took to Twitter, urging people to remain indoors. “Let’s make things better for people, who are working day and night for the safety of citizens. Stay indoors and stay safe,” Bhujbal said, appealing people to maintain social distance even at home.District collector Suraj Mandhare allayed public fear about delivery of essential goods ordered by them. “There have been some issues about delivery of goods – food parcels, vegetables, grocery and other essential items. Efforts are being taken for streamlining the same. In a day or two that also will fall in place,” he said.

Title: Social distancing outside grocery stores in Nashik
Content: NASHIK: The grocers in the city have demarcated places outside their shops where customers should stand, maintaining safe distance from each other, when they come to make purchases.“We have demarcated spaces where people coming at our shops should stand. This has been done keeping in view the health advisory on coronavirus and the safety and precautionary measures of social distancing to be followed to contain the spread,” Rajesh Patel, a grocer from Nashik Road, said.Railways had implemented the same idea when they were still taking current booking for trains. “The Railway authorities had earmarked the space where the customers could stand. Using the same concept, we decided to demarcate the space outside the kirana shop,” Patel added.The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) also swung into action and demarcated the spaces that people could follow.The NMC officials at Nashik Road carried out the painting of such demarcations at several places. “It suggested by one of our employees and the idea was quickly replicated. It would not be feasible for the corporation to go to every place and do so. But nonetheless the people are getting the idea of how to deal with it,” the officer said.The shopkeepers now have the responsibility of disciplining their consumers or closing down their shops till further notices.“The orders by the district disaster management authority (DDMA) are very clear that the shops that will be allowed to function during the lockdown period will have to stick to central government’s health advisory on social distancing. The message is loud and clear – if the consumers stand dangerously close, the shopkeeper will have to face the music,” the police officials said.

Title: No curbs on grocery stores, says joint CP
Content:
Struck: A policeman charges at a man while another looks on and a man in khaki hits a scooterist with a lathi

Pune: Joint commissioner of the city police, Ravindra Shisve, on Wednesday said no restriction was imposed on the functioning of grocery shops, but a blanket permission cannot be given to all employees of such facilities to move around on roads.

On Tuesday, there were complaints from several citizens about the police forcing closure of grocery shops. Even the shopkeepers complained about the police blocking their employees from moving around, forcing them to prematurely close their shops.

Grocery shops are among the essential establishments exempted from the prevailing lockdown orders.

On the ground, some people faced issues related to access to these shops and high-handed approach of policemen despite instructions from the higher-ups against the use of force. “Clearly, the instructions are not percolating to the policemen implementing the orders on the ground,” said a Kondhwa resident.

Shisve told TOI, “The 21-day lockdown announcement on Tuesday evening was followed by a rush of people at various grocery shops for panic-buying, and this compelled us to forcibly shut shops at many places. We have not imposed restrictions on how long the shops should operate in a day, but the crowding was defeating the social distancing purpose. The local police stations are taking care of this issue. We have requested the shopowners to allow their employees to stay with them for two to three days till things get settled.”

He said, “It has been observed that policemen are behaving politely, but large number of people are misbehaving. Strict instructions have been issued to policemen against the use of force.”

He said a majority of Puneites were supporting the police by staying indoors but conceded that people in the fringe areas and slums were venturing out on the roads. Most of the city thoroughfares, otherwise, wore a deserted look on Wednesday.

“We shall be focusing on the fringe and slum areas to secure a total lockdown and have started making frequent announcements through the public-address system in these areas. Still, if they don’t listen, we shall start booking them for offences under Section 188 (disobedience of order promulgated by a public authority) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).”

He said, “We have set up check-posts at more than 180 spots across the city to ensure only the vehicles engaged in transporting essential goods and services move on roads. Apart from physical presence of police personnel at these posts, they are being monitored by CCTV cameras.”

At places where there is no CCTV backup, the police have started taking photographs of errant motorists and issuing them written orders to report to the police station concerned after the lockdown period is over for facing legal action under Section 188 of the IPC. “The whole purpose is to avoid any confrontation between the police and the people,” the joint police chief said.

On Wednesday, the police received 7,315 messages on the WhatsApp helpline numbers, 5,000 requests on Twitter handle and 233 requests, mainly from private firms, on emails. The police responded to 5,683 of the WhatsApp messages, he said. Almost half of the calls were for travel requests citing medical reasons, especially from cancer and diabetic patients.

Title: Activist gets notice over rumours
Content:
Pune: The Koregaon Park police have served notice on an activist from Nagpur for sending false WhatsApp messages on the Pune divisional commissioner’s number on the night of March 15, asking him to shut down two hotels in the city claiming that their guests and employees were suffering from coronavirus.

The divisional commissioner, Deepak Mhaiseker, during verification found the messages were false. He then lodged the first case of spreading rumours about coronavirus against an unidentified man under Section 188 of the Indian Penal Code and the Disaster Management Act.

Senior inspector Pramod Patki from the Koregaon Park police said, “We conducted technical investigations and traced the activist to Nagpur. The activist, during questioning, told police that he had received messages on his WhatsApp number and had forwarded them to the divisional commissioner without verifying them.”

Patki said, “We have served notice to him under the Criminal Procedure Code, asking him to join in investigations.”

Title: All hands on deck: Three big pvt hospitals join corona fight
Content: New Delhi: The city’s fight against Covid-19 got a shot in the arm on Thursday with three top private hospitals — Indraprastha Apollo, Max and BLK — announcing isolation and treatment facility for people suffering from the disease.Till date, only public hospitals like Safdarjung, Ram Manohar Lohia (RML), Lok Nayak, Rajiv Gandhi Super Specialty, Guru Tegh Bahadur (GTB), Deen Dayal Upadhyay and Baba Saheb Ambedkar hospital had this facility. Fortis group is also likely to announce the creation of isolation facility on Friday, sources said.While Apollo hospital has reserved 50 beds for Covid-19 patients, Max group has reserved 20 beds each at its Saket and Patparganj centres and BLK 10 beds for isolation and treatment. All three hospital groups said they were prepared to scale up the infrastructure significantly, depending on the need, on a short notice.Apollo has also received licence for Covid-19 testing. Sangita Reddy, joint managing director of the group, said most centres have been cleared for testing.“Full-scale testing is likely to start by the end of March. We will have the provision for home collection of samples as well as drive-through testing. In-hospital testing will be discouraged, except for in-patients. Dedicated fever clinics are being set up to screen people. People who qualify under the criteria for tests will enter via the drive-through, make payment as per government recommendations and then be tested,” Reddy said.Reddy added more than 50% Covid-19 positive cases need only isolation and symptomatic management. “Isolation is not possible in many Indian homes where 6-7 people share common accommodation and toilet. Soon, we will be launching “Project Stay I” to create medical rooms in hotels/hostels with light medical supervision for quarantine and creating a barrier before people come into the hospitals,” she said.The medical rooms will be rolled out in Chennai, Mumbai, Hyderabad, Kolkata, Bengaluru and Delhi, starting with approximately 50 in each city. They will go up by 50 rooms every three days, to reach an eventual target of 5,000 across the country, said Reddy.Preetha Reddy, vice-chairperson of Apollo, said preparations are on for the next stage of community transmission of the virus. “There will be over 250 beds, which can be enhanced to 500 beds, to treat the critically ill. We expect to give advanced care to over 2,000 patients a month.”Max Healthcare will begin admission of Covid-19 patients from Friday. The treatment will be available in specially designated isolation wards — east block of Max Super Speciality Hospital, Saket and Patparganj, said Dr Sandeep Budhiraja, group medical director, Max Healthcare. Max Labs will also begin testing for Covid-19 from samples collected from four units across Delhi-NCR, he added.“We will keep adding bed/wards in case there is a surge in the number of patients,” Dr Sanjay Mehta, unit head and vice-president of BLK said.Delhi has reported 39 cases of Covid-19 as on Thursday. Of this, state authorities said, 31 are admitted in various hospitals. “The total number of patients admitted till date is 156. Some of them were allowed to go home once the tests results came negative. Five people found positive have fully recovered,” said an official.

Title: FIR against 4 for violating quarantine norms in Trichy
Content:
Representative image

UDHAGAMANDALAM: Police have registered an FIR against four people, who are under house quarantine , for coming out in public places in the Nilgiris. While two are from Kotagiri taluk , the other two are from Gudalur taluk .

The four are among the 732 people in the district who are being monitored by the healthcare officials. As on Wednesday, as per the public healthcare department, the number of people under home quarantine stands at 732, which include people from abroad. The number of people under home quarantine increased by fivefold in the past four days. It was 142 four days ago.

“These people are asymptomatic, but they have travel history. Hence, they were advised for home quarantine,” deputy director of public health department Dr P Balusamy said. “We are monitoring all the quarantined people in the district.”

Roping in police, revenue and health departments, the district administration has formed several teams to follow up the 732 cases. Exercise of pasting stickers of self-explanation, in connection with home quarantine, on the respective doors of the houses of 732 people is underway.

“All the people returned from abroad have a seal on their hand for monitoring. But people who crossed the state border don’t have such identification. Hence, we are carrying out awareness programme in the neighbourhood,” said P Babu, project director, TNSRLM, who is part of the coordination team.

Public can contact the control room number 1077, if they see persons of home quarantine in public places.

Title: Realtors ask govt to release cess for labourers’ benefit
Content:
Jaipur: Developers in the state have requested the state government to utilise the funds of labour cess, approximately amounting to Rs 2000 crore, to support the real estate industry during the lockdown period.

In a letter to chief minister Ashok Gehlot, the Confederation of Real Estate Developers’ Association of India (CREDAI) chairman, Gopal Dasgupta, said labour cess should be distributed among the workers of projects as there survival has become difficult .

After the developers in the state also showed their helpnessess to support their labourers for long as the industry has been facing a slump for many years, the appeal was made to the state government.

Dasgupta said, “The developers deposite 1 per cent of the project cost in the development authority, housing board or municipal corporation, wherever the project is constructed. We have requested the state government to utilise the funds for labourers who have lost their employment due to the lockdown.”

Acting on the request, the state has also sanctioned funds for labourers associated with the industry.

According to sources, Rs 400 crore has been sanctioned and Rs 1,000 will be transferred in the accounts of labourers who are registered with the labour and employment department.

A developer however said this would not solve the purpose as registration of all labourers is not done at the department. As per estimation, there are nearly 2 lakh labourers in the state associated with the construction industry.

“The builders only register their permanent labourers. Temporary ones are paid on a daily basis. The state should involve developers too in the process so all the workers of the industry can be benefited,” said the developer.

Title: Masjids shut for the first time; Teka protest off
Content:
Nagpur: Masjids across the city have been completely shut probably for the first time.

On Tuesday, the muezzins announced no azaan (call for prayers), namaz and even juma (Friday prayers) will be held at masjids in the wake of restrictions imposed by the government to contain coronavirus.

Complete lockdown of city had resulted in big turnouts in masjids. Muslims have now been asked to offer all prayers at home.

The Shaheen Bagh-style protest, which had started in February at Farooq Nagar’s Teka ground, was also suspended by the organizers. They put up a board announcing they were extending support to Maharashtra government’s decision of complete lockdown to fight coronavirus.

Last Friday, the ‘Juma’ and Khudba (sermon) durations were curtailed from 45 minutes to just 10-15 beside shutting wazuhkhana (abulation taps), removing carpets and towels in their bid to prevent the spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19).

Though Muslims turn up in large numbers for the Juma, many reached the masjids only at the start of prayers and left soon after.

At some places, volunteers requested the namaazis to maintain social distancing guidelines and not crowd the premises.

Following the curfew, it wouldn’t have been possible to hold prayers as more Muslims had been visiting masjids.

Title: Kolkata police ferry seniors in distress to kin’s places
Content:
Police in civilian clothes help an elderly couple get to their relative’s place on Wednesday

KOLKATA: The city on Wednesday witnessed several individual efforts from Kolkata Police personnel that helped senior citizens and those from outside the city find some relief amid the 21-day lockdown that came into force on Tuesday midnight.

A scribe, who was quarantined in Nagpur, was at his wit’s end when his parents Tapan Bose (88) and Kalyani (73) informed him that they had run out of necessary ration and medicines. The couple resides in Thakurpukur and live on the third floor of a building that has no elevator. They used to shop online but with home deliveries uncertain, they were stranded.

The scribe, who works in Nagpur, decided to tweet their distress. “I tweeted around 9pm, tagging Kolkata Police commissioner Anuj Sharma and joint CP (crime) Murlidhar Sharma. The joint CP reverted within an hour and sought details. I told them I needed to shift my parents from the apartment in James Long Sarani to my sister’s residence on Jatin Das Road. On Wednesday morning, they took my parents in a police vehicle,” he said. He later thanked the cops in another tweet.

In Chitpore, Sonali Bose (77) and her sister Somali (72) were in dire straits after they ran out of ration. They turned to their nephew Swapan Sen for help, who sent an alert to cops via social media. Soon, the local police dropped them off at a relative’s place in Girish Park.

Biswajit Banerjee shared on Kolkata Police’s Facebook page his experience when his uncle residing at Bansdroni felt that he did not have enough to sustain him during lockdown. His uncle spoke of his helplessness to Banerjee. He then sought help from the local police who arranged for an auto and dropped Banerjee’s uncle to a relative’s residence at Hazra.

Cops also lent a helping hand to people from other states stuck in Kolkata. One of them, Omkar Nath, initially tweeted about his troubles, tagging the PMO. His friend Naresh Kumar Boblani, tagged Kolkata police in the thread and the joint CP took note. Soon, cops spoke to Nath and assured him of all help.

Title: Nashik civil hospital seeks 20,000 personal protection equipment kits
Content: NASHIK: The Nashik civil hospital authorities have asked the administration for 20,000 pieces of personal protection equipment (PPE) for doctors, nurses and staff working at the isolation ward.Senior health officials at the hospital said their stock of PPEs will likely run out in a month. The PPEs comprise essentials such as body coveralls and N95 masks.There have been no positive cases so far in the district.Resident medical officer Anant Pawar confirmed the civil hospital only has enough equipment to last a month. “We have placed an order for 20,000 PPEs, which would be sufficient for the next year,” he said. The PPEs will be available within the next three to four days.The PPEs are used by doctors, nurses and staff working in the isolation ward, where those with Covid-19 symptoms are admitted. “The PPEs will also be provided to healthcare workers and staff at the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC), which has set up a 100-bed Covid-19 treatment facility at the Zakir Hussain hospital,” Pawar said.According to records with the Nashik civil hospital, 411 people with travel histories to countries with the infection have arrived in the district. So far, the district civil hospital has sent 57 throat swab samples to the National Institute of Virology, Pune, for investigation. Of them, 56 have tested negative, while the result for one is awaited.Officials said hospitals and medical workers are bracing themselves for infections. They said more beds could be added for Covid-19 patients at the Nashik civil hospital.Medical staff have to take serious precautions — right from taking samples for tests to administering treatment for those who have tested positive. The swabs are then preserved in tubes before dispatching them to NIV at Pune for investigation.Officials said they were also keeping a close eye on those with travel history. A total of 92 people have already completed the mandatory 14-day quarantine.

Title: Civic body fumigates bus shelters in city
Content:
Trichy: As part of the preventive measures undertaken by Trichy corporation for tackling the spread of novel coronavirus, bus stops and other public spaces in the city were fumigated on Wednesday.

Officials said that bus stops are being disinfected twice a day as it witnesses a huge flow of passengers, including those from neighbouring districts. Apart from bus stops, auto stands and taxi stands are also being sanitized.

The officials said that the over 200 bus shelters falling in the corporation limits would be covered under the disinfection drive gradually. “Our sanitary workers are spraying a mixture of Lizol and water at the bus stops,” a sanitary official said.

The disinfectant is being sprayed in the ratio of 1 litre Lizol for 9 litres of water. Official sources said that around 20 sanitary workers have been deployed at each of the four zones for sanitizing the bus stops, including the floor, chairs and handrails. The private omnibus stands and other public spots with large footfall like government offices and shelter homes too are being sanitized. “We have adequate quantity of Lizol with us, new hand spraying kits are also being purchased,” the sanitary official added. Officials said that safety masks, gloves and jackets were provided to sanitary workers to ensure their safety.

Title: RU teachers return from abroad, home quarantined
Content:
Jaipur: Rajasthan University has nine teachers on home quarantine for 14 days after they returned from abroad. According to the university administration, the teachers had taken permission to visit abroad for attending various conferences or carry out projects.

In total, 14 faculty members were given nod from the administration out of which nine teachers went ahead with their plan. On their return, they have been put on home quarantine and health officials have been alerted.

Registrar Harphool Yadav said the teachers have been put on home quarantine as a precautionary measure. “Most of the teachers have returned except two. We have put them in home quarantine. One teacher just recently returned from Thailand and he is not allowed to leave his house on the campus as of now. We are following the process as instructed by the authorities,” said Yadav.

Sources said the RU administration wasn’t aware about the return of a few teachers and swung to action immediately after they arrived. They are regularly checking up on any symptoms of coronavirus.

Title: Nashik Zilla Parishad to keep close eye on health of villagers
Content: NASHIK: The Nashik Zilla Parishad authorities have told all block development officers and taluka medical officers to keep a close watch on village houses, especially focusing on those who have returned from other cities.ASHA workers, gram sevaks and sarpanch of the villages have been instructed to check if these people, who have returned from other cities are suffering from cold, cough and fever and immediately get them screened at the primary health centres (PHCs).Leena Bansod, chief executive officer of Nashik zilla parishad, said, “We have also decided to make announcements, through criers at the village level to sensitize such people about the need of getting screened if they are facing health problems.”Once at the PHC, the medical officers would give treatment as per their condition and counsel them about remain self-quarantined for a period of 14 days.People of the rural areas migrate to bigger cities for work, business, education, etc. However, in view of the current scenario, they are returning to their native villages.“The gram panchayat has been told to make a list of such people so that their health can be monitored. These are very emotional and critical issues and have to be handled in a humanitarian way. We do not want to jeopardize the health and well-being of anyone,” Leena Bansod, added.Meanwhile, the Nashik ZP has also made a jingle to be played on FM and radio channels. It is appealing people to fight the spread of coronavirus by not moving out of their respective houses, washing their hands clean with soap and visiting the closest PHC if suffering from cold, cough, body ache and difficulty in breathing.Bansod said that the government and administration has braced to take care of everyone and it is also the responsibility of everyone to cooperate with the administration.The Nashik ZP has also conducted workshops of ASHA workers and anganwadi sevikas to inform them about coronavirus.

Title: Ashok Gehlot, Sachin Pilot back PM Narendra Modi’s 21-day lockdown order
Content:
In this time of crisis, my appeal to all families, who can afford, kindly cook extra meals for atleast two ppl,then… https://t.co/8gS7Lrhh2q — Ashok Gehlot (@ashokgehlot51) 1585146145000

JAIPUR: There is consensus across the political spectrum on Prime minister Narendra Modi’s call for a 21-day lockdown across the country to tackle Covid-19.Hailing modi’s decision, chief minister Ashok Gehlot said Rajasthan was the first state in the country to impose a total lockdown to prevent the spread of the virus.“I am happy that Rajasthan was the first state to declare a complete lockdown. I support Prime Minister Narendra Modi's announcement of a 21-day lockdown. Together we must fight it and defeat it,” Gehlot said in a tweet.“#COVID19 is one of the greatest challenges in our times & we all need to be extra cautious to surmount this challenge. I urge all of you to stay indoors & follow the instructions of the government. True spirit of service to the nation is in doing what is best for everyone,” tweeted deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot.“I support the PM’s decision to implement a 21-day lockdown across India. Rajasthan was among the first states to implement a lockdown. We will ensure that public is not put to inconvenience during this period & essentials are supplied,” Pilot added.The chief minister emphasised there was no time regulation on shops or business establishments and directed police to ensure trucks carrying essential items not disrupted. He said there is no ban on purchase of wheat from the market. Only procurement process of wheat at support price is stopped.

Title: Maharashtra: Police help desk for emergency travel
Content: NASHIK: A Corona Police Assistance Cell has been created at the commissionerate level to help those in need of emergency travel in view of the curfew that has been imposed in the city to contain the spread of Covid-19 Police have issued four cellphone and Whatsapp numbers on which citizens, especially those in need of emergency travel on medical grounds, can send messages to the police. They can provide details such as the nature of the travel, the purpose of travel, the to and from place of travel, documents pertaining to it and seek permission regarding the same.The Whatsapp numbers are 7020583176, 8485810477, 7709295534 and 9373800019.Senior police officials said that use of vehicles has been banned in the city given the curfew imposed to stop the spread of Covid-19. However, personnel of the health department, police and other essential services will continue to work as part of their duty.Those under the essential services category will not face any kind of hassle while moving in the city, said police. The concerned people can contact police on the given numbers if they face any problem. Police also said that ambulance service will also be available.Meanwhile, the police also have come up with 0253 2971233 helpline for industrial permission. The online form for permission can also be filled on https://corona.nashikcitypolice.gov.i\\

Title: Rajasthan govt to give Rs 1,000 to each poor family
Content:
Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot

JAIPUR: In a major step towards ameliorating the hardship of the poor due to 21-day lockdown, the state government on Wednesday announced Rs 310 crore to provide immediate cash relief of Rs 1,000 each family in the state. This would help them to meet the immediate cash requirements, said the government.

The government said the families eligible for the benefit include the BPL, state BPL and Andyodaya beneficiaries who are not receiving any of the social security benefits like pension.

The others eligible are registered construction labourers, street vendors, rickshaw pullers, destitute and other vulnerable sections who are not receiving any social security benefits.

The selection of the eligible families will be made based on Aadhaar database and the amount will be directly transferred into their accounts. The transfer of the money will be communicated to them through mobile SMS alerts.

The government said in case of the eligible family does not have a valid bank account, the district collectors could pay them in cash. For that the state government had made available amount to the collectors.

While Jaipur collector has been allocated Rs 1 crore, the six collectors in the divisional headquarters were given Rs 75 lakh each and collectors in other districts were given Rs 50 lakh each for this purpose, said the government statement.

Title: Agra administration to give food to needy, Bareilly group feeds stray animals
Content: AGRA/BAREILLY: District administration in Agra will provide cooked food to street-dwellers and poor families soon. The work to identify all such people began on Wednesday as the country started its 21-day lockdown to prevent the spread of novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak. Several social organisations have also come forward to help the district administration for the cause.District magistrate (DM) has assigned responsibilities for doorstep delivery of essential items such as fruits, vegetables, grocery, dairy products and medicine, while for any medical emergency, people have been advised to call helpline number ‘108’ and ‘102’.Talking to TOI, DM Prabhu N Singh said, “We are working on a plan to distribute cooked food with help of certain industrialists and social organisations. We have identified 15 places where street dwellers and poor families will be given food packets. The process to identify the needy has been initiated. The distribution of food packets will be done by the police.”Taking cognizance of profiteering by some, the district administration on Wednesday ensured fixed rates of 21 fruits, vegetables and other food items. The DM stated that FIR will be registered against profiteers under Essential Commodities Act, 1955.After PM Narendra Modi’s announcement of the complete lockdown on Tuesday evening, locals rushed to the vegetable markets, grocery and flour shops the next morning. At a few places, Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) officials along with local councillors ensured supply of essential items at doorstep. Police maintained strict vigil after 9am. They patrolled the interior parts of the city appealing to residents not to step out of their houses.In another act of kindness, a Bareilly-based group has arranged food for poor who dwell in the city’s slum areas, at bus stands and railway platforms. They are also feeding stray cattle and dogs. The group’s president Nadeem Shamsi said a campaign has been initiated to feed the needy and stray animals at the time of this crisis.Shamsi, who runs an NGO called ‘Samaaj Sewa Manch’, further said, “On Wednesday, we visited a few areas in the city to look for stray cattle, dogs and even birds, and fed them with bread and biscuits. They were mainly spotted in Civil Lines, Quila, Choupla, Qutubkhana and near dumping sites. We have decided to carry on with this drive to ensure these animals don’t starve or not die. The local administration has allowed us. We will continue with the drive. We are also following the necessary precautions like wearing masks and sanitisers.”“We had bought food - milk packets, wheat and pulses - in large quantities to distribute among the poor. We have chalked out a plan to identify and give food to slum-dwellers near Bakerganj and Chawni, along with beggars at public places like railway stations,” Shamsi added.Meanwhile, Agra DM also chaired a meeting with representatives of medicine retailers and wholesalers. Decision was taken that retail medical shops will operate from 10am to 5pm on even days and wholesalers will operate on odd days from 12pm to 3pm. The DM asked the chemists to publish their contact numbers. Chemists will be taking orders over phone. Their representatives will be issued passes to deliver medicine on two-wheelers. For ordering fruits and vegetables, residents can call in the following numbers: “9058512391”, “9997995812” and “9068311511”.

Title: ESIC hospital sees 13 new cases with symptoms
Content: COIMBATORE: At least 13 new patients with travel history were admitted to the ESIC hospital on Wednesday with Covid-19 symptoms. Their throat swabs were taken and sent for test. While awaiting results, doctors have begun administering them medication based on their symptoms and quarantined them.Speaking to TOI, Dr A Nirmala, hospital dean, said a total of 44 patients, including the 13 arrived on Wednesday, were either isolated or quarantined in the hospital. “Two of them have been tested positive for the virus. The remaining are either their contacts or those with travel history and symptoms.” Dr Nirmala said of four of the five people, whose throat swabs were taken for tests on Tuesday, were tested negative for the virus. The hospital is still awaiting the results of 33 patients.Among the new patients, she said, most of them have a travel history from other states. “Since international flights were banned a week ago, we have only a few patients with travel history abroad. Most of them are patients who recently returned from other states like Kerala and Maharashtra , among others.”According to a health department official, patients who test negative despite having symptoms are also being isolated and treated. The official, however, refused to comment on whether there was any evidence of community transmission of the virus in the district.

Title: Rajasthan govt to give Rs 1,000 to each poor family
Content:
Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot

JAIPUR: In a major step towards ameliorating the hardship of the poor due to 21-day lockdown, the state government on Wednesday announced Rs 310 crore to provide immediate cash relief of Rs 1,000 each family in the state. This would help them to meet the immediate cash requirements, said the government.

The government said the families eligible for the benefit include the BPL, state BPL and Andyodaya beneficiaries who are not receiving any of the social security benefits like pension.

The others eligible are registered construction labourers, street vendors, rickshaw pullers, destitute and other vulnerable sections who are not receiving any social security benefits.

The selection of the eligible families will be made based on Aadhaar database and the amount will be directly transferred into their accounts. The transfer of the money will be communicated to them through mobile SMS alerts.

The government said in case of the eligible family does not have a valid bank account, the district collectors could pay them in cash. For that the state government had made available amount to the collectors.

While Jaipur collector has been allocated Rs 1 crore, the six collectors in the divisional headquarters were given Rs 75 lakh each and collectors in other districts were given Rs 50 lakh each for this purpose, said the government statement.

Title: No time curbs on essential item shops in city: Admn
Content:
Jaipur: The district administration on Wednesday clarified that there was no time restrictions on keeping shops for essential items like grocery items, medicines and milk open. People can walk into the nearest shop to buy these items, authorities said. The district administration has asked all the shopkeepers and grocery associations to keep their establishments open during the lockdown.

For any complaint with regard to supply chain management/supply shortage of essentials and police harassment, one can contact the district collectorate's control room - 0141- 2204475.

Following complaints received at the collectorate, district administration has asked police to ensure giving safe passage to delivery men of online retailers engaged in delivery of essential items to people.

“As IPC section 144 is in place (not more than 5 persons can assemble at a place) and private vehicles are banned, one can go walking and buy grocery items from the nearest shop," Jaipur Collector Joga Ram told TOI. There are about 7,000 grocery item shops in the district.

Iqbal Khan (ADM I) said the district administration doesn't have the recources and manpower to start home delivery servives of essential items.

"There is no such directions (to start home delivery services) from the government for the collectors. Jaipur has a population of 40 lakh. It is not possible to implement it,” Khan told TOI.

Title: Offer help to unorganised workers: CPI to citizens
Content:
AURANGABAD: The Communist Party of India (CPI) has appealed to the people to contribute food for those who have lost their livelihood due to coronavirus outbreak and preventive measures taken thereafter.

In an appeal made through the social media, the CPI members stated that lakhs of hawkers, autorikchsaw drivers, temporary drivers, construction workers, porters, daily wage workers in hotels and theatres are bracing for survival crisis as they are unlikely to get money during the lockdown.

District joint secretary of CPI Abhay Taksal said an appeal is being made to the residents of the city to help such people by donating rice, oil, wheat, flour, spices, toiletries, sanitisers and masks during the lockdown imposed in wake of pandemic.

People who want to donate can bring supplies to INTUC premises, Kamgar Housing Society , Khokadpura. One can also call on 98500 09665 if they are willing to contribute for the cause. Supplies will be distributed to the needy families in the city at their doorstep.

Taksal added that on the lines of decision taken by the Kerala government the CPI appeals to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray to arrange a provision of Rs 500 as unemployment allowance per day and doorstep delivery of free ration to the families of unorganised workers.

Free ration to waste pickers

People involved in collected waste and working at Bajaj Auto and Aurangabad Municipal Corporation ’s dry waste sorting centre in Vitthal Nagar were distributed free ration by corporator Manoj Gangwe on Wednesday. Around 30 workers were provided wheat, poha, saboodana and other kitchen essentials.

Title: PCMC authorises seven medical facilities to treat infected people
Content:
Pimpri Chinchwad: The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) has authorised seven private hospitals for testing and treating patients with Covid-19 symptoms.

Among those authorised “in accordance with the state government guidelines” are Dr DY Patil Hospital in Sant Tukaramnagar, Aditya Birla Hospital, Niramaya Hospital and Lokmanya Hospital in Chinchwad, Lokmanya Hospital in Nigdi, Sterling Hospital in Pradhikaran and Accord Hospital in Moshi.

“A total of 48 beds have been earmarked across these hospitals for treatment of those with Covid-19 symptoms. There will be seven beds with ventilator facilities to take care of extremely-sick patients, if any,” said Santosh Patil, additional commissioner, PCMC.

The PCMC said that the count of Covid-19 positive patients remained unchanged at 12 for the fifth consecutive day on Wednesday. Of the 141 people whose throat swabs were sent for testing till Tuesday evening, 122 samples tested negative. The test results of 7 patients were awaited.

—Satyanarayan Iyer

Title: Kolkata: Not for public, but key drug scarce after ICMR advice
Content: KOLKATA: Within two days of Indian Medical Research Council ( ICMR ) recommending the use of hydroxy-chloroquine as a preventive medication for Covid-19 for high-risk population, medicine shops have been flooded with requests for the drug. This, despite doctors warning that the medicine is not meant for the general public but for specific individuals. On one hand, chemist shops are faced with a glut of demand for hydroxy-chloroquine, and on the other, they are struggling with the depleting stock of medicines as residents have been buying them in huge quantities.The ICMR’s national task force for Covid-19 recommends hydroxy-chloroquine only for asymptomatic healthcare workers handling confirmed or suspected cases and for asymptomatic household contacts of a confirmed case. “Traditionally used in the treatment of malaria and rheumatoid arthritis, there is limited but positive clinical data on this drug as a prophylactic (protective) agent against the current virus. I am getting numerous calls from patients, asking if they should take the medicine. This is not for everyone but for specific individuals, specified by ICMR,” said Subhroyoti Bhowmick, a trained clinical pharmacologist and head of clinical research at Peerless Hospital.Due to discriminate purchase of the drug by others, a young woman from south Kolkata said she was having a tough time replenishing the stock for her mother, who has to have it for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. “My mother has been taking hydroxy-chloroquine for the past five years and it is a life-saver for her. After the ICMR recommendations, the medicine is unavailable in at least a dozen medicine shops in my locality. Even online stores are saying they have run out of stock. How can people make a rush for a medicine, which is not meant for them,” said the woman.Medicine shops agreed many bought bunches of strips at one go. “Ideally, we should not sell it without a prescription.
