But as it happens with other drugs, many stores are handing it out without the mandatory prescription,” said wholesaler, who has been getting frantic calls from local distributors for more supply of the medicine.Avijit Hazra, professor of pharmacology at SSKM Hospital, warned people against this panic buying and discriminate consumption of the medicine. “This a safe drug for most, except those with contraindications. Toxicity might not be a grave issue, but the season for vivax malaria, for which the drug is prescribed, will arrive soon. This unnecessary demand will create a supply crisis when required the most,” he said. “Owing to limited evidence of hydroxy-chloroquine being a protective drug for Covid-19, even specific people, for whom ICMR has made the recommendation, have to follow precautionary and safety measures, even after the dose is prescribed. If people think they are guarded against the virus by taking this medicine, they are treading a dangerous path.”Medicine stores in the city said they were running out of other medicines too—even very common ones—due to panic buying. “The current stock across the city will last about a week. It is depleting fast as people are buying in huge quantities. If transport remains shut, it will be a problem. We are trying to sort out what can be done to maintain the chain,” said a senior office bearer at Bengal Chemist and Druggist Association (BCDA). “The queues in front of the shop are due to panic buying,” said Subodh Ghosh, vice-president of BCDA.A wholesaler pointed out that another reason for depleting stock was that many wholesale shops were shut. “Around 90% wholesale shops in Burrabazar are closed as employees don’t have any mode of transport. The crisis in supply of medicines is going to hit the roof within the a week,” said the wholesaler at Burrabazar.

Title: Aurangabad: People resort to panic-buying despite repeated appeals
Content:
Photo for representational purpose only

AURANGABAD: People across the city, falling prey to the rumours circulating on social media, resorted to panic buying even after both state and central governments assuring that there will be no scarcity of daily essentials.

Authorities have expressed their anguish over people not paying heed to the pleas and fear that this unwanted buying spree may lead to artificial shortage of essential commodities in the markets , giving further scope to black-marketing,

However, authorities are coming out with ways to address the issue at hand. In Aurangabad, the grocery shops are being made to mandatorily put signboards seeking visitors to keep safe distance from one another while visiting the shops.

At some places, where customers did not pay any heed to the safety guidelines as well as the restrictions imposed by the police , shops were made to down their shutters.

The administration’s repeated appeals to the people to not rush to the vegetable markets in large numbers continued to fall on deaf ears following which on Wednesday vegetable vendors were made to set up their stalls at a distance of several feet from each other.

At markets in Shahgunj, Aurangpura, Osmanpura, Mukundwadi and Jadhavwadi, police had to intervene to ensure maintaining of safe distance between vegetable vendors.

In Beed district, vegetable vendors from the traditional vegetable market have been divided into smalls groups and being made to do business from makeshift markets that have been allowed to come up in different parts of the town.

Even in Jalna, Osmanabad, Latur, Nanded, Hingoli and Parbhani, the district administrations and police were found taking steps to ensure that those dealing in essential commodities ensure that customers maintain safe distance while visiting them.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Health workers conduct survey without sanitisers in Aurangabad
Content:
Representative Image

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has failed to provide hygiene items such as masks and hand sanitisers to members of teams carrying out door-to-door surveys to identify people with symptoms of Covid-19 or travel history.

The health teams comprise nurses and healthcare workers.

The teams have been tasked with identifying suspect cases and carrying out primary screening of persons with symptoms such as cough, cold or fever. They are to refer these individuals to health authorities.

Lack of hand sanitisers has the potential to make these teams vulnerable to infection. It was revealed that the healthcare workers use scarves or handkerchiefs to cover their mouth or nose.

Activist Rahul Ingle of the Shahar Parivartan Aghadi said the teams’ members have to be equipped with such items to protect them from the viral infection.

Mayor Nandkumar Ghodele said the AMC has not been able to buy enough hand sanitiser because of a shortage in the market.

State food and drug administration minister Rajendra Shingne has asked manufacturers of hand sanitisers to increase production. The manufacturing of such items is permitted even during the lockdown.

Meanwhile, Eurolife Healthcare Pvt Ltd., a pharmaceutical company has donated sanitisers worth Rs 1.5 crore to deputy district collector of Aurangabad. The collectorate issued a statement that the sanitisers would be distributed to government establishments.

Title: AMU extends Phd submission date due to nation-wide lockdown
Content:
Agra: In view of the nationwide lockdown to curb the outbreak of COVID-19, Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) has permitted research scholars to submit their thesis when the university resumes its routine functioning.

Vice-chancellor professor Tariq Mansoor has directed all AMU students, including foreign nationals, to remain in their respective hostels and residences and avoid travelling. “The PhD students, who completed their course after March 20 and are unable to submit their thesis due to the lockdown, have been permitted to submit their thesis later,” the VC said. He added that the date of submission will be considered as March 21.

Meanwhile, AMU registrar Abdul Hamid said that the essential services staff required for functioning of the hostels, which still have 4,500 students, are supposed to bring their university identity cards for issuance of curfew passes. He said they will be issued passes as it is important to run all the necessary facilities in the residential halls and other places on the campus.

AMU also announced that the university petrol pump will remain open from 8am to 11am on all working days including Friday until further orders.

Title: Erode: Flowers dumped on roadside after merchants refuse to buy
Content: ERODE: After merchants refused to buy tuberose flowers citing closure of markets over Covid-19 pandemic, farmers dumped tonnes of flowers on the roadsides and waterbodies in Sathyamangalam on Wednesday.Farmers from Sathyamangalam and its surrounding villages have planted jasmine, marigold, tuberose and other ornamental flowers in nearly 1,000 acres.The flowers were transported to Erode, Tirupur, Coimbatore and Salem in Tamil Nadu and Cochin, Ernakulam in Kerala and Bengaluru, Mysuru in Karnataka and Hyderabad in Andhra Pradesh One of the farmers S Kandasamy from Vadavalli near Sathyamangalam told TOI that he was not aware of the 21-day lockdown announced by the Prime Minister.“I have brought nearly 200kg of tuberose flowers to the market for sale today,” he said.Kandasamy said one kg of tuberose will be sold for Rs 50. Tuberose is used for puja and garlands. A few merchants who came forward to buy the flowers demanded for Rs 5/kg.Another farmer M Jayaraman said they had spent nearly Rs 7/kg to pluck them from the plants. “We don’t get even that price when merchants demand for Rs 5/kg,” he said.The farmers said the flower plant will wilt if they failed to pluck the flower after they bloom. “To avoid plant damage, we must pluck the flowers even when there is no demand for it,” a farmer said.The farmers demanded compensation from the state government for the loss they had incurred due to non-sale of flowers.

Title: Six more test positive, total coronavirus cases rise to 38 in Rajasthan
Content:
Bhilwara collector takes stock of situation on Wednesday

JAIPUR: Six persons—four from Bhilwara, one each from Jhunjhunu and Jodhpur—tested positive for Covid-19 in the state on Wednesday.

Among the three from Bhilwara, a 75-year-old patient, who tested positive, is undergoing treatment at a private hospital in the district which became the hotspot for the spread of the virus in the state.

He was in the ICU when the first case of Covid-19 was reported from the hospital on March 21. He was in a coma following a stroke. His sample was taken for the test when the family shifted him home. He tested positive today. He is still unconscious and undergoing treatment at his home in Bhilwara. He is the first patient from the hospital to get viral infection. The rest 16 are hospital staff.

Apart from him, two other healthcare workers at the hospital also tested positive for the disease. So far, 17 persons have been diagnosed with the disease at the private hospital.

According to the health department, the four new cases have taken the total number of infected person in the state to 38.

After the 75-year-old tested positive, a team of doctors and nursing staff rushed to his house and isolated him. Officials said that a nurse and an administrative department staff at the hospital too had tested positive.

“The two hospital staff and the patient were infected by the doctor, who had tested positive a few days ago in Bhilwara. The fourth infected person, a woman from Jodhpur, had travelled along with a couple, who had already tested positive for the disease few days ago. They travelled together in the same first AC compartment from Mumbai to Jodhpur,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary, health department.

Following this, chief medical health officer (Jodhpur) Dr Balwant Manda launched a drive to track all people who came into contact with the infected person and traced 17 persons.

She had boarded the Surya Nagri Express on March 17 from Mumbai abd travelled with the elderly couple. The two were travelling back from Istanbul in Turkey. The health department team tracked the woman while checking the couple’s contacts. The train had reached Jodhpur on March 18 at 6.30am. She was picked up by her friend and reached home in 15 minutes. Officials said that she had told them that she did not meet anyone other than her family members. She is now at MDM Hospital undergoing treatment for the disease.

Title: Guv relieves medical team for aam aadmi
Content: Governor Kalraj Mishra on Wednesday relieved his personal medical team from Raj Bhavan to serve the common man. He has been very concerned about the situation in the state, said a Raj Bhawan release. Mishra sent the medical team posted round-the-clock duty at Raj Bhavan to SMS Hospital for public service. Mishra inquired about the situation in the districts from Bhilwara, Pratapgarh, Jhunjhunu and Jodhpur collectors. He has been regularly reviewing the efforts of the government to prevent the global pandemic. He is constantly talking to the chief minister over telephone and getting information about the state's condition. The governor said he supported Modi’s decision.

Title: Milk supply will continue unabated: Sumul
Content:
Representative image

SURAT: Authorities of the Surat District Co-operative Milk Producers’ Union Ltd (Sumul) have urged the residents in Surat and Tapi districts to stay away from panic buying of milk and milk powder as the supply will continue unabatedly during the 21-days lockdown period.

After PM Narendra Modi announced the three week lockdown across the country to contain the spread of COVID-19 on Tuesday night, rumours spread in the city that there will be severe shortage of milk in the coming days. Residents in the Diamond City thronged the milk outlets, dairies and provision stores to purchase milk and milk powder.

Chairman of Sumul dairy, Raju Pathak took to social media on Wednesday urging consumers to stay away from panic buying and assured that Sumul is committed to the regular supply of milk to its consumers in Surat and Tapi districts.

Pathak added, “There are some vested interests in the industry who are trying to gain benefit in the prevailing situation. Our agents and dealers are working hard for the timely delivery of milk to the consumers.”

Sumul supplies about 11 lakh litres of milk in Surat and Tapi districts. “We are receiving milk from all our collection centres across the district on regular basis,” Pathak said.

Talking with TOI, marketing manager of Sumul, Manish Bhatt said, “A detailed list of our agents and dealers is posted on our website. People are free to call them in case they need any kind of assistance.”

Title: Jaipur: Milk by Saras dairies to be available once a day
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Wake up early in the morning to get milk for your family, as Rajasthan Cooperative Dairy Federation (RCDF), through its Jaipur Dairy, has announced to supply milk once in a day during mornings only. Because of this, the supply of milk from Jaipur Dairy was adversely affected on Wednesday, leaving many worried across the city.

The RCDF had on Tuesday decided to supply various varieties of its milk brand Saras only once in a day, that created a problem in the city. Likewise, the private milk booth dairies selling milk in various colonies were also closed down, aggravating the problem.

In the localities such as Jhotwara, Khatipura, Murlipura, Vaishali Nagar, Queens Road, Malviya Nagar, Sodala, Mansarovar and others, Saras dairy milk was supplied only during the early morning hours.

“The problem with us is that our men involved in supply too have shown their reluctance in giving the supply to ensure that they too have lesser exposure. Thus, we have decided to supply milk once in a day. Also, while supplying milk once in a day, we will provide as much milk to a booth as it gets twice in a day,” said a senior officer of Jaipur dairy on Wednesday.

People who don’t usually wake up early to get milk and were dependent on the evening supply, were clueless and were seen roaming around to get milk. “The government should at least allow the private milk booths in the locality. Also, Saras Dairy supply should be monitored by the government agency. At many booths by 9.00am there was no milk and at some booths, the tetra pack which costs Rs 60 was sold in Rs 70 to Rs 80,” said Mudassar Ali, a native of Udyog Nagar in Jhotwara.

When contacted, Anil Gaur, an officer with RCDF said, “While supplying twice in a day we are giving nearly 8.50 lakh litres of milk in a day but on Wednesday, we could supply nearly 7 lakh litres. Those involved in the supply vehicles have shown their reluctance to be on duty twice a day, thus we are supplying only during early morning hours.”

However, consumers suggested that with the changed scenario after lockdown, the state government should bring measures to allow the private milkmen to operate. “Those who come from villages with milk should be allowed as presently, people are dependent only on the Saras dairy which is inadequate,” said Radheyshyam Agarwal, a native of Shyam Puri, Jhotwara.

Title: Robot to serve drugs and food to coronavirus patients in SMS hospital
Content:
The robot has been provided by a private firm to the SMS Hospital

JAIPUR: A robot was brought to Sawai Man Singh Hospital for providing medicine and food to the Covid-19 patients undergoing treatment here on Wednesday.

A private firm has provided the robot to the SMS Hospital on voluntary basis to help the nursing staff and doctors to maintain distance from the Covid-19 patients.

“The work of providing medicines and food, which is done by nursing staff and doctors at the hospital, will be done by a robot for Covid-19 patients. However, to check its efficiency first, we are going to have a demo. If the robot is found useful and does the work efficiently, we will use it to provide medicines and food to Covid-19 patients,” said Dr D S Meena, superintendent, SMS Hospital. Dr Meena said there are higher chances of doctors getting infected from the virus, so it is always a wise idea not to get in touch with the Covid-19 patients frequently; in that case, this robot is useful.

The robot is designed in such a way that it has a tray which is useful for carrying food and medicine from one place to another. Nursing staff were happy to see the robot moving on its own and carrying objects along with it.

However, at the corona out-patient department, patients kept pouring in on Wednesday. The hospital OPD registered 403 influenza-like illness patients, among those 40 are suspected Covid-19 patients.

Title: It was a complete disregard for law in Salem region
Content:
Representative image

SALEM: In a complete disregard for the state government’s efforts to contain Covid-19 outbreak by imposing Section 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, people in Salem region on Wednesday took to streets in large numbers as usual.

While Salem city police booked 10 motorists for violating Section 144 and registered another 1500 cases of traffic violation, a total of 54 people were arrested across Namakkal district for violating Section 144. Namakkal superintendent of police R Arularasu said people had gathered in large groups in various places of the district.

Talking to TOI, Salem city police commissioner T Senthil Kumar said strict action would be taken against the people who violate CrPC section in the coming days. “Since it was the first day of curfew, we warned the public, especially motorists, when they came out on roads. Ten of them were booked under Sections 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) and 269 (negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life) of the Indian Penal Code.”

He said many motorists had taken to the streets for jolly rides while the entire nation was fighting Covid-19 outbreak. “I have directed police personnel to check medical prescriptions and identity cards of road users. Those who fail to produce relevant documents will have to face the law.”

Meanwhile, district collector S A Raman ordered closure of all kinds of tea shops and bakeries from 6pm on Wednesday. He also warned them of strict criminal action, if they were to remain open.

In a few places, including Sathyamangalam in Erode district and Salem city, police personnel resorted to lathi-charge to send out a strong message to the motorists

A senior district administration official in Erode said bikers, especially college students, were coming out of their houses without any valid reasons.

Title: Coronavirus update Agra: Covid-19 suspects getting 5-star hospitality in Agra
Content: AGRA: After a sip of tea, Vijay Kumar (name changed) peeked outside the balcony of the luxury hotel. The tranquil setting outside the twitched curtains made him forget the illness for which he was grounded by Uttar Pradesh health authorities, surprisingly in a 5-star hotel in Agra. The Dubai-based software engineer, who tested negative for novel coronavirus on Wednesday after a brief stay at the 45-bed quarantine facility in the upscale hotel, was hesitant to leave after doctors asked him to go home.The 30-year-old said he was “overwhelmed” by the arrangements made by the state government and district administration.“I was worried about my stay in government facility. But, I couldn’t believe my eyes when I reached the five-star hotel. I was served packed food and mineral water as prescribed by the doctors. The room was spacious, had a very nice bed and a television. The chief medical officer (CMO) gave me his personal number for any consultation,” he said.The techie had returned from Dubai via Amritsar to celebrate Holi at his home in Raghupura village in Agra’s Sainya block on March 7. On March 22, he experienced severe cold and fever. He called the district coronavirus control room and shared his concerns. Soon, his blood, nasal and throat swabs were taken at Agra’s district hospital and he was shifted to the quarantine facility at the hotel in Agra’s Cantonment area.The administration has booked the 45-bed facility in the luxury hotel till March 31 to quarantine suspected coronavirus patients.“People should have full faith in the authorities. They are doing their best to fight the novel coronavirus. People with a travel history or symptoms of the disease should immediately report to the district administration or the health department. The control room number for coronavirus can be used. The best prevention of the disease is to stay home,” he said.The CMO said, “All the 17 samples including that of the Dubai-based techie sent to the King George Medical College (KGMU) have been tested negative. He has been advised home isolation for a few days.”District magistrate (DM) Prabhu N Singh said, “So far, 1,816 people have been advised home quarantine. Health department teams are closely monitoring the condition of all these people.“Eight positive cases have surfaced in Agra so far. Of them, seven people have been cured of the disease and are in home quarantine. A woman Covid-19 positive patient is being treated at SN Medical College. On Wednesday, nine samples were collected at the district hospital and were sent to KGMU. Reports are likely to come on Thursday afternoon. People are advised not be step out of their homes without any valid reason.”

Title: ‘Lockdown stamp’ picture goes viral, Kolkata cops deny
Content:
This is the photo being widely circulated online

KOLKATA: The photograph of a man’s hand, which was claimed to have been stamped by cops at a police station in southeast Kolkata, went viral on social media on Wednesday, triggering a huge sensation among netizens.

The stamped hand photograph raised curiosity among people, some of whom seemed convinced that the police had put the stamp on people as a sign of warning against not staying indoors and venturing out. However, senior police officers at Lalbazar denied any such action on their part and called it fake news.

Adding more to people’s speculation, some sources in the south east division said that cops would not arrest twice the person with stamp on his hand for defying the lockdown . It was also claimed that the stamp would help the police ascertain the person’s movement back home after being released on bail. The police officers rubbished the claim.

“No such instruction was passed on to the police stations from Lalbazar. There are several other practical methods of policing for the present time of crisis,” said joint CP (headquarters), Subhankar Sinha Sarkar. According to sources, cops are taking several measures to ensure that none is harassed unduly for flouting the lockdown norms.

“Some small steps have been taken to ensure that two police stations will not take action against the same person. These measures will also act as warning and we can spot the repeat offenders,” said an officer from south east division.

Title: Coronavirus: Bengaluru techie’s wife tests negative, to be discharged from isolation on Thursday
Content:
Representative Image

AGRA: The Bengaluru techie’s wife who tested positive for Covid-19 infection a fortnight ago, is expected to be discharged from isolation facility on Thursday.

A senior doctor of the isolation facility at S N Medical College said, “Both samples of the 25-year-old woman, sent to KGMU and Aligarh’s JNMC on Tuesday and Wednesday, have tested negative. We expect her to be discharged on Thursday.”

Unaware of her infection, the asymptomatic woman had landed from Bengaluru at New Delhi airport early morning on March 9, after returning from honeymoon in Europe. She later boarded Gatimaan Express to reach Agra. Her husband too was admitted in a Bengaluru hospital with Covid-19 infection.

Title: Mutton, poultry products are essentials: Aurangabad district administration
Content: AURANGABAD: A number of mutton and chicken shops opened in the city on Wednesday evening, following a directive by the district administration that these products fall in the category of essential commodities.The authorities concerned said that the earlier order issued by the state did not have livestock and eggs in the list of essential commodities, police were restricting the movement of vehicles carrying these products.Livestock and poultry products were not in the list of essential commodities issued in the lockdown order. Hence, department of animal husbandry and dairying joint secretary OP Chaudhary issued an order.In the communication to all the chief secretaries and Union Territories, Chaudhari said, “It is requested to issue necessary direction to the law enforcing authorities to include live chicks, eggs and meat in the list of commodities to be exempted from lockdown and also allow movement of maize and soya for animals and bird feed with necessary certification.”Following the directives, Aurangabad turned out to be the amongst the first districts in the state to include them in the list of essential services.Aurangabad district collector Uday Choudhary told TOI, “Livestock and eggs are very much part of essential commodities and we have instructed police to not prevent the entry or exit of such vehicles in or from the district.”Even Jalna superintendent of police S Chaitanya issued directives to police, asking them to not restrict the entry or exit of vehicles carrying livestock and poultry products.After the lockdown came into force, checkposts at the entry points of the district as well as on state borders restricted the movement of vehicles carrying poultry products and livestock, resulting in shortage.Chicken prices had started recovering and was being sold for Rs 40 per kilogram before the lockdown was announced. Within a day of the lockdown, the supply chain took a direct hit and chicken started being sold for Rs 140 per kg.With the latest directive, the rising price of meat and poultry products are set to come under control.

Title: Haryana to grant prisoners up to 3-month parole
Content: CHANDIGARH: To prevent spread of coronavirus infection in Haryana jails, the state government on Wednesday decided to grant parole/furlough/bail or other form of release of up to two months to prisoners.Convicts already on parole or furlough would get extended special parole of four additional weeks. Convicts who have already availed one parole/furlough peacefully and surrendered on time will be granted a fresh one-time special parole for six weeks.The state government took the decision a day after the recommendation of Haryana Legal Services Authority (Halsa) meeting headed by Justice Rajiv Sharma of the Punjab and Haryana high court. Other senior officers who were present in the meeting included Haryana additional chief secretary (home) Vijai Vardhan and DGP (prison) K Selvraj.According to the government decision, all convicts above the age of 65 (except those involved in multiple cases or convicted for recovery of large quantity of drugs under the NDPS Act or convicted under Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso), under Section 379-B (snatching) and convicted for rape or acid attack shall be granted six-week special parole. Prisoners who are foreign nationals would not be entitled to this relief either.Convicts who are not facing a sentence of more than seven years, are not facing any other case and do not have any fine imposed on them will be entitled to release of six to eight weeks on parole, if their behaviour in jail has been recorded as good.Applications of convicts pending before deputy commissioners (DCs) or divisional commissioners for release on parole are to be decided sympathetically within three to six days.As for undertrials, those facing criminal cases in which maximum sentence is seven years and those who are presently confined in jails shall be released on bail by district and sessions court, additional sessions court or chief judicial magistrates. They may be released on interim bail from 45 to 60 days.Similarly, all convicts with good behaviour may get remission in their sentence for two months by the DGP, prison and one month by the superintendent of concerned jail in accordance with the Punjab jail manual. However, this remission would not be applicable on convicts in heinous offences.Haryana jail minister Ranjeet Singh said the decision has been taken to prevent the spread of coronavirus in jails. “The decision has also been taken in compliance of the SC guidelines issued on Monday and on humanitarian grounds so that the pressure on jails can be reduced in the present circumstances,” he added.

Title: Covid-19: 62-year-old textile businessman in Surat city tests positive
Content: SURAT: The total number of COVID-19 cases in Surat touched seven with a 62-year-old male from Parvat Patia, working in Radha Krishna Textile (RKT) Market at Sahara Darwaja, testing positive for the virus on Wednesday.Health department officials said the patient is into textile business and had visited the textile market on Ring Road several times and also Kolkata where he may have come in contact with infected persons.The patient was first shifted to a private hospital in Parvat Patiya and then to the isolation ward of New Civil Hospital three days ago. About 12 of his close contacts, including his family members have been quarantined at the government facility at Samras Hostel of Veer Narmad South Gujarat University (VNSGU) on Wednesday.Dr Ashish Naik, deputy municipal commissioner (health and hospital), told TOI, “He had visited the RKT Market several times in the last 15 days. It is difficult to ascertain the number of people whom he may have met. They could be traders, workers, security guards etc.”According to Dr Naik, an advisory has been issued for those owning shops in the RKT Market and others, who may have visited the market in the last 15 days, to strictly undergo home quarantine.Meanwhile three healthcare staffers of Mahavir Hospital, where 67-year-old COVID-19 positive patient died on Sunday, have been admitted in the isolation ward after they showed symptoms of the virus. The staffers include two males and one woman.Municipal commissioner Banchhanidhi Pani said that as on Wednesday there are six COVID-19 positive cases undergoing treatment in hospitals in the city. Along with these cases, three other suspected patients include a 55-year-old male from Gopipura and 68-year-old man from Palanpore, both without any travel history and a 30-year-old male from Adajan who had travelled to Satara in Maharashtra. They have been admitted in the isolation ward of New Civil Hospital as suspected COVID-19 patients. "We have started sending smses to people living or working in close contacts of COVID-19 positive patient and telling them to self isolate them so that virus does not spread,'' Pani said.

Title: Tollywood celebs turn chefs to beat their lockdown blues
Content: The country is under a 21-day lockdown and time, it seems, has slowed down. To keep boredom at bay, many Tollywood stars are trying their hands at a variety of creative engagements — from painting, playing a musical instrument to even singing. But the winner in the creative category is, hands down, cooking! From hot beverages, evening snacks to lavish dinner spreads and desserts — these celebs are master chefs in their own rights! We find out what’s cooking!I have been cooking delicacies every day. I love cooking. It’s therapeutic and makes me happy. This quarantine period has given all of us time to do things we love but otherwise don’t get enough time to do. I cooked biryani the other day. It’s pretty easy to whip up as opposed to what people think. The best part is that it’s one whole meal. One doesn’t need to cook 10 items to go with it. It was the first time that Nikhil (Jain,husband) tasted authentic biryani and he loved it! A plateful of of this dish makes most people happy! I, for one, cannot get enough of it. Nusrat JahanMy speciality lies in kosha mangsho. I love preparing mutton. For this one, I marinated the meat in curd, ginger-garlic paste, turmeric, salt and grated raw papaya. I roast the whole masalas myself — readymade masalas are a strict no-no for me. I take around 1.5 hours to cook it properly. Oh, and my secrets are that I cook in a kadhai and use red chillies instead of green. Though I love cooking, I feel a bit suffocated in the kitchen.Cooking is not just a hobby, but a passion for me. But this time, I am keeping the menu simple. The other day, I thought of preparing vegetarian dishes. Rajma salad, sautéed vegetables, chilli paneer and steamed rice were on the menu. These are simple and easy recipes. It’s not very often that I get time off to cook at home. Since the country is in lockdown, I thought of utilising the time to nurture the cook in me!— PaoliI cook out of habit. I am quite used to it. I live in with my partner and she is sous-chef de cuisine! I have lived alone for a long time, so cooking is a part of my daily routine. I oscillate between vegetarian and non-vegetarian dishes. Yesterday, I cooked bhaat, dimer dalna and dal. For dinner, I cooked paneer, alu phoolkopi bhaja and roti.— Anindya ChatterjeeThese days, I am happily spending time in the kitchen. I have started to cook recently and I’m loving it. Now that I have ample free time, I am preparing something tasty and healthy every day. I will be getting married at the end of November. And I feel that cooking is a very important skill to impress one’s partner or make up after a fight. I have promised my fiancée that by the time we get married, I will turn into a great cook! A good butter chicken can definitely break the silence after an odd fight.I am back in the kitchen after a long time and I love to prepare chicken delicacies. I have always loved cooking and I believe it is a great stress-buster. I rustled up a chicken curry yesterday and my family loved it! I had it both for lunch and dinner. I am spending hours in the kitchen to kill the boredom and plan to nurture the hobby. In the coming days, I want to devote a lot of time to improving my culinary skills. I want to learn as many new recipes as possible.— Ushasi RayI can cook almost everything. I cook basic dishes like rice, dal, sabzi, fish and meat. I am utilising my self-quarantine time by whipping up breakfast recipes like cheese omelette, chicken sandwich and garlic bread. In the evening, I make pasta in different sauces. Since I am a big foodie, I love experimenting. I also love to bake either a chocolate brownie or a plain vanilla cake every day. Baking is one of my favourite pastimes. My mom is my biggest critic, who always gives an honest opinion.— Trina SahaThese days, I am happily spending time in the kitchen. I have started to cook recently and I’m loving it. Now that I have ample free time, I am preparing something tasty and healthy every day. I will be getting married at the end of November. And I feel that cooking is a very important skill to impress one’s partner or make up after a fight. I have promised my fiancée that by the time we get married, I will turn into a great cook! A good butter chicken can definitely break the silence after an odd fight.— Uday Pratap SinghI just love to don the chef’s hat. I enjoy cooking and sharing them on social media. Recently, I tried my hand at mutton rogan josh and vanilla custard. I then moved on to dishes like cream of asparagus and spinach soup. It’s made entirely with green veggies that are vital for our body’s immunity at this point. Yesterday, I made creamy cafe latte, chilly cheese garlic toast and chocolate lava cake.

Title: Panchkula patient’s 29 neighbours safe
Content: PANCHKULA: Some good news. Of the 33 tested neighbours of district’s first positive case at Khark Mangoli, 29 are negative for coronavirus, while four results are awaited.The 29 negative reports reached the civil hospital in Sector 6. The remaining four people are quarantined in Gurdwara Nada Sahib, where they have special isolated beds. The entire Khark Mangoli is being sanitised while doctors from Panchkula screenits villagers. Asked about overall picture of the district, chief medical officer Jasjeet Kaur said: “We have 335 people in home quarantine, besides the four at Nada Sahib.”Daily wagers of Rajiv Colony, Indira Colony, Buddanpur, and Khark Mangoli received Rs-5 food from the administration. The packet contains six chapattis, vegetable, and pickle. Three foodsupply vans are on job in the district.The district administration has told fruit and vegetable vendors to barricade their shops with tapes or ropes to keep buyers at a safe distance.Deputy commissioner M K Ahuja said: “Social distancing is important for shopkeepers, police, doctors, municipal workers, suppliers of essential commodities, and those running essential service in these tough times. Nothing except essential commodities can enter Panchkula.”

Title: Surat: Option-less migrant workers start marching home
Content:
A section of these workers seen walking on Wednesday

SURAT: A large number of migrants to the city have embarked on footmarch to their native places since Tuesday night. With no mode of conveyance available amid the lockdown, these people are left with little option but to start walking hundreds of kilometres.

The exodus includes tribal people from Madhya Pradesh and also districts of Gujarat like Dahod and Panchmahal . Hundreds of Saurashtra natives have also started their padyatra to reach home located more than 500kms away and requiring them over six to seven days of tireless marching.

Not only Surat, people are leaving other cities in south Gujarat too, including Valsad, Vapi and Navsari. Several groups of people are seen leaving the city in groups including women and children and many carrying their belongings and young children on their shoulders and heads. With non-availability of food along the way, these people are also having to carry their food and water too.

Some of these home-bound people are also seen travelling on motorcycles and autorickshaws as well.

Majority of those going to Madhya Pradesh and other tribal districts of state are involved in construction industry. With fear of getting no work during the lockdown, they have started to leave for home as in the city they lived in makeshift shanties or even in the under-construction building sites.

After the district administration came to know that such a group of migrant labourers from MP have come on foot from Killa Pardi in Valsad on Tuesday night, they provided them shelter in a public school at night. Another group of MP labourers from Navsari who were seen at national highway 48 had been shifted to a public school.

Those going to Saurashtra are mostly diamond industry workers who live in rented accommodations in the city. "We will make a few stops on the way, but right now there is no other option to reach our village," said Vipul Patel , who left early on Wednesday and was seen going to Bhavnagar with his family.

"There is strict checking on the borders of each district. No one will be allowed to cross. It is advisable for all to stay put whereever they are," said Dr Dhaval Patel, collector, Surat.

Private vehicles offering illegal rides ata premium

Since all the toll plazas on highway are closed those walking are searching for vehicles after crossing the toll plazas. In case of Surat, people walk up to Kamrej toll plaza and then keep looking for private vehicles. "Jeep, rickshaws and goods vehicles are offer ride up to Tarapur charging Rs 1,000 per person. They use internal roads to cross the district borders. People then change vehicles to reach their village," said Bhavesh Rabari, a municipal councillor in city.

Title: Chandigarh: 1,700 detained, 45 arrested in three days
Content:
Cops took the detained people to the temporary jails at Cricket Stadium, Sector 16, and Sports Complex, Manima... Read More

CHANDIGARH: Police detiained 1,764 people and arrested 61 for violating curfew in different parts of the city between March 23 and 7pm on Wednesday.

Cops took the detained people to the temporary jails at Cricket Stadium, Sector 16, and Sports Complex, Manimajra, and released them after the day. Police have their contact details. Cops have also detained 773 vehicles and impounded another 79 in the past three days. Of the total detained vehicles, 505 were two-wheeler, 25 three-wheeler, and 243 four-wheeler.

The men in khaki caught thousands of people roaming about aimlessly on the city roads. The 16 police stations of the city registered 45 FIRs (first information reports) under section 188 (defying public order) of the Code of Criminal Procdure (CrPC) aginst the arrested people between March 23 and 25.

In the city, 38 drivers had their vehicles impounded for violating the lockdown and curfew on Wednesday till 7pm. Teams from the east division, sectors 19, 26, Manimajra, Mauli Jagran, IT Park and Industrial Area, Phase I police stations detained 889 people. Squads from the sectors3,17,11andSarangpurpolice stations apprehended 447 people, while south division cops from sectors 31, 34, 36, 39, 49 and Maloya caught 428 people between March 23 and Wednesday.

As residents complained about not getting milk and vegetables , Shashank Anand, SSP, traffic, responded with a tweet on Wednesday., asking the people to be patient and said the administration is making all efforts to reach out to everyone.

Title: Unseasonal rains in S Gujarat
Content:
Surat: Parts of Bharuch and Surat district received unseasonal rains on Wednesday.

Bharuch town, Ankleshwar and Jambusar talukas in Bharuch district received light to moderate rains, while some of the talukas including Bardoli, Kamrej, Choriyasi and Olpaad taluka received drizzles on Wednesday. The atmosphere in Surat remained cloudy on Wednesday morning, which resulted in light drizzles in some parts of the city including Vesu, Parle Point, Adajan, Pal, Udhana etc.

Moderate rainfall was reported in parts of Dangs district including Gujarat’s only hill station at Saputara.

President of Gujarat Khedut Samaj (GKS), Jayesh Patel said, “Amid COVID19 scare, unseasonal rain is not a good news for the farmers. The wet spell may have destroyed the standing crops including vegetables.”

Title: Citizens of Nagpur coming up with own recipes to cut food wastage
Content:
Representative image

NAGPUR: Nagpurians might be missing out on their favourite roadside tarri poha and samosas, but they are making the most of their at home by cooking delicious and healthy food in their kitchens.

Meal prep and planning have become the newest trend as it promotes zero wastage and requires less ingredients. TOI tried to find out what are th citizens doing to fulfil their appetite and cravings.

Parveena Lambhajiya , a chef, has come up with an innovative idea to prepare for breakfast which can be used for two days so that it leads to zero wastage and is a healthy alternative to snacks. “I make the batter for dhokla, idli and dosa in bulk which can last easily for at least three days. One can make variety of meals with their own twist into it, such as adding green chili, ginger garlic paste etc. One must avoid using a lot of ingredients, but still make healthy recipes at homes,” she said.

Snehajeet Meshram, a company secretary by profession, has a passion for cooking. He is managing by using less oil making tasty items with leftover food. “ I make sure to use spices minimally and create a balanced meal by including all the nutrients. I use the leftover chana, rajma etc to make dips and sauces,” he said.

Citizens are also stressing on making one-pot recipes as these save gas, serve good and are easily made in less time with minimal ingredients. Ganesh Thorat , accounts officer at South Central Zone Cultural Centre, said, “I am enjoying cooking food for my family. I am helping my wife in the kitchen and strictly cutting down excess use of oil, butter and other primary ingredients to avoid wastage. I made dal fry for my children and they appreciated it. I believe making one-pot khichdi, dal, lentils, and oily food is a great step towards zero wastage,” he said.

Homemaker Savita Tharate said, “I have made a variety of rice flake recipes such as namkeen poha, chiwda and also laddoos with besan. I am making sure to soak the lentils overnight so that it can be used to make various dishes,” she said.

Things are easy for entrepreneur Vjay Dhole as he has a terrace garden which has all the fresh vegetables. “We are avoiding stocking up our pantry. We pluck fresh vegetables from our terrace garden and make delicious meal at home. Proper meal planning is the need of the hour. Wastage must be avoided, as there are people who sleep hungry every day,” he said.

Poonam Khatri, a homemaker, said, “We are lucky that we have a small grocery store right next to our apartment. Hence, we are not stocking things up. But I make sure to prepare masala khichdi, which can be used the next morning as breakfast.”

Title: Salman Khan's production house puts all the operations on hold; announces the same with a post
Content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi declared the 21-day nationwide lockdown on Tuesday to combat the Coronavirus Bollywood celebs welcomed his decision and also relayed his message of 'stay home stay safe' to their fans.Now, Salman Khan 's production house announced that it has suspended all their operations and abiding by the lockdown issued by the Government. The Company's official handle shared a post announcing the post. It read, "In these testing times of the Coronavirus pandemic, we will continue to keep our operations on hold following the Government of India's directive of a 21-day lockdown. Stay Home Stay Safe!"Check out the post here:Salman was busy working on his next 'Radhe: Your Most Bhai', however, the filming was stopped due to COVID-19 outbreak. The film stars Disha Patani and Jackie Shroff along with Bhaijaan. The film is being helmed Prabhu Deva Meanwhile, COVID-19 has brought the whole world to stand still. Everyone has been asked to stay at home to avoid any infection. Celebs have been sharing pictures and videos on their respective handles of how they are spending their home-quarantined time.

Title: Nuisance detection squad faces abuse in Nagpur
Content:
NAGPUR: A group of vendors allegedly abused the Nagpur Municipal Corporation ’s (NMC) Nuisance Detection Squad (NDS) during enforcement drive on Craddock Road, Jagnath Budhwari. The incident occurred on Monday and came to fore after a video recording of it went viral on social media on Wednesday.

Though several people could be seen openly abusing the squad members, Tehsil police have registered an offence against only one vendor.

NMC officials told TOI, “Information was received that large number of vendors had put up stalls of vegetable, fruits, flowers and other products on the road. A team from NMC Satranjipura Zone including employees of enforcement department and NDS squad reached the spot. Vendors had put up stalls close to each other which is a violation of guidelines of Covid-19, lockdown and Section 144. Therefore, the NMC team tried to seize products and remove stalls. A group of vendors gathered and abused NDS squad despite Section 144 prevailing in the city,” the officials said.

Video shows the group of vendors abusing NDS squad, physically pushing them and forcing them to return.

Surprisingly, NMC officials from Satranjipura zone did not take lead in registering a complaint. A NDS member Santosh Shirsat registered complaint with Tehsil police.

Tehsil police registered an offence against Badal Pande under Section 186 and 504 of IPC on Monday. NMC officials said, “We talked to police officials who assured to identify and book other vendors. We have handed over the video to the police,” they said.

NMC sources told TOI, “NDS squad personnel who are retired army men are upset with lack of support from NMC administration. None of the officials came forward and talked to police. Even the police reached late at the spot after repeated calls,” sources said.

Title: After missing Padwa, coronavirus positive patients in Nagpur hope to meet families soon
Content: NAGPUR: “Although I missed celebrating the auspicious occasion of Gudi Padwa at home, my children made my day by raising the Gudi on their own for the first time, watched by me and husband from hospital,” said the emotional mother recuperating in isolation after testing positive for coronavirus Although the Maharashtrian New Year was celebrated on a smaller scale in most households due to ongoing lockdown and curfew, the four persons who tested positive and are recuperating in hospital missed out on being with their families on the occasion.“Obviously, I’ve missed it badly being a wife, homemaker and mother, but my children made my day. This is the first time I am away from my family, which was disappointing. My daughter studying in Std VIII standard, however, compensated by trying her hand at sweets with my mother-in-law,” said the wife of the first Covid-19 patient in Nagpur.She added that she would be getting new year gift as her husband told her that he would be getting discharged on Thursday.Echoing similar sentiments, the second positive patient said that being away from home during such occasions is certainly painful, but being in a joint family has an advantage. “I am happy at the maturity shown by my family members, who are all in quarantine because of me, and also by my friends, relatives and neighbours. They’re maintaining restraint and not venturing outside. I had apprehended that we may face social stigma, but fortunately it didn’t happen with my family members,” he said.Expressing concern over his two daughters, who’re confused on their condition, the second patient says all these happenings may have a psychological impact on their tender minds in the long term. “However, being in a joint family has its advantages, and my family members are taking their good care,” he says.Like the other two, the third patient is also upset over being in the isolation ward and not being able to celebrate the occasion. “I am staying with my parents and obviously they are missing me. But I am content after watching the entire hospital staff working for us day and night that included doctors, nurses and others. They take very good care of us without caring for festivals or their families. They clean our rooms thrice a day despite facing threat of getting infected,” he says.After testing negative in the subsequent tests, all four are hoping to be discharged after 14 days of isolation, which they term as ‘vanvas’ or exile. While the first patient is likely to be discharged on Friday, the second and third would be released on Saturday.The wife of the first patient, however, would take a couple of days more to be released, as her fourth test was inconclusive. Even at home, they would have to remain in quarantine for 14 more days, to avoid any chances of spreading the infection, they told TOI. All of them hope the new year would bring them good tidings, of reuniting with their families after the trauma and isolation period.

Title: Kabul Gurdwara Attack: 8 women among 25 killed in Kabul gurdwara attack
Content: Twenty five devotees, including eight women, were killed and eight others injured in one of the deadliest attacks on the minority Sikh community in Afghanistan at Gurdwara Har Rai Sahib in capital Kabul on Wednesday morning. Agencies said a suicide bomber struck the gurdwara and the so-called Islamic State, which has targeted Sikhs earlier in Afghanistan, claimed responsibility for the attack in a statement.However, the Sikh residents of Kabul, including one devotee who was in the gurdwara at the time of the attack, told TOI over the phone that multiple terrorists were seen at the time of the attack.A Sikh resident, who did not wish to be named, said pilgrims had assembled at the gurdwara to pray for the well-being of humanity and the elimination of coronavirus when they were attacked. India reacted by saying that such "cowardly attacks" on places of religious worship of the minority community, especially at this time of the Covid-19 pandemic, reflected the "diabolical mindset" of the perpetrators and their backers. "I am saddened by the terror attack at the gurdwara in Kabul. I express my condolences to the families of all the deceased," Prime Minister Narendra Modi said.The attack comes against the backdrop of the US-Taliban peace deal. The agreement doesn't cover IS operatives though. The Taliban issued a statement denying it had anything to do with the attack. Sikh pilgrims told TOI said the group of terrorists entered the gurdwara complex and started firing indiscriminately at the devotees.The interior ministry of Afghanistan confirmed that 25 people were killed in the attack. It said about 80 people were rescued by Afghan special forces from the gurdwara. Another Sikh devotee, who resides in the gurdwara, sent a video to TOI which shows him and his family huddled in a corner of the house. The Sikh devotee, who is seen bareheaded in the video, said he along with his uncle had gone out of a room in the gurdwara around 8am when they spotted three bodies — of two Sikhs and one person in security uniform.He then saw a terrorist whom he mistook to be a securityman in civvies. He said the terrorist fired at him and he barely escaped. The terrorist hurled a bomb in the gurdwara complex which didn’t go off. In another video uploaded on social media, Afghanistan’s Sikh MP Narinder Singh is heard saying that police were not letting him enter the gurdwara and he doesn’t know how many devotees had died in the attack. He told a news agency that “three suicide bombers entered” the shrine.In a statement, the Indian foreign ministry said: “We convey our condolences to the immediate family members of the deceased and wish speedy recovery to the injured. India stands ready to extend all possible assistance to the affected families of the Hindu and Sikh communities of Afghanistan.”

Title: Saurashtra observes complete lockdown
Content:
6 FIRs filed in city, 22 in rural areas against violators on Wednesday

Rajkot: The 21-day nationwide lockdown announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday was almost complete in Saurashtra’s commercial capital as well as other cities of Saurashtra.

All the major roads were deserted with people adhering to Modi’s ‘stay at home’ call.

However, six FIRs were lodged in the city and 22 in the rural areas for the violation of the public notification regarding prohibitory orders.

According to police, most of the FIRs lodged were related to shops of non-essential commodities that remained open despite the lockdown . Police had operated several auto rickshaws in the residential area announcing that people were prohibited from venturing outside of the house.

All the major markets too observed a complete shutdown in the city. The shops selling essential commodities remained open for few hours of morning and evening which resulted in crowds at many places. The shop owners are not allowing more people to enter and people have to wait in queue outside. Police also made circles on the road outside some of the shops asking customers to maintaining adequate distance.

Title: Problems galore for patients, relatives in Nagpur hospitals
Content:
Representative image

NAGPUR: Sandip Dashesar was having heated arguments with an ambulance driver in front of CIIMS hospital in the city on Tuesday. The driver was demanding Rs5,500 to drive back his father to his native place near Bhilai in Chhattisgarh .

“Ambulance from the same service charged Rs2,500 when we came to Nagpur some ten days ago. Just because we can’t go back in any other vehicle now, they are demanding more than double money,” he said. The driver was firm on the new rates and finally, Dashesar had to settle on Rs4,500.

Many patients and their relatives coming from parts of Madhya Pradesh , Chhattisgarh, and Telangana to Nagpur for medical treatment are facing such problems, although, travelling for medical purpose is not banned during the lockdown. After district borders were sealed, patients and their relatives from neighbouring districts are also facing such difficulties.

Nagpur is Central India’s medical hub and receives hundreds of patients from all parts of Vidarbha, Marathwada and neighboring states daily.

The super specialty hospital and trauma care centre attached to Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) and Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital (IGGMCH) are preferred by poor patients as they get benefits of many government schemes here.

Private super specialty hospitals like CIIMS, Meditrina, New Era and Alexis also provide benefits of government health schemes and receive such patients. But during lockdown, these patients and their relatives are facing problems right from accommodation, travelling, and now food too.

“We have 16 patients in the ICU at present. Hotels and lodges are closed. So, their relatives are left with no option but to stay in hospitals. We are arranging accommodation for them in our basements, and in vacant wards,” said Dr Sameer Paltewar of Meditrina Hospital.

As the number of patients reporting to these hospitals has gone down due to the lockdown, most relatives can get accommodation within hospital premises.

“Those having their personal vehicles can also drive back to their places. Discharge card and a letter from the hospital is must. Police may stop them for enquiry, but will let them proceed after showing these documents,” said Dr Anand Sancheti of New Era Hospital.

While private hospitals are arranging accommodation and managing travel facilities for their patients, GMCH and Mayo Hospital are facing a different type of problem. As both hospitals are treating positive patients of the Covid-19, other patients are reluctant to visit here.

On Tuesday and Wednesday, only 170 patients got themselves admitted to the GMCH which is not even half of usual daily count. Similarly, only 1,386 patients reported to the Out Patient department (OPD) of the GMCH in the last two days as against the daily count of 2,500. The condition is Mayo hospital is also similar. Authorities, however, said that the count is not going down due to Covid-19 stigma.

“Non availability of public transport could be the reason behind this. We have also postponed many planed surgeries. Due to this, many patients are not getting admitted,” said a senior doctor in Trauma Care Centre.

Social activist Trisharan Sahare said that patients who want to go back to their native places after treatment should get government ambulances. “We have many 108 ambulances these days. The government should arrange them for these poor patients coming from different states,” he said.

Title: Sitabuldi: From bustling market to selfie point for bored cops
Content: NAGPUR: The lockdown to check the spread of coronavirus on Wednesday seemed to have transformed the character of city’s busiest business locality of Sitabuldi . The usual sight of the heavy traffic was reduced to a trickle with vehicles which would be counted on an hourly basis.Having turned into an almost no-man’s zone, the chowk through which hundreds of vehicles criss-crossed prior to the lockdown had become a selfie point for bored cops who did not have much to do apart from shooing away the occasional curfew violators without reason.Beyond the deserted roads and vanished traffic lay the closed shutters of shops and other businesses that were undoubtedly leading to losses running into crores of rupees each day. Without the chaos and cacophony of traffic, all that was left now was the idly parked police vehicles.Sitabuldi, between Samvidhan square and Jhansi Rani square, has quietened beyond imagination with only police barricades partially blocking the roads. Apart from checking an occasional biker or motorist straying into Variety Square, the cops are not left with much to do apart from chatting among themselves or happily tik-toking on mobile phones.Though the display board revealing the noise and sound pollution levels was not functioning, the earlier skewed parameters of the city’s environmental benchmarks must have improved beyond doubt. It was so silent the sound of giggling women cops from the other side of the road and their banter could easily be heard. The other sounds that could be heard here is the announcements regarding coronavirus and how to avoid contracting it.With no vehicles, the stray canines and occasional bovines too were found ambling around looking for some eatables.Amid the calm, vehicles of Good Samaritan citizens and their groups visited the place offering cops tea, biscuits, chhaas, snacks, food and also doses of sanitizers on their hands. TOI found a group from Ashirwad Nagar and another from Vishwakarma Nagar reaching the place to offer the cops something to quench their thirst and munch. Activist and diver Jagdish Khare and his group also came with masala rice for the cops and also to some homeless at the chowk.Some citizens were found making a beeline to the Sitabuldi police station for curfew passes. Sitabuldi police issued 46 of them on the second day to citizens so they could can move around. Still there were many waiting for them.Vikas Sharma, owner of a tiffin service, said he needed the passes to cater to a handful of his clients who stayed alone in the city. He was waiting outside the police station. He pointed at his customer, Rajnish Chandra , a student of MBA at Dhanwate National college, stating he has been starving for last two days as the tiffin service could not function without the police pass.

Title: Doctor on call: Govt issues guidelines for telemedicine
Content: NEW DELHI: The health ministry issued telemedicine guidelines on Wednesday enabling doctors to write prescriptions based on telephone conversations that reduce risks of transmission for medical professionals as well as patients.The move, aimed at decongesting healthcare facilities in the wake of Covid-19 , will also make healthcare accessible to remote areas in general and make faster intervention possible with the current immobilisation due to coronavirus making hospital and clinic visits difficult.The document provides information on various aspects of telemedicine, including on technology platforms and tools available to medical practitioners and how to integrate these technologies to provide healthcare delivery. It also spells out how technology and transmission of voice, data, images and information should be used in conjunction with other clinical standards, protocols, policies and procedures to provide care."Disasters and pandemics pose unique challenges to providing healthcare. Though telemedicine will not solve them all, it is well suited for scenarios in which medical practitioners can evaluate and manage patients. A telemedicine visit can be conducted without exposing staff to viruses/infections in the times of such outbreaks," the guidelines framed by the board of governors of the Medical Council of India along with Niti Aayog said.The guidelines said that telemedicine practice can prevent the risk of transmission of infectious diseases to both healthcare workers and patients. Unnecessary and avoidable exposure of the people involved in the delivery of healthcare can be avoided using telemedicine and patients can be screened remotely. Besides, it also enables additional resources."Thus, health systems that are invested in telemedicine are well positioned to ensure that patients with Covid-19 kind of issues receive the care they need," the guidelines said."Clarity in regulations around telemedicine and digital healthcare was the need of the hour, especially in light of Covid-19. This has made access to quality healthcare simpler and reachable to masses," Shashank ND, co-founder & CEO of Practo, said.

Title: Coronavirus cases in India: 19 states/UTs report fresh cases, virus confirmed in northeast
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: The Covid-19 contagion spread to Goa (three cases reported) and northeast India, where Manipur and Mizoram confirmed one case each, even as 20 states and UTs on Wednesday reported 94 fresh infections — the second highest for a single day after 99 cases on Monday.Two more deaths, one of an 85-year-old woman in Ahmedabad and another in Tamil Nadu, took the national toll from the virus to 13. The health ministry clarified that the death it had reported in Delhi on Tuesday was not a Covid-19 case.The total coronavirus cases in India stood at 656, as reported by states. At least 60 daily cases have been reported in the past five days. A total of 56 patients have recovered so far, eight on Wednesday. The health ministry has confir med 606 cases and 10 deaths so far. The three positive cases in Goa are all male, aged 25, 29 and 55, respectively. All three have recently returned to Goa from Spain, Australia and the US.State health & family welfare department officials said the Wednesday’s victim was from Danilimda area and had travelled to Mecca in Saudi Arabia. “She was admitted to the Civil Hospital in Ahmedabad with respiratory illness on March 22. She had developed bilateral pneumonia,” said an official.With 15 new cases, Maharashtra again overtook Kerala as the worst coronavirushit state. State authorities have confirmed 122 cases so far while Kerala has reported 118 (nine new). Karanataka (51), Telangana (41), UP, Gujarat and Rajasthan (38 each) are next in the list.Delhi, which did not report a single case of Covid-19 in the last two days, confirmed five new cases on Wednesday, taking the state’s total to 35.Of the new cases, three are linked to the Saudi-returned woman who was found positive on March 17, and two others are residents of Sainik Farms in Delhi with travel history to Brazil and London, officials said.“The Delhi patient who died on Tuesday tested negative for Covid-19 and therefore he was excluded from the list of Covid-19 deaths. Only one death has taken place in the capital due to Covid-19,” said a health ministry official.Meanwhile, Mizoram reported its first Covid-19 case, that of a 50-year-old pastor who had returned from the Netherlands on March 16.“The man belongs to the Mizoram Baptist Church. His wife and two children have also been shifted to the isolation ward at Zoram Medical College (ZMC) in Falkawn, about 20 km south of the capital. The pastor’s samples have been tested at the Gauhati Medical College laboratory,” Lalthangliana added.Manipur had reported a case on Tuesday, which has since been confirmed as a coronavirus infection.

Title: PWD workers risking their safety at MLA Hostel in Nagpur
Content:
Representative image

NAGPUR: For the last 10 days, the Public Works Department ( PWD ) is unable to find safety kits for its workers who are serving food, cleaning rooms and attending to inmates at the MLA Hostel, where around 159 flyers have been quarantined.

Officials said workers are scared of entering rooms without safety kits but they are left with no choice due to the intense pressure from the district administration to ensure that there are no lapses in providing facilities to those quarantined.

PWD executive engineer Janardhan Bhanuse said the district collector has been informed about the need for kits. The agency is even ready to make the purchase on its own, but the problem is that the kits are not available.

“We have sent requests everywhere, right from the government departments to medical institutions. There is a shortage on e-commerce websites too,” Bhanuse said.

Work can’t be stopped as only selected workers are authorized to enter the hostel. “As of now, we do have some kits, but they are not enough. We will soon run out of kits,” he said.

A kit includes a mask, a skull cap, a pair of gloves, a synthetic apron, gum boots and sanitisers for personal as well as general use like cleaning the premises.

Officials said the PWD was suddenly roped in after the administration failed to find an alternative. “The agency was not given enough time to make preparations. The affairs are being run on whatever last moment arrangements could be done as far as safety is concerned. We had to convince our staffers that patients wouldn’t be kept but only passengers would be brought to quarantine them,” a worker said.

An official said 25 to 30 kits are urgently needed. “There are several disposal items which can’t be used by others. Medical stores and pharmaceuticals companies, too, have declined our requests,” the official said.

The official also blamed the deputy director of health services for ignoring the safety of workers at MLA hostel. “When we asked for sanitizers and gloves, they said the items were not available,” the official said.

In the morning, four men and four women enter the building to render housekeeping services. Four men serve food and dispose the leftover in three shifts. Two more frequently enter the premises to attend to day long calls, the PWD contractor said.

“After the shift, they are asked to take a shower with a special liquid and wash their clothes. We know that these are only passengers but what if they turn out to be carriers,” he said.

Title: 84% samples test negative, but fight not over, said Pune's health minister
Content:
Over 2,500 samples -ve, but fight not over: Tope

PUNE: As many as 2,531 samples, which constitute 84% of the total samples taken from presumptive or suspected persons for Covid-19, have tested negative, state health minister Rajesh Tope said on Wednesday.Tope said this was a “good sign” but cautioned that the fight was far from over. It is an indication that the state has not hit the third phase or community transmission stage, he pointed out.On Wednesday, the state registered 122 positive cases with five new ones reported in Mumbai and one in Thane.The samples that turned negative were from among the 2,988 persons tested in the state since January 18. The reports of 335 samples are still awaited.“We are reaching out to the entire state through our tagline, “Main hi mera rakshak” (I am my own saviour). The administration and home department are relentless in emphasizing social distancing,” Tope said.In Pune division, comprising Pune, Satara, Sangli, Kolhapur and Solapur, results of 737 of the 825 samples sent for testing have been received. Of these, 692 tested negative and 37 were positive. It means about 93% of the cases are not coronavirus infected.Tope said, “This is a good sign as we are able to curtail the spread. Those who tested positive have travelled to high-risk countries and were the first contacts. The samples that tested negative were of suspected persons or those in close interaction with these first contacts which means social distancing has helped. The lockdown announced by the Prime Minister till April 14, section 144 and overall awareness will help prevent cases from rising.”So far, 11 patients have been discharged after they tested negative in the second test as per the WHO guidelines. Eight of them were from Mumbai, two from Pune and one from Aurangabad.The discharged persons have gone through proper intervention and monitoring during their hospital stay. The state has been following a four-step process of identification, isolation, testing and treatment, the minister said.Nine government laboratories are carrying out tests and five private facilities will join them soon, Tope said.The state government will issue orders for 1,000 government and private hospitals to address cases under the Mahatma Jotiba Phule Jan Arogya Yojana from April 1, he added.

Title: Mumbai: Moneylender held for raping woman in car
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

MUMBAI: A 36-year-old moneylender from Kurla, who allegedly raped a 29-year-old woman in his car in Wadala, was arrested by Wadala police on Tuesday.

Sunil Gangaram Anna alias Reddy, a resident of New Mill Road in Kurla, was arrested under Indian Penal Code sections for rape, outraging modesty of a woman, assault and threats, and was remanded to police custody.

The victim, who is unmarried, does odd jobs, and police said she had in 2017 taken a loan of Rs50,000 on 5% interest from Reddy. Mid-2018, she took another loan of more than Rs 1 lakh and gave two cheques, her property documents, ration and Aadhaar cards as security.

“As per the agreement, she was to repay him Rs20,000 per month and was to return the entire amount by February 2020 but failed,’’ said an official. She was to pay him Rs 5.7 lakh with interest, and when she defaulted, Reddy started calling and threatening her. In January, Reddy called her to a hotel in Kurla, and said he would help her get the entire loan amount from a credit society in Wadala, only if she returned all his money.

When the victim agreed, he took her in his car to a credit co-operative society near Mumbai Port Trust, and the society agreed to giver her a loan of Rs 2 lakh, police said. While returning, he allegedly offered to drop her at Sion railway station and, on the way, allegedly touched her inappropriately.

He then allegedly raped her in the car. He threatened her, dropped her off at Sion station, and fled, police said. She complained to police few weeks later.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Salt-making comes to a halt in Kutch
Content:
Rajkot: Salt manufacturing has come to halt as a result of the lockdown, which adds to the fear that this may impact the demand of edible salt in the near future.

According to the manufacturers, the present stock is enough to last one week, but after that they will have to start production to meet the demand in the country. Kutch accounts for 80 percent production of India’s total salt needs.

Kutch sends 7,000 tonnes edible salt every day across the country by rail network. Kutch, Santalpur and Kharaghoda are the main producers of salt in Gujarat. Salt is also used in production of caustic soda which is a raw material used in making sanitizers.

Vice president of Indian Salt Manufacturing Association (ISMA), Shyamji Kangad said, “We believe that if we can halt production for one week, but after will face shortage of salty if production does not start soon afterwards. We will represent the government after a week to allow us to start production and by that period the purpose of isolation will also be served.”

There are nearly 15,000 people working in the salt manufacturing industry in Kutch. Even export of salt has been affected as for the last three months there has been no export due to Coronavirus. According to the exporters, export has reduced by 2 lakh tonne per month and if the situation continues in the same manner, salt will pile up by May.

Title: Four years’ jail for man who slashed BMC sweeper
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: Four years after a BMC sweeper from Kurla was slashed with a blade when he refused to give a neighbour Rs 100 for liquor, a sessions court sentenced the accused, Shyam Rokade (40), to four and half years in jail.

The court relied on the statement of the victim Mahesh Palve and an eye witness. The court said that since Rokade had not slashed him multiple times, it did not amount to attempt to murder.

Title: Delhi helpline Number: Helpline, e-passes for essential services in Delhi
Content: NEW DELHI: While announcing five new Covid-19 cases in Delhi in the last 24 hours taking the total to 35, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal also detailed on Wednesday the measures to be taken to remove hurdles in the way of essential supplies reaching people during the 21-day nationwide lockdown.The CM announced a helpline number, 1031, which people engaged in manufacture, transport and storage of essential items as well as those involved in the supply and distribution of milk, vegetables, rations and medicines can call to acquire electronic passes. These passes are meant to ease travel across the city during the lockdown for those active in these services.After calling the number and submitting details, an epass will be given to the applicant via WhatsApp. The passes will be issued by district authorities and can be used only for essential travel, for instance, to procure stocks. The 1031 helpline has more than 20 lines. It will be further strengthened as the government expects a large number of calls for e-passes.Kejriwal stressed that 1031 was not a general helpline number and urged people not to congest the line with calls other than for e-passes. He also clarified that citizens did not need a pass for going to their nearby ration or grocery shops for daily necessities or to go to chemists for medicines.Delhi government has also increased the number of locations where free food for the poor will be available. "We have arranged fooding at our night shelters, free ration for 72 lakh beneficiaries, higher pensions for widows, the elderly and physically disabled beneficiaries,” he said. “We are also increasing the number of spots from where free food will be provided."Kejriwal and lieutenant governor Anil Baijal reviewed the situation on Wednesday and discussed implementation of the lockdown and relief measures. “We will ensure that the essential services are maintained during the lockdown. Details have been worked out on how we will go about it,” Baijal later said.The CM requested people not to engage in panic buying and avoid all outdoor activities. “We observed that after the announcement of the lockdown by the PM, there were long queues of people outside general stores. If we continue to crowd places this way, the whole purpose of the lockdown will be defeated and local transmission of the virus will not be checked," Kejriwal said.“We have taken all efforts possible to ensure that nobody sleeps hungry during the 21-day lockdown,” Kejriwal continued, adding that Delhi Police commissioner S. N. Shrivastava had also announced a helpline number, 011-23469536, which can be contacted in case of police-related problems.

Title: Keep prices of groceries in check: High court to Telangana govt
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: The Telangana HC on Wednesday converted into a PIL a TOI news report highlighting loss of jobs and spiralling prices of essential commodities due to lockdown.

The March 24 TOI report revealed how traders at rythu bazars in Mehdipatnam, Falaknuma and Miralam Mandi were selling vegetables and essential commodities at exorbitant rates, reports Sagar Kumar Mutha Stating that it was the duty of officials to keep prices in check, the HC made chief secretary, principal secretaries of civil supplies, agriculture and home departments, collectors of Hyderabad and Ranga Reddy, GHMC chief, DGP and police commissioners of Hyderabad and Cyberabad as respondents.

Initially, CJ Raghavendra Singh Chauhan had scheduled the hearing on Thursday but it was postponed due to lockdown. A bench of Justice MS Ramachandra Rao and Justice T Amarnath Goud will take up the hearing later.

Title: Four booked for assault on woman cop in Mumbai
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: Four people, including a mother-son duo, were booked for allegedly assaulting a woman constable on March 21. Police received information about youngsters playing cricket in Andheri (E) despite the prohibitory orders.

While most of them fled on seeing the police, one stayed and argued. His mother, a relative and a neighbour then assaulted the constable, said a senior inspector.

Title: Number of Covid-19 cases in Rajkot 4 now
Content:
