Rajkot: Son of a 75-year-old Covid-19 positive woman also tested positive in the city on Wednesday, taking the total number of virus-infected persons to four. The 42-year-old man, who runs a garment showroom, had no travel history. He was suffering from cough and cold since March 11.

District health officer, Dr. Manish Bhanderi told TOI: “Neither of them have any foreign travel history. It’s difficult to find out the source of infection. We are checking people with whom they may have come in contact.”

His mother went to doctor on March 15 for treatment of cold and cough and her health improved. However, she developed fever on March 19 and again went to the doctor. However, as she didn’t recover, she contacted another doctor on March 23 who sent her to the civil hospital where she tested positive on Tuesday.

RMC officials has checked 252 people living in their neighbourhood. Of these, two were found having cold and cough and have been put under the observation. Samples of eight more people were taken on Wednesday and these will be sent for testing.

Title: Centre bans export of malaria drug
Content: NEW DELHI: The Centre on Wednesday put hydroxychloroquine on the prohibited list for exports to prevent a rush of shipments out of the country after US President Trump suggested that the anti-malaria drug could help fight Covid-19.In a notification on Wednesday, the directorate general of foreign trade (DGFT) has put hydroxychloroquine and formulations made from it on the prohibited list. The drug joins ventilators, sanitisers and face masks on a list of items whose exports have been barred.There are, however, a few exceptions. For instance, exports will be permitted from special economic zones and export-oriented units as well as to meet the export obligation under the advance license scheme. Shipments will also be allowed if an irrevocable letter of credit was issued before the notification or if full advance payment has been received.

Title: Landlords to face action for harassing medical staff: Lieutenant governor Anil Baijal
Content: NEW DELHI: Amid reports that doctors, nurses and paramedics treating or testing Covid-19 patients are being asked to leave rented accommodations by house-owners, lieutenant governor Anil Baijal on Wednesday asked police and district magistrates to take penal action against the offenders.Baijal has also directed officials to make transport arrangements for hassle-free commute of healthcare providers to and from their workplaces.Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal has warned house-owners of strict action if they force doctors and nurses to vacate their premises under the notion that they may have got infected while treating Covid-19 patients. “This will not be tolerated. We will take care of our doctors if something happens to them, we are there for them,” he said.Baijal’s directives came a day after the Union home minister asked the Delhi Police commissioner to take strict action against the offenders.The LG is “deeply concerned” over the reports of “misbehaviour” with healthcare personnel, said a statement issued by his office. All district magistrates, zonal deputy commissioners of municipal corporations and district deputy commissioners of police have been asked to take penal actions in such cases and submit a daily action-taken report to the office of the additional chief secretary (home) of Delhi government, it added.

Title: Jharkhand: Man confronts home-isolation violators, killed
Content:
Representative image

DALTONGANJ: Four Jharkhand youths who were advised home isolation after returning from other states to their village in Palamu district thrashed a 45-year-old man on Wednesday when he objected to the locals roaming around in the village despite lockdown orders. The man died of his injuries in hospital.

Palamu Sadar SDO Sandip Kumar Gupta said the group of four, who were armed with sticks, attacked the victim, Kashi Saw, at Chak Udaipur village following an altercation. Saw was first taken to Patan community health centre and later shifted to Palamu Medical College and Hospital, where he died during treatment. "An FIR has been filed against the four people," said Gupta.

No arrests have been made in the case so far. Jharkhand is one of the few states which hasn't reported a single Covid-19 case.

Title: Swiggy, Zomato men to deliver essentials in Rajkot
Content: RAJKOT: Delivery boys of food aggregators Swiggy and Zomato will deliver essential commodities to the citizens at their door steps during the lockdown period.On Wednesday, Rajkot Municipal Corporation (RMC) announced that it will mediate between the malls and supermarkets and the delivery boys. “Citizens will have to place orders with the supermarkets run by the top retail chains like Big Bazar, Reliance, Golden Supermarket and place their order. These orders will be picked up the delivery boys who will hand it over to the citizens,” municipal commissioner Udit Agrawal saidRMC held meeting with the mall owners and service providers of Swiggy and Zomato in the city to formalize the system..The provision stores near the residential areas will also be allowed to remain open during the lock down period.In the near future, people may be able to order the essential commodities through the Swiggy and Zomato apps.Small provision store owners, who buy in bulk from these malls, will also be able to get the essentials from these delivery men. RMC also exhorted people not to hoard essential commodities and resort to panic buying as enough stock is available.

Title: Supply of essentials takes a hit as goods vehicles stay off roads in Kolkata
Content:
Many shops in Gariahat remained closed on Wednesday after running out of stock

KOLKATA: Many wholesale outlets in Posta and Burrabazar — the main source of rice, atta, maida, sugar, potatoes and oil — remained shut on Wednesday as small goods vehicles, an important link in the delivery chain, were off the road allegedly following instructions from police.

This impacted the availability of essential edibles in retail markets where flour and sugar went out of stock on Wednesday. While shop owners said more staples could go off the shelf if the supply chain is not revived, wholesalers claimed they had enough stock but nobody to ferry the goods.

After a meeting on Wednesday afternoon, when chief minister Mamata Banerjee stressed that action will be taken against cops who stop vehicles carrying essential items, Lalbazar hinted they might introduce a pass system.

“The administration has been assuring people that these supplies won’t be affected, but the situation on the ground is different. If corrective measures are not taken, it will trigger more panic buying,” said Siddharta Roy, a resident of Kavi Raj Row off Central Avenue.

Abhinay Tiwary, general secretary of the Burrabazar Posta Goods Vehicles Owners’ association, said the drivers could not even bring vehicles out of the stands. “The cops forced them to park their vehicles and chased the drivers away at many places in Burrabazar. The drivers have refused to ferry goods from Posta and Burrabazar. If drivers are given passes, it will resolve the issues to a large extent,” said Tiwary.

The unavailability of manpower posed yet another challenge. “Most of the staff are from suburban areas but they cannot come because of the lockdown. It is not possible for us to lift so many sacks of rice, flour and sugar and load them on vehicles,” said a shopowner.

In orders sent to all divisional commissioners, ACPs and OCs, Lalbazar iterated on Wednesday evening that trucks carrying essential commodities should not be stopped.

Talking to TOI, special CP Jawed Shamim and joint CP (headquarters) Subhankar Sinha Sarkar said they expected the teething problems to be solved in a day or two. “Movement of essential commodities is as much a priority as keeping people indoors. We are doing everything to smoothen the process,” said Sarkar.

At Howrah’s main vegetable and fish markets, police made a four-hour window (5am-9am) for business. After 9am, cops forced vegetable sellers to wind up and warned them that force would be used if they did not listen. Cops stood guard at the markets to ensure that people did not come back. Vegetable markets at Ichhapur and Dumurjala did not function on Wednesday.

Title: Man booked for spreading rumours on social media
Content:
An aerial view of a deserted highway near the city on Wednesday

Rajkot: A miscreant was booked on Tuesday night for allegedly spreading rumours on WhatsApp and social media about a COVID-19 positive patients in Jangleshwer locality of Rajkot.

The Rajkot police said the accused, identified as Razak Qureshi, allegedly circulated a video on WhatsApp and social media that the first COVID-19 positive case from Jangleshwer in Rajkot was in fact a negative case and that the health department of the Rajkot Municipal Corporation and the Rajkot police had forcibly taken him to the hospital.

“After the video came to our notice, we have booked Qureshi for violating the government’s notification by spreading rumours,” said V K Gadhvi, inspector with Bhaktinagar police station.

The police have launched a manhunt for Qureshi, who went absconding after a case was filed against him.

So far in Rajkot district, 28 cases of violating government’s notification on coronavirus have been registered. In Jamnagar district, four such cases have been filed.

Title: Mumbai Lockdown: Lockdown brings Mumbai’s ‘love-all spirit’ to the fore
Content:
It’s a similar story of compassion and brotherhood being repeated elsewhere in the city

MUMBAI: Your city may have the notoreity of being heartless, but the lockdown is bringing the city’s humane side to the fore as locals and social organisations continue to do their bit to help people in need as well as those on the frontlines combating the pandemic.

In Dadar (east), the Naigaon Sarvajanik Navratrostav Mandal, at Dadar (E), started providing tea and breakfast to 70 policemen at Bhoiwada police station from Wednesday and will continue to do still till March 31. The mandal’s former president, Datta Divekar, said they have requested officials of various stores to provide ingredients to prepare tea.

The cost of the ingredients will be borne by the mandal, but he refused to reveal the amount they would have to shell out. “The cost does not matter at this point. What we will have to shell out is insignificant if you compare the altruistic service that police personnel at the forefront are rendering,” said Divekar.

“Until Wednesday, for at least two days, the police personnel had been deprived of even as much as a cup of tea in the evening...,” he said.

It’s a similar story of compassion and brotherhood being repeated elsewhere in the city. A group of friends comprising lawyers andsocial workers from Mira-Bhayander have come together under the banner ‘We Group’ to provide essential commodities to families of daily-wage labourers in the twin city.

They distributed rice, dal, flour, oil, salt, sugar and biscuits to 54 families. The stock is expected to last for about two weeks, said Sailesh Mishra, a social worker. The cost for each family has worked out to around Rs 600 and the group has sought donations from people.

They have taken permission from Mira-Bhayander Municipal Corporation. The volunteers said they are following all precautions in the wake of Covid-19.

Title: Coronavirus: Finally, Kerala closes all booze outlets
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: A day after PM Modi announced a nation-wide lockdown , the Kerala government on Wednesday decided to shut down all the liquor outlets of the beverages corporation (Bevco) and toddy shops across the state. Bevco is a state-run liquor manufacturing and distribution company .The 306 outlets of Bevco had been functioning even after Kerala decided to impose a state-wide lockdown till March 31. With this decision, all liquor selling outlets will be shut at least till the time the nation-wide lockdown is in force. Bar hotels and Bevco outlets were allowed to function because the sector is among the biggest revenue earners of the government.The decision to allow Bevco to remain open had invited widespread criticism from various quarters.Meanwhile, excise commissioner S Aananthakrishnan has asked all his department officials to ensure that liquor that is stocked in all Bevco outlets, warehouses, bar hotels and clubs are not misused.

Title: Mumbai: Petrol pumps for essential services, business down by 90 per cent
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

MUMBAI: Government officials instructed petrol pump owners on Wednesday to serve vehicles dealing with essential and emergency services on priority, sources said. Thus, private vehicles may now find themselves spending more time at pumps. Private car owners and bikers were even turned away at some locations on Wednesday.

A pump owner said though a directive was issued to sell petrol and diesel only to essential service vehicles, it would be difficult to identify them. “Police must be deployed at pumps to identify which vehicles are of essential services. Our attendants will not be able to do that,” said Ravi Shine, a petrol pump owner from Ghatkopar (E).

M Venkat Rao of Petrol Dealers’ Association, the umbrella organisation of most pumps in the region, told TOI business at almost all pumps was down by 90%. “We are also facing a staff shortage, and there is no point having all pumps open from 7am to 7pm. The government should identify prominent ones, mainly owned by oil marketing companies, at strategic locations to serve essential service vehicles. Others should be allowed to shut down,” he said in a fresh letter to the city collector.

He said there was a potential “health hazard” for those working at pumps in view of the coronavirus threat. He added that while pumps will serve needs of essential services, they will also protect employees.

“Petrol pump dealers have reported staff attendance of not even 10%. We have requested government to advise police personnel to allow our staff who have valid IDs to reach their work places. BEST buses should be advised to carry our staff too,” he said.

Oil marketing companies have begun to regulate supply of petrol and diesel on alternate days as there is less demand at pumps. “This will not result in any dryouts but will help with social distancing in view of the coronavirus threat,” said Rao.

There are more than 200 pumps in the Mumbai region.

Title: Two held for murder of ex-Army man
Content:
Rajkot: Two persons were arrested on Tuesday night for allegedly stabbing an ex-Army man to death in Madhapar village of Bhuj taluka in Kutch district on the night of March 20.

Police said the accused, identified as Usman Kachcha (25) and Kanuji Soni (24), had murdered Musar Gurung (55), with the intention of robbery. “The accused duo looted two gold rings, two imitation jewellery and a bag from the deceased, thinking it contains valuables. However, the bag contained property papers only,” said R N Khant, inspector with Bhuj B division police station.

Kachcha was identified by his girlfriend Niruta Gurung, who is also the niece of the deceased. She saw him in a CCTV footage along with Soni. Kachcha had once visited Gurung’s house along with Niruta.

“Kachcha surveyed Gurung’s house and observed that he was living all alone. Thinking that he might have got a good amount of valuables, he plotted the loot plan along with Soni. Then both the accused executed the loot and murder on the night of March 20,” said Khant.

Gurung’s body was found lying in a pool of blood by his nephew Suraj Gurung (19), Niruta’s brother, who had come to visit Gurung from Gandhidham on March 21 evening.

Title: PM, ministers practise distancing
Content: NEW DELHI: Setting an example of social distancing in the fight against coronavirus, Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his cabinet colleagues were seen following the norm during the cabinet meeting on Wednesday.The ministers were seen seated maintaining a distance from each other during the meeting which took place at 7 Lok Kalyan Marg, the Prime Minister's residence.The picture of the meeting, chaired by the Prime Minister, was shared by Union home minister Amit Shah on his social media accounts with a caption, "We are following social distancing. Are you?"On Tuesday, the Prime Minister announced a 21-day lockdown in the entire country effective from midnight to deal with the spread of coronavirus, saying that "social distancing" is the only option to deal with the disease, which spreads rapidly.Earlier, Modi, while offering greetings on the occasions of Navratri, Ugadi , Gudi Padava, Navreh and Sajibu Cheiraoba , once again highlighted how to fight against coronavirus. The Prime Minister said, "We are marking these festivals at a time when our nation is battling the Covid-19 menace. The celebrations will not be like they are usually but they will strengthen our resolve to overcome our circumstances."He said, "May we keep working to fight Covid-19. May these auspicious occasions bring good health, happiness and prosperity in our lives."

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Ram Lalla’s idol shifted to its new abode after 28 years
Content:
A model of Ram temple at Kar Sewak Puram in Ayodhya (PTI)

LUCKNOW: UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath carried the idol of Ram Lalla from the makeshift temple under a tent to a resplendent temporary abode of wood and bulletproof glass in 'brahma muhurt' before the break of dawn on Wednesday.

The shifting of Ram Lalla's idol - for the first time in 28 years - from the makeshift temple took place on the first day of Chaitra Navaratra and marked the completion of the first phase of temple construction at Ram Janmabhoomi .

CM Yogi offered prayers and also donated a cheque of Rs 11 lakh from his personal account in favour of the Ram Janmabhoomi Teerth Kshetra Trust for the construction of the temple, more than four months after the Supreme Court delivered verdict in its favour.

"The idol was placed on a silver ' singhaasan ' (throne) amid chanting of mantras and other rituals," said trust general secretary and Vishwa Hindu Parishad vice-president, Champat Rai, who was also present on the occasion.

"Ram Lalla idol was draped in new clothes and then puja and aarti were performed in the presence of UP CM. Later, darshan of Lord Ram ensued," Rai added.

Title: Suddenly jobless, migrant workers on long walk home
Content:
Reuters photo

Ankit Kumar, a contractual labourer, had walked all night — for about 10 hours — when TOI spoke to him on Wednesday morning. “My home in Saharanpur is 135 km from Meerut. With no income for the past few days and no hope of any in the coming month, I had no option but to leave,” said Kumar. He will have to walk some more.

In Uttarakhand, Moorat Lal — who has had one meal in two days — will cycle 800 km from Dehradun to Raebareli . Along with eight others, the 30-year-old has covered 90 km and reached Laksar (Haridwar) on Wednesday. Tonight, this crew of plumbers, electricians and carpenters, would be taking shelter at the railway station. There’s 700 more km to go. Among them, they have less than 2,000 rupees. “It might take five days to reach, unless we are stopped by police. But we can’t go back. There’s nothing there for us,” said Lal.

With Covid-19 lockdown robbing daily wagers and labourers of their income, thousands across India are walking long distances, over 100 kilometres in many cases, and often on empty stomachs to reach their native villages and towns.

In Agra, closure of tourism and footwear industry which employs scores of daily wagers has left many in dire straits. UP CM Yogi Adityanath has announced Rs 1,000 monthly allowance each for around 35 lakh labourers, hawkers and vendors and free ration to 1.65 crore daily wagers, but many that TOI spoke to said they had no information about this.

With no money and no work, those working in bordering states are desperate to make it home. Mohammad Kasim and five others managed to reach Aligarh from Palwal (Haryana) after 28 hours of being on the road, walking and hitchhiking on trucks. “We ate biscuits and bananas as we didn’t have money for proper meals,” he said.

Gaurav Kumar, who worked at a shoe manufacturing company in Haridwar, said about 200 of them left on Tuesday night — hours after the 21-day lockdown was announced — to reach Bijnor in UP. “Even the children walked,” he said. Another person, Yaseen, travelled with his friends in an empty milk tanker to Najibabad.

In Rudrapur, Madan (who only uses his first name) was trying to make the trip with a five-monthold infant to Bareilly but was turned back. He was, however, adamant that he would try to leave again. “I don’t have money to feed my family as I have not got any work for past five days. I have no option,” he said.

Uttarakhand CM Trivendra Singh Rawat released a helpline number where migrant workers can seek assistance to reach their hometowns. Some good samaritans have also extended a helping hand. A local journalist went out of his way to drop a labourer who was planning to walk from Haridwar to Chamba, 90 km away. He then picked up another woman, who works at a hotel in Devprayag, and drove her to Rishikesh.

Title: Bengal lawmakers fund Covid-19 fight
Content:
Kolkata: Lawmakers and political parties in Bengal have started donating towards a corpus to procure medical supplies to fight the coronavirus pandemic.

Trinamool Youth Congress on Wednesday donated Rs 1 crore to the West Bengal Emergency Relief Fund, set up by CM Mamata Banerjee to deal with the growing virus threat. “We stand shoulder to shoulder with our people in these tough times. We will win this battle together,” tweeted AITYC national president Abhishek Banerjee.

Basirhat MP Nusrat Jahan has said she will use her local area development fund to procure test kits and get people of her constituency examined. Hooghly MP Locket Chatterjee has allocated Rs 1 crore from her MPLAD fund while Jhargram MP Kunar Hembram, Alipurduar MP John Barla, Darjeeling MP Raju Bista and Cooch Behar MP Nisith Pramanik have handed over Rs 50 lakh each to respective district magistrates.

Burdwan-Durgapur MP S S Ahluwalia has allocated Rs 1 crore from his MPLAD fund for Purba Bardhaman medical facilities and Rs 50 lakh for Paschim Bardhaman hospitals. Darjeeling MLA Neeraj Zimba has pledged a month’s salary and Rs 20 lakh from his MLALAD fund.

CPM leader Sujan Chakraborty said Left MLAs had decided to sanction Rs 10 lakh from their MLALAD fund for equipment and infrastructure. Congress’s Adhir Chowdhury has also decided to pitch in.

Title: Kolkata: Fear grips health workers in absence of protective gear
Content: KOLKATA: Foot soldiers in the fight against coronavirus — doctors, nurses and health workers — are extremely worried about falling prey to easy transmission from Covid-19 patients in the absence of adequate protective gear (personal pretection equipment or PPE) at city hospitals. The concern has been triggered by a shortage of PPE — masks, gloves and go-wns, which are now mandatory for medics — at several private and state hospitals in the city.Murmurs of discontent have been getting louder across hospital corridors in Kolkata ever since PPE supplies started drying up last week following a sudden spurt in demand. The first public vent came on Wednesday when a section of nurses at the Beliaghata ID Hospital — epicentre of the state’s fight against the outbreak — demanded more PPE cover and threatened ceasework. They alleged they were being forced to work without PPE and made to travel in ambulances carrying Covid-19 suspects. They were pacified and made to ret-urn to work with the assurance that their grievances would be addressed.Wary of treating suspects without proper gear, many doctors across city hospitals have reportedly asked patients to visit later. A couple of surgeons even refused to conduct operations on suspected Covid-19 patients without proper measures fearing infection. This could be dangerous and help to prolong the outbreak, felt several senior medics in Kolkata.At least five private hospitals in the city are short of PPE. Another said it has got stock to last just a week. “Many of my colleagues are scared to attend to patients without the gear. We are using the PPEs sparingly and many are even operating without them, though it’s extremely risky. As per protocol, every Covid 19 suspect has to be treated like a positive patient till a test rules out infection. We had to convince some of our colleagues to treat these patients. Their fear is understandable since each one of us has a family at home and we could now be at the starting point of a spurt in the number of infected. The fear could be mitigated if we have enough PPEs at our disposal,” said a private hospital consultant.“Even with the gear on, doctors are wary since they are mingling with other hospital staff who are not always using protective gear. As the number of infected rises, the fear will grow and many will be turned away without treatment,” said another private hospital doctor.At a south Kolkata private hospital, some 50-odd medics have stopped visiting the outpatient department since last week citing lack of patients. The hospital authorities tried to get them to return but failed. “Since there has been an explosion in demand for masks, PPEs have turned scarce. We are rationing their use and unfortunately several doctors at our emergency are working without any protection. If they now refuse to attend to patients with Covid symptoms, we can’t blame them,” said a hospital spokesperson. The hospital is now worried about having enough doctors on duty at its fever clinic started on Wednesday.According to Fortis Hospital pulmonologist Raja Dhar, doctors in Kolkata are fighting a risky battle without enough protection and are extremely worried about themselves. “We have just treated six Covid 19 suspects who have all tested negative. Test reports of two more are pending. Over the next fortnight, there could be a big surge in the number of patients. Even with PPEs, transmission can’t be ruled out. We are having to tread very cautiously and all are obviously worried about preventing infection,” Dhar said.A private hospital with multiple units said its PPE stock is ‘nowhere near enough’. “Any hospital taking in suspect cases will need at least 20-30 PPEs everyday. We have got just 100 for one unit from the government,” said a representative of the hospital. He, however, added that since there is an acute shortage, the hospital is exploring other sources to procure PPEs.RN Tagore International Institute of Cardiac Sciences (RTIICS) is trying to procure PPEs from all possible sources. “Hopefully, we will be able to get some in the next 2-3 days. At this stage, we are able to provide these to doctors whenever necessary,” said RTIICS zonal director R Venkatesh.

Title: West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee asks cops to issue special passes for delivery agents
Content: KOLKATA: West Bengal chief minister Mamata Banerjee on Wednesday directed police to issue special passes to delivery agents to ensure there’s no problem in doorstep dispatch during the lockdown. Essential commodities, and the home delivery of such items, have been kept out of the lockdown purview, she reminded at Nabanna on Wednesday.Late on Wednesday, health department sources said there was one more confirmed case at a private hospital in Kolkata.Banerjee asked people engaged in emergency trade and services to get in touch with local police stations and the state police headquarters at Lalbazar. “The police will issue passes to traders, who will distribute the passes to delivery boys,” she said.The CM took note of teething problems in enforcing “complete safety regulations” in and around the city. “Supply of essential commodities has to be there,” she said. “Delivery boys should be allowed to work. No one should stop vegetable vendors. Farmers should be allowed to work, two to three at a time. Those found obstructing these people will be taken to task.”Banerjee — unlike the Telangana government that has warned it would issue “shoot-on-sight” orders against those trying to break the lockdown — said her government wanted to enforce the regulation with a humane face. “We are not going to enforce the lockdown with an iron hand. People have to survive,” she said.The CM also hinted at some “relaxations” after a review on March 31. “The state government has powers to announce relaxations to the lockdown. Poila Baisakh (the Bengali New Year), comes within the regulation period. But we may consider it after taking stock of the situation on March 31,” she said. The Bengali New Year starts on April 14, the last day of the announced lockdown.Banerjee also acknowledged the plight of senior citizens in housing complexes, and appealed to housing committees to help them out with buying essentials. “I urge housing committees to help out senior citizens in their complex. These people can’t go to the grocery store for essentials. Committee members can help them out,” she said. Pavement dwellers, she added, were being shifted to night shelters.In view of businesses taking a hit due to the lockdown, the CM appealed to citizens and NRIs to stand by the people and the government at such an “extraordinary situation” and donate to the Emergency Relief Fund set up by the state government.“We haven’t got anything from the Centre yet. The government has been straining its coffers to run its social sector schemes even after a huge debt servicing of Rs 50,000 crore annually. We have set up a Rs 200 crore fund to fight the pandemic, which is not enough,” she said.The government has placed orders for four lakh personal protection equipment, mainly for health workers, two lakh surgical masks, 300 ventilators, 200 infrared thermometers and three ECMO machines, Banerjee said. They are, however, yet to reach the state’s healthcare facilities. A section of nurses at the Beliaghata ID Hospital reached out to the superintendent to complain that they can’t run the service without protective gear. Banerjee also addressed the difficulties faced by the state government regarding diagnosis. “We are yet to get permission from the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) to set up three laboratories in the state to undertake swab tests of patients,” she said.

Title: warangal: #CoronaScare casualty: Medicos face discrimination
Content: They are being hailed as heroes world over; some call them warriors who are at the frontline to lead the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic; on Sunday, the entire nation broke the deafening silence of Janata Curfew for a few minutes to clap and cheer for them. And yet, the very same medical professionals who are lauded on social media by day are shunned by night at their societies, apartment complexes and rented houses when they return home from hospitals. Yes. we are talking about medicos who are met with discrimination ever since COVID-19 scare hit the state. “We’re being applauded with salutes on social media but in the real world, nobody wants to come near us,” say junior doctors , interns and medical students, who are working round the clock in the fight against coronavirus On Tuesday, Ahmed Uzair, a house surgeon from Warangal , took the Internet by storm when he wrote about how many doctors in the city are being asked to vacate their rented homes because people feel “doctors staying in their homes will make them more susceptible to the virus.” “One owner said that we were dirty. We were evicted without any notice and most of the doctors are now stranded on the roads with their luggage, with nowhere to go. Our campus hostels too are being converted into isolation wards,” Ahmed posted on his Facebook page.Like Ahmed, many doctors from across the country shared similar experiences of facing discrimination at their colonies or on the streets. Raghavi Latha, an intern at Nampally Government Hospital, says she might not have a home to live in after two months. “I stay at a paying guest accommodation in Ashok Nagar and my landlord is scared that I might bring the virus from the hospital. Thankfully, I have a signed agreement for the next two months so he cannot ask me to leave right away, but he has already indicated that I’ll have to make alternate arrangements once the contract runs out. It breaks my heart that we’re being kicked out of homes despite working selflessly round the clock to take care of the ill,” she says.Doctors who don’t have their own vehicles to commute in also faced discrimination while travelling in public transport before the lockdown was announced. Madhuri Ravi, a house surgeon at Gandhi hospital, says, “When patients who tested positive for coronavirus started getting shifted to isolation wards at Gandhi hospital, we noticed the traffic around the hospital almost disappeared. People ran away from us like we’re the plague. Autos refused to take me back home and cab drivers would cancel the ride looking at my pick-up location. They would think that because the hospital hascoronavirus patients, the doctors too are infected.”While the country is in lockdown mode for the next three weeks and public transport is non-functional, the discrimination of young medical professionals continues in other ways. “After the coronavirus outbreak in Hyderabad, people started thinking that every doctor treats only corona infected patients. I play with kids in my neighbourhood everyday but for the last couple of weeks, they stopped coming near me. I was told their parents asked them to stay away from me since Iwork in a hospital,” shares Swetha Sivalenka, a fourth year medical student from Hyderabad, adding, “Now, there is a lockdown. but still when people see a white coat and a mask, they get scared. Even when I go out to buy groceries or other essentials, people seem to be extremely wary of my presence and are uncomfortable around me. This ignorance and discrimination are disheartening.”The discrimination faced by healthcare professionals was condemned by the government with Union Health Minister Dr Harsh Vardhan taking to social media to express his concern. “I’m feeply angusshed to see reports pouring in from Delhi, Noida,Warangal,Chennai etc that doctors & paramedics are being ostracised in residential complexes & societies. Landlords are threatening to evict them fearing #COVID2019 infection. Pls don’t panic ! #CoronavirusLockdown (sic),” the Health Minister tweeted, adding, “All precautions are being taken by doctors & staff on #COVID2019 duty to ensure they’re not carriers of infection in anyway. Any harsh steps will demoralise them, derail the system.On Sunday,nation applauded their selfless services. It’s our bounden duty 2 keep their morale high (sic).”

Title: This couple complemented each other in a silk sherwani and silk lehenga and you can't miss their photos
Content: We know the country is facing such difficult times and it's only internet that helps us sail through a day, sanely. Whether it's Bollywood's fashion diaries or Indian brides dressing to kill, we always try and keep you posted with the looks that leave us impresses. And, we can across one such couple who looked simple elegant on their wedding day, which was obviously before all of us got locked down in our respective houses. We are sure the pictures of this stylish couple with bring a smile on your face, don't believe us? Have a look!Bride Priya Chaudhary looked nothing less than regal on her wedding day as she picked up a pale ivory-gold tulle and silk lehenga for her wedding ceremony. The lehenga, by designer duo Rimple and Harpreet was hand crafted with lotus blossoms, delicate Pichhwai florals, chevrons and geometric patterns derived from sacred geometry and resplendent birds of paradise; rendered using iridescent hand cut metal sequins, pearls, resham zardozi and kasab-dori marodi ka kaam. The lehenga was paired with an embroidered choli and sheer tulle dupattas in hues of ivory and salmon pink.Her handsome groom, Abhinav Gambhir chose an ivory raw silk sherwani by the same designer duo for the ceremony. The jacket featured a tessellated jaal derived from Mughal inlay work, rendered on the silk base with tonal resham zardozi and marodi ka kaam. It was paired with a vintage embroidered dushala (restored by our artisans and layered with marodi ka kaam in kasab-dori) and a cotton mul saafa which was hand printed with traditional varq ka kaam.Well, we can't have enough of the wedding pictures of this beautiful couple, tell us what do you think about their wedding avatars in the comment section below.

Title: Veteran lensman Nemai Ghosh dies
Content:
Kolkata: When acclaimed photographer Nemai Ghosh breathed his last at his Kolkata residence on Wednesday due to cardiac respiratory failure, many referred to it as the end of a legend who among other attributes was known as Satyajit Ray’s Boswell and the only Indian lensman to have photographed director Michaelangelo Antonioni at work. Ghosh, a Padma Shri recipient, was 86 and is survived by wife Sibani, son Satyaki and daughter Sharmistha.

Even last September, Ghosh had asked his photographer son to keep just one camera for him at home. “The rest he had given to me. But when he suffered a fall at home in November, he asked me to take away everything,” Satyaki said, remembering his father’s last request. “He had asked me to do something with black and white films,” added Mumbai-based Satyaki, who wouldn’t be able to attend the last rites because of national lockdown.

However, it was theatre and not photography that was the first vocation of Ghosh, who was born on May 8, 1934 in Kolkata. While working as a theatre actor with the likes of Utpal Dutt and Rabi Ghosh, it was the receipt of a still camera left behind in a taxi that changed his course of life.

Through common friends, he ended up on the sets of Ray’s ‘Goopy Gyne Bagha Byne’. Impressed with the angles of his photographs, Ray asked him to click photos for him. He continued till 1992. In Ghosh’s words, the Rays were the “best models” he had ever had. In his kitty also lies a rare series of some unseen “romantic” photos which the couple agreed to click on their wedding anniversary (October 20).

Yet, director Sandip Ray wouldn’t limit Ghosh’s treasure trove to just his father’s 90,000 photos. “He photographed Kolkata, the world of theatre and tribals. He had gone to meet French photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson,” Sandip remembered.

Alongside photos of Italian director Antonioni while the latter was painting, Ghosh also filmed Ritwik Ghatak, Mrinal Sen, Goutam Ghose, Roland Joffe and Mira Nair. Then, there are his exemplary visual essays in ‘The Faces of Indian Art: Through the lens of Nemai Ghosh’ and his four books with painter Paresh Maity. A copy of the yet-to-be-released book titled ‘Paresh Maity: A Portrait of the Artist in the World’ had reached Ghosh some days back.

“Simplicity was the hallmark of his works,” Maity said. “This book, a visual journey of two artists for 25 years where we travelled across the globe, has him taking some 5,000 black and white photos of mine on his analogue camera,” he added. “He was like a child. Every time I went abroad, he would ask me to get black and white films. As a mark of respect, I have kept the book on the altar in my puja room.”

Title: Nurses to ambulances, all stopped at border by cops
Content: NOIDA: The lack of preparations to enforce a lockdown that kept the essential supply chain running was evident in Noida throughout Wednesday, as police stopped a number of vehicles ferrying medical staff to the city from Delhi at the border. An ambulance destined for Kanpur with a critical patient was also stopped. Cops said people crossing the border needed to establish their urgency.Police were especially stopping private vehicles at the Noida-Delhi border, like the one in which four medical staff of Delhi’s Safdarjung hospital were travelling. One of the staffers was made to get off and walk till he crossed the border and only then they were allowed to go.Ved Pal, who was asked to get down, told TOI that the cops said that more than three persons should not be seated in the car. “I showed my I-card but was asked to get down. We are on medical duty and returning to our home in Greater Noida . I was asked to cross over the DND toll after which I boarded the car again,” he said.Similarly, a bus carrying 70-80 nurses from a leading Delhi-based private hospital was stopped for checking by police in Noida and allowed to go only after the driver informed that they were medical duty. “We are on medical duty and reside in hostels in sectors 40, 41 and 46 in Noida. We went to Delhi around 7am and were returning from there where we were stopped,” one of the nurses said. The hospital, however, has not commented.There was also a case of ambulance carrying 8-10 people being stopped and heated arguments between attendants and cops. The personnel on duty were eager to know why so many people were seated in the ambulance that was ferrying a critical patient to Kanpur.Police said they were allowing only those with medical documents or patients to pass. “There were too many people in that ambulance, but a woman shouted that it had a serious patient inside who was possibly on the death bed. It was allowed to go,” a police officer deployed at the DND said.Dr Abhimanyu Thakran, head operations (north zone) SastaSunder, a portal for online delivery of medicines was also asked to show the documents authorising him to perform the duty. “We have a warehouse in Noida out of where some 20 people are operating and providing medicines online. I was allowed to go after I showed a letter from the company.”DCP (Noida) Sankalp Sharma said the medical staff is totally exempt from the restrictions and there is no limit on the number of the staffers who can travel since they were providing medical duty.Sector 53 resident Varun claimed that he was out to buy ration and insulin from Delhi as he could not do so in Noida, but was asked by police to show his documents establishing his medical emergency. He was later allowed to go when he got his medical prescription on WhatsApp.Noida police additional DCP Ranvijay Singh said cops on the ground are stopping the people only to understand why they are on roads without documents and understand their role. “We are very liberal with the medical staff but some people tend to make excuses and those, travelling without any documents need to prove they are out for a valid reason,” he said.

Title: Cops still a barrier for health workers in Lucknow
Content:
LUCKNOW: Essential service providers , mostly health workers and chemists, were stopped by police as they do not have special passes issued by the administration on the third day of the lockdown on Wednesday. Such a scenario was witnessed in Indiranagar, SGPGI, Cantonment, Mahanagar, and Bazaarkhala.

“I was going to Dr RML Hospital but the police at Munshipuliya stopped me. When I showed them my IDcard they said it was not issued by the district administration,” said Ashish Mehrotra, a support staff. Mehrotra added that he was required in the hospital as he had to assist doctors during a major surgery which was to be conducted urgently.”Similarly, in SGPGI area, Harsh Agarwal, a chemist , bringing some surgical items from Chowk, was stopped. “We were not issued any passes by the administration, But we form part of essential services and cannot be stopped. The issue will be taken up in the court once it opens,” he said.

In another case, a nurse employed with civil hospital in Hazratganj was stopped at Bazaarkhala.

“I was stopped at Bullaki Adda and asked to show pass. I showed my ID card but policemen did not budge,” said Nazia Khatoon (name changed). Similarly, an anaesthetist of a private hospital Vinod Sharma was stopped at cantonment by the police.

Title: Neighbours surprise Mumbai couple with warm welcome
Content:
MUMBAI: If there was relief at recovery for the first batch of the city's Covid-19 patients who were discharged on Tuesday, there was also anxiety about how neighbours would welcome them. And most have been pleasantly surprised.

The city's index patients - a septuagenarian and his 68-year-old wife - began their journey home in an ambulance from Kasturba Hospital on Tuesday evening. She had been suffering from side-effects of the drugs and was too weak to stand. So, the husband was worried how to reach their second floor apartment, but above all, he was fretting about how the neighbours would react to their homecoming.

A day after, he told TOI : "They have pleasantly surprised us. They arranged for our dinner on Tuesday night. It was simple homecooked food. They also provided us with lunch on Wednesday and someone has promised us dinner too. We are happy to be back home". The couple had gone to Dubai as part of a 40-member tour group. They were the first to test positive from Mumbai on March 11, two days after another couple from Pune had tested positive.

In a Ghatkopar slum, the son of a 68-year-old woman was apprehensive since people in the locality had treated them as untouchables after she was detected with the infection. However, on Tuesday, when his mother returned and they showed that her reports were normal, things were better. "It will improve once she gets fitter," he said with relief.

In Ulhasnagar, after a 49-year old woman and her brother were discharged and reached home on Tuesday, their families were not only relieved that they made it safely, but said people living around them also were happy.

The couple in the western suburbs has also been awed by the support of the BMC. On Wednesday morning, members from the ward office landed at their house and sanitised it. "They have also assured us of any help, including buying medicines during the lockdown," said the man.

The man said: "Our worry now is how to shop for vegetables and fruits during the lockdown. There are long queues and we cannot step out for another 14 days," he said.

Title: Society residents buy supplies for their guards after they threaten to walk out
Content: GREATER NOIDA: Residents of Trident Embassy Housing society in Bisrakh said they would bear the expenses on groceries and essentials of their security guards , who had threatened to quit if they were not paid their salaries in advance.“I felt the need to help them. We have asked the guards to prepare a list of essential items and buy them using my account from the local grocery stores,” said Ajay Kumar, a resident. The guards had said the prices of most items had gone up. With the lockdown in place, they had to make sure they had supplies at home but did not know how they would pay for it.The society’s estate manager said the guards had had an ongoing problem regarding the salaries with their recruitment agency. “The guards were apparently denied advance payment of salary. They said they would leave their jobs. So some residents volunteered to help them out with supplies. The security agency is also working to resolve the problem,” said Ravi Chauhan, another resident.

Title: BJP identifying its 1 crore members who can feed 5 crore families
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: Responding to Prime Minister Narendra Modi ’s call to the effluent people to help at least nine families during the lockdown period, BJP on Wednesday asked its state presidents to assign at least one crore of its party workers to feed at least five families every day.Party president JP Nadda had an interaction with national office-bearers of the party through video conference in which he asked for identifying at least one crore party workers, who could take the responsibility to feed five families a day during the lockdown in view of Covid-19 outbreak.Read also: Coronavirus outbreak live updates“State party presidents were asked to assign the responsibility immediately so that they start feeding the needy from Thursday onwards,” a senior BJP functionary said.PM Modi, while interacting with people of his constituency Varanasi, on Wednesday urged people to feed at lest nine families per day for 21 days so that none is left hungry. He said this will be the best way to express devotion during the auspicious period of Navratra.

Title: Focus on people, take economic steps: Rahul Gandhi
Content: NEW DELHI: With the country under a 21-day lockdown in an attempt to rein in the coronavirus pandemic, Congress 's Rahul Gandhi on Wednesday said the government should adopt a two-pronged approach to tackle the crisis - one focusing on isolating people and ramping up health infrastructure, and the other on economic measures."I believe our strategy should have two components. The first is tackling Covid-19 by isolating the virus, blocking its escape routes, expanding testing to identify and treat those who are infected and creating emergency field hospitals in urban areas with full ICU capability to provide care to patients," Rahul said.He said the second part should focus on the economy. "Those who survive on daily wages need immediate support through direct cash transfers and free rations. Delaying this will cause widespread devastation and chaos. Many industries are struggling. Act quickly by announcing tax breaks and financial support to prevent massive job losses and reassure business owners that the government will support them through this crisis," he added.Congress also demanded implementation of its flagship campaign pitch for the 2019 Lok Sabha polls, the Nyay Yojna, reiterating its ability to provide succour to daily wagers, poor and migrant labourers.While Congress promised a bank transfer of Rs 6,000 to the poorest, it urged the government to implement the minimum income guarantee scheme and announce a cash transfer of Rs 7,500 to every Jan Dhan, PM Kisan and pension account.Full report on www.toi.in

Title: Of 25 lakh seized masks, BMC gets 6 lakh, rest for Haffkine Institute
Content:
Home minister Anil Deshmukh with the seized masks on Tuesday

MUMBAI: With the state government grappling with acute shortage of masks to tackle the Coronavirus outbreak, the seizure of 25 lakh masks on Monday has come as a major relief.

Sources said of the 25 lakh masks worth Rs14 crore seized by the city police, the BMC commissioner, in an order dated March 24, invoked the Essential Commodities Act and took possession of six lakh masks on Wednesday. These include one lakh N-95 masks and five lakh three-ply masks.

Deputy commissioner (Zone 7), Vishwas Shankarrao, is in possession of the masks which are likely to be distributed among health workers in various BMC-run hospitals, particularly Kasturba Hospital, which is the main hospital treating the Coronavirus patients. The masks are currently stored at Andheri Sports Complex in K-ward, said a source.

The remaining 19 lakh masks will be handed over to the Haffkine Institute in Pune as per the Collector’s order.

Seized goods automatically become court property and need to be produced during trial and returned. When asked how they could distribute these seized items, police said the Essential Commodities Act empowers the BMC and the Collector to take over such property.

In wake of the shortage of masks and sanitizers in the market, the Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution had on March 13 issued a notification bringing masks and sanitizers under the Essential Commodities Act.

"We have videographed the seizure and followed due procedure and will produce this in court during trial," said a crime branch official.

Meanwhile, the crime branch probing the blackmarketing of masks is looking for the key conspirators.

The city crime branch had on Monday raided two godowns, one near the international airport at Sahar and another at Bhiwandi, and had seized the huge stash of masks. Police had arrested Balaji Muthupedi Nadar, Shahrukh Shaikh, Gulam Murtuza and Mihir Patel, a Customs House Agent. A search is on for Mihir’s father, Darshan Patel, who, along with a few others, had allegedly hoarded the masks with plans to blackmarket them.

Title: 277 evacuated from Iran tested negative: India
Content:
ANI photo

NEW DELHI: The government Wednesday evacuated 277 Indians from coronavirus-hit Iran , officials here said. All of them, sources said, had tested negative for coronavirus.

As confirmed by government in Parliament, 255 Indian nationals had tested positive for the virus.

Those evacuated were brought to Jodhpur on Wednesday. A defence spokesperson said preliminary screening of the evacuees, mostly pilgrims, was conducted at the airport upon arrival and thereafter they were taken to the Army Wellness Facility set up at the Jodhpur Military Station.

The Army, in coordination with the Rajasthan state medical authorities and civil administration, has made adequate medical and administrative arrangements to ensure a comfortable stay for the evacuees and provide prophylactic medical support, he said.

Additional chief secretary (health) Rohit Kumar Singh said that 273 of the evacuees are pilgrims.

Title: 5 committees formed to ensure delivery of essential items in Ghaziabad
Content: Ghaziabad: Ghaziabad administration has formed five committees to ensure that all essential services, as well as medical facilities, are provided smoothly to people. Moreover, there are committees to ensure that factories do not cut salaries of labourers and norms of the lockdown are implemented properly.A three-tier system involving nodal, liaisoning and overseeing officers have been formed and each have been assigned specific jobs, for instance, to ensure ration and other essential commodities reaches migrant and factory workers. Ghaziabad Development Authority vice-chairperson will be overseeing it with city magistrate acting as a liaisoning officer while officials from industry department will carry out work on the ground. They will also ensure that their salary and wages are not deducted.The chief development officer has been entrusted with the responsibility of streamlining health services and ensuring seamless coordination with hospitals.In the list of essentials , there are grocery items, fruits, vegetables and milk, and transportation and delivery of the same have been exempted from lockdown. “Transportation of medicines, medical equipment, petroleum products and cattle fodder have also been exempted from lockdown and traffic police and others have been instructed to allow its unhindered movement within the district,” said Ajay Shankar Pandey, district magistrate.The DM said that as many as 220 hand carts and 230 auto-rickshaws and battery-operated vehicles were arranged with the help of Mandi Parishad officials and sent to various parts of the city with fruits and vegetables so that people do not face any sort of inconvenience.Pandey added that grocery and medical shops, besides e-commerce companies, can operate between 6 am and 11 pm. However, shop owners and people should ensure social distancing and ensure there is no crowd. “As there is no shortage of any product, people should not hoard, and buy things only in required quantity. After buying products, people should directly head to their homes,” he added.The DM reiterated that all vehicles involved in ferrying essential products would not be stopped from entering Ghaziabad and instructions have already been given to the police in this regard.“While nodal officers have been assigned for specific purposes, a control room has been established in the collectorate to oversee the entire delivery mechanism devised. Here, officials will be deputed in three shifts of eight hours each,” Pandey added.

Title: Neighbours welcome back first batch of recovered patients in Mumbai
Content: MUMBAI: If there was relief at recovery for the first batch of the city’s Covid-19 patients who were discharged on Tuesday, there was also anxiety about how neighbours would welcome them. And most have been pleasantly surprised.The city’s index patients — a septuagenarian and his 68-year-old wife — began their journey home in an ambulance from Kasturba Hospital on Tuesday evening. She had been suffering from side-effects of the drugs and was too weak to stand. So, the husband was worried how to reach their second floor apartment, but above all, he was fretting about how the neighbours would react to their homecoming.A day after, he told TOI: “They have pleasantly surprised us. They arranged for our dinner on Tuesday night. It was simple homecooked food. They also provided us with lunch on Wednesday and someone has promised us dinner too. We are happy to be back home”. The couple from the western suburbs had gone to Dubai as part of a 40-member tour group. They were the first to test positive from Mumbai on March 11, two days after another couple from Pune had tested positive.In a Ghatkopar slum, the son of a 68-year-old woman was apprehensive since people in the locality had treated them as untouchables after she was detected with the infection. However, on Tuesday, when his mother returned and they showed that her reports were normal, things were better. “It will improve once she gets fitter,” he said with relief.In Ulhasnagar, after a 49-year old woman and her brother were discharged and reached home on Tuesday, their families were not only relieved that they made it safely, but said people living around them also were happy and relieved, saying it is good news for all of Ulhasnagar.The couple in the western suburbs has also been awed by the support of the BMC. On Wednesday morning, members from the ward office landed at their house and sanitised it. “We were made to wait in another room as they cleaned the rooms. They have also assured us of any help, including buying medicines during the lockdown. The officials are constantly in touch with us over the phone, which is very reassuring,” said the man. The flat next door belongs to their daughter, who lives abroad. There is a neighbor on the floor, for whom they had got a box of dates from Dubai. Unfortunately, the person has also tested positive and is admitted in Kasturba.Profusely thanking his neighbours for providing them dinner, the man said: “We have asked them to keep the food near the elevator. They call us once the food is placed there,” he said. “Our worry now is how to shop for vegetables and fruits. There are long queues and we cannot step out for another 14 days,” he said.

Title: Noida Sector 58 police won’t let everyone step out for essentials
Content: NOIDA/GHAZIABAD: Police in Sector 58 are enforcing social distancing by asking RWAs to not allow anyone to step out, not even for essentials. The police station has issued an advisory, asking RWAs to appoint two to four persons who can buy essentials for everyone.The nation-wide lockdown restricts non-essential and non-emergency movement. Stepping out for essentials is not banned. “It is a measure at the local level. In other areas too, RWAs are coming up with local mechanisms to enforce social distancing,” said DCP (Noida) Sankalp Sharma.Residents didn’t see the logic. “It’s not practical. Just a few people can’t be expected to buy so many things for everyone. Even if I appoint 10 people, they will never be able to stay home if they have to keep going on grocery runs,” said Gajinder Singh Bansal, president of the Sector 55 RWA. “The alternative is that we ask them to step out one by one ... No RWA will take such responsibility,” he added.Ghaziabad police, on the other hand, has asked residents to only send out one member from a family to purchase essentials. “We found more than three members of a family had come out for shopping. We have requested people several time, but nothing has changed. So police will take action against them. If found repeating the offence, they will be booked under Section 188 of the IPC (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant),” Ghaziabad SSP Kalanidhi Naithani said.At shops in Noida and Greater Noida, owners have been asked to mark circles with chalk or keep boxes to mark a 2-3-metre distance from the shopkeeper. Shops in Ghaziabad, too, have been given similar instructions but to mark a 1-metre distance from the shopkeeper.Ghaziabad district magistrate Ajay Shankar Pandey, meanwhile, has said all essential items industries are running and shops will remain open from 6am to 11pm.

Title: How senior citizens in Noida are coping with lockdown
Content: NOIDA: Some of them are patients, others are giving care to spouses undergoing treatment, and most have retired and are leading a slow-paced life. Several elderly persons of the city, especially in the sectors, live on their own as their children are now employed in far-away towns. It’s a tough time for them as they are now left without the support of helps, cooks and in some instances, drivers too.Domestic helps are a most important support system for the elderly people as many of them could be alone after their spouses’ death. The lockdown along with no help is now forcing them to manage their homes all alone and even give care to an ailing partner at the same time.Meenakshi Sharma, a resident of Sector 21, is somehow multitasking despite her ill health. “I have been unwell for over a month and my husband suffered a heart attack two months ago. Now I’m cooking, cleaning and taking care of his medical requirements, all by myself. We are managing somehow but the lockdown announced amid Covid-19 scare, of course, is taking a toll on us,” she said.In Sector 37, Meera Khanna has been living on her own, but she usually tries to keep herself busy.“I have friends here. I meet people and have social get-togethers, so I never feel lonely or helpless. But now suddenly without helps and other supports, I am forced to cook, clean utensils, and feel very disconnected. My daughters live in Ghaziabad and South Delhi. I could have gone there but the border is sealed, and it’s not possible to go now,” Khanna said.Meena Vohra, a resident of Sector 21, who runs a community facility for elderly citizens of the city, claimed most do not have the strength to clean homes, cook meals and get all essential commodities as they do not have the habit ogf going out of the house to make purchases.“In our group, there are elderly people who are suffering from several health problems. Some are frail and others have never lived without the support of helps, cooks and drivers. So, it’s a big shift to tougher situation. We are trying to make do with those helps who live with their families and those who are available now. Some of us are cooking for a friend who is too unwell. We are trying to be there for each other,” said Vohra, who lives with her husband. Her three children live abroad.Vohra said a friend’s driver was stopped at the society gate and she had to go to the hospital. “People are facing problems. Elderlies need support and we are not equipped for an emergency situation,” Vohra added.

Title: Restaurants, temples to run community kitchen for poor in Uttar Pradesh
Content: LUCKNOW: To ensure that daily wage labourers with no access to food do not go hungry in the ongoing lockdown, the government has decided to rope in hotels, restaurants and religious establishments like temples and gurdwaras to work as community kitchens from where cooked food is supplied to these people. Awasthi said: “Cooked food packages will then be distributed among daily wagers and hawkers through volunteers.”Immediately after PM’s announcement of 21-day lockdown on Tuesday night, Awasthi said, the CM issued directions to district administrations to ensure that doorstep delivery of food, medicines and other essential goods is undertaken in some form or the other so that people do not need to leave their homes for any kind of work.On Wednesday, he met with the chief secretary, DGP, agriculture production commissioner (APC), infrastructure and industrial development commissioner, principal secretaries of health, health education, agriculture etc and asked them to coordinate to ensure door step delivery was rolled out in the state.“A committee has been formed under APC to ensure availability of civil supplies. All DMs, commissioners and senior police officials have been told that bulk supply chain at mandis should not be stopped and the movement of farmers and other suppliers should be allowed. People who are carrying out doorstep delivery should be registered and it should be ensured that they are provided with pushcarts, erickshaws, four wheelers and mini-trucks for easy delivery,” he said.Till 3pm on Wednesday, 5,419 mobile vans, e-rickshaws and tractors had started home delivery of foods items across all divisions. Another 6,407 vehicles would be pressed into service shortly, taking the total to 12,133 vehicles.Meanwhile, since the lockdown, police have registered 1,787 FIRs under Section 187 IPC and challaned 5,592 people for violation of the lockdown order. Around 1.52 lakh vehicles have been checked at 6,022 barriers across the state.

Title: Coronavirus news India: No evidence of community spread yet, govt says
Content:
More on

NEW DELHI: There is still no evidence of a wider spread of novel coronavirus through community transmission, the Centre said on Wednesday on the basis of sampling of ICU cases suffering from severe influenza symptoms. These patients are outside the testing focus on persons exhibiting symptoms who have travelled abroad or have been in contact with such a person.Indian Council of Medical Research ( ICMR ) has informed that “as of now there is no community transmission,” health ministry Joint Secretary Lav Agarwal said. The official's caution underlined the concern that the highly infectious disease has the ability of rapid transmission and the situation needs to be assessed on a daily basis.Yet, the conclusion spelt relief for monitoring agencies as it was drawn based on testing of over 2,000 random samples drawn from patients hospitalised in intensive care units with severe acute respiratory infections (SARI) like pneumonia over past few weeks. These patients had no history of international travel, neither were they in contact with any such person who has travelled aboard recently.While the government took proactive steps to first lock down the affected districts where positive cases were reported, and then eventually shutting down all states except for essential services, it maintained “social distancing and lockdown is essential to break the chain of transmission”, triggered by increased influx of Indians coming back mainly from the US and UK in past few weeks.Rigorous testing of persons after they exhibit symptoms and contact tracing remain the basic elements of the government's strategy to combat the spread of Covid-19. Despite stringent restrictions on international travel, nearly 64,000 persons have arrived from other countries just ahead of the complete ban on such travel. It was also seen that appeals to stay at home were not working and large number of people were heading for their homes in states from big cities, raising the prospects of the disease spreading into the hinterland."The steps taken by us are depending on the increasing trend in number of cases,” Agarwal said. Till Wednesday, the health ministry reported a total 616 confirmed cases of COVID-19 across the country. Of this, 553 were active cases, whereas 42 were cured and one was a migrated case. Besides, 10 deaths were also reported till Wednesday.To tackle the rising burden and enable testing at a larger scale, the government has also ramped up its laboratory network in both public and private sectors. So far, there are 118 public labs with capacity to test 12000 samples a day. Besides, ICMR has also approved 29 private labs chains with 16000 collection centres.“We don’t want testing without reason,” Agarwal said, articulating the view that random testing may be a waste of resource and even deliver a large number of false negatives, encouraging people who may later develop the infection to mingle freely. The government has held that only those who develop symptoms will be tested.

Title: Ensure media can function smoothly: PCI to state govts
Content: NEW DELHI: The Press Council of India on Wednesday issued an advisory addressed to all state governments and administrative authorities asking them to take all necessary measures to ensure the smooth functioning of media during the 21-day lockdown to rein in the coronavirus pandemic.The PCI statement read, “At this critical juncture, ensuring uninterrupted operation of printing press, facilitation of functioning of mediapersons and continuity of distribution infrastructure of newspapers and magazine is vital.”The statement added that it is essential that media houses be facilitated with the required support or assistance for continued dissemination of appropriate information not only to create awareness amongst people but also for keeping the nation updated on the latest status related to the Covid-19 outbreak, it added.Earlier in the week, PM Modi , during his interaction with print and electronic media persons, had said media was a part of the critical infrastructure that would help the country tide over the coronavirus crisis by creating awareness as well as by countering fake news.On Monday, the ministry of information and broadcasting had also dispatched a similar missive to states and Union Territories asking them to ensure operational continuity of print and electronic media in the current situation, emphasising the vital role of the news media, across print, FM and TV formats, in news dissemination.
